HEADLINE: Faster, Better Concorde Is Planned

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PARIS, May 7

 BODY:
The British and French aircraft makers that built the Concorde are expected to announce on Wednesday an agreement to study and design a second-generation supersonic aircraft to carry twice as many passengers as the Concorde and have almost twice its range.
Aerospatiale, France's largest commercial aviation company, said today that it would announce ''an important agreement'' on Wednesday, and several French newspapers reported that it and British Aerospace would announce an accord that aims to have a 250-seat ''son of Concorde'' in service in the year 2005.
Aerospatiale officials, who say the new aircraft will cost between $9 billion and $14 billion to develop, add that they hope American, Japanese and possibly even Soviet aerospace companies might join the project to help spread the huge costs.
 
Invitations to Others
They spoke specifically about inviting manufacturers like the Boeing Company, the McDonnell Douglas Corporation and Mitsubishi Heavy Industries to help. Both McDonnell and Boeing, which abandoned a supersonic project in the late 1960's, are already studying the development of a new supersonic transport. 
Because the development costs are so great and the market is limited, however, it would be foolish for two competing groups to develop new supersonic aircraft, the Aerospatiale officials said. But with their expertise and experience in supersonic transport, it is clear Aerospatiale and British Aerospace hope to lead any worldwide consortium formed to develop a new Concorde.
For more than a year, Aerospatiale officials have acknowledged that they have been studying a new supersonic transport, a super-Concorde, that would be designed to overcome the Concorde's shortcomings: it carries only about 100 passengers, is inefficient in the use of fuel and has a range of only 3,700 miles.
According to Le Figaro, a Paris daily, and La Tribune de l'Expansion, a business daily, the new supersonic carrier would accommodate between 200 and 300 passengers, use fuel far more efficiently than the Concorde and have a range of up to 7,500 miles. That range would enable it to fly from the United States or Europe to the Far East. A flight from Europe to Japan would take the new plane five hours, compared with 12 hours now.
The new Concorde would also be a bit faster, flying at almost 2.5 times the speed of sound, or Mach 2.5, compared with the Concorde's speed of Mach 2. The speed of sound is roughly 750 miles an hour.
Aerospatiale officials said the worldwide growth in long-haul traffic demonstrated a rising need for a new generation of economical supersonic transports. Company officials added that they hoped to sell more than 500 of the aircraft, which the French have dubbed FAST, for ''Future Aircraft of Supersonic Transport.''
''We are confident that it is technically feasible,'' one Aerospatiale official said. ''For us the real question is whether it is financially feasible.''
 
Only 13 in Service
British Aerospace and Aerospatiale had hoped to sell about 300 Concorde aircraft, but today there are only 13 of the aircraft, which had its maiden flight in 1969, in commercial service. The Concorde, which cost about $2 billion to develop, proved a gigantic commercial flop for its two state-owned manufacturers and for the French and British Governments that backed the project.
The sharp rise in fuel prices in the 1970's made the Concorde largely uneconomical. Its limited range prevented it from serving the fast-growing market from the Far East to Europe and the United States. In addition, protests about noise pollution severely limited the routes it could fly, which hurt it, especially in its efforts to serve the American coast-to-coast routes.
The 13 Concordes in commercial service are profitable for British Airways and Air France, the only two companies that fly them. The Concordes fly from Paris to New York in three and a half hours, half the seven hours needed for a typical passenger aircraft. The Concordes are used for the most part on regularly scheduled trans-Atlantic routes, but British Airways and Air France also rent them out for luxury charter flights.
 
Large Market Seen
''There is a large market for supersonic transport,'' said Wolfgang Demisch, an aviation analyst with UBS Securities. ''It's a large market that will remain until someone seizes the intiative. My guess is that the super-Concorde is a step in the right direction.''
The Concordes in service are due to be retired between the years 2000 and 2010.
The French newspapers said that British Aerospace and Aerospatiale would need five years of research, eight years of production and two to three years of tests before the new aircraft could go into service.
Last December the two companies that produced the engines for the Concorde announced an agreement to study the demand and technology for a new engine for the next generation of supersonic aircraft. Those two companies are Rolls-Royce and Snecma, as the Societe Nationale d'Etudes et de Construction de Moteurs d'Aviation is known. Aerospatiale officials said, however, that they would consider engines from other manufacturers as well.
Aviation experts see the next-generation Concorde as a step toward the development of aircraft that will fly five or more times the speed of sound.

HEADLINE: A Tire Maker Outdistances Rivals

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: FINDLAY, Ohio, May 7

 BODY:
At a time when most tire companies are merging in the face of global competition and shuttering many factories, the Cooper Tire and Rubber Company is thriving as an independent and expanding its capacity.
By eschewing business with automobile manufacturers and focusing on the growing and less cyclical market for replacement tires, Cooper has achieved a record in the last decade that is the envy of giants like Goodyear, Bridgestone and Michelin. Its profits have increased at a compounded rate of 22 percent annually and its share of the domestic replacement-tire market has doubled, to 10 percent. And with the recent acquisition of Uniroyal Goodrich by Michelin of France, the prospect of Cooper as a takeover target has received new attention from many tire executives and some analysts. 
The success of Cooper can be attributed in good part to its ability to win over many independent tire dealers, which account for nearly two-thirds of the replacement-tire sales in the United States. It has done this by ''building a reputation as a reliable supplier with up-to-date plants,'' said Harry W. Millis, an analyst with McDonald & Company in Cleveland. What is more, Cooper is popular with the independents because it does not have retail outlets that compete with them, as do the bigger tire companies. (Cooper also sells tires through the independents under a number of private labels, including Atlas, Western Auto and Pep Boys.) Margins in the replacement-tire market are higher than in the new-car market because tire makers sell to car manufacturers at a discount. And demand has been appreciably higher than in the new-tire market because people are driving their cars longer. While people may postpone purchases of cars, they continue to replace their tires.
Cooper, which was founded 75 years ago, has also prospered through a lean operation. Indeed, its Spartan headquarters in this quiet town in northwestern Ohio look like an old high school, with old-fashioned furniture and linoleum floors. There is little in the way of plush offices and fancy furniture here.
Cooper's strategy has worked well enough that the company's plants have been running at full capacity and the company had to acquire an old Firestone plant in Georgia to meet demand.
''Cooper decided long ago to become a niche player and they have become the quintessential niche player,'' said Dennis J. Byrne, an economics professor at the University of Akron who studies the tire industry. ''They have never tried to become a major tire company. They have built up tremendous dealer loyalty and they are a well-run, low-cost company.''
 
Earnings Spurted in '89
Last year Cooper had net income of $58.2 million, up 41.6 percent from $41 million in 1988. Sales last year came to $866.8 million, a gain of 15.9 percent from $748 million the year before. Meanwhile, Cooper's stock, which traded at $8 to $10 five years ago and about $30 a year ago, closed yesterday at $39.125, up 62.5 cents, on the New York Stock Exchange.
Some executives of rival tire companies suggest that Cooper's stock price has been raised by takeover speculation. Cooper is the only remaining publicly traded tire company apart from Goodyear. ''There have been a number of takeover rumors about Cooper in the last two to three years,'' a senior executive at Goodyear said.
Already, consolidations have reshaped the tire industry. General Tire was acquired by Continental A. G. of West Germany in 1984, and Firestone was purchased by the Bridgestone Corporation of Japan in 1987.
 
A Potential Suitor
Much of the takeover speculation about Cooper has involved a large foreign tire maker eager to gain a foothold in the replacement-tire market in the United States. The most frequently mentioned potential suitor is Pirelli S.p.A., the Italian tire maker that three years ago lost to Bridgestone in a bidding war for Firestone. Pirelli subsequently bought the smaller Armstrong Tire Company, but is still said to be interested in another acquisition in the United States.
Ivan Gorr, the chairman of Cooper, said that takeover rumors were nothing more than a consequence of being a publicly traded company and that there was little worry among Cooper executives that a bid might emerge. ''Everyone is potentially a takeover target,'' Mr. Gorr said. ''But on the other hand, we are not a company that has resources that are not being used. Our split-up value would not be any greater than the value of the whole. Because we've done well and we're growing, our share price has been at reasonable values.'' Analysts agreed.
William T. Fitzgerald, Cooper's president and chief operating officer, added: ''Anyone interested in acquiring Cooper would have to be really interested in the tire business. Then they would have to be able to demonstrate that they could run the company better than we can. That's a combination that would be hard to find.''
 
Stock Price Defended
Mr. Gorr and others here say the company's share price reflects not so much takeover speculation as profitability, solid strategy and a committed work force that can add to its income by as much as 13.5 percent through profit sharing.
The 60-year-old Mr. Gorr, who became chairman last November after 17 years with the company, takes pride in the fact that Cooper operates only three retail tire stores, unlike Goodyear, Firestone and others that have operated national networks of retail tire centers. ''We have only three stores and they are in cities where we have plants and we use them to train our people,'' Mr. Gorr said. ''But, other than that, all of our tires are sold through independent dealers, who know that we're not in competition with them. Our aim is to assist them, rather than to compete against them.''
Automobile and truck replacement tires account for 80 percent of Cooper's sales. The remaining 20 percent represents sales of industrial products like inner tubes, reinforced hose, and door and window seals.
While Cooper has shown steady gains, some analysts question whether the company's performance might soon be hurt by mounting competition from larger tire producers that, suffering from low growth in sales to auto makers, are looking more to the replacement market.
Mr. Gorr said Cooper could easily counter any potential assaults through a number of strategies, including building upon its small presence in foreign tire markets, now about 4 percent of Cooper's business. ''We are able to respond quickly to what happens in the marketplace,'' Mr. Gorr said. ''We're an aggressive company.''

HEADLINE: First-Quarter Productivity Declined 1%

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7

 BODY:
The productivity of business in the United States fell an unexpectedly sharp 1 percent in the first quarter of 1990, despite the biggest gains in the manufacturing sector in nearly three years, the Labor Department said today.
The decline in non-farm productivity, a measure of efficiency and competitiveness of American businesses, compared with a revised advance of five-tenths of a percent in the fourth quarter last year.
The drop in the first quarter this year was the largest since a 1.3 percent decline in the first quarter of 1989. The first three months of the year are often sluggish after the holiday season. 
Economists were expecting a modest gain in productivity, which gauges the output each hour of all workers.
The figure is considered of long-term importance for the nation to reduce its trade deficit because American companies must produce more at lower costs.
''It is negative for the trade deficit because productivity weakness means we lose out in competitive terms internationally,'' said Michael Englund, an economist at MMS International Inc.
Manufacturing productivity, frequently stronger than overall results, rose a brisk 4.1 percent, exceeding a 3.1 percent gain in the fourth quarter. It was the strongest climb since the second quarter of 1987, when the index advanced 7.2 percent.
 
One-Time Factors
But one-time factors - the return to work of striking Boeing Company workers, a climb in output at aerospace supply companies idled by the 1989 strike and a rebound in productivity of West Coast companies after the San Francisco earthquake - accounted for much of the spurt, economists said.
After eliminating these factors, the results are gloomy, analysts said.
''The jump in manufacturing productivity is nothing to cheer about,'' said William MacReynolds, a United States Chamber of Commerce economist. ''It reflects a severe cutback in jobs and hours worked, another manifestation of the economic slowdown.''
Manufacturing hours slid 3.2 percent on top of a 4.3 percent drop in the previous quarter. Output rose a meager eight-tenths of a percent against a revised 1.3 percent fourth-quarter decline.
''For the whole economy, the numbers look pretty atrocious,'' said David Wyss, an economist with Data Resources Inc.
Core manufacturing productivity showed no improvement from its average annual rate of about 3 percent, he said.
 
Inflationary Fear
In addition, unit labor costs in the non-farm sector rose by a stiff 4.9 percent on top of a revised 5.5 percent fourth-quarter gain, Mr. Wyss said.
''If this persists, it has to be passed on in prices, which is inflationary,'' he said.
For all business sectors including farming, productivity declined five-tenths of a percent, compared with a four-tenths of a percent climb in the previous quarter.
Hourly compensation in the nonfarm sector rose 3.9 percent, compared with 6 percent in the prior quarter. But after taking inflation into account, real wages fell 3.9 percent against a 1.9 percent fourth-quarter advance, the department said.
Manufacturing compensation rose 3.2 percent, slowing from a 7 percent fourth-quarter climb. But a jump in consumer prices in the first quarter led to an effective 4.5 percent decline in real wages.

HEADLINE: O.E.C.D. Chief On Textiles

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 7

 BODY:
The international drive to reform the world's trading system will fail unless industrial nations agree to scrap their barriers to textile imports from developing countries, the head of the O.E.C.D. said today.
 
Jean-Claude Paye, Secretary
General for the Organization of Economic Cooperation and Development, said his group's members must back up their words with actions if they want international trade talks, known as the Uruguay Round, to succeed. 
The Uruguay Round, which aims to increase worldwide trade by eliminating barriers to imports, is scheduled to wrap up by the end of this year.
Developing nations, particularly those in Asia, have been pressing rich countries to abolish the so-called Multi-Fiber Arrangement, which governs most world trade in textiles through bilateral tariffs and quotas. It will expire in 1992.
Mr. Paye, who was here to take stock of the United States position before the O.E.C.D.'s annual ministerial meeting at the end of this month, urged industrial nations to get rid of the Multi-Fiber Ararangement.
 
He also called on the United
States and Europe to take steps toward settling their dispute over trade in farm goods when they meet in Paris at the end of this month.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Declines on Worries About U.S. Unemployment

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell yesterday against most major currencies, as the West German mark strengthened and concern continued over the United States unemployment rate.
Gold prices strengthened. Gold rose $1 an ounce, to $371.90, on the Commodity Exchange in New York. The Republic National Bank later quoted a bid of $371.70, up 40 cents from late Friday. 
Traders said the currency market continued to feel the effects of Friday's unemployment report, which showed the jobless rate rose from 5.2 percent in March to 5.4 percent in April, the highest rate in more than a year.
Andrew Hodge, vice president of corporate treasury services at Bank Brussels Lambert in New York, said the unemployment report ''was not only weak, but it raises the question of whether we're seeing a slowdown in the service sector.''
The report touched off concern that the Federal Reserve would be reluctant to let interest rates rise because of the signs of economic weakness. Mr. Hodge said interest rates, which have risen in recent weeks, have been a prime supporting factor for the value of the dollar.
Higher interest rates tend to make the dollar more valuable relative to other currencies.
Mr. Hodge said the mark rose relative to most other currencies after officials of East and West Germany gave assurances that the imminent merger of the monetary systems of the two nations would not disrupt financial markets or be excessively inflationary.
The mark also continued to be increased by the negotiation of a West German metalworkers' union contract on Friday that was viewed as less inflationary than many had feared, he said.
Against the West German currency, the dollar fell to 1.6556 marks, from 1.6660 late Friday.
In Europe, where London markets were closed for a holiday, the dollar fell against the British pound. One pound cost $1.6710, more expensive than $1.6595 late Friday. In in New York, the pound cost $1.6685, up from $1.6635 late Friday.
In New York trading against the Japanese currency, the dollar bought 158.15 yen, down from 158.30 yen late Friday. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar fell 0.75 yen to close at 157.80 yen. And in Europe, the dollar was quoted at 157.55 yen.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday, included: 1.4310 Swiss francs, down from 1.4430; 5.5615 French francs, down from 5.5930; 1,214.50 Italian lire, down from 1,221.00, and 1.1633 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1629.
In Zurich, gold rose to a closing bid of $371.70, up from $371 late Friday. In Hong Kong, gold rose 34 cents to close at a bid $373.10.
Silver prices also rose. Silver for current delivery traded at $5.016 an ounce, compared with $5 late Friday on the Commodity Exchange.

HEADLINE: Savings Bailout Agency to Allow Large Cuts in Prices of Real Estate

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8

 BODY:
Seeking to speed up the nation's savings and loan bailout, the Government today agreed to permit big markdowns on the $16.4 billion worth of real estate and other properties it has for sale.
The board of the Resolution Trust Corporation, which manages the day-to-day affairs of the bailout, voted unanimously to permit the agency's local managers and national directors to cut prices on the appraised value of the real estate that it inherited by seizing troubled savings institutions.
The plan allows them to reduce prices immediately by 15 percent below the appraised value on properties that have not sold for six months, and then by another 5 percent on those still not sold after another three months. The vast portion of the assets the agency has to sell is real estate but the properties also include cars, planes, furniture and office equipment.
''We have concluded that holding on to property is too costly to the taxpayer,'' said L. William Seidman, chairman of the trust corporation, after he and the board's three other members voted. The others on the board are Comptroller Robert L. Clarke; T. Timothy Ryan Jr., director of the Office of Thrift Supervision, and C. C. Hope Jr., a board member of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation. ''I think it is time to get this property off the shelves and sell it,'' Mr. Hope said. 
 
Backed by Administration
The price-cutting plan, which has the full backing of the Bush Administration, also permits the agency to reduce by as much as 30 percent below appraised values the prices it can accept on parcels of real estate and other assets sold at auction. That provision is in preparation for the agency's first major auction, which is scheduled for July, when it is planned to sell as much as $300 million in appraised volume.
The plan is the latest in a series of new policies put into effect in recent months by the agency to remedy the slow start of the bailout.
It also represents an attempt by the trust corporation to reduce the loss to the Government. If the plan is as successful as trust agency officials expect it to be, the accelerated sales would reduce the cost of the bailout, thus lowering the nation's budget deficit.
The plan is essentially the idea of Mr. Seidman, who has recently come under pressure from White House officials to leave because of his independence. But he has said he will decide the day of his departure and is proceeding with his ambitious plan to sell 141 institutions at a cost of more than $50 billion by the end of June.
Trust agency officials denied that their new approach to the nation's biggest real estate liquidation would permit investors to make windfall profits on everything from Houston golf courses to Miami hotels and Denver condominiums. But they admitted that their aim was to make the properties more attractive to private-sector buyers.
Mr. Seidman has said for months that the most critical aspect of the agency's task was to liquidate its inventory of troubled real estate efficiently. Seventy percent of the real estate is in the Southwest - primarily in Texas, Oklahoma, Louisiana and Arizona, and other pockets of major concentration are in Colorado, Florida and California.
 
Fears on Market Effect
But one of the major concerns is whether such cut-rate pricing, which some have warned could lead to dumping of properties, will have a spillover effect on local real estate markets, not only depressing the value of thousands of homes, but causing strains on healthy banks and savings institutions.
In recent months, however, both members of Congress and many industry representatives who initially warned about dumping have muted their criticism and even begun to support a plan to quickly sell off the trust agency's real estate.
''I think a lot of people would expect our reaction to be utter horror, but we are cautiously optimistic that this will work,'' said David Seiders, chief economist for the National Association of Home Builders. ''We don't believe they want to dump and realize they need to search for true market values.''
''The objective is the correct one,'' said Donald W. Crocker, president of J. E. Robert Companies, a national real estate firm. ''If, in fact, they have exposed the property to the market adequately and have given people a reasonable opportunity to make offers at the appraised value, and still don't have a deal, it is obvious that the asking price is higher than the market price.''
Mr. Crocker added that he was not concerned about the program depressing further local real estate prices. ''Frankly, my view is that having sales take place and moving excess inventory into private hands so you reduce the amounts of properties that are boarded up, that are fenced in, that are eyesores, is what you need to do to signal to everyone that things are going to start coming back,'' he said.
 
New Flexibility Is Seen
William D. North, executive vice president of the National Association of Realtors, hailed the plan as introducing ''some marketing flexibility.''
'' This is exactly what happens in the live real estate marketplace,'' he said.
Trust agency officials said that in the long run, not selling the assets would keep already weakened real estate markets depressed with little hope of a recovery. ''The overhang of these unsold assets freezes the market in place, and until that overhang is sold you can't break that freeze,'' Mr. Seidman said. The primary reason for selling now at reduced prices is that, so far, eight months into the bailout, very little real estate has been sold and is essentially deterioriating under Govenrment supervision. And for every day the agency holds onto these assets, the losses mount, as does the ultimate cost for the taxpayer of the savings and loan debacle.
Trust agency officials and even many real estate experts have estimated that the cost of not selling the $16.4 billion inventory of single-family homes, undeveloped land, partly completed apartment complexes, vacant office buildings and other assets is as much as 20 percent of its total value a year. That would translate into an added cost to taxpayers of more than $250 million a month, or almost $9 million a day.
''Thus, if you can get 80 cents on a dollar now, it's worth selling it,'' said Lamar Kelley, director of the asset and real estate management division of the trust agency.
 
Revisions Previously Adopted
Before today's new pricing policy, the trust agency had already adopted a series of revisions in its measures for handling the savings and loan bailout. Plagued by bureaucratic infighting and unrealistic approaches to selling institutions, the agency decided to give buyers of sick savings institutions up to two years, rather than six months, to return to the Government assets they deem unsellable.
The agency also reduced the down-payment requirements on assets bought by the public with Government financing to 15 percent, from 25 percent. It began a program to sell insolvent institutions to interested buyers before they are seized by the Government and a plan to assist nearly insolvent but viable savings and loan associations that have a reasonable chance of avoiding failure.
William Taylor, president of the trust agency's oversight board, which rules on broad agency policies, said in a letter to the trust corporataion that he endorsed the new plan and supported ''a higher degree of flexibility and a less mechanical formula in order to expedite asset sales.''
Marlin Fitzwater, the White House press secretary, said the Bush Administration wanted ''the assets to be disposed of as rapidly as possible.''
 
Endorsement in Congress
Representative Bruce Vento, a Minnesota Democrat who is the chairman of the House Banking Committee's trust agency panel, also endorsed the plan. ''The R.T.C. properties have a shelf life problem,'' Mr. Vento said. ''They are not like red wine. They do not get better with age. Quicker sales will mean savings to the Government in the long run.''
Under the two-part plan, if the trust agency has had, for example, an office building to sell for six months with no acceptable offers, it can immediately mark the price of that down by 15 percent below its appraised value, without getting a new appraisal. If the building does not sell after another three months, the price can be cut another 5 percent. But after the total 20 percent drop, a new appraisal is required to reduce the price further.
Single-family homes can be marked down after only four months.
For auctions, the agency can sell any asset that is valued at under $100,000 in a so-called absolute auction, which means that the property is guaranteed to be sold that day to the highest bidder, no matter how low the bid is, provided it has been widely exposed to the market.
However, for properties valued at $100,000 or above, the agency has to set a reserved price below which it will not sell the property. But that price can be as low as 70 percent of the appraised value of the property.

HEADLINE: I.M.F. PANEL VOTES TO ADD $60 BILLION TO POOL FOR LOANS

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8

 BODY:
After three years of contentious negotiations, rich and poor countries agreed today on a 50 percent increase in the resources of the International Monetary Fund, giving it the money to speed market-oriented economic policies in Eastern Europe and help third world countries cut their debt burden.
The $60 billion that would be pumped into the 152-nation lending organization after each Government ratifies the accord, a process that could take up to 18 months, would reinforce the I.M.F. as the central pillar of the monetary system. After ratification, the fund could tap as much of that money as needed.
The agreement, reached early this morning after a series of compromises by members of the I.M.F.'s policy-making Interim Committee, also codifies the realignment of world economic power that has taken place since 1945, when the institution was founded. 
 
Britain Drops in Rank
Britain's place as No. 2 in the institutional rankings of voting strength, which it has held throughout the postwar period, is being taken by Japan and West Germany, which will share the ranking.
Britain and France will now share the next position. The United States continues to command the largest vote, about 20 percent, retaining veto power over major decisions.
Since capital contributions are in line with voting strength, the United States would put up 20 percent, or $12 billion, of the $60 billion. Japan and West Germany would each put up 6 percent, and Britain and France 5.5 percent.
''Each country had to put a little water in its wine to come to an agreement here,'' said Michael Wilson, Finance Minister of Canada and the Interim Committee chairman.
Michel Camdessus, the former French central banker who is managing director of the I.M.F., said the institution was now well placed to meet the tremendous challenges of the 1990's.
Among the concessions made by Washington was to bow to a 50 percent rise after initially arguing that no increase was justified and later insisting on a limit of 35 percent.
The Bush Administration also accepted a demand of third world countries that negotiations on the next capital increase begin in 1993, two years earlier than it had wanted.
But because of the dominant role of the United States in the organization, it could easily delay any agreement until it felt a need was justified - as it has done over the latest negotiating cycle.
''After all, we still control the process,'' said a senior Treasury official who spoke on condition of anonymity.
The new role for the monetary fund in Eastern Europe, where $715 million of I.M.F. assistance is already backing the Solidarity-led Government of Poland in its program that is practically a cold-turkey conversion to a market economy, is expected to help the Administration sell the capital increase to Congress.
''I.M.F. legislation is always difficult here,'' said Robert Browne, staff director of the House Banking Committee's Subcommittee on International Development, Finance, Trade and Investment Policy.
''But I suspect in the end this will go through because of interest up here in the debt strategy and helping Eastern Europe.''
Because of the complex way the monetary fund works, the money does not increase the Federal budget deficit, but the Bush Administration still faces a battle in Congress, where any form of foreign aid is unpopular. Technically, the money represents an exchange of assets. The United States makes the dollars available on call, but increases its own rights to borrow the currencies of other nations as needed.
The I.M.F. makes short- to medium-term loans, mostly around three years, to countries having trouble making ends meet. To qualify, borrowers must pledge tough economic measures, like cutting subsidies, selling state enterprises or revamping public administrations.
 
Seal of Approval
The I.M.F. helps create the programs and monitors progress. Its seal of approval helps borrowers line up other sources of capital, possibly from the World Bank or commercial banks. If the borrower falls short of meeting the I.M.F. targets, it risks a cutoff that jeopardizes the other forms of assistance.
In the past, some client states, like Zambia, Jamaica, Egypt and Venezuela, have accused the I.M.F. of causing human suffering through austerity programs.
But in recent years such criticism is being heard less. One reason is that many governments have come around to the belief that market-oriented policies improve economic performance. In addition, I.M.F. programs are now being set up with greater focus on economic growth.
The World Bank, which was founded along with the I.M.F. after World War II, makes longer-term loans for big public projects like irrigation, highways, schools, hospitals in developing countries. Its membership, like the I.M.F., recently voted to double its capital.
In a capital-short world, competition is likely to be keen for the new resources.
Among countries expected to ask for money are Poland, for a second loan, Czechoslovakia, Bulgaria, Brazil, Morocco, Argentina and Indonesia.
In the past year the I.M.F. has committed close to $10 billion to Mexico, the Philippines and Venezuela.
Officials say the Soviet Union will not become a member, and therefore able to borrow, until at least the middle of the decade. The timing depends on the progress of market-oriented economic changes undertaken by President Mikhail S. Gorbachev.
This is the ninth time that the monetary fund has come to members for additional funds, and it represents the largest infusion of all.
 
Behind on Payments
In the deal worked out this morning, the United States and other developed countries won a tough plan to deal with the problem of countries that are far behind in their loan payments to the fund.
Nigeria and India were among countries that objected but then joined the consensus that permitted conclusion of the agreement.
The arrears plan has to be formally accepted by a vote of at least 85 percent of the members if the capital increase is to go forward. This linkage was a sine qua non of the United States.
Eleven countries are more than six months overdue on $4 billion of loans. In the Bush Administration's view, the existence of such large arrears could undermine the credibility of the fund and weaken the case before Congress for the infusion.
The plan calls for delinquent countries to lose their voting rights if 70 percent of the executive board approves, but special efforts would be undertaken to help such countries improve their economic conditions and win their rights back, provided they are willing to impose heavily supervised economic policies.
''It is in the interests of the arrears countries themselves to have clear rules of the game,'' said the French Finance Minister, Pierre Beregovoy, in explaining the plan to reporters today.
He called the suspension of voting rights ''a kind of warning,'' before use of the ''ultimate weapon,'' expulsion from the fund, an action that has yet to be taken against any member.

HEADLINE: BUSH BUDGET CHIEF SOUNDS THE ALARM ON A RISING DEFICIT

BYLINE: By ANDREW ROSENTHAL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8

 BODY:
Raising the pressure on Congress to negotiate a budget settlement, the White House warned today that without agreement on major reductions in the deficit, the Government would face mandatory cuts of up to $100 billion this fall.
Richard G. Darman, the White House budget director, gave Republican lawmakers projections indicating that the deficit for the 1991 fiscal year could be as high as $165 billion, while the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law requires that it be no more than $64 billion.
 
Suddenly, Higher Stakes
In his original budget proposal to Congress in January, President Bush forecast a deficit of about $100 billion. To reduce that to $64 billion, he called for $36 billion in spending cuts and modest increases in airport landing fees, highway user fees, taxes on phone service and the like.
Over the past two months Mr. Darman has increased the figure on spending cuts to $40 billion to $50 billion. But today's even larger estimate of the deficit and the cuts needed to reduce it seemed intended to alarm legislators into reaching a quick agreement. Today Mr. Darman estimated that the needed cuts would range from $60 billion to $100 billion, depending partly on how the costs of the savings and loan rescue are counted and partly on interest rates and other economic measures. 
 
Fears on Economy
Mr. Darman attributed his gloomier projections to rising interest rates, a decline in Government revenue and the increasing costs of the savings and loan bailout. These reasons offered clues to Mr. Bush's new willingness to discuss tax increases. The Administration fears that a high deficit will cause increased competition for loans as the Government is forced to borrow more, leading to high interest rates that could set off a recession just in time for the 1992 Presidential election.
White House officials said Mr. Bush's concern that the economy might be weakening was deepened by last week's report that unemployment had risen from 5.2 percent to 5.4 percent. He set up a meeting with Congressional leaders on Sunday to plan a ''budget summit'' meeting and on Monday allowed his press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, to say tax increases were on the table in those talks. [Page B8.] Normally, tax cuts and increased spending - the opposite of the steps now being discussed at Mr. Bush's urging - are the prescription to revive a sagging economy. But the White House has decided that reducing the deficit is the first priority for sustaining the seven and a half years of economic growth that is a leading factor in Mr. Bush's popularity.
Today's forecasts, outlined in meetings with Republican leaders in the White House and on Capitol Hill, seemed intended to strengthen Mr. Bush's hand in negotiations with Congress over the 1991 budget by raising the stakes for a quick agreement and laying the economic justifications for any tax increases.
Specifically, Mr. Bush's aim today seemed to be to prepare Republican members of Congress for the possibility of a tax increase, a politically unpopular idea in an election year.
 
A Message for Democrats, Too
But the message was also aimed at Democrats in Congress. Mr. Bush, who is hoping to lure the Democrats into a budget deal with his new willingness to discuss tax increases, hopes to avoid any debate over taxes later in the year, when Congressional elections are in full swing.
Mr. Bush is to meet with Democratic and Republican Congressional leaders again on Wednesday, and both sides predicted that the budget summit meeting would be convened soon. To entice the Democrats, who bear scars from Mr. Bush's skill in portraying them as wasteful advocates of higher taxes, Mr. Fitzwater promised today that negotiators could propose any idea ''without being politically castigated for it.''
But both sides are eager to avoid being tarred as tax raisers, and Democrats remain wary on this third day of the White House's budget offensive. By some people's reckoning, Democrats would stand to lose politically by either endorsing a tax increase or helping a White House that is suddenly nervous about a recession. Next, a National Lottery? Senator Alan K. Simpson of Wyoming, the Republican whip, said a long list of ''revenue increases'' were ''in the mix,'' including a national lottery and a value-added tax, a national sales tax of 1 percent. He said Mr. Bush had not endorsed or rejected any of them, but predicted that an increase in income-tax rates was out of the question, for political reasons if nothing else.
''George Bush is the oldest pro in the village as a political man,'' Mr. Simpson said after the White House meeting. ''No one is going to come out here and say that we're going to do anything at all with income tax.''
Despite White House efforts to reassure the opposition, Representative Newt Gingrich of Georgia, the House Republican whip, sought to stigmatize the Democrats as the true authors of the current thinking about a tax increase. ''I don't think there's any question in this country which party is addicted to tax increases and which party is reluctantly willing to negotiate,'' he said.
Although some Democrats suggested that some sort of tax increase was inevitable, most seemed intent on making Mr. Bush say so first.
Otherwise, Senator Dennis DeConcini of Arizona said, ''I don't think the Democrats are going to talk taxes.'' Senator Paul Simon of Illinois said: ''Clearly, there has been an attempt to paint the Democrats as forcing the President's hand on taxes. There's a general consensus that the President has neither defined the problem nor suggested what we should do as a solution.''
In his meetings with Congressional officials today, Mr. Darman said the size of the deficit for 1991 would depend largely on how the savings and loan rescue is handled.
The budget chief said the Administration would have to reduce the deficit by $100 billion to reach the Gramm-Rudman target if the money spent to buy assets of failed savings and loan institutions is calculated as part of the Federal budget.
If it is removed from the calculation, as many lawmakers and Administration officials would like, that would still leave a forced reduction of about $60 billion under the Gramm-Rudman law, Mr. Darman told lawmakers today.
Under the bailout program, the Government buys the assets of failed savings and loan institutions and then tries to sell them, usually at a discount.
 
Bailout Calculations
When money is spent to take over the institutions, it increases Government outlays. When the assets are sold, the proceeds are recorded as income.
Since the purchase and the sale do not necessarily come in the same fiscal year, the Administration and most members of Congress argue that they distort the size of the difference between income and spending.
They say the bailout program should therefore be removed from the Gramm-Rudman calculations.
Although that would reduce the pressure on the Congress and the Administration this year, since it would reduce the size of the deficit, the savings and loan rescue could be removed from the deficit calculation only as part of an overall budget agreement.
Mr. Fitzwater said today that Mr. Bush had outlined three broad objectives for the budget negotiations. He said the President wanted a budget that would maintain economic growth, and an agreement with Congress on a long-range program to reduce the deficit. Some Democrats said such an agreement did not seem likely.
Mr. Bush will also continue to argue for two items he and Ronald Reagan have long called vital: a Constitutional amendment requiring a balanced budget, and the power to veto individual items in a spending bill without rejecting the entire measure.

HEADLINE: U.S.-Kenyan Dispute Grows a Little Testier

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, May 8

 BODY:
A Kenyan Cabinet member accused the United States today of supporting the opposition, another step in the dispute between the United States and Kenya over the future of democracy in this nation. The American Ambassador denied the accusation. 
The Minister for Livestock Development, Elijah Mwangale, was quoted this morning in The Kenya Times, the newspaper of the nation's sole political party, as saying that he had information to the effect that Kenyan dissidents in the United States were using the Ambassador to pour money into the country to disrupt it.
Mr. Mwangale said Kenya would ''not tolerate treasonable activities by Americans living in Kenya.''
The American envoy, Smith Hempstone, denied that the United States was supporting Kenyan dissidents.
In a telephone interview, Mr. Hempstone characterized Mr. Mwangale's statements as ''arid nonsense.'' The envoy added, ''It is well known that if anyone knows about illegal money, he knows about it.'' He did not explain what he meant.
Last week, Mr. Hempstone said Congress favored economic aid to countries that ''nourish democratic institutions, defend human rights and practice multiparty politics.''
President Daniel arap Moi took exception to the comments and warned that foreign diplomats should not meddle in the internal affairs of Kenya.
A traditional ally, Kenya received $65 million in economic aid last year, one of Washington's largest grants in sub-Saharan Africa.

HEADLINE: EUROPEANS WEIGH FUND TO AID EAST

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: UNITED NATIONS, May 6

 BODY:
The 12 European Community nations are discussing a plan to help Eastern Europe break away from barter-based trading and start trading in convertible currencies as Western countries do, European officials say.
The idea is to create a revolving fund of dollars or other hard currencies from which Eastern European nations could borrow to settle their trade debts with each other. These loans would be repaid when the borrower earned a trade surplus.
Such a fund would enable Eastern European countries to stop using the inefficent trading system, coordinated by the organization known as Comecon, that links them with each other and the Soviet Union. Instead, they would start exchanging goods at world prices paid in convertible currency. This would promote the competitiveness of their economies and help sustain Eastern European trade. 
 
Control vs. Market Forces
All Eastern European currencies, like the Polish zloty and the Soviet ruble, are called soft, or nonconvertible, because the exchange of those currencies is governed by strict rules and controlled by the Government. Western currencies like the American dollar or the West German mark are all hard, or convertible, meaning that their value is determined by market forces and they can be freely exchanged for other currencies at prevailing market rates.
In a recent interview, the Italian Foreign Minister, Gianni De Michelis, discussed the European plan for a such a hard-currency fund, similar to the European Payments Union the United States created to assist Western Europe's recovery after World War II.
But he said the plan had run into difficulties because the Soviet Union also wanted such benefits and had warned that any attempt to exclude it would be regarded as ''an unfriendly political act.'' The community's position is that extending the plan to cover the Soviet Union would be too costly.
The Italian Foreign Minister said the warning reflected the Soviet Government's ''desperate need'' for Western assistance in modernizing its economy.
The Soviet warning creates ''a political dilemma'' for the community, he said. A quarrel now over trade and finance would sour relations with Moscow just when the West wants the Soviet leadership to accept a united Germany's inclusion in NATO and other changes.
 
'It Would Be Expensive'
Mr. De Michelis said, ''It would be expensive to replace all Comecon and guarantee the convertibility of the ruble.''
Senior Eastern European economic officials attending a United Nations conference said the community idea, though still at the exploratory stage, had been well received in Eastern Europe. But they also said it would be difficult and expensive to include the Soviet Union.
Dr. Karel Dyba, director of the Institute of Economics in Prague and an adviser to the Czechoslovak Government, said such a fund would help Eastern European nations ''stop exchanging shoddy goods and start trading in real money.'' This, he went on, would prevent ''a massive destruction of East European trade, leading to recession.''
Dr. Dyba said a pool of about $1 billion would probably be enough to finance Eastern European trade balances in convertible currency. But if the Soviet Union is included, he said, the cost will rise to ''many billions.''
He said the Soviet Union would probably have a massive trade surplus with Eastern Europe if trade was measured in dollars, because the main Soviet exports to Eastern Europe are oil and raw materials, while the goods it imports in exchange tend to be of poor quality and unsalable in the West.
 
Financing Modernization
The European Community, the United States and other Western countries have pledged $1 billion in aid to Poland and Hungary and are setting a new bank to finance modernization of Eastern European and Soviet industry.
In an interview devoted to the changes in Europe, the Italian Foreign Minister said the community and the Eastern Europeans had reached substantial agreement on the ''political architecture'' of a more unified continent linking Eastern European nations more firmly to the community.
All agree, he said, that the Eastern European nations should join the 21-nation Council of Europe and accept the jurisdiction of its Human Rights Court by 1991. The council was established in 1949 to promote democracy and unity in Europe. Hungary, Poland, Czechoslovakia and Yugoslavia have already started negotiations on membership, and Romania will soon do so shortly.

HEADLINE: U.S. WILL OPPOSE AID IN OZONE PLAN

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHABECOFF, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8

 BODY:
The Bush Administration has decided to oppose an international plan that would grant $100 million to developing nations to drastically reduce the use of chemicals that are depleting the earth's protective ozone layer, officials said today.
A State Department official who spoke on condition of anonymity said Richard G. Darman, director of Management and Budget, and John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, insisted on the decision to oppose the plan over the objection of Environmental Protection Agency Administrator William K. Reilly. The decision is regarded by officials as a crucial part of President Bush's environmental policy but one that could eventually be reversed. 
Representatives of the United States and other nations are are expected to take up the ozone proposal, which has strong support in Europe, Wednesday in Geneva. The meeting is designed to lay the groundwork for a conference in London next month that would strengthen a 1987 treaty that restricts the chemicals, cholorofluorocarbons, or CFC's, and eliminate production of the industrial chemicals outright.
 
Emphasis on Economic Growth
The State Department and the Environmental Protection Agency are trying to persuade President Bush to reverse his decision in time for the London conference.
President Bush has repeatedly pledged that his concern for the environment, but critics maintain that his words are stronger than his actions. Mr. Darman and Mr. Sununu have emphasized economic growth over environmental considerations in previous debates on such issues.
The proposed prohibition on CFC production would require the development of substitutes for their use in refigerants, solvents, foam insulation and a wide variety of other products.
Scientists say the chemicals persist in the atmosphere, destroying ozone, which shields the earth from harmful ultraviolet radiation from the sun. Such radiation can cause skin cancer and immunological problems in humans, harm wildlife and crops.
 
Use of World Bank Suggested
India and China, which together make up more than a third of the world's population, never signed the 1987 treaty, the Montreal Protocol.
India informed American oficials last month that it would not participate in the ozone treaty without substantial financial and technical aid from the industrialized countries. The Indians informed the United States that they and the Chinese would procede with plans to continue CFC production. They also said that without such aid not only would developing countries refuse to join in the ozone treaty but that a number of countries that had already signed would withdraw. They did not identify the countries.
Mr. Darman reportedly opposed any financial aid to developing countries to help them with environmental programs. Mr. Sununu was said to suggest that the World Bank could finance such programs.
White House officials were also said to have discussed the possibility of denying World Bank loans to countries that refused to sign the ozone treaties.

LENGTH: 452 words

HEADLINE: Yes, Cut the Deficit. Then What?

 BODY:
Will the budget deadlock finally be broken this time? President Bush's willingness to hold wide-open talks with the leaders of Congress is encouraging. But ultimate success depends on an agreement that goes beyond honest deficit reduction and addresses urgent national needs.
Preoccupation with the deficit-reduction process has been unavoidable. But it distracts from the budget's purpose - to shape policy. Conditions are ripe to do just that. Eased East-West tensions invite cutbacks in defense. The question is no longer whether to trim, but how. At the same time, unanticipated developments in the economy force a fresh look at the whole range of budget issues. Rising interest rates and drooping tax collections have sent the deficit back up again. 
To shrink next year's deficit to the $64 billion target in the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings law would require severe spending cuts that are unacceptable to the Administration and Congress alike. So despite his distaste for new taxes, even Mr. Bush now seems to be willing to consider them.
For a while, political Washington's attention will be riveted on this opening for tax increases, and understandably so. It's a dramatic new element in the budget debate, long overdue. Political realism suggests that the increases won't be large and won't quickly wipe out the deficit. But with added revenue, and savings in defense and entitlement programs, there will at last be funds to ease the deficit paralysis. The more difficult question remains: How should the Government use them?
What's needed is a plan that looks beyond one year and one arbitrary target. For too long, domestic needs have been shortchanged by spending for military security. The President and Congress now have the opportunity to focus on social and economic security.
Two prime contenders for better funding are programs to give disadvantaged children a better start in life and repair the nation's infrastructure. But there's pressure for more of everything. Genuine needs for education, drug programs, AIDS research and Medicaid confront powerful interests that want still more for space, technology and farm programs.
The new negotiations won't settle details, but it's essential that there be broad agreement in good faith. Democrats are properly wary of being tagged once more as the advocates of tax-and-spend. The Administration, for its part, wants assurance that Congress will honor whatever agreement emerges on spending cuts.
Such mutual suspicion will only keep both sides from seizing the rare opportunity that presents itself. They can break the paralysis of budget battles, year upon year, or they can concoct yet another smoke-and-mirrors solution that solves nothing.

HEADLINE: Congress Provides Open Forum on Soviet Data

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In his April 27 column, ''Intelligence Fiasco,'' William Safire misleadingly criticizes the Joint Economic Committee for publishing Central Intelligence Agency estimates of the size of the Soviet economy and defense establishment.
The J.E.C. makes available a wide range of research on the Soviet economy, including declassified reports from both the Central Intelligence Agency and the Defense Intelligence Agency. All Western estimates of Soviet economic conditions are uncertain, due to Soviet secrecy, questionable official statistics and the absence of market prices and a freely convertible currency. Within our Government, the C.I.A. has the greatest capacity to monitor the Soviet economy. By publishing its estimates, the J.E.C. offers researchers, government experts, scholars and the media the opportunity to examine the intelligence community's views. 
Mr. Safire did not mention that the J.E.C. has invited critics of the C.I.A. to testify and contribute to the debate. Five of the eight economists he cites favorably have been invited to testify. Every three or four years, the committee publishes a massive study of the Soviet economy.
The committee has never taken a position in the debate. At times, J.E.C. members have expressed serious disagreement with C.I.A. positions, and J.E.C. members express differing opinions among themselves in interpreting C.I.A. evidence. Mr. Safire says the C.I.A.'s ''views were expressed'' in a letter to the editor from the staff of the J.E.C. in response to one of his previous columns. The committee did not write to either the editors or to Mr. Safire on this matter and when asked, Mr. Safire could not produce any such letter.
There is no hard evidence that proves or disproves the C.I.A. or its critics, and the effects of the military burden on the Soviet economy have not been fully understood. That is why the committee has provided an open forum for widely differing views.
 
(Rep.) LEE H. HAMILTON
Chairman, Joint Economic Committee
 Washington, May 2, 1990

HEADLINE: Bush's Second Chance on China

BYLINE: By Winston Lord; Winston Lord was Ambassador to China from 1985 to 1989.

 BODY:
June 3 marks the first anniversary of the massacre of innocents in the streets of Beijing.
It is also the deadline for President Bush to decide whether to recommend continued most-favored-nation trade treatment for China.
This irony poses a dilemma - and offers a major opportunity - for the Administration. In one stroke, President Bush can close the breach between Capitol Hill and the White House on China policy, forge a common American front and promote Chinese human rights and U.S. national interests. 
He should invite Congress to join him in crafting a joint statement for the first weekend in June. The essential components:
* An eloquent tribute to the Chinese who demonstrated and died for the aspirations America has supported elsewhere in the world.
* Extension of most-favored-nation trade status for one year, with the openly expressed purpose of supporting progressive forces in China, protecting concrete American interests and maintaining the framework for future American-Chinese relations. (This status entitles China to the standard treatment that the U.S. grants almost all other trading partners.)
* Explicit reaffirmation of such existing measures as the suspension of military ties, the freeze on liberalization of technology exports and the postponement of World Bank loans.
* Determination to move ahead on related issues, such as positive consideration of Taiwan's application to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade and enlarging future immigration opportunities for Hong Kong citizens.
* A substantial increase in Voice of America funding to overcome jamming of programs beamed to China.
* A meeting between President Bush and selected Chinese studying in America to exchange views on China and American policy.
There are solid grounds for revoking most-favored-nation status.
Both the preamble to the relevant statute and its legislative history include concerns for human rights.
The situation in China has greatly deteriorated this past year: executions, purges, imprisonment, surveillance, political indoctrination, the rollback of many economic reforms - all cloaked in the Big Lie.
The xenophobic regime has launched attacks on Western values and crude invective against the U.S. It muzzles foreign correspondents and jams the Voice of America.
Revoking most-favored-nation treatment, which would increase pressures on Beijing, would be the strongest signal of censure to date.
There is also the specific legislative criterion of free emigration. While many are still allowed to leave China, new restrictions have curtailed others, including students and scholars. Obviously, both dissidents in our embassy and tens of thousands in jail cannot move. Countless Chinese have no chance of getting exit papers or dare not even try.
In any case, the most potent argument for revocation is that extension of most-favored-nation status could be misconstrued by China's hardliners. In internal policy debates, they could argue that they can repress and reap commercial benefits, too.
Unfortunately, this view has been reinforced by Bush Administration actions: its unrequited conciliatory gestures; the double standard between China and support for democracy in Eastern Europe, Latin America and South Africa.
Beijing might conclude that there is no limit to our toleration of its abuses. So might Mikhail Gorbachev, as he contemplates his policies toward the Baltic states and his summit meeting with Mr. Bush on the eve of June 3.
For these reasons, simply extending most-favored-nation treatment would be a grave mistake. If the other steps outlined above are not undertaken, this trade status should be ended.
On balance, the arguments favor extension of most-favored-nation treatment - if imbedded in a larger package. Termination would trigger serious consequences.
First, it would hurt the wrong people in China, reducing their leverage in the struggle for its future.
The most severe impact would be on the sectors we wish to support -entrepreneurs, business people, Chinese in the coastal areas and open cities. They are the ones most dependent on foreign trade and investment and most committed to reform and contact with the outside world.
The regime, meanwhile, would use America as a handy scapegoat for China's floundering economy.
Second, termination would undermine Hong Kong. Seventy percent of China's $12 billion in exports to the U.S. passes through there. Millions working in Hong Kong and southern China would be affected. As Hong Kong residents look with trepidation toward 1997, when Britain turns Hong Kong over to China, this is no time to deal them additional economic and psychological blows.
Third, it would harm many Americans. Consumers would pay more for certain products; importers would need to look elsewhere; exporters would face retaliation by China. Business people in China and Hong Kong would lose markets and investments, perhaps permanently. Competitors in Japan, Europe, South Korea, Taiwan and elsewhere - where governments would not follow our lead - would profit, at America's expense.
Fourth, it would undercut our long-term objectives. While granting China new privileges would be wrong, we should be wary of dismantling frameworks like most-favored-nation treatment and the related overall trade agreement that were carefully constructed during the 1980's.
Once commercial and personal links with progressive forces are severed, repairing them would be difficult. We will need them in place when a more moderate regime allows us to resume full cooperation. That time is not far away.
President Bush has an opportunity to heal wounds on the single foreign policy issue where he has provoked heated debate and about which he may care most deeply. He can align himself solidly with the Chinese people for the first time and restore the bipartisan approach that marked our China policy for two decades through five Administrations. Congress, torn on the trade issue, would respond positively to a Bush initiative that made clear where this nation stood. Together, the President and Congress can send a powerful message to the transitional leaders in Beijing and to the Chinese people who herald a more hopeful future for their country.

HEADLINE: Adirondacks Report Upsets Residents

BYLINE: By SAM HOWE VERHOVEK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: OLD FORGE, N.Y., May 8

 BODY:
After holding hearings from Long Island to Buffalo, the Commission on the Adirondacks in the 21st Century released a final report today in Albany, where the fate of its proposals for preserving the area's wilderness will largely be determined.
People here in this North Country village are hoping for a say in the process, which they say will determine the fate of their livelihoods.
''The Adirondacks are a special and a different place, and of course protecting that is a good idea,'' said Don Kelly, the zoning officer for this village and the surrounding town of Webb in the southwestern Adirondacks. ''But there's also a fatalistic view here that we'll really wind up having no say about our future.'' 
Apprehension over the commission's report is high here and in many of the other 104 communities within the ''blue line'' that defines the Adirondack Park. The pace of new home construction, the amount of privately owned land, even the size of merchants' signs and the noise from motorboats, would all be curtailed under the sweeping recommendations of the commission.
 
'A Last Clear Chance'
The panel, appointed by Gov. Mario M. Cuomo, concluded that New York State had ''a last clear chance'' to preserve the wilderness character of the Adirondacks. And it proposed a one-year moratorium on nearly all construction within the park, new restrictions on building, and further state purchases of private land.
Today, as many environmental groups rushed to embrace the panel's recommendations, some local leaders were skeptical. Despite the report's endorsement of ''revitalization'' programs for Adirondack hamlets and more state aid for the health, education and housing of year-round residents, they said, the larger effects of the report's proposals could be crippling.
George P. Hiltebrant, the Webb town supervisor, said that the zoning restrictions and a proposed one-year moratorium on new construction permits on nearly all lakefront property would be ''economically damaging,'' to the town.
''I think the environment is an important thing and we have to protect it,'' he added. ''But to just say 'Stop!' is going too far.''
 
'Great Open Spaces'
The commission's chairman, Peter A. A. Berle, said that the program outlined today would benefit people in the park by fostering both ''great open spaces and dynamic hamlets'' that would keep the Adirondacks ''unique in the American scene'' for generations.
The primary reason for the tension here is that the Adirondacks, while frequently referred to as the largest park in the lower 48 states, are not a park in the sense of Yellowstone or Yosemite: About 58 percent of the park is in private hands, though much of that must be preserved as forest under existing regulations.
While the amount of private ownership would decrease to 48 percent under land acquisitions proposed by the commission, the question remains how public concerns about protecting the park's overall character should be reconciled with private-property rights.
The commission is now advancing recommendations that, through the state's purchase of conservation easements and a program of transferable development rights, would channel most new construction into about one-tenth of the park's 6 million acres.
 
Construction Has Soared
That would clearly slow the current pace of development. But the costs of such restrictions, both to the state and to the people who make their living here, are now likely to be at the heart of the debate that will determine whether the proposals will become law.
In the town of Webb, construction of new homes has soared in recent years, and many of the town's 1,700 year-round residents depend on that construction for their paychecks.
The lakefront construction moratorium would have an immediate impact, said Mr. Kelly, the zoning officer. Nearly one-third of the 249 new residences constructed in the past four years are on the Fulton chain of lakes, and several more projects are pending.
''The people who sit on our town boards are as concerned about overdevelopment as anybody else,'' said Mr. Hiltebrant, the town supervisor. ''But to have more rules imposed from the outside is not fair to us.''
 
Public Presentations
A realtor in town, Chuck Eldridge, said that new restrictions in the Adirondack Park could drive up already escalating prices of real estate, aggravating the housing problems of year-round residents and penalizing others who look for a summer place here.
The recommendations will now be the subject of public presentations across the state. How soon or even whether they will go before the Legislature is largely up to Governor Cuomo.
The Governor, who charged the commission with finding a way to head off an era of ''unbridled land speculation and unwarranted development that may threaten the unique open space and wilderness character of the region,'' did not comment today.
Several lawmakers have said he is likely to gauge public reaction to the report before deciding whether to press for adoption of any of the major recommendations. A spokesman for Mr. Cuomo, Gary G. Fryer, said the Governor planned to back implementation of ''at least some'' of the proposals.
 
Battle Lines Being Drawn
While the Governor and legislative leaders remain consumed with the long-overdue state budget, battle lines are already being drawn over the report among private lobbying groups.
The Adirondack Fairness Coalition, an 800-member group of residents that says it seeks to balance park protection with economic growth, criticized the report today for ignoring economic concerns and said it contained ''some of the most radical controls ever proposed for private land'' in America.
''Adirondackers aren't paving mountaintops,'' said the group's director, Andrew Halloran. ''There is no development crisis.''
But the executive director of the nonprofit Environmental Planning Lobby, Lee Wasserman, praised the report as a ''watershed document.''
''Anyone who loves the Adirondacks, who knows how lucky New Yorkers are to have this resource within our borders, has to be pleased,'' Mr. Wasserman said. ''The steady pattern of developmental abuse could not be sustained without irreparably damaging what makes the Adirondacks unique.

HEADLINE: Experts on Hill Sift Taxes to See Which to Raise

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8

 BODY:
As the White House and Congress lay plans for formal budget negotiations, fiscal experts on Capitol Hill are beginning to examine a long list of possible tax increases, ''user fees'' and tax-loophole closings that could yield $25 billion or more for the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1, and even larger amounts in future years.
The options theoretically encompass everything from a national sales tax to eliminating the home mortgage interest deduction. But most lawmakers believe that political and economic realities have already severely circumscribed their choices.
Republicans say that if they are going to accept tax increases, they must have guarantees that the new revenue will be used to reduce the deficit, not to finance domestic spending. Democrats say that to produce a tax package large enough to make negotiations worthwhile, there are only three real revenue sources: the income tax, energy taxes and excise taxes. 
And members of both parties remain skeptical that an agreement can be reached, either on spending cuts in popular programs like agriculture and Medicare or on tax increases.
 
Some Likely Combinations
At this preliminary stage, the most likely combinations of revenue sources appear to be an oil import fee, probably coupled with some type of gasoline or energy tax, a capital gains tax cut combined with an increase in the top income tax rate for high-income taxpayers, and excise taxes on wine, beer, liquor and cigarettes.
Two other potential revenue sources may figure in the tax negotiations: a levy on securities transactions similar to the one imposed in Japan and in many European countries, and taxes on fringe benefits like employer-provided health insurance plans.
Despite the White House contention that budget negotiations will be ''unfettered'' by any preconditions, lawmakers in both parties expect the Bush Administration to draw the line at raising income-tax rates and to confine real bargaining over tax increases to items like excise taxes and fees on various Government services and activities.
The exception may be a rise in the top tax rate for high-income taxpayers, a proposal that is likely to be the Democratic price for agreeing to President Bush's proposal to reduce the capital gains tax rate.
 
Cutting the Gains Rate
Capital gains, the profits on sales of stocks, real estate and other investments, are now taxed at the same rate as ordinary income, either 28 percent or 33 percent for most taxpayers. The Administration contends that cutting the gains rate would raise money by encouraging investors to sell off their existing assets and by stimulating new investment and economic growth.
Under the Administration's proposal, in 1990 profits on an asset held for one year or more would be taxed at a rate of 19.6 percent. In 1992, the asset would have to be held two years to qualify for that most preferential rate. In 1993 and thereafter, it would have to be held three years. Taxpayers who hold assets for shorter periods would receive proportionately smaller breaks, but would still pay less than they do now.
Democrats contend that reducing the capital gains rate would benefit only the wealthiest taxpayers. They insist that any proposal to reduce it must be accompanied by measures to insure fairness for lower-income taxpayers.
One possibility is a plan to eliminate the ''bubble'' in the current tax rate system, which allows wealthy taxpayers to pay a top rate of 28 percent on their income, while taxpayers with lower income are taxed at a top rate of 33 percent.
 
Higher Taxes on Cigarettes
The least politically painful tax increase would involve the Federal tax on cigarettes and alcohol. While such taxes hit consumers directly in their pocketbooks, lawmakers in both parties say the new health consciousness means it would be both good policy and good politics to raise such taxes now.
Cigarettes are now taxed at 16 cents a pack. Doubling that tax, the Congressional Budget Office says, would raise nearly $14 billion over the next five years.
Beer, wine and liquor are taxed at different rates. The beer tax, which has not been increased since 1951, comes to about 16 cents a six-pack. Wine taxes, now 17 cents a gallon, have also not been raised since 1951. Taxes on distilled spirits, which were last raised in 1985, are now $12.50 a proof gallon.
Adjusting the beer, wine and liquor tax rates so that they are all based on alcohol content and raising them to $16 per proof gallon would bring in an estimated $37 billion in the next five years.
 
Energy and Environment Taxes
Such an increase would translate to 81 cents for a six-pack of beer, 70 cents for a bottle of wine and $2.54 for a bottle of liquor, the Congressional Budget Office says.
Energy and environment taxes involve dozens of potential revenue raisers, from taxes on polluting chemicals in the air and water to those on gasoline, imported oil and utility bills.
The Federal tax on gasoline, last raised in 1982, is now 9 cents a gallon, and the Congressional Budget Office calculates that each 1-cent increase would raise $1 billion for the Treasury.
Imposing a fee of $5 a barrel on imported oil would raise $8.5 billion in 1991 and nearly $47 billion over five years, according to estimates by the Congressional Budget Office.
Congressional tax and budget say there may also be discussion of taxing a host of fringe benefits provided by employers, from health and life insurance to parking and athletic- club fees. According to the Congressional Budget Office, the current tax exemption for employer-paid health and life insurance premiums will cost the Treasury of $55 billion in 1991.
