HEADLINE: Bush Seems Concerned That Economy May Slip

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8

 BODY:
Just when it seemed clear that the economy had once again avoided sliding into recession, thereby further confounding those who still profess belief in business cycles, President Bush appears to have decided that the seven-and-a-half-year expansion is, in fact, at risk.
Within hours after his top economic adviser received word on Thursday of a surprisingly weak April labor market, the President phoned the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell, to propose a budget summit meeting at which no subject, not even higher taxes, would be excluded. (The chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, now Michael J. Boskin, receives job data and other figures the day before they are released to the public.) To be sure, one statistical report -albeit probably the most important indicator of monthly economic performance - is not by itself weighty enough to prompt a major shift in policy. In this case, moreover, the lack of real job growth last month resulted perhaps as much from exceptionally warm weather as from the beginnings of an oft-predicted but elusive business downturn. 
But Friday's report came at a particularly inappropriate time, coinciding with ever-escalating estimates of the cost to the Government of rescuing savings and loan depositors, the arrival in town of foreign central bankers and finance ministers for a meeting of the Group of Seven industrial nations and a disconcerting rise in inflation.
 
Widespread Pessimism
In addition, there is this week's giant Treasury financing, uncertainty surrounding the economic restructuring of Eastern Europe, the woes of the real estate and ''junk bond'' markets and, according to at least one poll taker, widespread pessimism among consumers.
There are also domestic political stirrings that may have underscored the worst fears of the Bush White House: that the economy could have a sinking spell, if not in this election year, then as President Bush is seeking re-election in 1992.
Not all of the economic forces, of course, point in the same direction. If, for example, the American consumer goes on strike, this would reduce anxiety over inflation. Then the Federal Reserve would presumably be able to push interest rates down instead of wondering whether it should push them up further.
Tuesday's meeting of the Fed's chief monetary policy body, however, is expected to result in neither tightening nor easing of money. This is because the economy itself is emitting mixed signals.
This, indeed, has been the case throughout much of the recovery that began in late 1982, an expansion already the longest in peacetime and approaching the record set in the 1960's, during the Vietnam War.
The lack of a widespread recession recently has prompted some to wonder whether the traditional business cycle - booms that end in inflation-arresting busts - has become a relic.
Most economists think not, though they suspect that slumps may now be less severe and less frequent. Among the reasons cited are improved control of inventories, increasingly credible monetary policies that reassure business and investors that inflation will not be allowed to get out of control, greater world economic integration, the fruits of techology, tax cuts and greater fiscal restraint, even in the United States.
''We don't see the inevitability of the repetition of past cycles,'' Ernesto Hernandez-Cata, an economist for the International Monetary Fund, said the other day.
Economists and some politicians have also concluded that expansions die not of old age but of bad policy. But it is not quite clear what this might be, particularly in the present circumstances.
Ordinarily, President Bush's implied acceptance of tax increases, whatever multi-syllable word is employed to disguise them, is not the medicine to prescribe if recession seems to loom. The simple antidote would be lower taxes, not higher.
In this case, President Bush and his advisers may well be calculating that a tax increase, combined with accompanying spending cuts that the Administration could presumably exact, would keep interest rates at levels that would sustain economic growth and not choke it off. Rates assume increasing importance as Government borrowing swells for the savings and loan rescue. The Treasury is already in the embarrassing position of having to borrow each year all the money needed to pay interest on its huge $3 trillion cumulative debt.
 
Recession Would Be Costly
A recession, the Administration must also figure, cannot be tolerated for this would reduce revenues - they are already falling somewhat short - while raising outlays. There would simply be less economic activity to tax and spending would rise automatically to pay for such cushions as unemployment insurance.
Yet it may well be that the Administration is simply playing it safe, that the economy is not really at risk and that the decline in private-sector jobs and the rise in the unemployment rate last month will prove an aberration.
That is still the bet of most independent economists who point to various other recent figures - on gross national product, factory orders, the Government's forecasting index and others - to argue that the expansion will continue.

HEADLINE: EDUCATION;
At Wesleyan, a Day to Reflect on Racial Tension

BYLINE: By KIRK JOHNSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MIDDLETOWN, Conn., May 8

 BODY:
Hundreds of Wesleyan University students gathered this afternoon on the broad campus green to sit and tell stories of hate and fear.
Organized by students as ''Unity Day,'' this was an attempt at catharsis after a month of rising racial tensions and violence against property, including the firebombing of the president's office a month ago and vandalism last Friday that left a dining room at the Center for Afro-American Studies spray painted with racial slurs and threats.
With the administration's blessing, many classes were canceled today and the day's curriculum became instead what one student called a ''community soul-search.'' Some spoke of their hopes, others of their fears. 
''We don't know who wrote that stuff - we don't know if he's sitting here, or over there, or if he will get into your room at night,'' said Andrea Harris, a black freshman who had organized one group of students into a discussion of violence against women in general and black women in particular. ''It's really hitting home how dangerous it is.''
 
Sense of Identity Destroyed
Faculty members, administrators and students said the increase in racial strife here has done far more than destroy the end-of-term calm at Wesleyan, long considered one of the most aggressive elite private institutions in recruiting minority students and incorporating cultural and ethnic diversity into the curriculum. Many people spoke of the damage to the school's sense of identity as an island of tolerance.
Officials say about 10 percent of Wesleyan's 2,700 students are black; 9 percent are Asian-American, and about 4 percent are Hispanic. The university has also incorporated cultural differences into mainstream courses.
''If you studied modern dance at Wesleyan, that meant modern black dance along with Balanchine and others,'' said Robert G. O'Meally, an English professor who left Wesleyan last year after 11 years for Barnard College in New York City. ''If you studied American literature, it was Richard Wright along with Hemingway. It's a very special place.''
But now there are questions that have fed suspicions and fueled tensions. No one yet knows, for example, why the firebombs were thrown or who threw them. And many students and teachers said that the attention paid to the violence has overshadowed larger concerns about the departure of black professors like Mr. O'Meally, and the long-term direction of the university under its new president, William M. Chace.
 
Paring the Curriculum
Mr. Chace, who took over in late 1988, replaced Colin G. Campbell, who was president for 18 years during a period that some faculty members described as a sort of golden age. Almost immediately, Mr. Chace announced that economic pressures would require a paring of Wesleyan's 997-course curriculum.
About the same time, said the chairwoman of the Afro-American Studies Program, Erness Brody, ''a dramatic exodus'' of black professors began. Over the last two academic years, 6 of the 11 black faculty members who were either tenured or eligible for tenure left.
Mr. Chace, who met with students on Monday for what a school spokesman, Bobby Wayne Clark, called ''four hours of unadulterated rage,'' said today in an interview that the faculty members who left did so for personal reasons or for jobs at larger or more prestigious institutions against which Wesleyan could not compete.
 
No Arrests
Professor Brody, in an open letter also signed by eight other black faculty members, said the university should have done more.
''If the administration had a coherent policy to retain minority faculty, they might have remained,'' said the letter, which was published in a recent issue of the campus newspaper, The Argus.
On April 7, while Mr. Chace's office in the South College building was closed and unoccupied, someone threw a bottle containing a flammable liquid through a window, causing about $60,000 in damage. A few weeks later, another firebomb was thrown against the wall of the rowing team's boathouse.
Although no one was arrested in either crime, students and faculty members said that suspicion quickly focused on a loosely organized group of vocal black students who had spoken most harshly against Mr. Chace, and who had seemed at times to be condoning violent measures.
 
'A Larger Problem'
The spray-paint incident last week, in the basement of the Malcolm X House on the edge of campus, further raised the level of recrimination and emotion by putting the question of the bombings in the crudest racial terms. ''Nigger bombs,'' was written on one wall. The writing on another wall made an obscene reference to black women that was interpreted by many students as an invitation to rape.
Mr. Chace said today that he considered the latest incident a cynical and calculated provocation rather than an actual statement of racism.
''The perpetrator knew the kind of dissent and chaos he would be sowing on campus,'' he said.
For many students today, the message - repeated in many cases almost like a dirge - was that Wesleyan was simply caught in the same rising tide of intolerance that has been witnessed on other campuses across the country. For all the promise of its curriculum, its history of diversity and the green New England ambiance of its campus, the university cannot escape the larger forces of society, they said.
''It's a larger problem,'' said Julie Doar, a senior in Afro-American studies and one of the organizers of Unity Day. ''But you have to do something. I want people to just let people be.''

HEADLINE: In Looks, a Sense of Racial Unity

BYLINE: By LENA WILLIAMS

 BODY:
YOUNG Americans seem to be looking more alike these days. And that's not all. Young people of different ethnic backgrounds are acting and sounding a lot alike, too.
White males are wearing dreadlocks, fade haircuts and African medallions; black men and women are going blond and sporting Metallica T-shirts. There are black Valley girls and white home girls.
Large lips are the latest Hollywood look, so some white women are fattening theirs up with silicon injections. Meanwhile some black women are painstakingly making up their lips to achieve a thinner, more typically Caucasian lip line. 
Michael Bolton, a white pop musician with a soul-inflected, blues-based vocal style, has beaten out black challengers for New York Music Awards' prestigious soul music title. And the hip street vernacular of black youths has become so mainstream that even Madison Avenue executives are using it in television commercials.
''I call it the darkening of white America,'' said Dr. Charles W. Thomas, a professor of urban studies and planning at the University of California at San Diego who is writing a book on the black-white crossover phenomenon. ''What we are seeing is white people being totally engulfed in black life style and behavioral patterns. It started with the music. Now you see it in fashion, religion and expression.''
At the same time, Dr. Thomas and other experts in black culture noted that more blacks are adopting white styles and social patterns than at any time since the early 1960's. They say many blacks may not realize that in imitating whites, who in many ways are imitating black culture, they in essence are reclaiming their own culture.
Dr. Thomas said, ''We are seeing the black middle class doing what E. Franklin Frazier, the black sociologist, accused them of doing in the 1950's: 'poor imitations of whites' without understanding that they are reclaiming what is already theirs.''
Alana Valencia, a 15-year-old black high school student who lives in Washington, is critical of the trend. ''We call them the 'Wannabees,' '' she said. ''The black kids who 'wanna be' white and the white kids who 'wanna be' black.''
The trend, which started in the mid-1980's, is predominant among young people, which has led to speculation that it is a fad. Some, however, believe the phenomenon is an expansion of a cultural exchange that dates to the Harlem Renaissance of the 1920's and 30's, when whites flocked to Harlem nightclubs and dance halls, regarding black life as exotic.
But the degree to which blacks and whites have immersed themselves into each others' culture and life styles, at a time when many cities seem to be more racially divided and reports of race-based hate crimes are on the rise, has even some of the experts scratching their heads.
''I've been puzzled by this,'' said Todd Gitlin, a professor of sociology at the University of California at Berkeley. ''It's kind of like, one color fits all. I don't quite get it, although it's not unprecedented. Whites, no matter what their racial feelings, have tried to look darker for some time. This new phenomenon is in that tradition.''
Dr. Alvin Poussaint, associate professor of psychiatry at Harvard University, said black styles have crossed over but that there is more going on than meets the eye. ''The stigma has been removed from features that were Negroid and thus considered inferior, like thick lips,'' he said. ''We're seeing a freeing up of style, just like there was a freeing up of sexuality in the 1970's.''
The trend is not exclusively American.Around the world, a universal standard of beauty is emerging,projecting a multi-racial mix. Indeed, it's difficult to tell the race or nationality of models on some magazine covers.
''They're like a little bit of this and a little bit of that,'' said Audrey Smaltz, founder of Audrey Smaltz and the Ground Crew, a fashion support services concern in New York City. ''They're these beautiful caramel-colored children who can be accepted by blacks, whites, browns and yellows.''
A growing number of black celebrities are flaunting new looks and attitudes. There's Michael Jackson, who despite denials, appears lighter in complexion and thinner in nose and mouth; the new golden locks of Shari Belfonte, the actress daughter of Harry Belafonte; the occasionally green or blue eyes of Oprah Winfrey, courtesy of contact lenses.
Meanwhile, the managers of the white pop-music group New Kids on the Block acknowledge it is a clone of the black group New Edition.
Vernetta Lynch, a 20-year-old Washington college student who is black, said she once dyed her dark brown hair blond, but ''just to see how it looked, not because I was trying to be white.''
''It is unbelievable,'' she added. ''The white girls are all wearing these imitation gold door-knocker earrings, have these short, sassy haircuts and talking like, 'yo, home girl,' and the black girls are acting like, 'wow, golly gee,' in their little Sperry docksiders. We're all mixed up.''
Although some blacks view the imitation of their life style as a form of flattery, others say it is cultural theft.
''I think some blacks may feel a little vindication that the things that were rejected in the past, whites are trying to adopt,'' said Dr. Poussaint, who is black. ''It is in a sense flattering. What bothers blacks most, though, is that they aren't given attribution for their contributions, and there is a feeling that it will be usurped by whites and blacks won't get any economic gain from their own styles or music.''
Erik Simon, a 28-year-old white Californian who has a mop of two-toned dreadlocks that are mostly peroxide-yellow, said of his looks: ''Some people are offended; usually older black women don't like it. But others think it's neat.
''I've never had anyone say, 'Why can't you just be white?' but you can tell just in the way they say things or look at you that they disapprove.''
Mr. Simon said he started growing his locks about a year ago by not washing his hair for six months and vigorously rubbing his head every morning to snarl the strands. He said he decided to wear his hair in the Rastafarian style to shock people, more than anything else.
''It's not like we're stealing it from them,'' said Mr. Simon, who works in a Long Beach pet store. ''It's the new punk. In the other direction, you can see black guys shaving their heads, which is a ripoff of the English punk-rock style, too. There always is that sort of trading between radical blacks and whites.''
Jonathan Roberson, 32, a black New York hair stylist who recently dyed his hair blond, has noticed that a growing number of his black clientele are lightening their hair.
''I think blacks have come to a point where they are making more of a crossover than whites,'' Mr. Roberson said, adding that whites have always mimicked black hairstyles, like the Afro in the 1960's. ''We used to be hung up on four walls of staying in this black identity. If you didn't, you didn't get the support of your brother. Now we're becoming more individual.''
A survey being conducted on how 12- to 15-year-old black girls in Oakland define beauty has found that many have contradictory images of themselves.
''So far, I've found that many of these girls have strong identities as young black ladies, and yet they held on to these choices that seem to have more of a white standard of beauty,'' said Maxine Snow, a graduate student in sociology at University of California at Berkeley who is doing the research for her doctoral thesis. ''For instance, they seem to borrow white standards of beauty in terms of long hair or blond hair and light skin. Yet, in terms of adopting styles, most of them say they didn't want to act or look white.''
Ms. Snow said that the girls come from different socio-economic groups, but that many lived in homes where positive black identity was stressed.
The practice of adopting ''white'' standards of beauty was highlighted by an essay, ''The Bluest Eye,'' in the January 1988 issue of Essence magazine. The author, Elsie B. Washington, a senior editor at the magazine, denounced the growing tendency of black celebritites, trendsetters and ''just plain folks'' to ''alter their natural-born God-given dark eyes,'' by wearing tinted contact lenses.
''Green and blue contact lenses are a groping to identify with all that has been presented - erroneously and slanderously, I contend - as better than us,'' Ms. Washington wrote. ''In my mind, I'm connecting this blue-eyes-green-eyes trend with the current anti-black mood around the country. I'm connecting it with another trend that glorifies and promotes mixed-race (read light-skinned) models and screen heroines, even in films that decry the maltreatment of blacks by whites.''
But there is another view: that perhaps some of the preconceived notions, stereotypes and perceptions that blacks and whites have of each other are gradually changing.
''Everybody puts a little into their own special blend,'' said Orlando Taylor, a 15-year-old black sophomore at Aviation High School in Long Island City, Queens. ''No one takes offense if there is a particular style that is black or white. Whether someone who isn't black or white is wearing it doesn't really matter.''

LENGTH: 1171 words

HEADLINE: WINE TALK

BYLINE: By Frank J. Prial

 BODY:
GLOOM and doom. If anyone on the wine industry's mailing lists were asked to sum up the current mood among professionals, it would be hard to come up with three more descriptive words.
Consider: in spite of all the hype and hard sell of recent years, wine consumption per person is less now than it was in 1980. Table wine, the one segment of the market everyone thought was poised for explosive growth 10 years ago, declined 8 percent during the 1980's. Without wine coolers, which the industry persists in counting as genuine wine, all wine would have rounded out the decade down 10 percent.
Ten percent may not sound disastrous, but in 1980 the experts were all convinced that wine shipments would double over 10 years, with the biggest growth in generic table wines, or jug wines, the stuff we know as California burgundy and chablis. 
What's happening instead? Big wineries in California's Central Valley, the giant wine factories that specialize in jug wines, are shutting down. The gallon - or more recently, four-liter - jug could soon be a relic.
According to Impact, a trade publication, 86 million cases of generic wine were shipped in 1985; last year the figure was 73 million, the lowest in the decade. The jug wine market declined almost 20 percent in the 1980's. In a decade that saw significant price increases for most wines, jug prices increased very little because of fierce competition.
In fact, the only jug wine among the top 10 from California to post any serious gains recently is one few consumers have ever heard of: William Wycliff. The wine is made by the E.&J. Gallo Winery and is sold mostly to restaurants as a bar wine.
Gallo, by the way, still holds a commanding lead in the generic category, with a 41 percent share. Its Carlo Rossi brand is the nation's leader, while the regular Gallo label, which appears on Hearty Burgundy and other wines, is second. Carlo Rossi was down 5.7 percent last year and the Gallo-label generics were down 7.4 percent, Impact said.
Sparkling wines were up 30 percent compared with 1980, but all that growth occurred in the first half of the decade; since 1985 they have been steadily declining. Jon Fredrikson, a California industry consultant, cites greater awareness of the laws against drunken driving. Most sparkling wines, he points out, are consumed at celebrations away from home.
The figures for foreign wines are even more ominous. They reached their high point in 1984, when they accounted for 26 percent of the American wine market. Since then, they have fallen off by nearly half, to less than 14 percent of the market.
Is wine finished? Is it destined to go the way of the Studebaker, the straw hat and the long-playing record? Probably not, though the people who stoutly maintain that this is just a cyclical decline are the same ones who painted such rosy pictures for the industry 10 years ago.
But there is a silver lining, and it's called trading up. The already somewhat hackneyed phrase is ''drinking less but drinking better,'' and for the most part, better means varietal. A varietal wine (as opposed to a generic wine) bears the name of the grape from which it's made, like chardonnay, zinfandel or cabernet sauvignon.
In 1985, the California wineries shipped out 20 million cases of varietals; by 1989 that figure had nearly doubled, to 38.5 million cases.
Theoretically, the consumer is becoming more sophisticated and more prudent at the same time. Health concerns and tougher enforcement of drunken driving laws have prompted everyone to cut back, this theory holds, so they can spend more money on the smaller amounts they now buy and drink.
Well, O.K., but it would sound more convincing if it weren't for white zinfandel. In 1989, this bland, faddish drink made up more than a quarter of the entire varietal category, something over 10 million cases. Whether someone who has switched from a good red jug wine to white zinfandel is ''drinking better'' is open to question.
Big grape surpluses in the early 1980's gave many wine newcomers a chance to sample good varietals at exceptionally low prices. For a time, decent varietal wine could be found for $3 a bottle.
That all ended in 1987 and 1988, when the surpluses were depleted and prices began to climb, but a new market had been created. What's more, good California varietal wines can still be found for $5 and less.
The economics of the premium market - wines selling for $3 a bottle or more - are especially interesting. Shipments of premium wines in 1989, about 30 million cases, made up about 28 percent of all California table wine shipments. But the premium wines brought in about $1.1 billion, while the far larger generic, or jug, category came to only $810 million.
The serious decline in imports was mostly a result of the decline in the dollar: in 1987, a dollar bought only half the French francs it did in 1985. Waning interest in Lambrusco, the big-selling Italian wine in the early 1980's, also contributed to the drop-off in imports.
Even so, just as with domestic wine, there were a few bright spots. French wine shipments last year were up 63 percent over 1980, giving them almost 30 percent of the entire imported wine market.
Australian wines, which showed major gains in the United States earlier in the decade, slipped somewhat in the past two years, but wines from South America, particularly Chile, began to have a serious impact. Mr. Fredrikson, the California wine consultant, predicts continued growth for French and South American wines.
The widespread interest in wine is still a new phenomenon in this country, and as the experts have so amply demonstrated, no one knows which way the market will go.
But while the market continues to change, one thing will remain constant: with 3,000 different wines on the market in this country, it's unlikely that there will ever be a shortage of good, reasonably priced wine.
TASTINGS
 
Rubicon 1982, Niebaum-Coppola Estate, Napa Valley, around $30.
Thirty dollars is not an inconsequential sum to pay for a bottle of red wine, but in this case it is actually something of a bargain. The Coppola of Niebaum-Coppola is Francis Ford Coppola, the film director and producer. Back in the early 1970's, he purchased the historic Niebaum estate in the Napa Valley and set about restoring it to what it was in the days of Gustave Niebaum, the founder of Inglenook Vineyards. Rubicon is Mr. Coppola's proprietary label. The wine is rich, velvety and garnet red. It's mostly cabernet and is meant to compete in the same league as those other ultra-premium wines with Latinate names, Opus One and Dominus. This it does with considerable success and at a lower price than either of those. Mr. Coppola has so far refused to release any Rubicon until seven years after the vintage, which makes the 1982 the year most likely to be found in shops. But not too many shops: total production of Rubicon is only about 3,500 cases a year. The 1982 probably will be at its best from 1992 to 1997.

HEADLINE: Sales Below Estimate at a 2d Auction

BYLINE: By RITA REIF

 BODY:
Willem de Kooning's ''Palisade,'' an abstract parkway landscape from 1957 in bold, colorful strokes, was sold for $7.2 million at Sotheby's in New York last night. The price was the highest paid in an auction at which the selectivity of the market became clear. Although 10 records for the works of artists were rewritten, several major paintings did not sell, and others brought prices at or below their estimates.
At the end of a sale of 87 art works, 55 had sold for a total of $55.9 million - against the house expectations of $86.6 million to $112.9 million. In Monday night's sale at Christie's, 52 of the lots offered were sold for a total of $40.2 million, against an estimate of $50 million to $71.8 million. 
 
'Lesser Things Are Not Selling'
The de Kooning at Sotheby's was one of many works that brought a price lower than Sotheby's expectations, in this case $8 million to $10 million. To the buyer, the Chicago dealer Richard Gray, the development means ''a little sanity has crept in once again,'' he said.
''The market has softened, it is apparent this week, and it was quite apparent in London a month ago,'' Mr. Gray continued. ''This is a continuation, a tightening of the market. The things at the top are selling at the low end of the estimates or below. At the middle, things are also selling at the low end. And the lesser things are not selling.''
Lucy Mitchell-Innes, who heads contemporary art sales at Sotheby's, said last night's price for the de Kooning, although below the estimate, was the second highest ever paid at auction for a work by the artist. Last November, de Kooning's ''Interchange'' was sold at Sotheby's for $20.7 million.
''The auction houses are not policemen,'' she said. ''We do not police the art market we simply reflect it.'' Ms. Mitchell-Innes also said sales of contemporary art have increased 20-fold since 1984.
Richard Weisman, an art collector and investor from Seattle, said ''I thought it was better than last night, but the market was really teetering. The stars of the show are being sold - but just barely on the estimate, whereas the stars until six months ago were going well above estimate. The art market appears to be taking a major correction.'' #2 Bacon Works Sold Among the records for artists at last night's sale was $5.5 million for Cy Twombly's 1971 blackboard painting, about 10 by 16 feet. Mr. Twombly's previous record was $1.7 million, paid for a painting that was sold in November at Sotheby's.
Other major paintings, including two portraits by Francis Bacon, were sold at prices below expectations. ''Study for a Pope,'' from 1957, brought $5.5 million in a sale to a Japanese dealer who was not identified, and ''Portrait of Lucian Freud'' was sold for $3.85 million to an unidentified American collector.
A West Berlin collector and dealer, Reinhard Onnasch, who bought Robert Motherwell's ''Open No. 184 (With Charcoal Lines)'' from 1969, for $165,000, said the problem with this week's sales is that the auction houses put the reserves - the price below which an artowrk will not sell at auction - higher than they would have six months. Mr. Onnasch said that ''the market has dried out during the last two years,'' increasing the competition for artworks - and causing an increase in the prices collectors and auction houses expected they would bring.
The major disappointment last night was de Kooning's ''Woman as Landscape,'' a swirled abstract from 1955. Expected to sell for $9 million to $12 million, it went unsold.
 
The Hype Is Gone
Many dealers insisted that the lower prices paid did not indicate a major downturn. Thomas Ammann, a Zurich dealer said: ''I don't think at all it is a recession. I sold this morning a Rothko. The hype feeling - that everything sells at any price - is gone.''
Andre Emmerich, a New York dealer, who paid a record $1.04 million for Morris Louis's ''Nun,'' a colorful abstract from 1959, was positive in his assessment of the results of both nights. ''It is quite normal what occurred,'' he said. ''If you compare what happens at gallery exhibitions and at art fairs, to sell two-thirds of what is offered is doing well.''
The surprises of the evening were Ad Reinhardt's ''Abstract Painting,'' from 1958, which was sold for $2.53 million to an unidentified Japanese collector, and Richard Diebenkorn's ''Ocean Park No. 40,'' from 1971, which was sold for $1.76 million - a price almost double the presale estimate - by a buyer who was not identifed.

GRAPHIC: photo: a detail from Francis Bacon's ''Portrait of Lucian Freud,'' which was auctioned for $3.85 million. (Sotheby's)

HEADLINE: BUSINESS TECHNOLOGY;
Shrinking the Old-Tire Mountain: Progress Slow

BYLINE: By BARNABY J. FEDER

 BODY:
A variety of companies are making progress toward ways to put to good use the hundreds of millions of tires Americans throw out each year. But environmentalists say the new technology still falls short of conquering on its own a problem that has become one of the nation's most notorious.
Everyone agrees that the most environmentally sound way to deal with a used tire is to retread it. But that only temporarily staves off the day when the tire is too damaged or worn to be safely renovated. Last year, according to Government estimates, American drivers threw out 279 million tires. Those tires joined 2.5 billion to 3 billion others already choking landfills and blighting roadsides, vacant lots and riverbanks, where they attract disease-carrying mosquitoes and pose fire hazards.
The dumping occurs even though improvements have been made in systems that shred tires for re-use or better disposal in landfills, in processes that burn tires as a fuel in place of coal, oil or wood, and in breaking up old tires into raw materials. Those materials can then be used in new rubber and plastic products or as substitutes for concrete in road paving. 
The problem: none of the recycling methods have been attractive enough economically even to keep up with newly disposed tires, much less make a dent in the existing mountain of scrap tires.
''It is simply cheaper to throw them away than to recycle,'' said Representative Esteban E. Torres. Democrat of California, in a bill filed in February to encourage tire recycling.
The Torres bill and a similar measure in the Senate set out to change that economic balance. They would force the tire industry to recycle about a quarter of its products - and to increase that figure by about 5 percent annually - or buy ''permits'' from others who run tire recycling programs. Tire producers would get twice as much credit toward their quota, under the legislation, for tires that are recycled into new products as for tires burned as fuel.
It is easy to see why backers of the bill feel that Government intervention is needed. Tires have been getting more complicated as manufacturers tinker with their design and composition to improve performance. In addition to natural and synthetic rubber, tires may now incorporate a wide range of chemicals, minerals, natural fibers and metals.
No one wants to tell the manufacturers to stop improving tires. But each change seems to have added to the technical challenge of efficiently burning the tires or, better yet, breaking them down into components that can be re-used.
 
Machinery Costly
The machinery required to separate materials and cut the tire down to ''crumb rubber'' or even smaller salt-sized grains for easy reprocessing into new products can easily cost $2 million or more.
When rubber is further reduced to particles the size of those in talcum powder, it can be cooked with various oils in devices known as digesters to make a polymer that can be easily molded into a wide variety of products. That expensive process, known as reclaiming, was used at more than 30 plants as late as the 1960's. But as tires became more complicated, tire companies shut down their reclaiming operations, and only two independents survive. ''It's pretty much a lost art,'' said Michael Rouse, president of Rouse Rubber Industries of Vicksburg, Miss.
But as interest in tire recycling grows, more and more machinery companies are attempting to improve shredding and related equipment. And start-up concerns like Phoenix Technologies Inc., which is based in Jacksonville, Fla., are working on new designs in the hope of sharply reducing operating costs.
Phoenix's approach relies on standard chopping and steel recovery equipment to produce halves of passenger tires that can be flattened under 1,000 pounds of pressure, then fed into a rotating drum with carbide-alloy teeth that mesh with teeth on a base plate.
Phoenix says that on the first pass its shredder can cut 350 tires an hour into 3/8-inch pieces, a size that requires multiple trips through most existing shredders (or one trip through a sequence of shredders). The shredder will be coupled with other equipment, like demagnetizers to remove metal, cyclones to blow fibers like nylon out of the mix, and granulators for further shredding.
 
One More Obstacle
Even when rubber is finally separated from other tire components, a major hurdle remains for those who want to recycle it. In making tires, rubber is strengthened in a heat-intensive process known as vulcanization that links strands of rubber with sulfur bonds. No one has figured out a simple, environmentally acceptable method to break those links. That drastically limits the ability of recycled rubber to bond with new rubber or other materials.
''Trying to use rubber again is like trying to grind up old bread into flour and then baking a new loaf from it,'' said John C. Zimmer Jr., a business and technology analyst at the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company.
While a number of entrepreneurs have proclaimed breakthroughs in processing that allow them to use high proportions of reclaimed rubber in new plastic products, they have stumbled on their way to market. Rubber Research Elastomerics Inc. of Minneapolis persuaded public and private investors to put up nearly $10 million for a recycling plant in northern Minnesota to make the granular ''crumb rubber'' it needed to produce a material it calls Tirecycle, for a number of household and industrial uses. But the plant functioned poorly, piled up heavy losses and was surrendered last autumn to the local county government. Small amounts of Tirecycle are now being produced for Elastomerics at a plant in Wadsworth, Ohio.
Similarly, RW Technology Inc. of Cheshire, Conn., has had trouble getting its Typlax out of the starter's gate. It has demonstrated that the material - which consists of reclaimed rubber that has been chemically altered so that its surface bonds well with plastics - can be used to make products like carpet backing that is two-thirds recycled tires. But RW has yet to show it can reliably produce Typlax in significant quantities.
Recycling experts say such products may well succeed, but only when they attract both manufacturing and marketing expertise. And success is likely to come in a series of niche markets that may not have a major effect on the overall disposal problem.
''People like RW have tried to sell this as a commodity, like rubber itself,'' said Greg Koski, president of Phoenix Resources Ltd. of Leominster, Mass., who developed Typlax under a research contract with RW. ''But it's more like an engineered plastic that requires a sharp strategic marketing plan with plenty of technical help for each customer in fine tuning the formulation and developing methods for processing it into products.''
 
High Energy
Tire companies say that using scrap tires as a ''sweetener'' to improve the quality of fuel used in a boiler makes sense because their energy value per pound is higher than coal's. While expensive scrubbers are needed to cope with the air emissions from burning tires, some users, like cement companies, can use many of the metals and other unburned components in their products.
The most ambitious effort to date to use tires as fuel is at the Oxford Energy Corporation's power-generating station outside Modesto, Calif., which burns up to five million tires annually, producing 100 kilowatts of electricity - enough to power 15,000 homes.
The plant burns whole tires. But it has experienced repeated problems with its system for feeding tires into the boiler and shutdowns to deal with accumulations of slag on the boiler walls that interfered with thorough burning.
It operated at a loss last year despite receiving 8.5 cents a kilowatt-hour from the the Pacific Gas and Electric Company, about five times what it would cost the utility to generate that electricity from steam plants fired by natural gas.
Oxford, based in Santa Rosa, Calif., is confident it can cut costs and improve efficiency with new plants. It is building a larger plant in Sterling, Conn., and plans several others.
 
The Best Hope
Those who believe that burning tires is nearly as environmentally shortsighted as dumping them see rubber-based road pavement as the best hope for creating a mass market for recycled tires. Rubber-based asphalt costs 40 percent more than concrete, but can be laid more thinly and saves money in the long run because it lasts up to three times as long, said the Rubber Asphalt Producers Group, a Phoenix-based trade association.
It estimates that 45,000 tons of rubber - about six million tires' worth -went into roads last year. If 25 percent of the nation's annual paving work used rubber asphalt, 200 million scrap tires annually would be consumed, said Russell Schnormeier, the group's technical director.
Demand is growing steadily, but proponents of rubber asphalt need to reduce the price differential, develop equipment that makes it easier to store and apply their product, and overcome a legacy of quality problems.
They also have to overcome powerful opposition from traditional paving contractors, some of which fear a decline in business if pavement lasts longer, and the wariness of state highway officials about paving roads with proprietary products instead of standard concrete-asphalt.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
New 3-Year U.S. Notes Sell Well

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
Driven by a record bid from small investors, the Treasury sold $10.5 billion in three-year notes yesterday, with the yield rising to 8.74 percent, the highest level in a year.
The rise in interest rates over the last few months had led analysts to project that demand from individual investors would be strong, but the size of the bids exceeded expectations.
At the first leg of the quarterly refunding auction, a total of $37.3 billion worth of bids was received for the securities. The average yield of 8.74 percent compared with an average of 8.43 percent at the previous three-year sale on Feb. 8 and with 9.12 percent at the refunding auction on May 9, 1989. 
Noncompetitive bids, which are a good indicator of demand from individual investors and smaller commercial banks because these investors are willing to buy the securities at the auction's average price, were a record-high $2.5 billion.
The figure was far higher than the $1.75 billion in noncompetitive bids submitted at the auction of three-year notes in February 1989, which had been the record.
Market analysts said they were pleased with yesterday's results, but added that the auction shed little light on the prospects for the new 10-year notes and 30-year bonds that will be auctioned today and tomorrow.
 
'Fairly Discrete' Events
''By all the standard criteria, this was a very good auction,'' said Raymond W. Stone, a managing director at Stone & McCarthy Research Associates, a Princeton, N.J., firm that provides research and commentary on developments in the foreign exchange and credit markets. ''But history has shown that these three auctions have been fairly discrete events.''
Because of their much longer maturity, 10-year and 30-year securities tend to be more speculative investments than three-year notes. As a consequence, they tend to appeal to a different base of potential investors.
Reflecting a worry that has haunted the credit markets in recent years, Mr. McCarthy and others expressed concern that foreign investors, an important source of demand for the 10-year and 30-year issues in the past, may choose to pare back their purchases at the upcoming auctions. Without a good bid from overseas, particularly Japan, yields on the new securities may have to move higher in order to sell the securities.
Traders at Japanese investment houses said that they might place bids on 25 percent to 30 percent of the $20 billion in 10-year and 30-year securities to be sold, a level that would be roughly unchanged from the bids they placed in February.
By late yesterday in the when-issued market, the 10-year notes were offered at a price to yield 8.81 percent, off slightly from 8.82 percent late Monday. And the 30-year bonds were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.80 percent, down from 8.82 percent on Monday.
The new three-year notes were sold as prices firmed in the secondary market for Treasury notes and bonds.
In late trading, the benchmark 8 1/2 percent bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 96 5/8, up 5/32, to yield 8.82 percent, down one basis point, or hundredths of a percentage point, from yesterday.
Among note issues, the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered at 98 27/ 32, up 3/32, to yield 8.77 percent. And the 8 7/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 11/32, up 2/32, to yield 8.68 percent.
Rates on short-term Treasury bills fell slightly. By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.77 percent, down one basis point. Six-month bill rates fell by four basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.78 percent.
 
Pennsylvania Serial Bonds
In the tax-exempt municipal bond market, the Commonwealth of Pennsylvania offered $185 million of serial bonds at competitive bid.
A bid from a group led by Chase Manhattan Securities Inc. won the issue, which consisted of serial bonds with maturities from 1991 to 2010. The bonds were reoffered with coupons ranging from 6.15 percent in 1991 to 7.25 percent in 2010.
Meanwhile, prices of actively traded issues in the secondary market for tax-exempt bonds posted gains of about half a point.
Activity in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds was very sluggish, with most issues unchanged on the day.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of three-year Treasury notes:

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Small Business, Large Mirage

BYLINE: By Peter Passell

 BODY:
THESE are disillusioning times. Evangelists steal, athletes cheat and even old Bossy the cow has been caught wreaking death and destruction. But at least one culture hero remains untarnished: the small business, America's engine of employment and prosperity.
Well, not quite untarnished. ''Employers Large and Small,'' a study to be published next month by Harvard University Press, turns a gimlet eye on the legend and finds it hollow. According to the authors, James Hamilton and James Medoff of Harvard and Charles Brown of Michigan, small businesses make no special contribution to employment, productivity or social mobility. 
What small business does seem especially good at, the authors argue, is winning political friends and influencing Congressional votes. And as a result, they say, small businesses are getting a free ride that is hard to justify.
Back in 1981 an economist named David Birch estimated that small businesses created eight out of ten new jobs. And since then everyone from Republican Presidents (Ronald Reagan) to Democratic Senators (Dale Bumpers of Arkansas) to business lobbyists (Richard Lesher of the United States Chamber of Commerce) have been repeating the statistic like a mantra.
In fact, the authors contend, Mr. Birch erred by counting new jobs in small plants and stores that were actually owned by large businesses - here defined as companies with 500 employees. The actual figure, they believe, is closer to the six out of ten calculated by the Small Business Administration than Mr. Birch's eight out of ten. And even this ''right'' number, they contend, represents the answer to the wrong question.
Small businesses may create the majority of new jobs, the authors concede. But small businesses are also responsible for most of the jobs that are lost because 60 to 80 percent fail within five years of starting up. From 1976 to 1986 the share of jobs in businesses with fewer than 100 employees actually fell to 35 percent from 36 percent.
According to the authors, moreover, the typical job in a small business is nothing to write home about. Wages average about 10 percent less than big business pays, even after adjusting for the lower skill levels demanded by small employers and the greater likelihood that the job is in a low-wage market.
That is not all the bad news. Small businesses offer less on-the-job training, as well as a greater prospect of being laid off in lean times. And benefits are typically inferior: Small businesses are only half as likely to underwrite a pension plan.
There may well be some intangible benefits in being part of a small business - direct contact with the boss, for example, or the prospect of rapid promotion. But apparently there are some special frustrations as well.
Between 1973 and 1977, 30 percent of the employees of small businesses quit, compared with 21 percent of the employees of big ones. And while small businesses are less likely to be unionized, that may have more to do with lackluster recruiting than with employee attitudes: A Harris poll showed that a higher percentage of small-business workers would vote ''yes'' in a certification election.
Myths can sometimes be socially redeeming even if they are not entirely true. One might argue that the excessive respect of Americans for the virtues of small enterprise - and its flip side, their dislike of big business - safeguards competitive markets and economic liberties.
The fallacy here, the authors suggest, is that small businesses have become as adept as big ones in using the political system to achieve narrow economic ends. Unlike giant corporations, the ''little guys'' - car dealers, bankers, funeral directors, insurance brokers - are influential citizens in every Congressional district. And their trade associations have learned to mobilize the troops when hostile legislation or regulation threatens.
Money is no problem: A 1983 survey showed that households with assets of $500,000 or more owned 80 percent of all small businesses. And political action committees representing small businesses contributed one-quarter of all PAC money received by incumbents during the 1984 senatorial campaigns - the same percentage as organized labor. Congress has not been shy in expressing its appreciation, delivering everything from subsidized loans to tax breaks to a kinder, gentler touch on health, safety and consumer regulations.
Any serious effort to limit the influence of small businesses (or big ones) turns on effective curbs on campaign financing. But that is no reason, say the authors, to leave attitudes toward small business entirely in the hands of the image-makers.

HEADLINE: Survey Cites Problems At Black Companies

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS

 BODY:
The nation's largest black-owned companies, hurt by weakness in the economy last year, had virtually flat sales and a sharp decline in employment, according to a survey by Black Enterprise magazine.
The annual survey of black-owned companies indicated that sales for the 100 largest industrial and service companies were down 3.8 percent in 1989, to $4.28 billion, although sales for the nation's 100 largest black-owned automobile dealers were up 8.4 percent, to $2.52 billion. Sales for the combined list of companies were up three-tenths of 1 percent, the survey said.
Earl G. Graves, the magazine's editor and publisher, said that figures reflected the economy's general sluggishness. ''This is the first year we have seen this kind of sluggishness in the list,'' Mr. Graves said. ''Construction is not exactly booming, the publishing industry is down, automobile sales are down, and there are a number of other industries that are having problems,'' he continued. ''Black-owned businesses are part of the mainstream, and they mirror what happens in the economy.'' 
For the economy as a whole last year, corporate profits fell 3.5 percent, to $271.9 billion, from $281.8 billion in 1988, and employment edged up 1.5 percent, to 117.9 million, from 116.1 million in 1988, according to Government figures.
Employment for the nation's top black-owned industrial and service companies plunged 10.4 percent last year, and employment for the 100 largest automobile dealerships was down 1.3 percent, resulting in a total decline of 9 percent, the magazine said.
 
Additional Problems Seen
In the survey, Black Enterprise added that there would be additional problems in the near future for many companies on its list because of declining military spending and what it called a diminishing commitment by Government agencies to affirmative action programs and plans that reserve a portion of contracts for minority companies.
''Black entrepreneurs will have to rethink their strategic focus and restructure their organizations, if they are to keep their competitive edge and reap profits from the ensuing chaos,'' Mr. Graves said. ''In other words, black business is going to have to get leaner, stronger, better.''
Last year, there was a 10.2 percent increase in the combined sales of the companies on the two lists. Because almost all the companies on the Black Enterprise list are private, net income figures are not available. To qualify for the top-100 industrial and service list, a company must be at least 51 percent owned by black entrepreneurs and must have operated for at least a year, Black Enterprise said. It must manufacture or sell a product or provide an industrial or consumer service.
Heading the list for the third consecutive year was TLC Beatrice International Holdings Inc., which includes the international operations of the Beatrice Companies. The holdings were purchased three years ago by the investor Reginald F. Lewis. The company, based in New York, reported sales of $1.51 billion in 1989, accounting for about a third of the sales on the list of industrial and service companies. But the company's sales were down from the 1988 level of $1.85 billion, primarily because of the divestitures of several businesses.
In second place was the Johnson Publishing Company, the magazine, broadcasting and cosmetics company based in Chicago. Johnson Publishing's sales totaled $241.3 million last year, up by 11.5 percent from $216.5 million in 1988. The company, whose magazines include Ebony and Jet, led the ranking three years ago.
In the No. 3 spot again this year was the Philadelphia Coca-Cola Bottling Company, which reported $240 million in sales, up by 14.3 percent from the $210 million reported in the previous year's survey.
There were 21 new companies on the industrial and service list, Black Enterprise said. Those ranged from the 11th-ranked Network Solutions Inc., a systems integration company in Herndon, Va., to the Granite Broadcasting Company of New York, which was no. 18 in the survey.
Other newcomers included 34th-ranked Orchem Inc., a manufacturer of industrial chemicals operated by Oscar Robertson, the former professional basketball player, and Drew Pearson Enterprises Inc., a maker of sportswear that was ranked 74th on the list.
Nineteen of the biggest companies from 1988 - two-thirds of them auto dealerhips - sought bankruptcy court protection from creditors during the year.

HEADLINE: Stocks Extend Gains as Dow Rises 11.94

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stock prices extended their gains yesterday for the seventh day, with the Dow Jones industrial average spurting 11.94 points, to 2,733.56.
Most of the gain came in the final minutes as computerized program traders moved in. Analysts said that investors were waiting for results of the Treasury's $30.5 billion refinancing - and the direction of interest rates - before deciding where to commit cash. Nervousness over the refinancing is expected to continue today and tomorrow as the sales continue. 
Stock volume remained sluggish, rising slightly to 144.23 million shares from 132.76. Advances outnumbered declines, 813 to 650.
Most major groups weakened, but utilities, oil, automotive, retail, insurance and military stocks gained. As widely followed leaders, I.B.M., rose 1/4, to 110 3/4; Digital Equipment 3/8, to 88 7/8, and Compaq Computer 3/4, to 105 1/4.
Hungry for any sign of takeover fever, traders pushed up the price of American General, the Texas insurer, by 1 1/2, to 50 1/2, in heavy trading. Torchmark, the Alabama insurer, which originally made a hostile takeover bid, rose 1/4, to 45 3/4. There were rumors of interest from Chubb, another big insurer, but after Chubb said the notion was ''false,'' its stock rose 3/4, to 88 1/2.
Among the strong moves, UAL rose 3 1/4, to 157 1/4; Williams Companies, the pipeline concern, 2 1/8, to 33 1/4, after Dan Dorfman, the Cable News Network financial commentator, said the stock was attractive. Ethyl, the oil chemicals company, rose 2 1/8, to 27 7/8, after saying it would seek approval for a gasoline additive to reduce smog and improve performance.
Republic New York rose 1 3/4, to 45 1/4, after it said that Edmond J. Safra, who already controls 29 percent, had received Federal Reserve approval to buy 1.5 million more shares, or 4.5 percent.
With the huge Treasury refinancing package weighing heavily on both the stock and bond markets, stock prices moved narrowly throughout the day. Early in the session, stocks first fell a couple of points, then rose a few, then fell a few, constantly turning, almost as if traders were unable to decide whether to buy or to sell.
Birinyi Associates, the Manhattan securities research house, said that a four-minute buy program before 10 A.M. lifted the market 2.47 points but that two subsequent sell programs before noon brought it back down 4 points. An eight-minute buy program just before the end of the day carried the market back up nearly 9 points.
Among the Dow industrials, Minnesota Mining rose a point, to 81, in brisk trading after Allen Jacobson, the chairman, told stockholders that 3M expected a fifth year of higher sales and earnings.
Amgen, the drug company, fell 1 3/8, to 64 1/4, after two industry groups backed Congressional steps to curb misuse of laws giving tax breaks and other incentives to companies that develop therapies for diseases where the profit potential is small.
Sotheby's, the auction house, fell 7/8, to 19 5/8, after Christie's reported lower-than-expected sales on the first day of its art auction in Manhattan.
The S.&P. 500 index rose 1.48, to 342.01; the Amex market-value 0.25, to 347.58, and the Nasdaq composite 0.61, to 431.84.

HEADLINE: Rating Cuts For 2 Banks

 BODY:
Moody's Investors Service reduced the long-term debt ratings yesterday of the Chemical Banking Corporation of New York, the nation's sixth-largest banking company, and Fleet Norstar Financial Group of Providence, R.I., the 16th-largest banking company.
The lowered ratings resulted from Moody's special review of the risks to banks and savings institutions from real estate lending. That review, which is more thorough than Moody's has conducted in the past, has led to rating cuts for more than 40 banking companies and savings institutions this year.
At Chemical, senior debt issued by the holding company was cut to Baa-3 from Baa-2, while long-term deposits of Chemical Bank were cut to Baa-1 from A-3. The holding company's commercial paper and the bank's short-term deposit ratings were unchanged at Prime-3 and Prime-2 respectively.
Moody's said lower ratings were justified by ''the deteriorating Northeastern economy'' and Chemcial's exposure to real estate loans to third world countries and loans to highly indebted companies. The rating agency said it was worried that Chemical's profits would be hurt by the need to increase its reserve for loan losses.
Joseph G. Spohholz, Chemical's chief financial officer, said ''we strongly disagree'' with the rating change. He noted that in the first quarter Chemical reported a decline in the level of problem loans.
At Fleet Norstar, Moody's cut senior debt of the holding company to Baa-1 from A-3 and long-term deposits of Fleet National Bank to A-2 from A-1.

HEADLINE: Home Resale Drop Is 1.6%

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 8

 BODY:
Ex-isting house sales declined 1.6 percent in the first quarter, a real estate trade group said today, as mortgage rates anchored themselves in double digits and prices in many areas continued to rise.
The National Association of Realtors said sales totaled a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 3.81 million units in the period, down from 3.87 million units in the fourth quarter and 3.90 million in the first quarter of 1989. 
At the same time, the survey showed the median price of existing houses rose 5.2 percent, to $95,900, up from $91,200 in the corresponding period of 1989. The median price means half of the homes cost more and half cost less.
Mortgage rates also rose from 9.83 percent as the year began to 10.22 percent as the quarter ended, according to the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Association.
The survey covered sales of existing single-family detached houses, town houses, apartment condominiums and cooperatives.
By region, the West posted a 3 percent sales increase, followed by the South, which was up seven-tenths of a percent.
The Northeast has the largest decline, down 5.5 percent, and sales were down 4.9 percent in the Midwest to 980,000 units.
The West also experienced the sharpest gain in median prices, up 7.6 percent, to $143,700. It was followed by the Midwest, where costs rose 6.9 percent, to $74,200. Prices advanced 2 percent each in the Northeast and South. The median price in the Northeast was $146,200, while it was $85,800 in the South.

HEADLINE: Food Prices Cause Concern

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: CHICAGO, May 8

 BODY:
A survey of consumers has uncovered what may be a growing unease over the health of the American economy, an industry group said today.
The Food Marketing Institute, a trade organization representing the nation's supermarkets and allied businesses, said its annual survey of food shoppers found a growing concern about food prices for the first time in nearly a decade. 
''We are seeing early warnings that price may be starting to increase as a general concern,'' said Timmothy Hammonds, a vice president.
The group's survey of 1,005 shoppers, conducted by the Opinion Research Corporation, found that 96 percent of those questioned cited low prices as a critical factor in where they spend their grocery money.
The figure was up four percentage points from a year ago.
The group said the increase was significant because since 1982 concern about prices had been declining while interest in convenience and saving time had been on the rise.
The survey also found that the average weekly household grocery bill held stable in 1989 at $74. In 1981, the average weekly cost of food buying was estimated at $55 per household.
This year's survey also found that the fat content of food has emerged as the biggest nutrition concern for consumers, outpacing cholesterol and salt.

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
Mead Data Trying to Stay No. 1

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: DAYTON, Ohio, May 8

 BODY:
In the last decade, the Mead Corporation moved swiftly and surely into the top rank of the multibillion-dollar electronic information business. But it is finding that staying there is getting tougher all the time.
Mead Data Central, the $400 million-a-year subsidiary of the giant Mead forest-products company, is constantly facing new competition matched against its Lexis and Nexis information services. There are some 800 computerized services battling for bits and pieces of the electronic publishing market share, up from about 300 just five years ago.
At the same time, profit growth has recently slowed for Mead's core information retrieval service: Lexis, which is used mostly by lawyers and legal scholars to research court decisions, and Nexis, which serves up news articles published in magazines and newspapers. 
To hold on to subscribers and to mine new ones, Mead Data continues to add several new services to that group, which saw revenues jump 30 percent last year. Among the newest is an electronic library of English-language publications covering Europe. Mead hopes the material will be of interest to American companies seeking to do more business overseas.
 
Other Operations Erratic
Mead Data's performance has never been more important to the corporate parent. Earnings have declined or become erratic at some other operations of the 147-year-old company known for lumber, paper, packaging and office supplies.
Mead recently reported that its net income fell 25 percent in the first quarter because of weaker prices for some grades of paper and costs related to new programs.
While Mead Data brought in less than a tenth of the corporation's $4.6 billion in revenues last year, it has been the corporation's fastest-growing source of operating cash. Last year, Mead Data's revenues were $401.3 million, up from $307.8 million the year before and from just $23 million in 1979. Profits reached $36.9 million, up from $34.2 million a year earlier.
Many big and small companies, attracted to an industry where revenues have been moving upward at 18 percent a year, have found profitable niches next to Mead Data by selling computerized information on everything from Chinese patents to nonferrous metal technology.
Big challengers include large media corporations like Knight-Ridder Inc., Reuters Holdings P.L.C. and Dow Jones & Company. Others are smaller companies like the West Publishing Company of St. Paul, which rivals the Lexis legal service.
So far, Mead has managed to stay ahead of most of them by pumping more and more information on more and more subjects into its computer-controlled data base of 75 million documents and by looking for ways to offer them more quickly and at a lower cost.
But the competition is trying to do the same. So for Mead Data to maintain its revenue growth of about 20 percent a year, company officials say it must compete on several fronts. It must lure new customers from professional fields where it has already won a following - lawyers, doctors, journalists and top business and government officials.
And it must get those customers to turn to Mead Data first each time they want information, since many subscribe to more than one information service. ''We compete on a daily basis,'' said Jack Simpson, Mead Data's president.
In recent years, Mead has added topics like over-the-counter drugs, Canadian financial data, and tax liens on file in every state. And Mead officials are pushing the European service as a timely addition in light of sweeping economic changes in Eastern Europe and the plan by the 12 nations of the European Community to drop internal trade barriers by the end of 1992.
 
Growing Access to Publications
The new service, which is part of the Nexis system, gives subscribers access to the texts or abstracts of 44 English-language publications, like the Economist weekly news magazine and The Financial Times.
''Knowledge is power,'' said Mr. Simpson, a 46-year-old former executive at the International Business Machines Corporation who has guided Mead Data Central's rapid growth since his arrival in June 1982. He said that businesses were increasingly looking for knowledge to give them an edge over the competition and that Mead Data's 240,000 subscribers included all 500 corporations on the Fortune list of the nation's largest industrial companies. Mead Data says it has more than a million users, because many companies have dozens of people who use the services.
Encouraged by its success in electronic publishing, the Mead Corporation is developing other nontraditional products, hoping to establish new markets. At the top of the list is a color-copying process the company calls Cycolor. It is designed to lower the cost of making fast and high-quality color photocopies by using specially coated paper rather than expensive machinery. But in the last three years, Mead set aside total losses of $109 million related mostly to Cycolor development costs, including $52 million last year.
Partly because of the continued development costs, Mead's first-quarter earnings fell to $39.5 million, or 62 cents a share, from $52.6 million, or 81 cents, a year earlier. Revenues edged up 1 percent, to $1.14 billion, from $1.13 billion in the 1989 quarter.
Mead hopes to make money eventually by selling the Cycolor paper to corporate offices and small printing companies. But some analysts say it may take several years before color copiers become widespread enough to make Mead's paper a profitable business.
For now, the momentum is with Mead Data Central's Lexis/Nexis. Lexis began in 1973 as the company's first public information service. Using it, a lawyer wanting to review right-to-die cases for all 50 states could pull the information in less than 30 seconds. The cost would be $27 plus 58 cents a minute to peruse it, Mead said.
 
Appeal of Services
Using a computer terminal and printer linked by telephone lines to Nexis, which started in 1979, the general information service, a reporter anywhere in the country seeking articles published this year about Donald J. Trump's marital difficulties could pull up more than 100 articles on the topic. Doing so would cost about $35.
Nexis offers the full text of articles that appear in more than 450 business and general publications, like Business Week, Fortune, The New York Times, The Washington Post and Tass, the Soviet press agency.
The services' appeal quickly becomes clear to anyone who has ever toiled through indexes of periodicals at the local library.
Mead Data, based in the Dayton suburb of Miami Township, prides itself on taking precautions to make sure the operation does not fail.
If there is a power failure, the Mead network can run indefinitely on five diesel generators.
And concrete barriers have been set up to prevent an errant vehicle from flying off a nearby road into the complex and interrupting vital computer links.
The Lexis staff processes court documents from more than 2,000 Federal and state jurisdictions by feeding papers into machines that read the typewritten characters and store them in the computer system.
A group of 70 workers then scans the data, correcting typographical or other errors.
One of Mead Data's strongest competitors is Dialog, a Knight-Ridder subsidiary that has about 400 data bases. Among them are the full text of McGraw-Hill publications like Business Week. Dialog is adding 50 newspapers from Knight-Ridder's Vu-Text unit, including The Chicago Tribune, The Boston Globe and Knight-Ridder's own newspapers, like The Philadelphia Inquirer.

HEADLINE: Real Estate;
Hotels Given Face Lifts In Manhattan

BYLINE: By Richard D. Lyons

 BODY:
MANHATTAN hotels, from the expensive small boutique lodgings to the larger chain properties and the more down-market inns, are in the midst of a restoration and renovation binge that is reshaping at least 25 properties.
Among them, the Drake Swissotel, on Park Avenue, is spending $52 million on renovations; the Essex House and Ritz Carlton, on Central Park South, $60 million and $35 million; the St. Regis Sheraton, on Fifth Avenue, $50 million; the Algonquin, on West 44th Street, $20 million, and the Mark Hotel, on East 77th Street, $30 million.
In addition to renovating all its rooms, the Drake Swissotel will build a new entrance on Park Avenue that is to be incorporated into a separate lobby bar, install five new high-speed elevators, increase space for meeting rooms, and expand its Lafayette restaurant. The renovations are expected to be finished in a year. 
A much larger property, the 1,700-room Waldorf-Astoria on Park Avenue, finished a $110 million renovation three years ago, while the 800-room Plaza on Fifth Avenue is in the midst of a $150 million overhaul. The Sheraton Corporation has declined comment on reports that its Sheraton Centre and Towers and City Squire properties on Seventh Avenue in midtown are in line for a collective $150 million face lift.
Such huge investments might seem odd, coming at a time when the New York area economy has softened and hotel-occupancy rates are falling. But experts in the hospitality industry insist that new investment makes sense in the long run because the city will continue to be an international attraction for tourists and business travelers.
''The present drop in business activity in New York is certainly a temporary thing, and we're looking 10, even 20 years ahead for the return on the funds invested in our renovation,'' said Jacques A. Hamburger, general manager of the 640-room Drake Swissotel, at 440 Park Avenue at 56th Street. ''With all the new hotels coming on line in Manhattan, the older properties have to renovate to moderize their traditional amenities and provide new systems in order to remain competitive,'' he added.
Moreover, according to those in the industry, renovating existing properties is often a better business strategy than starting from scratch because of the higher costs of new buildings.
''For many investors, it is still cheaper to buy and renovate an old hotel than build a brand new one, especially so in Manhattan, where real estate prices are so high,'' said Raymond N. Bickson, general manager of the 185-room Mark Hotel, 25 East 77th Street near Madison Avenue.
Arthur Adler, a hotel specialist with the consulting and accounting firm of Laventhol & Horwath, said much of the renovation investment was coming from foreign sources. The Drake Swissotel, for example, is owned by Switzerland's Swissair, and the Mark by a partnership of the Rafael Group Hoteliers, London, and E. William Judson, New York.
''Many foreign companies have demonstrated their willingness not only to pay for renovations, but even to overpay when they buy properties in Manhattan because, for them, a presence in the New York market is important strategically,'' Mr. Adler said. ''New York is a stable market relative to other hotel markets around the world and the foreign investors are counting not only on day-to-day operations to make money but also on the appreciation of these properties as a safe long-term investment.''
Mr. Bickson of the Mark Hotel agreed that the New York market remained strong. ''The average daily room rates at deluxe boutique hotels in this area are around $250, and the occupancy rates compare very well with those in similar properties in the other gateway cities of London, Paris, Hong Kong and Tokyo,'' he said.
Laventhol & Horwath, which tracks occupancy rates, noted that the latest data indicate that occupancy rates rose in February to 68 percent of capacity, almost 2.5 percentage points higher than in February 1989. Over the last three years, however, there has been an overall decline to a yearly average of about 76 percent in 1989. Still, the outlook is considered bright.
''The Manhattan lodging industry will continue to do well in the 1990's due to an overall room shortage, a healthy international tourism industry, and favorable year-round rates, which in turn can be invested in renovations,'' Mr. Adler predicted.
Stephen W. Brener, a hotel-management expert in Manhattan, pointed out several other reasons behind the upsurge in renovation, noting that hotel investors ''would never invest their money in renovations unless they had to, and they have had to because of increasing competition and Local Law 16.''
Enacted by the Board of Estimate six years ago, Local Law 16 mandates the phased-in installation of sprinkler systems and smoke detectors in most large hotels. These fire-safety systems are complicated to install and extremely expensive, almost forcing major renovation of the rest of the property itself.
''Hotels have a life cycle just like trees and, indeed, people, and many properties in New York simply got tired,'' Mr. Brener said. ''They need periodic rejuvenation to attract business and remain competitive.''

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Finishes Day Mixed After Rising a Bit Abroad

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar closed mixed in United States trading yesterday after strengthening slightly in Europe, but money brokers said the underlying direction of the American currency remained unclear. Gold prices fell.
The currency dealers said some outside influences were affecting the dollar, notably pent-up appetite for the currency in London after a three-day holiday weekend there and a surprisingly good sale of new American debt securities at a quarterly Treasury refunding auction yesterday in Washington. 
The dollar demand helped strengthen the currency, but the Treasury auction discouraged dollar buying because it suggested that United States interest rates would not rise significantly, some of the traders said. That could make the dollar less attractive to foreign investors relative to other primary currencies.
Despite the Treasury auction's immediate effect, Zlatko Glamuzina, the chief dealer at the New York branch of Banco di Sicilia, suggested that the long-term trend for dollars would remain strong.
But Scott Greene, the chief dealer for the New York branch office of Bank Julius Baer & Company of Switzerland, suggested that the currency of choice increasingly looked like the West German mark, reflecting the optimism about the economic dynamism expected from a reunited Germany.
''The vulnerable side is the down side for the dollar,'' Mr. Greene said. ''All we need is a slight push there.'' Others expressed reluctance to trade dollars, preferring to await the final outcome of the Treasury auction tomorrow, as well as any economic insight derived from reports on American retail sales and inflation for April, which are due to be released on Friday.
In Tokyo, the dollar rose to 158.13 Japanese yen, from 157.80 yen on Monday. Later in London, it fell to 157.92 yen. In late New York trading, the dollar fetched 157.63 yen, down from 158.15 yen on Monday.
In London, the British pound fell to $1.6697, from $1.6710 late Monday on European markets. London markets were closed Monday for a national bank holiday. By the time trading closed in New York, the pound brought $1.6705, more than its $1.6685 value late on Monday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those late Monday, included: 1.6575 West German marks, up from 1.6556; 1.4310 Swiss francs, unchanged; 1.1639 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1633; 5.5685 French francs, up from 5.5615, and 1,216.00 Italian lire, up from 1,214.50.
In gold trading, the Republic National Bank in New York quoted bullion at $369.90 an ounce late yesterday, down $1.80 from late Monday.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, bullion for immediate delivery fell $1.90 an ounce, to $370. Earlier in London, it fell $369.75, down from a $371.45 bid on Friday. The London market was closed on Monday.
Silver for immediate delivery fell 2.7 cents an ounce, to $4.989, on the Comex. Earlier in London, the metal fell 4 cents an ounce, to $5.01.
