HEADLINE: Economic-Political Unrest Erupts In Violent Protests in South Korea

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SEOUL, South Korea, May 9

 BODY:
In the largest anti-Government demonstrations in nearly three years, thousands of students marched through the streets of Seoul and other major cities to protest the apparent consolidation of power by a new political party controlled by President Roh Tae Woo.
The demonstrations, which broke into violence as the newly created party held its inaugural convention, came as political and economic tensions in South Korea were running high as the result of wildcat strikes, economic reversals, and harsh Government measures.
After taking over downtown Seoul for several hours tonight, the students set fire to the United States Information Service building.
Flames gutted at least one large first-floor room of the four-story building and smoke and water from firefighters caused extensive damage after students tossed firebombs through smashed windows. The protesters also burned the offices of the governing party in at least two provincial cities, and protests were reported in several other cities as well. 
As often happens in South Korea, protests against the Government turned into anti-American actions because of the alliance between the United States and South Korea, and the presence of some 40,000 United States military forces in the country.
 
One Student Is Injured
It was the first time that the U.S.I.S. building, which houses an agency that is widely seen as the propaganda arm of the United States Government, had been set on fire. No one was wounded in the fire. One student was hit on the head by a tear gas canister and was hospitalized, according to an unconfirmed report. Information on the number of arrests was not immediately available.
The attack on the building was part of a nationwide protest by an estimated tens of thousands of students against the formation of a new party headed by President Roh.
The party, the Democratic Liberal Party, was formed in February when two opposition parties joined the ruling camp. Since then, the party has been wracked by infighting.
Today, a senior official of the new party was quoted as saying publicly that because the party now has a two-thirds majority in the National Assembly, it was considering amending the Constitution to introduce a parliamentary system of Government.
The change is widely viewed as a mechanism for consolidating the party's power and prolonging its rule beyond the planned presidential election in 1993, when President Roh, a former general involved in the previous military government, had originally pledged he would step down.
Students, who had been losing public support for their radical movement, have taken the offensive and attacked the party's merger as a return to Korea's authoritarian past. A slogan spray-painted on a downtown bank building today read: ''Dissolve the Democratic Liberal Party. Step down, Roh Tae Woo.''
A faltering economy, including a double-digit inflation rate, sagging exports and skyrocketing housing costs, have increased the level of anxiety. The Dong-A Ilbo newspaper carried a public opinion poll today that showed that popular support for the new governing party had fallen to 13.9 percent from a peak of over 60 percent after the party merger was announced.
In recent weeks, the economic troubles have prompted angry protests. In Ulsan, more than 20,000 workers at the Hyundai Heavy Industries shipyard went on strike, demanding higher wages. The businesses hit by strikes this spring range from steelworks in Pohang to the Korean Broadcasting System in Seoul. Prices on the Seoul stock market have plummeted. Distraught investors have stormed stock brokerage houses, wielding bricks and placards. Other demonstrators have protested soaring real estate prices.
''The administration has not been able to gain public confidence in the consistency of its policies,'' President Roh acknowledged in a speech to the nation on Monday. ''The public now is skeptical about even the Government's determination to consolidate stability.''
Mr. Roh accepted some of the blame for ''a pervasive sense of anxiety,'' but insisted that the answer was even tougher Government measures in the political and economic realms.
''We are at a crossroads,'' President Roh said, ''one branch leading to progress onward and the other leading to chaos.''
 
From Campuses to Downtown
After rallies on campuses in the early afternoon, students gathered at spots in downtown Seoul. They tried to converge on the heavily guarded City Hall plaza about 6 P.M., witnesses said. Students battled riot policemen up and down streets, breaking up sidewalk blocks and heaving rocks and firebombs.
The police fired round after round of tear gas, blanketing parts of Seoul for hours. At least two police buses and a command jeep were set on fire.
About 1,500 students overpowered riot policemen guarding the U.S.I.S. building about 8 P.M. They pelted the four-story building with chunks of concrete, smashing about a dozen windows. Students forced flaming gasoline bombs through the steel grates and smashed windows, then started the fire in the agricultural trade office, which promotes American farm products in Korea.
The students then fought back riot policemen and firefighters for about 30 minutes while the fire spread. Firefighters from a United States military base and Korean firefighters eventually reached the blaze and battled it for about an hour.
 
No Estimate of Damage
Windows on the third floor of the colonial style building were smashed and glass littered the sidewalk, while large rocks covered the street. Embassy officials could not immediately provide an estimate of the damage. [In Washington, a spokesman for the State Department, Richard A. Boucher, said two United States guards were slightly injured, The Associated Press said.] The protests were the most violent in the capital since 1987.

HEADLINE: A Phone in Your Pocket? Tryout Set for New Service

BYLINE: By KEITH BRADSHER

 BODY:
The Federal Communications Commission has granted a cellular telephone company experimental licenses for a new type of telephone network that will greatly expand the number of callers who can use cellular service simultaneously.
The new systems are expected to lead to wireless phone systems within offices, allowing employees to carry lightweight pocket-sized cordless handsets about with them, even when they leave the building to go crosstown.
Known in the telephone industry as personal communications networks, the new systems are different from current cellular services in that they use high microwave frequencies, which have a shorter range. Because the signals will not travel very far, the same frequency can be used on different floors of a skyscraper without causing interference.
 
Limit Now Is 832 Channels
Current cellular systems rely on a few large radio towers to transmit signals in a radius of a few blocks to a few miles; within that area only 832 channels are available at any one time. The new systems will rely on many low-powered transmitters, each the size of a file cabinet or smaller, that will transmit signals across a limited area. 
Instead of the 832 channels available on Wall Street under the current system, for example, the new systems could provide hundreds of channels in each building. Thus, many more callers could use the systems at the same time.
The new systems' handsets are smaller and lighter than current cellular telephones because the low-powered signal needs only a small battery. Millicom Inc., the cellular telephone company that received the F.C.C. licenses, is using a new method for encoding calls, enabling it to use fewer electronic components in the handset.
The handset will come with a credit card-sized microprocessor that can be programmed to set up conference calls or to give different rings depending on whether friends, business associates or strangers are calling. The handset's speaker is a slit below the key pad, and the earpiece is a black rectangle above the key pad. The greater capacity of the new system means its construction costs are spread over a larger customer base, making it likely that the new service will be considerably less expensive than current cellular service.
The new systems would be an alternative service to both existing cellular systems and also to local telephone service that relies on wires and fiber-optic cables. As such, they pose a threat to cellular companies and local telephone companies, which are responding by increasing the capacity of their systems and asserting that they are the most qualified parties to operate the new systems.
The F.C.C. decision, reached Tuesday and announced yesterday, awarded the two-year licenses to Millicom for systems in Houston and Orlando, Fla. The New York-based company said it would spend $20 million to build a 25,000-subscriber system in Houston and a 20,000-subscriber system in Orlando. Both systems are scheduled to go into service within two years, the company said.
In December, the British Government selected three consortiums to build nationwide cellular systems using the new technlology. The consortiums have announced plans to spend $1.7 billion each to build their systems and plan to begin service in London in 1992.
Cable and Wireless P.L.C., the leader of one consortium, predicts that the charge for using its system might exceed local wired telephone rates by only 10 percent. That would be far less expensive than cellular calls made using current technology.
The eventual price of personal communications network service in the United States cannot be forecast yet, said G. Todd Hardy, Millicom's general counsel.
Millicom and several other American telephone and electronics companies are members of the consortiums building the British system.
 
Differences With Britain
The introduction of the new systems in the United States lags the beginning of such service in Britain because the United States has a less dense population, which requires the construction of more radio transmitters, and because most of the needed high-energy microwave frequencies are already in use, said Janice Obuchowski, the Assistant Secretary of Commerce for Communications and Information.
''In some sense, our success in radio-based services is now coming back to bite us,'' she said.
Millicom's plan to build the systems in Houston and Orlando is technically feasible, the American Telephone and Telegraph Company told the F.C.C. in a recent filing.
The technology involved will someday threaten the existing monopolies of local telephone companies, said Richard B. Snyder, A.T.&T.'s cellular business development director. ''I fundamentally believe that P.C.N.'s are going to be the first serious means of competition for local communications,'' he said, referring to personal communications networks.
 
Challenge to Bell Companies
The seven regional Bell operating companies, which were created by the 1984 breakup of A.T.&T., currently provide 80 percent of the local telephone service in the United States. They say the new cellular systems will supplement their networks but not replace them.
Millicom says it will beam calls directly from one of its transmitters to the next. The Bell companies say it would make more sense to connect the transmitters through the local telephone network.
Consumers will ''use the wireless phones in addition to the wired network,'' said Eric F. Ensor, the director of worldwide wireless strategy for the BellSouth Corporation, the nation's second-largest local telephone company, after the Bell Atlantic Corporation.
Mr. Ensor said BellSouth was researching the new technology and might begin field tests soon. If the Millicom experiment succeeds and regional or municipal licenses are issued for personal communications networks, BellSouth will apply for them, he said.
 
The Big Technical Problem
The new systems face an especially tough challenge from what has always been the biggest problem with cellular telephone service: avoiding the interruption of a conversation when the user of a handset goes beyond the range of one transmitter and into the range of another.
Cellular telephones automatically hunt for an available channel as they come within range of the next transmitter, but some experts say that new channels cannot be found quickly enough if the handset is in a fast-moving car. The new systems must hunt faster and more often because they use many more transmitters.
J. Shelby Bryan, the chairman and chief executive of Millicom, said urban auto traffic sometimes moved fast enough to create such a problem for users of his company's system, but not very often, particularly in congested cities like New York.
Transmitters that use the system in rural areas can use higher power and accommodate vehicles moving at up to 80 miles an hour, a spokesman for the Cable and Wireless consortium said.
Millicom and any other company that wants to start a high-frequency cellular system in the United States must deal with the clutter of microwave signals. Many large corporations already use microwaves to carry their voice and data communications, bypassing the local telephone networks. The F.C.C. chose Houston and Orlando for the Millicom experiment because those cities already have a heavy volume of microwave traffic and the commission wants to determine whether interference will result, said Maureen P. Peratino, a spokeswoman for the commission.
 
Improving Existing Systems
Cellular companies are racing to expand the capacity of their systems by installing more and lower-powered transmitters and by developing digital switches that use computers to squeeze more calls on the same frequencies.
The Nynex Mobile Communications Company is now creating transmitter areas in New York as small as one or two city blocks and may someday have transmitters that serve a single skyscraper, said James J. Gerace, a spokesman for the company. Within the next two years the company also will install digital switches that triple the number of calls handled on current frequencies, he said.
For all the excitement about the new systems, justifying their expense may be difficult because it might be cheaper to upgrade existing cellular systems than to build another system, said Herschel Shosteck, a cellular telecommunications economist in Silver Spring, Md.
The personal communications networks may eventually be offered to residential customers as well as businesses. In Britain, the systems will be offered to both urban and rural residential customers, allowing someone to walk to the park or drive to the store without leaving the telephone behind. Mercury Personal Communications, the consortium led by Cable and Wireless, plans to cover 30 percent of Britain's population with its transmitters by late 1992, 60 percent by 1994 and 97 percent by 1998.

HEADLINE: Israel Is Bolstered and Its Foes Are Weakened by Change Sweeping Europe

BYLINE: By ALAN COWELL, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: JERUSALEM, May 9

 BODY:
In a region where one side's gain is taken gleefully as the other's pain, Israel has emerged as the beneficiary of changing times in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union, while the Arab world confronts the losses.
Most obviously, the growing flood of Soviet Jewish immigrants, whose numbers reached a record high of more than 10,000 last month, has encouraged Israelis to believe that their land will be fortified by the influx of skills and numbers -the prognosis that forms the core of Arab and Palestinian apprehensions.
And since the fall of Communism in Eastern Europe last year, Hungary, Poland and Czechoslovakia have restored the ties that were broken by most Eastern-bloc countries after the 1967 Middle East war. After its acceptance of shared blame for the Holocaust, East Germany is seeking to renew ties with Israel. Last week Bulgaria too revived its relationship, and Yugoslavia is reportedly considering a similar move. 
The shifts end an era of unquestioning Communist support in Eastern Europe for the Arab cause. Israel believes that in practical terms the developments will deprive the Palestine Liberation Organization of training and military supply installations in Eastern Europe, said Dan Neveh, an Israeli Foreign Ministry aide.
 
Israel Preoccupied Internally
''We feel better if many countries that were supporters of our enemies are no longer supporters of our enemies,'' he said.
There are other gains, too: the Soviet Union, for instance, has served notice that it will limit arms supplies to Syria, traditionally held to be the gravest Arab threat to Israel, thereby perhaps reducing the risk of military adventurism.
But it remains unclear whether a perception of a reduced Arab threat implies conciliatory Israeli attitudes or whether Israel itself has any long-range view of how to exploit the changes.
''How can we here sit quietly and say there's less tension between the United States and the U.S.S.R. so everything will be O.K.?'' said Avi Pazner, spokesman for the caretaker Prime Minister, Yitzhak Shamir. ''The moment there is a perception in Arab eyes that it is possible to win a military victory over Israel, you can be sure that you will have a war in the Middle East.''
Prof. Itamar Rabinovich of Tel Aviv University's Dayan research center said ''the country has been so preoccupied with domestic affairs that it does not respond properly'' to the changes.
On the whole, he said in a telephone interview, change in the Communist world has produced a greater readiness in some Arab countries to talk peace, but those shifts have not yet been placed on an Israeli agenda dominated by domestic crisis and the reverberations from the Palestinian revolt in the occupied West Bank and Gaza Strip.
Israel's coalition Government collapsed in March over disagreements about American proposals for an Israeli-Palestinian dialogue to end the uprising, and since then the nation's political energies have been consumed by the effort to build a new administration.
At the same time, the perception of a reduced threat from Damascus ''has been more than compensated for by the rise of a threat from Iraq. Saddam Hussein has restored the warlike option,'' Professor Rabinovich said. Last month President Hussein, boasting of Iraq's chemical weapons capability, threatened to wipe out half of Israel if Israel attacked Iraq.
Iraq won widespread Arab applause as a focus of militancy against Israel largely because of a sense that other approaches in recent years had failed to soften Israeli hostility toward the Palestinians.
To undertake an avowed peace effort and secure a dialogue with the United States, Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the P.L.O., recognized Israel's right to exist and renounced terrorism in late 1988. But he has secured little in return, deepening a sense of Arab frustration and disillusion.
''We should not be surprised to discover that the candle that the Palestinians were forced to see at the end of the tunnel was nothing but an optical illusion,'' said Salama Ahmed Salama, managing editor of the Cairo daily Al Ahram. President Hosni Mubarak of Egypt said last week that he did not believe that Mr. Shamir was interested in peace efforts.
The immigration of Soviet Jews, which could total 100,000 before year's end, has increased Palestinians' suspicion that Washington is deliberately bolstering Israel and undermining the Palestinians by barring the immigrants from the United States.
Many of the thousands of Soviet Jews who have arrived in Israel in recent months are urbanites and professionals, whose first choice would not be to settle in the largely rural West Bank. Most, thus far, have sought new homes around Jerusalem and inside Israel itself. But that has not stilled instinctive apprehensions rooted in a history of mistrust and dispossession.
''It is going to be at the expense of the Palestinians,'' said Radwan Abu Ayyash, head of the Palestinian journalists association. ''How can you imagine that these people will not be settled in the occupied territories?''
Israel's economy is strained, with unemployment running at almost 10 percent and bereft of visible resources for absorbing the Soviet arrivals beyond foreign, mainly American, aid -potentially a lever to pressure Israel into accepting a dialogue with Palestinians. But some officials believe Israel can overcome such pressure.
 
Arabs Try to Close Ranks
Mr. Pazner, Mr. Shamir's spokesman, said: ''I think the U.S. knows very well that no economic pressure is going to work and this is why it wasn't applied and is not going to be applied now. They know how we are going to react.'' Many Arab officials say that as Israel extends its relationship with Eastern Europe and Soviet Jewish immigration increases, the Arab world has been forced to fall back on older reflexes, and a renewed quest for unity to confront what are seen as perilous developments.
''On just about every front, the Arabs are looking at situations they have not had to cope with before and which have consequences far beyond their control,'' said an Arab diplomat in Cairo.
Officials in Egypt, Syria and Jordan have all said in recent weeks that the end of superpower rivalry - and the opportunity it provided for playing off Washington against Moscow and vice versa - leaves the Arabs few options but to try to close ranks.
King Hussein of Jordan has sought to draw closer to President Hussein of Iraq. Syria and Egypt have ended a rift of many years caused by Cairo's 1979 peace treaty with Israel. Syria itself, anxious to shed United States opprobrium as a sponsor of state terrorism, has pressed for, and sought to gain credit for, the freeing of two American hostages from Lebanon. Both men, Robert Polhill and Frank Herbert Reed, were released via Damascus.
But characteristically the effort toward broad Arab unity remains stymied by inter-Arab division, and proposals for an Arab summit meeting to weld a common position remain deadlocked over a long-running and bitter dispute between Syria and Iraq.

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
Thatcher Urges Lithuanian To Compromise With Soviets

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, May 9

 BODY:
Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher today urged moderation and compromise on the visiting Prime Minister of Lithuania, the Baltic republic that proclaimed independence from the Soviet Union two months ago.
Mrs. Thatcher's aides said that she had been encouraged by the hour-and-20-minute meeting she held at 10 Downing Street this morning with the Lithuanian Prime Minister, Kazimiera Prunskiene, and that she would send a message to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev of the Soviet Union reporting on the conversation. The Soviet leader has imposed a partial economic blockade on Lithuania and demanded that it rescind its declaration of independence, made March 11. 
Mrs. Prunskiene said Mrs. Thatcher had ''absolutely, unquestionably'' supported independence for the breakaway republic. ''I expressed the hope that she would not stand on the sidelines but would use her good relations with Mr. Gorbachev,'' she said.
But a British official said Mrs. Thatcher had told Mrs. Prunskiene that while Britain had never recognized the Soviet annexation of Lithuania in 1940 and sympathized with its desire for independence now, she favored a compromise solution that would preserve the gains of East-West relations brought about by Mr. Gorbachev's policies.
 
Oil Stocks Running Low
''The two Prime Ministers left the meeting this morning saying that they saw absolutely eye to eye on these issues,'' William Waldegrave, a minister of state in the Foreign Office, said later in the House of Commons. ''Both agreed that there is no reality of progress without a diplomatic and negotiating process being developed,'' he said.
Mrs. Prunskiene said at a news conference today that Lithuania would run out of some grades of oil by May 25 if the blockade continued, but that there was still plenty of food. Lithuania would not withdraw its declaration of independence, she said, but was ready to suspend some of the measures passed since March.
Mrs. Thatcher's attitude encouraging dialogue and compromise is part of a coordinated NATO approach. President Bush saw Mrs. Prunskiene in Washington last week, and President Francois Mitterrand of France and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany jointly urged Lithuania last month to suspend some of the actions taken since independence.
Mrs. Prunskiene, who also met today with leaders of the opposition Labor and Liberal Democrat parties in the House of Commons, told reporters after her meeting with Mrs. Thatcher that she had been ''very pleased'' with their talk.
 
'Foot-Dragging' by Soviets
British officials said Mrs. Thatcher was concerned that Mr. Gorbachev was coming under increasing pressure from the Soviet military to crack down in Lithuania, and that he had stiffened Soviet positions in arms control talks with the United States and the NATO alliance.
In Brussels last Thursday, NATO's Secretary General, Manfred Worner, noting that the Vienna negotiations on reductions in conventional forces in Europe had slowed down in recent months, said there had been ''foot-dragging'' by the Soviet Union. The British Foreign Secretary, Douglas Hurd, also said in Brussels that there were fears that the Soviet Union was ''moving rapidly toward a state of confusion.''
Mrs. Thatcher has often urged her partners in the European Community to be cautious and avoid making statements about Lithuania or other matters that would jeopardize Mr. Gorbachev's position. ''I don't think the Prime Minister has lost faith that he'll get through,'' one of her aides said today. ''She thinks he's a most resourceful politician, and perhaps thinks he has to be.''

HEADLINE: To Save Fish, Judge Curbs Lowering of Lake

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: BISMARCK, N.D., May 9

 BODY:
In a dispute centering on the longtime drought afflicting the upper Great Plains, a Federal district judge today ordered the Army Corps of Engineers to bow to the wishes of three states and limit releases of water from a major Missouri River reservoir until June 1 in order to protect fishing.
The judge, Patrick Conmy, granted a request by North Dakota, South Dakota and Montana to stop the corps from lowering the reservoir, Lake Oahe, by three feet until the end of the month. The corps filed a notice today that it would appeal, United States Attorney Steve Easton said. 
The states contend that if the annual May release of water from Lake Oahe is allowed this year, it will wipe out the lake's walleye spawn. But the corps argues that the release is necessary to protect navigation downstream.
 
Corps' Actions Anger States
Officials of the three states said the legal dispute reflected growing anger at the corps's management of the entire Missouri River system during a drought now entering its third year in the upper Great Plains.
''The fish spawn are symptomatic of a much bigger problem,'' said former Gov. William Janklow of South Dakota, the lawyer for the three states. ''That's the neglect, the abuse and the disregard that ofttimes comes from people within the bureaucracy that make decisions.''
The lake is in North Dakota and South Dakota. Montana joined in contending that the corps was managing the system in favor of navigation in lower-basin states, to the detriment of recreation and wildlife in upper-basin states.
Charles Findlay, a Justice Department lawyer representing the corps, argued Tuesday that Judge Conmy had no authority to dictate how the agency should manage its system of six Missouri River dams.
But Judge Conmy said today that he was ''unwilling to accept an interpretation that would place any governmental agency beyond the scope of judicial review of actions having a direct economic effect upon thousands of citizens.''
 
Loss of Tourism Feared
The corps has many complex considerations to make in deciding how to handle the system, Mr. Findlay said, arguing that Judge Conmy's order would not be in the public interest.
But the states maintained that if the lake fell dramatically, walleye eggs laid in shallow water would be exposed and destroyed, a development that Mr. Janklow said would cost the states $20 million in lost tourism. ''We don't live in wealthy states,'' he told the judge. ''We have very limited economic opportunities available to us.''
The corps had argued that the three states' request would effectively end shipping in the Missouri's navigation channel, which stretches from Sioux City, Iowa, to St. Louis.
Another argument by the corps was that the states' request could impede the nesting of two federally protected rare birds, the piping plover and the interior least tern. The states dispute that there is any danger to the birds.

HEADLINE: Computers and Other Targets;
How Japan Learns, and Wins, Even by Losing

SERIES: First of two articles

 BODY:
Japan's Fifth Generation Computer project, now in its ninth year, has met so few of its vaunted goals that Japanese officials are now plotting another course toward achieving superiority in advanced computers. Observers who scoff at industrial policy can cite this as another failure of government attempts to pick winning technologies. Yet the opposite lesson is correct. 
For it's by just such methods that Japan has built from scratch a world-class computer industry that may soon overtake America's - methods that Americans would do well to scrutinize.
The Fifth Generation project was designed to develop computers capable of translating languages and understanding speech. It has failed to do that but has succeeded in other ways, like creating a large corps of computer researchers in Japan.
Far from cutting its losses, Tokyo is continuing the project, but it now has embarked on another huge initiative - an industrial effort to master the computing architecture known as parallel processing. The fizzling of the Fifth Generation project, even after an investment of $250 million, is insignificant in the context of Japan's larger strategy.
High on skilled people and low on natural resources, Japan's leaders decided in the 1950's that they wanted a computer industry. Instead of waiting for the market to create one, Japan set out to do so itself.
Tokyo's building blocks were companies supplying electrical equipment to the telephone system, like NEC, Hitachi and Fujitsu. Japan's industrial policy agency, MITI, created a demand for their computers by forbidding imports of similar machines. I.B.M. was allowed to set up a wholly owned subsidiary in Japan but, as Ezra Vogel recounts in his book ''Comeback,'' MITI prevented it from producing computers competitive with Japanese models.
Within these protective walls, MITI was careful to insure that its fledgling computer companies competed fiercely. At the research level, it also subsidized cooperative ventures designed to close the technology gap with I.B.M.
For years these efforts failed. When I.B.M. introduced the 360 series in 1964, it widened its lead. The 370 series in 1970 prompted I.B.M.'s American rivals, General Electric and RCA, to throw in the towel. But MITI kept on going, learning from each failure. In 1980 its cooperative research program on computer chips struck gold by creating commercially valuable technology. This, along with plentiful capital, led Japanese chip makers to dominate the pivotal market in memory chips.
Meanwhile, American computer companies had sold too much of their technology too cheaply to Japan. NEC, Hitachi, Fujitsu and Toshiba had at last closed the gap. When MITI launched its supercomputer project to beat the American leader, Cray, Japanese companies quickly produced machines of comparable power. By 1986 the combined research budgets of Hitachi, Fujitsu and NEC were twice I.B.M.'s.
After MITI's decades of careful tending, the Japanese computer industry has grown into a colossus. It now possesses commanding strengths in memory chips, chip-making equipment, flat-panel displays, laser printer engines and optical disks. By 1992, projections show, its share of the world market will have reached 42 percent, up from 10 percent in 1980. The U.S. computer industry's share, by contrast, will drop from 82 percent in 1980 to 38 percent by 1992.
''Over the past 40 years,'' says the President's Economic Report for 1990, ''the world has learned that excessive government involvement in the economy leads to unsound decisions . . . slows growth and costs jobs.'' That may be Washington's experience. But Japan's skillful bureaucrats have always followed a different philosophy. In the computer industry, they seem to have proved their case.
Tomorrow: The Fifth Generation Project's lessons for America.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

LENGTH: 202 words

HEADLINE: Cerebral Tax Folly

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The proposed state sales tax on ''cerebral service'' industries such as management consulting and public relations (news story, May 1) will have a disproportionate impact on New York City over the rest of the state, because the majority of these service companies are in Manhattan.
The proposed legislation is more than unfair, it is counterproductive. It will drive business out of the state, as clients seek services in venues not subject to a tax. Many New York companies have operations in other states and could purchase services elsewhere. Similarly, many management consulting and public relations companies have offices outside the state where work could be performed.
The growth of ''cerebral service'' industries in the last decade has had a positive ripple effect on the entire New York City economy. The proposed tax will have a negative impact on this growth. We estimate that companies with revenues of $5 billion employing 100,000 people will be affected. In the short term it may cause a reduction in jobs; long term it will impede future job creation.
 
JAMES H. DOWLING
New York, May 2, 1990
 The writer is president of Burson-Marsteller public relations company.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: IN THE NATION;
Alphonse and Gaston

BYLINE: By Tom Wicker

 BODY:
George Bush could use the charming manner and glib tongue of Ronald Reagan, now that the President is trying to get out of the tax corner he painted himself into in 1988.
As Governor of California, Mr. Reagan once pledged that he would not tolerate a tax increase; on that issue, he said, his feet were planted in concrete. When events nevertheless forced him to agree to higher taxes, Mr. Reagan cheerfully called in reporters and told them that the noise they heard was the concrete cracking up around his feet.
Unfortunately for him, Mr. Bush has shown neither the verbal nor the political agility to extricate himself gracefully from his own cheap but effective campaign pledge: no new taxes. Instead, his Budget Director's cries of alarm about the deficit have pushed Mr. Bush and the Congressional Democrats into the old game of Alphonse and Gaston: you go first and I'll follow. 
Mr. Bush has invited the Democrats to negotiate on what's to be done about the deficit, supposedly with all possibilities on the table, and with neither side to attack the other for whatever either might propose. All involved are well aware, however, that this translates into Bushspeak about as follows:
''Gee, fellows, we can talk about anything but maybe the graduated income-tax thing; but, golly, if there's going to be an increase, sorry, hard cheese, but you Democrats have to propose it. Then I'll just have to tell the taxpayers I'm going along only because you big tax-and-spenders left me no choice.''
Witness Senator Alan Simpson, the Republican economic whiz from Wyoming, who said with his usual eloquence: ''No one is going to come out here and say that we're going to do anything at all with income tax.''
And witness Representative Newt Gingrich, the Republican hit man from Georgia: ''I don't think there's any question in this country which party is addicted to tax increases and which party is reluctantly willing to negotiate.''
Not, of course, that Gaston can't play the game as well as Alphonse. ''We have absolutely no interest in asking for taxes and having a reluctant-bride President,'' one wary Democrat confessed. Of course not. Both sides are less concerned about the supposed need for higher taxes than about ducking the blame.
It's not clear, however, that higher taxes are required. To cut the deficit? The economy has been expanding since 1982, despite huge annual budget shortfalls. To sustain the expansion? A tax increase, reducing public spending power, is not the usual pump-priming prescription. To hold down interest rates? The relationship is not proven, and rates have come down from their early-80's peak, despite the continuing deficit.
With both sides ''negotiating,'' however gingerly, a tax increase conceivably lies ahead (a bizarre prospect in an election year for 435 members of the House). If so:
* Why not accomplish something other than holding down the deficit, specifically with new taxes on oil and gasoline? Demand for these is relatively elastic, the potential revenue is enormous, and beneficiaries would include at least the air we breathe, public transport and national security.
* Why not soften the blow against middle- and lower-income Americans, by putting the graduated income tax on the table, casting a cold eye on Mr. Bush's capital gains boondoggle and asking the rich to pay a fair share?
If those objectives seem to contradict each other, they don't necessarily. A gasoline-tax rebate could be arranged for low-income people who have to drive to work; other Americans for years have been subsidized in profligate driving habits by the low Federal gasoline tax; and all would benefit from the environmental consequences of reduced auto usage.
Another promising possibility is the investment of a substantial share of new tax revenues in the nation's needy physical infrastructure -bridges, highways, city streets, water and sewage facilities, uninsulated buildings and the like. That would put lots of people to work (perhaps reducing the costs of crime as well as welfare), stimulate the economy and bring in revenues over and above those from whatever new tax might be passed. The last effect would be delayed but worth waiting for.
Finally, as Alphonse and Gaston urge each other on, it's well for the rest of us to remember who created the deficit bogeyman - Ronald Reagan, that's who, with the tax cut of 1981 followed by the military buildup he never really paid for.

HEADLINE: ON MY MIND;
The Window Washers

BYLINE: By A. M. Rosenthal

 BODY:
At a party in Prague, the new dean of the journalism school at Charles University presents his calling card and leans forward to translate the two words under his name.
''Window washer,'' he says. ''Shop windows. That is how I made my living, eight years.'' 
Dr. Cestimir Suchy smiles as he explains that he used to be foreign editor of Radio Prague, but that after he declined orders to call the Soviet invasion of 1968 an act of brotherly support he was fired. The Communist Government then allowed him to earn his living cleaning windows.
Dr. Suchy seems quite jovial about it - how it was healthy to work outdoors, how he met the best people that way. Foreigners standing around chuckle.
But the next day, toward the end of another gathering, he talks of the cruel years of isolation from the world he loved and was trained for, the theft of those years from his brain and his life, and there is no smiling in his voice.
Everybody loves Prague in these days of its new freedom. But sometimes when I was there recently I felt that foreigners were loving a dream Prague where everybody told witty stories, where a gentle playwright-President soared in the skies of international stardom as a delighted world watched, where a velvet revolution cost so little and gained so much, where you could get a full meal for one American dollar.
It crossed my mind that not enough people were waiting until the party thinned out so the harshness of the past and the problems of the future could emerge and the lines of worry be seen, just as real as the warmth and the wit.
In the United States, Czechoslovakia suffers from its own wonderful publicity - the exhilaration that President Vaclav Havel aroused in Congress, the crowd of celebrities that turned out for him in New York, the stories about golden Prague becoming the absolutely essential trip for everybody in the know.
Czechoslovakia is like a small restaurant that suddenly gets a three-star review. The next day it is swamped with reservations, customers wait hours on line, the staff is edgy and in the kitchen the chef says he just cannot cook any faster.
Exhaustion is on Prague's face. The people in the Havel Government work without rest to create a new government, a new political system, a new constitution, a new economic order out of the chaos of Communism.
Every minister is surrounded by the apparatchiks of the Communist days. The weeding out is deliberately slow.
''We have had enough purges in this country,'' says Jan Urban, the head of Civic Forum, the revolutionary political movement, a plain-speaking man. ''How do you judge who is tainted? Nearly all members of the society cooperated with dictatorships, one way or another.''
In the Presidential castle, Mr. Havel is cooking fast.
Already he has carried out the first job he set for himself - restoring Czechoslovakia and Europe to each other, bringing his country out vividly as an individual nation after 40 lost years in the gray world of Soviet captivity.
But some people around him say he is not going fast enough, particularly on economics. They want him to act on the most important issue facing the country - moving the country toward free enterprise, away from the Communism that wrecked its once-solid bourgeois base.
Move slowly, say others, including his conservative opponents; the peo-ple will not put up with interim unemployment, rising prices, the loss of the hospital-ward economic security of Communism.
So far Mr. Havel has not committed himself. He seems to be waiting for the June elections. A new parliament will be chosen and will name him President again, a new mandate.
But delay will make the economic decisions even harder. How will staggering, obsolete Government plants be sold? Where will the money come from to buy them, money needed for new investments?
Every day it gets more difficult to put off housecleaning in Government ministries and to quiet the public desire to settle scores with the old secret police, who have been told to stay at home, just waiting by the telephone.
All these problems were created by the Soviet-run Communist regime, not by the revolution. That will be important to remember in the days ahead when the exhaustion lines on the city's face get deeper.
Prague is still golden. But it is not simply a show-business hit. It is a real place with real problems that needs real friends, not just those who will clap, hug and leave.

HEADLINE: Cuomo Plan: Protect Jobs, Raise Taxes

BYLINE: By KEVIN SACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 9

 BODY:
New York's state government, which is struggling to close a $4 billion budget gap, employs more workers in relation to its population than any of the other nine largest states. But this year, as in most years, the budget will almost certainly not be balanced by laying off employees.
Thousands of jobs may be eliminated through attrition, and the payroll may be trimmed further with a new early-retirement plan. But the forces of policy and politics insure that relatively few of the state's 264,000 workers will be dismissed. 
Gov. Mario M. Cuomo proposed 396 layoffs in his executive budget last January, and 605 more pink slips were included in March on a list of budget cuts announced by the Governor and legislative leaders. But many of those jobs have been restored during prolonged budget negotiations.
 
Taxes Instead of Cuts
Critics of the budget process said the state's reluctance to pare its work force reflected the desire of the Governor and the Legislature to close the budget gap primarily with tax increases and one-time revenue measures rather than with deep cuts in spending.
''I'm concerned about whether we've seen enough of the solution on the spending side,'' said Cynthia Green, a senior analyst with the Citizens Budget Commission, a watchdog group. ''And reducing the size of the state's work force politically seems one of the most difficult issues for the state to deal with.''
Opponents of layoffs say dismissing workers does more harm than good because it traumatizes them and their families and demoralizes other employees. They add that large numbers of highly paid bureaucrats must be laid off to save significant amounts of money.
 
Payroll Called Bloated
But some fiscal conservatives - like Edwin S. Rubenstein, an economist who recently analyzed the state budget for the Manhattan Institute, a research group - believe the state payroll is bloated. They argue that laying off workers saves money faster than reducing the payroll through attrition.
Mr. Rubenstein pointed to 1988 Census Bureau statistics showing that New York had 158 full-time state employees for every 10,000 residents, compared with 107 in California, 124 in Texas, 114 in Florida and 104 in Pennsylvania.
Elected officials never like to lay off workers, but they find the task particularly difficult in election years. This year the state's well-financed public employee unions exploited election-year fears with a crafty strategy that used both back-door diplomacy and high-publicity politics.
Although the long-overdue state budget is not complete, the campaign to hold down layoffs seems to have worked. Mr. Cuomo warned this week that there might still be some dismissals, but aides believe there will be only a few hundred.
''The layoffs are always infinitesimal compared to the threats,'' said Ross D. Hanna, director of contract administration for the Civil Service Employees Association, which represents more than 100,000 workers. ''We start off with thousands every year, and by the time it's played out it's 20 or 30.''
 
Barking Worse Than Bite
In Mr. Cuomo's eight years as Governor, during which the number of state employees has grown by 12 percent, the state's barking about layoffs has regularly been worse than its bite.
In 1983, Mr. Cuomo's first year, the Governor's budget threatened 8,400 jobs, but only 547 workers were eventually laid off, according to his budget office. Union officials believe many of those workers were eventually hired for other state jobs.
In subsequent years major layoffs took place only when the Federal Government made significant cuts in Labor Department funds or when the state closed mental-health and mental-retardation centers.
This year the state will forgo major layoffs by imposing hefty tax increases and by offering an early-retirement plan that was agreed to last weekend by budget negotiators. Mr. Cuomo expects 2,500 workers to take advantage of the plan, resulting in savings of $40 million to $60 million.
By giving the executive branch discretion over which workers are eligible, Mr. Cuomo hopes to avoid the fiasco of 1983, when a completely voluntary early-retirement plan drew 8,000 takers. Some departments were devastated by the loss, and more than half of the empty positions had to be refilled. The early-retirement incentives cost the state $145 million.
 
Effective Union Campaigns
Many legislators credit lobbying by the Civil Service Employees Association and a $200,000 publicity campaign by the Public Employees Federation with helping to kill most of this year's potential layoffs. Both unions catch the attention of legislators with well-financed political-action committees and with a statewide membership brimming with eager campaign workers.
Officials of the Civil Service Employees Association said they planned to spend about $500,000 on legislative and statewide races this year, and the Public Employees Federation contributed almost $150,000 to incumbent legislators and their campaign committees between January 1989 and March 1990.
The president of the Civil Service group, Joseph E. McDermott, was among those lobbying for early retirement as an alternative to layoffs.
The public employees' group focused on restoring the jobs of 262 outpatient mental-health workers and used the connection between mental illness and homelessness to stimulate public dissent. Among other tactics, the union erected a symbolic shantytown in Albany and distributed leaflets to New York City commuters who have daily contact with the homeless.
 
Personal Touch Exploited
''We tried to make this issue as personal as possible,'' said Ronald S. Kermani, the union's director of public relations. ''It's how it affects you and your family, your community, your train station, your subway stop.''
The Public Employees Federation, led by a former blacksmith and prison teacher, Rand Condell, also placed hard-hitting advertisements in several newspapers. One, which showed a copy of a dismissal letter sent to a mental-health worker, was headlined, ''For All You Do, This Slip's for You.'' Another blamed Richard Surles, the Mental Health Commissioner, for ''creating thousands of personal tragedies across the state.''
The ads infuriated Mr. Surles, who maintained he could compensate for the job losses by changing staffing patterns without reducing services.
''I think the P.R. campaign was anything but accurate, was totally sensational and verged on hysterical,'' he said. ''It also was very effective.''

HEADLINE: G.O.P.'s New Hope to Unseat Bradley

BYLINE: By PETER KERR

DATELINE: TRENTON, May 9

 BODY:
One of the least desired pursuits in the Garden State is running against Senator Bill Bradley, the Democrat who many voters hope will be the first New Jerseyan in the White House since Woodrow Wilson. Enter Christine Todd Whitman.
Ms. Whitman, the Republican expected to win her party's nomination next month to oppose Mr. Bradley, says that enthusiasm for the Senator may be tempered once voters take a close look at Mr. Bradley's 12 years in Congress. She says voters may begin to question why the Senator plans to spend $9 million to oppose a candidate who so far has been able to raise only $100,000. 
Ms. Whitman, a former president of the State Board of Public Utilities and a member of one of New Jersey's most prominent Republican families, has called on Mr. Bradley to agree to a spending limit for the Senate race. Mr. Bradley has endorsed legislation that would set such limits, but he refuses to apply a limit to his own campaign.
 
Promises Issues Campaign
''It's the question of leadership,'' Ms. Whitman said. ''Where has he been on the issues that are crucial to New Jersey? He's in such an ideal position to show you can live within campaign spending constraints.''
To Ms. Whitman, the Senate campaign will offer voters a chance to hear what she expects to be a discussion of issues involving the budget, children, criminal justice, education and the environment.
Both she and Mr. Bradley have promised to avoid the kind of personal attacks that became dominant features of the 1988 Senate race and the 1989 governor's race here.
But Republicans say the real object of Ms. Whitman's campaign - which party workers describe as a long shot at best -is to dim the aura around one of the Democrats' national stars. Mr. Bradley, a former forward for the New York Knicks, won re-election to the Senate in 1984 with 65 percent of the vote. He was an architect of the 1986 Federal tax legislation and is regarded as an expert on third world debt and the Soviet Union.
He has raised $9.5 million for the campaign so far, much of it in California, where Michael Eisner, the chairman and chief executive officer of Walt Disney Productions, has helped tap Hollywood coffers. Mr. Bradley's name is usually among those at the top of the list of future Democratic candidates for President, though he has said that if he is re-elected he will serve another six years in the Senate.
Ms. Whitman was recruited to run shortly after the Republican Party suffered the lopsided loss of the governorship and the State Assembly last fall. Even before then, Gov. Thomas H. Kean had said that Republicans could not beat Mr. Bradley.
But in an interview this week, Ms. Whitman said she believed that weaknesses in Mr. Bradley's record would show he is not the advocate for New Jersey that the state needs.
 
Challenges Senator's Record
In particular, she will raise questions about crime and suggest alternatives to incarceration to relieve overcrowding in the Federal and state prison systems. She said she would also challenge Mr. Bradley's environmental record and question whether he has been addressing ''family issues,'' like health care for aging parents.
She supports a balanced budget amendment to the Constitution, greater Federal involvement in the acquisition of open space and parkland, increased financing for programs to help care for the elderly and legislation giving employees the right to take leaves for family emergencies.
Ms. Whitman has already attracted publicity by calling on Mr. Bradley to limit his spending in the race to $3 million. Including an expected $600,000 contribution from the national party, Ms. Whitman said she expects at most to raise $1.5 million for the campaign.
The 43-year-old candidate says she has a paid campaign staff of six and hopes to wage her effort primarily with campaign volunteers across the state rather than with television.
 
'Just Plain Silly'
''You can't have a President who constantly tests the wind before he takes a stand on an issue,'' she said. ''I don't think he is as good as the aura that has built up around him.''
A spokesman for Mr. Bradley, Bob McHugh, described Ms. Whitman's criticisms of the Senator as ''just plain silly,'' saying he was as active on issues of local concern as he was on national issues and foreign affairs.
Ms. Whitman, a former Somerset County Freeholder, is the daughter of Webster Todd, a former state Republican chairman, and Eleanor Todd, a major fund-raiser for President Bush.
She is a graduate of Wheaton College in Norton, Mass., where she received a bachelor's degree in government. In 1970 Ms. Whitman was an assistant to the director of the Federal Office of Economic Opportunity. She is now a member of the executive committee of the National Council on Crime and Delinquency.
She and her husband, John Whitman, live in Far Hills with their son, daughter, two dogs, two horses and two ferrets.

HEADLINE: Board Proposes Rent Increases At Lower Level

BYLINE: By GEORGE JAMES

 BODY:
New York City's Rent Guidelines Board last night proposed increases of 3 percent and 5 percent on one- and two-year lease renewals for rent-stabilized apartments.
The proposed increases, which are about half the size of those proposed and approved last year, prompted a group of angry landlords to walk out of the board's meeting in Stuyvesant High School on the Lower East Side.
They are the first increases proposed by the nine-member board since Mayor David N. Dinkins appointed six members to the panel. Five members voted for the increases; two, representing landlords, were opposed, and two abstained. The two abstaining were public representatives, Victor Marrero, who was appointed by Mr. Dinkins, and Agustin Rivera, appointed by former Mayor Edward I. Koch. 
Last May, the board proposed increases of 6.5 percent and 9.5 percent for one- and two-year leases and in July approved increases of 5.5 percent and 9 percent.
 
June 25 Vote
Two public hearings will be held on the proposed increases, on June 20 and 21, with the board's final vote scheduled for June 25.
The increases that are finally approved will affect lease renewals on renewals signed from Oct. 1, 1990, to Sept. 30, 1991, which will include about 600,000 of the city's 940,000 rent-stabilized apartments.
The board also proposed a 5 percent increase in the rent for all vacant apartments where tenants change. Last year's proposal was 10 percent. John J. Gilbert, president of the Rent Stabilization Association, which represents 25,000 owners of rental buildings, said: ''I think what the Rent Guidelines Board has done is simply said to property owners, 'Pick up your belongings and leave New York. This is no place to own private property.' ''
But not all tenants were pleased either. Michael McKee, coordinator of the Tenant and Neighborhood Coalition, consisting of about 120 member organizations statewide, said the proposed guidelines were still too high.
The board bases its determination on an annual survey of landlord operating costs. This year, the State Division of Housing and Community Renewal reported that the mean registered rent for stabilized apartments in the city is $523, which was disputed by landlords and was considerably higher than the rent board estimate of $476.

HEADLINE: Democrats Prepared for 'Good Faith' Talks on Budget

BYLINE: By SUSAN F. RASKY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 9

 BODY:
Democratic Congressional leaders told President Bush today that they would accept his invitation to begin ''good faith'' budget negotiations, but hours later fierce skirmishing erupted in Congress over who would take the blame if the bargaining led to tax increases.
Representative Robert H. Michel of Illinois, the House Republican leader, struggled to quell open rebellion in his ranks over the tax issue, urging Republican lawmakers at a closed session earlier today to ''hold their fire'' and to stop criticizing Mr. Bush and the leadership for trying to get negotiations under way.
But his admonitions, as well as those from Democratic leaders to their own rank and file, were not enough to cool tempers on the House floor. Representative Robert G. Torricelli, Democrat of New Jersey, accused Mr. Bush of ''intellectual dishonesty.'' 
In the Senate, despite pleas from Bob Dole of Kansas, the minority leader, that his Republican colleagues refrain from ''positioning themselves to oppose anything that might not suit their fancy,'' 19 conservatives made public a letter to Mr. Bush urging that he maintain his no-new-taxes pledge and push ahead with his proposal to cut the capital gains tax rate.
Democratic leaders, speaking to reporters after an hourlong meeting with Mr. Bush at the White House, where the talks will begin Tuesday, acknowledged they had no assurance that Republicans would not attack them for raising taxes and brushed aside questions about whether they had even sought such a nonaggression pact.
''I think the understanding of everybody present is that we should have a good-faith negotiation here without political posturing,'' said the House Speaker, Thomas S. Foley of Washington.
The scheduling of the budget talks comes amid growing concern that a weaker economy, higher interest rates and ballooning costs for the savings and loan bailout will push the Federal deficit in the 1991 fiscal year to as high as $165 billion. That means Congress and the Administration will have to find from $60 billion to $100 billion in spending cuts or tax increases, or both, to avoid mandatory spending cuts in domestic and military programs to meet the requirements of the budget-balancing law.
At the White House today, Mr. Bush again had no public comments on the budget, but his spokesman, Marlin Fitzwater, offered the Administration's most candid acknowledgement to date of worries about the economy. ''We are saying that there is an economic problem here that's creating a much larger deficit,'' Mr. Fitzwater said. ''We don't shrink away from that.''
 
Darman Outlook on Economy
Richard G. Darman, the White House budget director, tried to put the best face on the Administration's gloomier analysis. ''It's not that the economy itself is weakening,'' he said in a televised interview on the ''MacNeil-Lehrer News Hour.'' ''It's that it's not as strong as it should be.''
Explaining his new forecast of a greatly increased deficit, Mr. Darman said that higher-than-expected interest rates had increased the expected shortfall by $10 billion and that a decline in corporate profits had added $8 billion or $9 billion.
''That's without the rising costs'' of the program to buy assets of failed savings-and-loan institutions, he said.
In the interview, Mr. Darman stuck to the Administration's general refusal to predict the outcome of the budget negotiations, but he said that in principle the White House was opposed to raising the income tax rate.
''Any solution to this problem has to be one which has a chance of increasing economic growth, not decreasing economic growth,'' he said. ''We do not believe that increasing marginal income tax rates is good for economic growth.''
Like some other Republicans, Mr. Darman sought to subtly shift the onus for any proposal onto the Democratic Party, by suggesting the Republicans will not propose taxes but are willing to listen if the Democrats raise the subject.
House Democrats, seeking to pin down the Administration on the economic outlook and the deficit, have asked Mr. Darman to testify next week before the House Budget Committee.
 
Trusting the White House
Today's White House meeting, which included the Senate majority leader, George J. Mitchell of Maine, Mr. Dole, Mr. Foley and Mr. Michel, produced a general agreement to work toward a multiyear budget agreement, but no specific agenda or timetable. The Democrats said President Bush had restated his pledge that there would be no preconditions on the talks.
Asked whether he trusted the White House, Mr. Foley replied: ''I trust the White House until I have reason not to, and I have no reason not to.''
Mr. Michel conceded that even with good-faith bargaining among the negotiatiors he would have difficulty keeping all of his own House troops in line.
''You can't silence members from making their own assessment of what they have to say,'' Mr. Michel said. ''We've got to be prepared to discuss these things.''
Senate Democrats were also eager to enter the fray, taking to the floor to criticize the House Republican whip, Newt Gingrich of Georgia for statements on Tuesday that accused Democrats of being ''addicted'' to tax increases. ''That statement is the equivalent of your 30-second attack commercial. Wham out of nowhere, and then it disappears,'' said Senator Daniel P. Monynihan of New York.

HEADLINE: The Tax-Rise Question;
Bush Rationale for Cutting Deficit Queried, But Economists See Need for Budget Deal

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL, Special to The New York Times

 BODY:
Congress may be prepared to buy the White House's rationale for putting a tax increase on the negotiating table now. But few independent analysts accept the Administration's peculiar argument that rising unemployment makes the case for a quick budget fix more compelling than it was a few months or a few years ago.
Indeed, by conventional economic logic the timing seems perverse: an increase in taxes or a cut in spending would let air out of an economy that may already be sagging.
Still, most analysts believe that the potential long-term gains from a budget accord are well worth the modest risk of pushing the economy into a recession. ''Whatever the reason the mood has shifted in Washington, I wouldn't say no,'' concludes Francis Bator at Harvard's Kennedy School of Management. 
President Bush has always claimed to be ready to negotiate with Congress on spending cuts. But only this week did he dip a toe in the Rubicon, accepting the possibility that taxes could be part of the deficit reduction deal. Changing economic circumstances, the White House suggested, had voided the President's guarantee against new levies.
Lagging Government receipts combined with larger-than-anticipated costs of the savings and loan bailout, the White House contends, have pushed the 1990 deficit up by as much as $40 billion above official Administration estimates, and sent the projected 1991 deficit into the stratosphere.
 
The Last Straw
The resulting need to finance the Government with borrowed cash, the White House argued, was pushing up interest rates for private borrowers, raising business costs and threatening to choke off investment. Fresh evidence of economic weakness, an increase in unemployment, proved the last straw: An immediate dose of deficit reduction was needed to ward off a recession.
Congressional sources scoff at the idea that Richard G. Darman, the President's budget director, has only recently discovered that the 1990 deficit was far larger than the official Administration projection, or that the 1991 deficit could easily exceed the Gramm-Rudman deficit reduction targets by $100 billion. But the likely economic consequence, the notion that fiscal restraint would save the economy from a recession, drew guffaws from economists.
''I nearly blew a gasket when I heard it was time to cut the deficit because the economy was weak,'' said Prof. Robert Solow. A back-of-the-envelope calculation suggests why.
A big cut in Federal spending or an increase in taxes next year - the consensus speculation is in the neighborhood of $40 billion - would initially reduce demand for goods and services by roughly the same amount. And according to Henry Aaron of the Brookings Institution, the ''multiplier effect'' on total income would be 1.5 to 2 times as great, as reduced purchases by those directly affected would lead other individuals and businesses to pull in their horns. That might reduce total demand by nearly 2 percent, wiping out the 2 percent growth in G.N.P. forecast by many private economists.
 
Would Lower Interest Rates
On reason not to be unduly alarmed is that the impact of fiscal restraint would be partly offset by a ''crowding in'' of investment, as the reduced demand by consumers eased the demand for credit, lowering interest rates and making it cheaper for businesses to expand. Indeed, the White House seems to be suggesting that ''crowding in'' would more than offset the impact on consumer spending and actually save the economy from recession.
That is possible - but only barely. The announcement of a budget deal might reduce expectations of future inflation, setting off a sharp drop in long-term interest rates and an immediate investment boom; the direct impact of fiscal restraint might only come later. But Professor Solow is skeptical: ''We have been told that capital spending has held up well in recent years because investors are insensitive to high interest rates. Now we are asked to believe that a reduction in rates would make a big difference.''
A recession need not happen even if fiscal restraint works as conventional wisdom suggests because policy makers would not sit by passively as factories were shuttered. ''The Federal Reserve has made it abundantly clear that it would respond to a swing in the deficit by pushing down interest rates,'' Mr. Aaron said. Along with stimulating business investment, lower rates would tend to reduce the value of the dollar, since foreign investors would no longer be lured to buy dollar-denominated securities bearing high interest rates. A lower dollar, in turn, would help United States exporters, by making American products cheaper in overseas markets.
In any case, most economists seem prepared to take the risk of a downturn because they are so eager to curb the Treasury's voracious appetite for private savings and pare its dependence on foreign capital. ''We passed up seven years of good times to cut the deficit,'' Mr. Solow points out. And he, like many economists, would settle for cutting it at a bad time.

LENGTH: 1379 words

HEADLINE: Politicians Seek Sign from California In Vote on Doubling of Gasoline Tax

BYLINE: By JANE GROSS, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, May 9

 BODY:
Californians will decide next month whether to double the gasoline tax and lift the lid on state spending to finance transportation improvements, a vote being awaited in Washington as a bellwether of national sentiment about tax increases.
California, after all, is the home of the tax revolt that laid the foundations for the supply-side economics of the Reagan Administration. If citizens here approve a tax increase and simultaneously loosen the taxing and spending handcuffs locked in place by a succession of voter initiatives a decade ago, the conventional wisdom is that Californians will once again be blazing a trail for the rest of the nation.
But political experts here, who are tentatively predicting passage of a pair of related ballot measures, say the lessons of the June 5 election should be read more narrowly than that.
If voters in the nation's most populous state approve the tax increase, which would double the gasoline tax of 9 cents a gallon in the next five years to pay for $18.5 billion in highway and rail projects, they will not be condoning new taxes in general, these experts say. Instead, voters would be telling the government that they are willing to pay more for specific projects that affect them directly, like improving a traffic-choked highway or an earthquake-damaged bridge in their neighborhood, the experts say. 
 
Seeing, Tasting and Smelling
''The general rule is that if there's a clearly identified purpose for which the tax is levied, you have a fighting chance of getting it through,'' said Randy Hamilton, a visiting scholar at the Institute of Government Studies at the University of California at Berkeley. ''Voters have to be able to see, taste and smell it.''
The ballot measures, which have a slight edge in recent polls, reflect a gathering awareness here that booming population growth, with its attendant increase in the number of automobiles, is having a profoundly negative effect on California's vaunted quality of life.
''Freeway gridlock dirties our air,'' said Gov. George Deukmejian in a recent radio address urging passage of the measures. ''It diminishes our quality of life. And it hurts our ability to create good paying jobs for your children because business will be forced to move out of our state.''
Along with the old concerns about congestion and pollution, Californians have a new fear: that earthquakes like the one last October can topple dilapidated bridges and highways that have not been maintained or upgraded because of fiscal constraints.
 
'Example of Urgent Public Need'
''That was a striking example of urgent public need,'' said William Schneider, a political scientist at the American Enterprise Institute in Washington, who writes frequently about California. ''That was not just a matter of inconvenience, but a matter of tragedy.''
The ballot measures were cobbled together by a rare bipartisan coalition led by Mr. Deukmejian, a Republican, who like President Bush was elected on pledges of no new taxes but is not seeking re-election. The work began in earnest in June 1988 after the narrow defeat of a measure that would have relaxed spending limits that have caused a quiet dimunition of services here in the last decade and another one that would have authorized $1 billion in bonds for highway improvement.
Assemblyman Richard Katz, a Democrat from Los Angeles, said: ''So little had been done for so long that we were hearing it from all sides. The enormity of the problem finally sank in.''
As the months passed, the measures were revised to meet the concerns of many special interest groups. Eventually, more than 200 organizations spanning the political spectrum endorsed the measures, along with all the gubernatorial candidates and most other elected officials.
''I don't ever recall seeing such unity on the part of what I would call the establishment,'' said Mervin Field, director of the California Poll, the state's leading independent opinion-gathering organization. ''That could set a model for the national Administration.''
 
Opposition From One Group
One small opposition group. Citizens Against Unfair Taxation, surfaced this week in Orange County. It counts among its members Arthur Laffer, a supply-side economist who was a member of the Economic Policy Advisory Board under President Ronald Reagan, who says the measures would hurt California in its competition against states with lower taxes. Also affiliated with the group is People's Advocate, an organization founded by the late Paul Gann, one of the authors of the ballot initiatives in 1978 and 1979 that curbed taxing and spending.
One measure on the June 5 ballot, Proposition 111, would raise the gasoline tax, now lower than that in 46 other states, by five cents a gallon on Aug. 1 and a cent a gallon in each of the next four years. Proponents say the increased gasoline tax would cost the average driver $60 a year and raise $13 billion in the next 10 years, with $2 billion more in the same time coming from increased truck fees. The second measure, Proposition 108, which only goes into effect if the first passes, would authorize a total of $3 billion from $1 billion bond issues in 1990, 1992 and 1994 to pay for mass transit rail projects.
The first measure, in addition to raising gasoline taxes, would also modify spending ceilings set by the so-called Gann limit, a 1979 ballot measure less well-known but more far-reaching than the 1978 measure, Proposition 13, which limited real estate taxes. Under the Gann limit, spending is tied to the state's per capita income or the Federal Consumer Price Index, whichever is lower. Under the proposed formula, spending would grow in lockstep with per capita income, which in this prosperous state tends to rise much faster than the price index.
 
Last Increase in 1983
The gasoline tax in California, where the car is king, was last raised in 1983, from 7 cents a gallon to 9 cents. Before that, there was a penny a gallon increase in 1963 and another in 1953. The average gasoline tax across the nation is 16 cents a gallon, making fuel a bargain here for the more than 20 million licensed drivers.
The $5 million advertising campaign for the ballot measures skirts the issues of increased gasoline taxes or new formulas for state spending, focusing instead on voters' immediate concerns about congestion and earthquake safety. Each region of the state has its own television and radio advertisements, talking about a familiar section of gridlocked of highway or a local mass transit need.
This strategy is based on the success here in recent years of local ballot measures that have raised taxes in cities or counties for specific projects, often involving transportation. According to Mr. Field at the California Poll, 70 percent of local tax measures have passed in the last two years, which he says is a sign that Californians have been growing ever more unsatisfied with the consequences of the Gann Limit.
''People recognize that there have to be more revenues to take care of pressing problems,'' said Bill Bradley, the publisher of New West Notes, a state newsletter about politics and economics. ''The caveat is they want to know exactly what the politicians are going to do with the money because they don't trust them.''
In that lies the problem in translating the California vote into a national mandate. While the increased gasoline tax here would pay for particular highway and transit projects, taxes increased by Washington would go toward the reduction of the Federal deficit. And to most people, said Mr. Schneider of the American Enterprise Institute, that is an abstract concept at best and another way to plow more money into ''big government'' at worst.
Mr. Schneider and others said that President Bush and Congress may interpret a passage of the tax increases here to indicate that it is politically safe to raise Federal taxes, even though that could be a misreading of the California message.
But Mr. Schneider and others said that a no vote would be entirely unambiguous to the policy-makers a continent away. ''If these measures fail, given all they have going for them, it will be heard loud and clear,'' Mr. Schneider said. ''That's the signal that will be most potent.''
