HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Rates Rise In Treasury Auction

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The Treasury sold $10.5 billion worth of new 10-year notes yesterday, but interest rates had to move higher to accomplish the task.
Anxiety about the debt sale, the second leg of the Treasury's quarterly refunding auctions, and a slide in the value of the dollar contributed to the decline in prices and run-up in rates before traders placed bids on the new securities at 1 P.M. yesterday.
The dollar fell sharply yesterday against major currencies, including those of West Germany, Japan and Switzerland, on what traders said was nervousness about the United States economy. [Page D19.] Better Results Than Anticipated Still, credit market participants said the results of the auction were somewhat better than anticipated. 
The new notes were sold at an average yield of 8.88 percent, up sharply from the 8.59 percent average rate at the last 10-year note sale in February. It is the highest rate on a 10-year Treasury note since the 10-year auction of May 10, 1989, when the yield was 9.18 percent.
Analysts were most impressed by the dollar amount of the bids placed at the auction. The amount of noncompetitive bids was the largest for a 10-year security in nearly five years.
More than three times as many bids were placed for the notes as the $10 billion that were sold, equaling the highest ''coverage'' ratio on record for a sale of 10-year notes.
 
Noncompetitive Bids Impressive
Noncompetitive bids were impressive, at $659 million. They are a good measure of demand from individual investors and smaller commercial banks because these investors are willing to buy the securities at the auction's average price. It is the highest total of noncompetitive bids since the 10-year auction in August 1985, when yields were nearly two full percentage points higher.
Demand from individual investors for securities like 10-year notes and 30-year bonds is generally limited because those issues are more speculative investments than short-term notes and bills. Attracted by high yields, the dollar amount of noncompetitive bids at Tuesday's auction of three-year notes was a record $37.3 billion.
Participants were also encouraged by the sale of 10-year notes because demand from Japanese investors for the new notes was not terribly robust.
Traders at the Big Four Japanese firms estimated that they placed a total of $3 billion worth of bids for the notes.
''Bids on the other $7 billion had to come from somewhere,'' a trader at an American securities house said. ''These results signal that domestic interest was greater than we had thought it would be.''
William V. Sullivan Jr., a senior vice president at Dean Witter Reynolds, said that ''the results allayed fears in the market.'' He continued, ''It shows that there is good demand for these securities at current yield levels.''
Despite the better-than-expected results, analysts and traders were mixed in their views of what the 10-year sale suggests about today's sale of $10 billion worth of 30-year bonds in the third leg of the refunding.
''This auction went O.K., but I don't know who is going to buy the bond,'' another trader said.
Some traders said they were reluctant to buy the bonds in advance of tomorrow's producer price report.
''If the number is good, all it does is reconfirm the notion that the Fed is not going to tighten monetary policy,'' the trader said. ''If it's bad, the market could go down a lot.''
 
Gain in Producer Prices Expected
MMS International, an economic information and forecasting firm, asked 45 economists across the country late last week for their estimates of the Producer Price Index for April. The median forecast was for an increase of two-tenths of a percentage point. The index declined two-tenths of a percentage point in March.
''But some of those forecasts were looking for another decline,'' David Cohen, an MMS economist, said. ''If we do get a drop, I expect the bond market would be appreciative.''
Mr. Sullivan and others said that the dollar's performance during overnight trading in Tokyo and Europe would be an important determinant of the success of today's bond sale.
''Continued weakness in the dollar could lead to further upward adjustment in yields before the auction,'' Mr. Sullivan said. Further dollar weakness could discourage skittish foreign investors from buying the bond. As a consequence, interest rates might have to move higher to compensate for a weaker currency. 30-Year Bond at 8.84% Late yesterday the 30-year bonds were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.84 percent, up from 8.80 percent late Tuesday.
While most of the activity was focused on the 10-year auction, prices slid in the secondary market for Treasury notes and bonds.
In late trading, the 8 1/2 percent benchmark bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 96 6/32, down 14/32, to yield 8.86 percent. That compares with a yield of 8.82 percent late Tuesday.
Among notes, the 8 1/2 percent five-year notes were offered at 98 21/32, down 5/32, to yield 8.82 percent. And the 8 7/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 9/32, down 2/32, to yield 8.71 percent.
Rates on short-term Treasury bills dipped slightly.
By late in the day, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.73 percent, down 4 basis points, or hundredths of a point. And six-month bill rates fell by 3 basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.75 percent.
In deference to the big Treasury auction, corporations, states and municipalities moved to the sidelines yesterday and did not offer any new debt issues.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal securities, traders said that prices of most actively traded issues slipped by about a quarter of a point.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, prices of most issues fell by about one-eighth point, traders said.
Following are the results of yesterday's auction of 10-year Treasury notes:

HEADLINE: Technology Official Quits At Pentagon

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF

 BODY:
The director of the Defense Department program that monitors the advanced technologies of America's foremost economic competitors has resigned, saying he has become frustrated by the Bush Administration's refusal to support plans to assist the nation's high-technology industries.
Michael C. Sekora, a 33-year-old physicist who has directed the program, known as Project Socrates, in the Pentagon's Defense Intelligence Agency, said yesterday in an interview that he had submitted his resignation on April 20.
Also on that day, Dr. Craig I. Fields, another leading advocate of assisting high technology, was removed from his position as director of the Defense Advanced Projects Agency.
Mr. Sekora's resignation was independent of Dr. Fields's transfer, but the two men shared professional frustrations. 
Dr. Fields's removal last month has heightened an already-bitter controversy over what the Federal Government's role should be in support of critical high-technology industries. Advocates of a national industrial policy have argued that the Government should step up its efforts to bring the United States back as a major player in the consumer electronics industry and in defending industries like semiconductors and computers that are threatened by foreign competitors.
But Administration officials have argued against any coordinated attempt to spend heavily on particular technologies, saying it is impossible to pick ''winning'' technologies.
Others have suggested that the recent cutbacks are more likely to be related to across-the-board reductions at the Pentagon than to ideological issues. ''A lot of this may have little to do with ideological issues,'' said Gary R. Saxonhouse, professor of economics at the University of Michigan. ''They are cutting everywhere in the Defense Department. They have to make hard choices.''
 
Reasons for Resignation
Mr. Sekora said he resigned because he thought he would be more effective doing similar research working with private corporations outside the Federal Government. He said that his resources had recently been cut at the Pentagon and that Defense Department executives had been stalling on legislation that would have combined his agency with a second group, the Defense Industrial Network, to create a stronger organization to collect information for industrial planning.
''All the initiatives that were started under Reagan are taking hits from the Bush Administration,'' Mr. Sekora said. Project Socrates was created in 1988 and it was intended to build an accurate data base of many of the world's most advanced technologies to help planners assess the status of American high-technology efforts compared with those of foreign competitors.
Mr. Sekora said he had set up a private company, Technology Strategic Planning Inc., and planned to work with corporations to provide assessments of foreign technology.
In setting up Socrates, Mr. Sekora had been successful at gathering experts who could be called on to gauge competitive foreign technologies.
 
'A Network of People'
''What he's put together is a network of people in all of the major labs that we have both corporate and government,'' said Dr. Roy L. Beasley, a Defense Department consultant who is a specialist in military manufacturing technologies. ''They were all willing to work together to determine the status of the United States technology in any area.''
Mr. Sekora said information-gathering operations like Socrates were essential because the United States is no longer the unilateral leader in all advanced technologies.
''Technology is becoming uniformly distributed around the world,'' he said. ''The way Socrates addressed technology was to say that every technology in the world is simulatneously a threat and a resource. The most advanced technology is now found in third-world countries or even small countries in the East bloc.''
The Socrates program in the Defense Intelligence Agency focused on tracking advances in microelectronics, exotic structural materials, superconductors, high-performance computers, high-definition television and a number of classifed technologies, he said.
 
Project's History
Project Socrates was part of a strategy advanced by Robert B. Costello, the former Under Secretary of Defense for acquisition during the Reagan Administration. Mr. Costello, who is now a research fellow at the Hudson Institute in Indianapolis, had established a number of programs to bolster economic competitiveness.
Mr. Costello called the cutbacks unfortunate. ''They're terminating the only data base on industrial policy that the nation has,'' he said. ''I don't see how they can do this. You have to have this kind of information to even know how lay out your research and development money.''
Project Socrates is currently in the midst of a detailed evaluation of technologies that are critical for high-definition television, an advanced version of television that offers far sharper pictures than today's commercial television.

HEADLINE: Labor's Hospital Drive Gets a Lift

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Executives at the nation's hospitals are struggling to overturn new Federal regulations that make it easier for unions to try to organize the three million nonunion workers at community hospitals.
The hospitals say a bigger role for unions would push soaring medical costs even higher at a time when hospitals are under growing pressure from employers and the Government to hold down costs. They fear a reversal of the decline in hospital-union membership that occurred in the 1980's, when the National Labor Relations Board during the Reagan Administration adopted procedures that discouraged union organizing.
But the labor relations board has changed its approach, and it ordered the new rules. It and the American Nurses Association, a professional association of 200,000 registered nurses, are asking a Federal appeals court in Chicago to let the regulations take effect immediately. 
 
Rules Put on Hold
The three-judge court unanimously upheld the regulations last month, but last week it granted a request from the American Hospital Association that the rules be suspended while an appeal is prepared.
Under the rules, registered nurses and seven other types of hospital workers can form bargaining units without receiving case-by-case approval from the labor relations board - a process that could take years. The other employees covered by the rule are physicians, medical technicians including licensed practical nurses, skilled maintenance workers, clerical workers, guards, other professionals and other nonprofessional employees.
Spokesmen for unions that already represent 400,000 of the 3.4 million workers in community hospitals across the country say they plan to organize in hundreds of hospitals under the regulations. While the new rules apply to community hospitals, which are private and can be nonprofit or for-profit, they do not apply to Federal, state and county hospitals and those specializing in psychiatric care or physical rehabilitation.
''Health care is one of our top organizing priorities,'' said David J. Hoffman, a spokesman for the American Federation of State, County and Municipal Employees, which represents 200,000 hospital workers, including 35,000 in community hospitals. His union plans to spend more than $1 million this year on recruiting new members in the health-care industry.
Paul Booth, director of field services with the federation, said any raises that unions could negotiate would only be ''a blip'' compared with the $230.1 billion that Americans spent for hospital care in 1989.
But Michael D. Bromberg, executive director of the Federation of American Health Systems, a Washington-based group that represents for-profit hospitals, said: ''I don't think it's a blip under any circumstances. It will put tremendous pressure on costs, which are already pressured by shortages of nurses and other skilled workers.''
 
Further Appeal Is Planned
Fred Entin, a senior vice president of the American Hospital Association, said, ''The costs will ultimately be passed on, and patients will ultimately suffer.'' His trade group of 5,500 hospitals plans to appeal the matter to the Supreme Court.
Dr. Laura Mercker, an association vice president, said that by dividing workers into eight classes, the rules would make it harder to save on costs by training food, housekeeping and transport workers to do each other's jobs. Judge Richard A. Posner, who wrote the appeals court's opinion, rejected these arguments.
Union spokesmen said patients would benefit from union-enforced increases in the number of hospital employees and insistence on better protection against infections that affect hospital workers.
''They haven't paid enough attention to human resources issues,'' said Gerry Shea, health-care director of the Service Employees International Union, which represents 210,000 hospital workers, including 110,000 in the community hospitals.
 
Variation by States
But the regulations may not make much difference to workers in states where legislatures and state health officials closely control hospital budgets through reimbursement rates, said Eli Ginzberg, a labor economist at Columbia University. He said that in states like New York, New Jersey, Maryland and Massachusetts, the unions often have to persuade state officials to raise reimbursement rates before they can negotiate for wage raises with the hospitals.
With the Government holding down spending for the Medicare and Medicaid programs, private health plans sponsored by employers may end up absorbing any increased fees by hospitals. ''They'll just overcharge corporate America to pay for it,'' said Kenneth S. Abramowitz, a health-care securities analyst at Sanford C. Bernstein & Company.
Hospitals said spending on payrolls and employee benefits rose 9.4 percent last year, to $105.5 billion, accounting for 54 percent of their overall costs. The Government said hourly wages and salaries in community hospitals rose 7.1 percent last year.
''The court decision and the new rules will create a gold rush of unions to organize hospital workers,'' said James Velghe, president of Management Science Associates, a consulting group based in Kansas City, Mo., that helps hospitals defeat union drives.
 
Nurses in Short Supply
Hiring and retaining registered nurses is a major concern. About 1.1 million nurses, about 50,000 of whom belong to unions, work in community hospitals but there are vacancies for 120,000. Mr. Velghe said some Michigan and Ohio hospitals have nurse vacancy rates of 30 percent. ''The hospitals are more vulnerable to a union organizing drive than ever before,'' he added.
In some cities, hospitals are already wooing nurses with pay that starts at $40,000 a year. Top pay can go as high as $70,000 in some New York, Boston and San Francisco hospitals. The median salary for registered nurses in hospitals was $30,695 in 1989.
Rush-Presbyterian-St. Luke's Medical Center in Chicago is offering a $10,000-a-year bonus to nurses who agree to take the night shift.
''Nurses in the San Francisco Bay area are making almost as much as salaried physicians,'' said Jeff Goldsmith, a health-care adviser with Ernst & Young, the accounting and consulting firm.
Other skilled hospital workers are also in short supply and are demanding pay scales to match the gains of the registered nurses, whose hourly wages have risen 43.7 percent, on average, since 1983.
 
A Focus on the South
Although many hospital workers now get higher wages than they could earn for similar work for other employers, their pay tends to be lower in states where unions are not strong. ''It may give the unions a foot in the door in places like the South, where they haven't been able to do much before,'' Mr. Bromberg said.
The hospital unions said that the National Labor Relations Board under President Reagan had imposed lengthy delays on their applications to organize bargaining units, and that hospital managements had told their employees that the delays were evidence that the unions were powerless and not worth joining.
Since 1983 union membership in community hospitals has dropped 11 percent, to 400,000 last year, from 450,000, while total employment in the hospitals rose 9 percent, to 3.6 million, the Federal Bureau of Labor Statistics said.
''Unfortunately, the history of representation cases in the health-care industry has been delay compounded by delay,'' said James S. Stephens, a Reagan appointee to the labor relations board who changed its approach after becoming chairman in January 1988.
Under the new regulations, ''the shortened time frame will make it much more difficult for hospitals to win union elections,'' said Mr. Velghe of Management Science Associates.
The hospital association said that dealing with eight groups of unionized employees would raise administrative costs and that strikes could add enormously to expenses. It said the rules were contrary to Federal law and ''would needlessly disrupt the delivery of health care.''
Lawyers on both sides of the dispute noted that the appellate court ruling was written by Judge Posner, also a Reagan appointee, whose decisions have rarely been reversed.

HEADLINE: Argentina to Get Aid and Begin Debt Talks

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 9

 BODY:
Setting the stage for the next major step in the Bush Administration's push to reduce third world debt, Argentina will get approval of renewed assistance from the International Monetary Fund and begin negotations on debt reduction with its commercial banks by the end of the month, Argentine and I.M.F. officials said here today.
Negotiations on debt reduction are also expected to begin sometime this summer between Brazil and its bankers. This means that Brazil, the third world's largest debtor, with $113 billion in outstanding loans, and Argentina, the third largest, with a total of $62 billion in loans from banks, governments and international financial institutions, will be negotiating at the same time.
The Argentine Government will discuss the resumption of current interest payments on the $40 billion it owes to commercial banks, said Javier Gonzalez Fraga, the vice president of Argentina's central bank and a key member of the Government's economic team. But he said the Government was not likely to make any payment soon on its unpaid interest of more than $6 billion. It suspended interest payments in April 1988. 
''We are in a position to start negotiations with the banks soon and serious negotiations will mean we will have to resume a flow of payments,'' Mr. Gonzalez Fraga said.
But when pressed on the details, he added, ''We will discuss the resumption of a flow of payments; payment of interest, not necessarily arrears.''
''We expect difficult negotiations,'' he said. ''But we also expect from the banks the understanding that Argentina is making all the efforts possible.''
In a speech in Buenos Aires today, Argentina's President, Carlos Saul Menem, said the Government was ready to resume interest payments based on the country's ability to pay. In addition to debt reduction, he said the Government would also like $1.5 billion in new loans from its commercial bankers.
William R. Rhodes, senior executive-international at Citibank, the head of Argentina's bank advisory committee, met with Mr. Gonzalez Fraga on Tuesday and said today he was pleased with the developments. ''I think that the discussions were positive in the sense that they feel that they are that close to an I.M.F. agreement and that they are ready to discuss such important issues as a schedule of interest payments.''
 
Victory for Bush
Agreements with both Brazil and Argentina would be a major victory for the Bush Administration's policy, which placed new emphasis on voluntary debt reduction as a solution to the developing world's $1.3 trillion debt problem. Agreements have already been reached with Mexico, the second-largest third world debtor with $102 billion; Venezuela, Costa Rica, the Philippines, and Morocco.
The approval of renewed aid from the I.M.F. is another of the positive swings in Argentina's up-and-down effort to rebuild its economy and crush hyperinflation. Its current $1.7 billion line of credit from the I.M.F., known as a standby agreement, was first approved last September as Mr. Menem began to put his economic program into effect after his election in July.
But the agreement was suspended after Argentina got just one $240 million installment because the Menem economic program faltered last winter and inflation shot up again at the beginning of the year, reaching rates of 100 percent a month. The approval expected by the end of this month from the I.M.F. will reactivate that standby credit line.
''We need to build up domestic credibility and international credibility and we are fully aware of the low standing Argentina has in both areas due to the permanent incapacity to comply with promises,'' Mr. Gonzalez Fraga said.
 
Rising Fiscal Surplus
He said that the amount of interest that Argentina would be able to pay the commerical banks would depend on the level of the fiscal surplus the Government could build up as its newest economic policy, begun on March 4, takes hold. Figures released by the Government today showed that inflation was cut from around 95.5 percent a month in March to 11.4 percent in April, and that the Government's fiscal surplus was rising.
Mr. Gonzalez Fraga did not say if the Government could resume full interest payments on its $62 billion of debt. But he did indicate that the Government wanted a healthy fiscal surplus, both to fend off another run on the Argentinian austral and to give the Government leverage in its debt negotiation.
''In order to have negotiating power with the banks we need a large position and we are very far from those levels,'' he said.
Both Mr. Gonzalez Fraga and President Menem said that Argentina would ask for substantial debt reduction from the commerical banks. As in the previous agreements with Mexico and Venezuela, such a plan would include reduction in existing pricipal, a cut in current interest rates to a fixed level and some new loans. Argentina is also is interested in buying back some existing debt at a substantial discount.
''The Government's strategy will be to propose wide-reaching negotiations which would imply a substantial reduction of the original debt capital,'' Mr. Menem said in his speech, as reported by the Reuters news service. ''This would be acheived through write-offs, interest reductions and repurchases at market prices,'' Mr. Menem said.

HEADLINE: Behind Thai Boom: The Japanese

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BANGKOK, Thailand

 BODY:
Asia is replete with economic miracle stories, so it is little surprise that Thailand has joined the list as having one of the world's fastest-growing economies. As evidence, the number of cars have tripled, choking traffic, and cement is in short supply as prosperous-looking houses and industrial parks rise almost at once.
But Thailand's remarkable boom has a twist that in many ways signals the future of much of Southeast Asia. The money, the technology, the business strategies and now even the emergency shipments of cement all come from Japan. And with a mixture of elation and misgivings, Thais themselves sometimes talk about their country as Japan's newest ''economic colony,'' a country whose prosperity is partly attributable to its role as a relief valve for Japan's skyrocketing land prices and acute labor shortage.
The torrent of Japanese investment so apparent in Thailand is also cascading into Indonesia, Malaysia and Singapore, where the skills of workers are rising and Japan sees a chance to lock up the booming Southeast Asian market while the United States and Germany are distracted by the rush into Eastern Europe. The question increasingly being asked here, though, is whether it is wise for Southeast Asia to place so much of its economic destiny in Japanese hands. 
''It is not in our interest to be too dependent on the Japanese,'' said Snoh Unakul, chairman of the Thailand Development Research Institute and a former Government official responsible for drawing in foreign investment. ''But we are having a difficult time getting the attention of America and Europe. They are simply not competitive.''
And though there are still conflicts with Japanese investors here, Dr. Snoh notes, corporate Japan is coming in largely on Thailand's terms -a change that has dampened the resentments and tensions that go back to Japan's brutal occupation of Southeast Asia 50 years ago.
''The land and labor problems in Japan have left them with no choice,'' Dr. Snoh said. ''They are forced by circumstances to be more open with technology and shared management responsibility. Now, we feel we are being treated more equally.''
The Thais have also encouraged the transfer of Japanese skills, notably by trying to enforce stringent local-content laws governing the automobile industry.
Japan's influence permeates Thailand in a way it did not even four years ago. The cars and pickup trucks jamming Thailand's city streets and back mountain roads are almost exclusively Toyotas, Nissans, Isuzus and Hondas - all with no emission controls. By 1992, Japanese officials predict, 300,000 Thais, or 15 percent of the country's manufacturing workers, will be employed by Japanese companies. That figure is now a little under 10 percent.
 
Adopting the Japanese Way
Japanese managers experienced in setting up plants in the United States and soothing political squabbles have arrived here, hoping to do in Bangkok what they did in Georgetown, Ky., and Smyrna, Tenn., the American production sites for Toyota and Nissan, respectively.
And like an uncertain student who decides the safest course is to mimic the teacher, Thailand's businesses are already adopting Japanese corporate behavior. At 8:30 one recent morning, employees at a nearby industrial park dominated by Japanese companies performed stretching exercises at their desks, while manufacturing workers outside sang a Japanese company song, translated into Thai. And deals are made by players on new golf courses.
So far, Japan's widening business role in Southeast Asia has had two dramatic effects, business executives and government officials say. The first is a significant erosion of American economic influence in the region, where the United States had been the biggest investor. When talking about money or technology the countries in the region invariably look to Japan.
The trend is clearest in Thailand: Last year Japan provided nearly half of the $8.2 billion foreign investment in Thailand. Taiwan, also stepping up its offshore investments, came in second, though far behind Japan. The United States invested only $1 in Thailand for every $6 that came from Japan.
 
A Shift in Strategy
The second effect, which is more subtle, is a fundamental shift in the way Japan is fitting Southeast Asia into its plans to internationalize its industries and blunt the political backlash from Japan's huge trade surpluses. Japanese companies have long had a significant presence in Southeast Asia, but in the past it was a small market for Japan and a cheap place to make low-cost, low-technology parts. Now the Southeast Asian market itself is exploding, and Japanese companies are carving the region into a loosely coordinated manufacturing bloc.
Under agreements with the major Southeast Asian nations, except Indonesia, companies like Toyota and Mitsubishi Motors plan to make diesel engines and electrical equipment in Thailand, then trade them for transmissions built in the Philippines or steering gears in Malaysia.
The result will be complete cars -most of them for sale in Asia, some for export to the United States and Europe - that never pass through Japan, and so do not add to Japan's trade surpluses.
Mitsubishi Motors is already assembling Japanese-designed cars in Thailand, then shipping them to Canada, where they are sold under an American nameplate - Chrysler. The car is not a Japanese import, but it is hardly entirely Thai, either.
 
'It Is Profitable'
''We are in Southeast Asia because it is profitable, especially now,'' a senior Japanese auto executive said recently. ''But it also solves a lot of political problems, not only in Asia but across the Pacific.''
Still, economists and business executives in Thailand say that in two or three years, Japanese investment may tail off, at least until the country's roads, dilapidated telephone system and work force catch up to the breathless 11 to 13 percent annual growth over the last two years.
''I can't imagine that the Japanese investment can keep increasing this fast,'' said Isao Kubokawa, a former official of Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry who now runs the Japan External Trade Organization's office here. ''There are very few Japanese companies that are not already here.''
The reach of Japan's investment can be seen throughout Thailand. Industrial parks are springing up around Bangkok; one recent morning, scores of Thai employees lined up, Japanese-style, at a new Toshiba plant to salute the company's first shipment of color television tubes, bound for other Southeast Asian nations. A few days later the president of Fujitsu Ltd. dedicated a new factory - owned by Fujitsu itself, a departure from the usual Japanese practice of taking on a local joint venture partner - that will produce computer parts.
The influence can even been seen in the smaller towns to the north, near the borders of Myanmar, formerly Burma, and Laos. One recent weekend in the ancient city of Chiang Rai, Buddhist monks lined up in their saffron robes at a temple, while next door at a Mitsubishi Motors dealership farmers inspected a pickup truck.
 
A Strong Auto Market
For years Japanese companies kept small operations here, even after American companies left at the end of the Vietnam War. In Tokyo, though, Thailand was considered something of a poor backwater, a market that would bloom some day in the distant future.
Now, for the Japanese and the few Americans who stayed, that day has arrived. The International Business Machines Corporation says that Thailand is now its fastest-growing Asian market. But American auto makers, who earlier shunned what they deemed a small and difficult market, are missing an explosion in auto sales.
In 1987, sales of cars and pickup trucks - Thailand's favorite mode of transportation - topped 100,000 for the first time. Last year they totaled 208,000, and some say they may approach 300,000 this year. ''I keep wondering where the Americans are,'' said Takashi Murasawa, a senior official of MMC Sittipol Company, the Mitsubishi Motors joint venture here.
The beneficiaries are all of Japan's car makers, who control 92 percent of the market despite stiff local-content laws that have required them to produce half to three-quarters of their components in Thailand.
 
Wages Are Low
But if Thailand thought it was about to learn the high-tech secrets of auto making it was wrong. Factories here look like flashbacks to the 1930's. ''We don't have any robots here,'' said Suparat Sirisuwanangkura, the manager of component engineering, ''because the labor is still very cheap.'' An average auto worker in Thailand earns about $200 a month, about what a skilled Japanese auto worker would make in a day.
A key element in the Japanese auto makers' regional strategy lies in persuading Southeast Asian nations to abandon their hopes of building ''national'' cars, in which every component is produced in their own country.
''The volumes are too low and they are very uneconomical,'' said Ninnart Chaithirapinyo, associate director of Toyota Motor Thailand. So the auto companies have assigned subsidiaries in each country to produce certain key components of each car, and in most cases have persuaded governments to treat those parts as if they were ''domestic content.''
''The idea is to trade parts roughly equally,'' Mr. Ninnart said. ''In practice, though, it is difficult to balance.''
Indonesia has refused to participate, apparently fearing that efforts to build its own cars would be undermined. Malaysia has already mounted its own effort. For five years, the country has been building the Proton Saga, a national car, although two years ago Mitsubishi had to step in to rescue the project.
Whether Japan is really willing to share its high-tech knowledge with countries like Thailand is a matter of considerable debate. The companies all say they share generously, often bringing Thai or Malaysian engineers to Tokyo for training. But employees say that Japan is keeping its most sophisticated manufacturing processes to itself.
''We need to put more emphasis on getting Japan to part with its technology,'' Dr. Snoh said.

HEADLINE: Talking Deals;
The Slowdown In Bank Mergers

BYLINE: By Michael Quint

 BODY:
WHEN the Bank of New York acquired the Irving Bank Corporation in 1988, the combination was hailed as an example of the wave of bank mergers that would create a new generation of larger, more profitable banks.
Bankers and analysts still agree that the benefits of mergers - particularly the opportunity to cut costs - will make some of them attractive. But a sharp drop in bank stock prices and poor earnings resulting from losses on real estate loans have made bankers more prone to look inward.
The change in conditions is dramatic enough that the Bank of New York is balking at acquiring the $3.4 billion-in-assets Northeast Bancorp of Shelton, Conn., as it agreed to do several years ago as soon as Connecticut law allowed. The Bank of New York has set a $12.31-a-share value on Northeast stock, which would result in a $215.4 million takeover, while Northeast values its shares at $33.50 each, for a sales price of $586.2 million. Northeast has filed a lawsuit to force the merger. 
The slowdown in large mergers is closely tied to the steep decline in bank stock prices since last October. ''Sellers are slow to adjust to the drop in bank stock prices, and they are now holding out for the high prices that seemed feasible last year but which are now beyond buyers' reach,'' said Richard J. Barrett, a managing director at Salomon Brothers.
With more than 12,000 banks, merger activity has not stopped cold. According to Bank Mergers and Acquisitions, a newsletter published by SNL Securities of Hoboken, N.J., there were 47 acquisitions of banks or savings and loans announced in the first quarter of this year, with a value of about $1.2 billion. In the fourth quarter of 1989, there were 59 deals valued at $1.8 billion and in the third quarter of 1989 there were 40 deals worth $5.3 billion.
Because most banks pay for most large acquisitions by issuing new stock, a lower stock price means that more new shares must be issued, to the disadvantage of existing shareholders.
''The currency for acquisitions, our stock, is depressed right now,'' said Robert Smith, the acquisition-minded chief executive at the Security Pacific Corporation of Los Angeles.
The mergers offering the greatest benefit for his bank, he said, would be those with companies like First Interstate Bancorp of Los Angeles, which operates in Security Pacific's home market. But according to an interview in the United States Banker, a trade magazine, Mr. Smith said he would consider a merger with the Chemical Banking Corporation of New York. Chemical would offer geographic diversity and has a large branch system. But it would not give Security Pacific the potential for cost savings as would a merger closer to home.
Chemical, the Chase Manhattan Corporation and the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation have been mentioned as logical merger candidates by many analysts. All have large, profitable branch networks. By cutting expenses, a merger of any two of those banking concerns would result in a company whose profits should be greater than the sum of the profits of the two independent banks. Assuming a 20 percent cut in non-interest expenses for things like duplicated branches and headquarters staff, profits at Chase would rise about $720 million following a merger with another of the large banks. At Chemical, the gain would be $520 million, and at Manufacturers, $400 million.
The need for consolidation is acute, Mr. Barrett of Salomon Brothers and other analysts say. With more than 12,000 banks in the United States, they say, the industry is too fragmented to compete effectively with foreign banks that are expanding their share of the worldwide market and the American market. ''Eventually, American banks have to begin thinking that it might be better to share the costs of new technology and new products rather than butting heads,'' Mr. Barrett said.
Gary W. Parr, an investment banker at Wasserstein, Perella & Company, said, ''The economic benefits of mergers are as great today as any time in the past.'' But the preference for independence is so ingrained among many bankers that ''it may take some outside force to force them to merge,'' he added. The outside force may be regulators or an unwanted offer from another banking company, he said.
Whatever the motives for merger, analysts expect that shareholders of acquired banks will reap a profit. The banks most likely to be taken over are profitable, have management that would not reject merger proposals out of hand, and have a large share of their local market, analysts at Shearson Lehman Brothers say.
These analysts' top 20 takeover candidates include five that are among the 50 largest banking concerns. They are: the UJB Financial Corporation of Princeton, N.J.; the Signet Banking Corporation of Richmond; the Southeast Banking Corporation of Miami; Huntington Bancshares Inc. of Columbus, Ohio, and the Michigan National Corporation of Farmington Hills, Mich.

HEADLINE: U.S. Talks to Banks About Easing Poland's Debt

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 9

 BODY:
The Bush Administration told Congress today that it opposed writing off American Government debt in Eastern Europe, but raised the possibility that commercial banks could forgive a portion of their debts and provide Poland with additional loans through special provisions of the Brady debt reduction plan.
Under the plan disclosed 14 months ago by the Treasury Secretary, Nicholas F. Brady, incentives offered by the International Monetary Fund and World Bank are meant to entice commercial banks to voluntarily forgive a portion of their debts in countries that pledge ambitious economic reforms. The Administration said Poland now met that requirement.
So far, the formula has been applied to six countries - Mexico, Costa Rica, the Philippines, Ecuador, Venezuela and Morocco. Poland would be the first to benefit in Eastern Europe. 
Of Poland's $38 billion of foreign debt, about 20 percent is held by commercial banks, mostly German. The stake of American banks is relatively small.
David C. Mulford, the Treasury Under Secretary for International Affairs, told the House Banking Committee's Subcommittee on International Development, Finance, Trade and Monetary Policy today that the Treasury had been in contact with American and foreign banks on Polish debt reduction. It was the first indication of active involvement by the Treasury in the Polish debt situation.
''We have not told the banks what to do,'' Mr. Mulford told the lawmakers. But pointing to Poland's sweeping free market economic reforms, he added, ''We would look to the banks for a voluntary negotiation to address the issue of debt reduction for those banks that want to make that choice.''
Representatives of some commercial banks were cool to the idea. ''The short-term problem is to stabilize the Polish economy,'' said Horst Schulmann, managing director of the Institute of International Finance, which represents 160 commercial banks.
He also said there could be a ''very strong negative impact'' if the United States and other governments sought to ''jawbone'' the banks into a debt-reduction plan for Poland, as occurred late last year with Mexico.
Asked whether his response meant that banks would not engage in negotiations with Poland under the Brady plan, he responded, ''Never say no.''
 
Government Firm on Loans
Bankers also argued that it was unfair to ask for commercial debts to be written off in Eastern Europe when the governments of the industrial countries refused to mark down their own loans. Third world governments owe the United States $63 billion, said Mr. Mulford; Poland's share of that is $3 billion.
Two subcommittee members, John J. LaFalce, Democrat of upstate New York, and Jim Leach, Republican of Iowa, urged a special American program to write off Government loans to Eastern Europe. Representative LaFalce proposed that the United States forgive Poland's $3 billion debt and see to it that the money went into the environmental cleanup of Poland.
But Mr. Mulford outlined a series of reasons why the Bush Administration was opposed to such actions. He cited budget implications, ''when we have major budget problems already;'' the drawbacks of favoring one region of the world over another, and technicalities in which a writeoff for one country automatically improves the status of debt held by others.
 
Strong Reaction
Mr. Schulmann reacted strongly to the idea that banks forgive debt while the Government does not. ''Mulford says he can't do it because of $63 billion,'' he said. ''But what the hell does he think he's talking about, commercial banks hold close to $1 trillion of third world debts.''
Poland's Finance Minister, Leszek Balcerowicz, who has been here to attend the spring meetings of the I.M.F. and the World Bank, told reporters Tuesday that a failure to obtain debt relief would jeopardize Poland's program to privatize large sections of its economy, which is 80 percent state-owned. He indicated that Warsaw would seek an 80 percent cut in interest payments.
At present, Poland is making no payments to commercial banks. Earlier this year it won concessions on debt it owes to foreign governments under which it is freed from interest payments until March 1991.

HEADLINE: Campeau Units Get Extension

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: CINCINNATI, May 9

 BODY:
Federated Department Stores Inc. and the Allied Stores Corporation today obtained a four-month extension in which to file their reorganization plan to emerge from Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection.
Lawyers for the retailing units of the Campeau Corporation told United States Bankruptcy Judge J. Vincent Aug Jr. that they might need even longer than the new deadline of Sept. 12 because the case was so complex. Federated and Allied have more than 200,000 creditors, about 100,000 employees and operate 260 stores. 
Judge Aug also ruled today against B. Bros. Realty Limited Partnership, the investment firm of the Bloomingdale family that owns the land under Bloomingdale's, the flagship store of the Federated chain.
 
Attempt to Evict Store
B. Bros had been trying to evict the Manhattan store, contending in court papers that Federated had violated the store's lease, which runs until 2006, by transferring it to the Bloomingdale's name as part of the bankruptcy proceeding.
B. Bros. had been prevented from acting on the eviction by an April 20 stay, but the firm, which wanted the store vacated by May 17, had moved to have the stay lifted.
But Judge Aug angrily rejected the motion to remove the stay, saying it was ''procedurally inappropriate'' and that the landowner should have proceeded under a different part of the Bankruptcy Code to protect its rights to the store lease.
He said the store was operating normally and paying the rent promptly, and added that he was puzzled why B. Bros. had waited so long to protest the purported breach of the lease since Federated had filed for bankruptcy in January. And he said that he ''saw no economic damage to B. Bros. from the alleged breach.''
The judge ordered B. Bros. to pay Federated's legal fees that arose from the litigation by B. Bros.
John L. Ernst, the general partner of B. Bros., could not be reached for comment yesterday.
Carol Sanger, a Federated spokeswoman, said the defense costs had not been determined. Settlement with I.R.S. Judge Aug also approved a settlement that Federated had negotiated with the Internal Revenue Service in a dispute over taxes on inventory movement and size from 1981 to 1983.
Under the agreement, Federated will receive a $23 million refund from the I.R.S., but will adopt I.R.S. tax computing methods over a 10-year period - starting with the 1983 tax year - that could increase Federated's taxes by $14 million.
Rick Cieri, an attorney for Federated, said the settlement increases the value of Federated for creditors, provides additional money for its operations and saves the cost of litigation.
The judge approved the settlement over the objection of Citibank, which wanted to know whether Federated's parent, Federated Stores Inc., would claim any of the $23 million refund.
Robert Seppelt, vice president of taxes for Federated Department Stores, said the parent company had no claim to the $23 million.

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Kodak Tells Holders To Expect Better Year

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: ORLANDO, Fla., May 9

 BODY:
The Eastman Kodak Company, the world's largest maker of photographic products, said today that it expected an improved financial picture for the year after posting a 62 percent drop in profits last year.
''As 1990 unfolds and our gains from restructuring take hold, we look forward to higher sales, better earnings and improved cash flows, especially in the latter part of the year,'' Kodak's departing chairman, Colby H. Chandler, told shareholders at its annual meeting here.
He reported progress on a reorganization plan for the company. Last year's profits plummeted to $529 million, from $1.4 billion in 1988, with Kodak attributing the setback to restructuring costs, higher interest rates and exchange-rate fluctuations that cut into overseas earnings. 
Mr. Chandler said that Kodak, based in Rochester, cut about 5 percent of its staff and that the employee wage-dividend formula had been tied to company performance.
Kay R. Whitmore, 57 years old, Kodak's president, will add the positions of chairman and chief executive on June 1, succeeding Mr. Chandler, 64. Mr. Chandler has been chairman and chief executive since 1983.
The company said it saw good growth in traditional photography and would exploit its proprietary technology in film and electronic imaging over the next decade.
Kodak said it had no plans to sell its Sterling Drug Inc. unit or any other assets to pay for its litigation with the Polaroid Corporation. Mr. Whitmore told reporters after the meeting that the company could pay for the pending litigation out of its earnings.
''Kodak can handle anything within what the Street talks about,'' Mr. Whitmore said. He was referring to recent Wall Street estimates that the Polaroid instant-photography case regarding patent infringement could cost the company about $1 billion.
A Federal judge is expected to set damages soon against Kodak for infringing Polaroid's patents.
In trading on the New York Stock Exchange today, Kodak's shares rose 50 cents each, to $38.125.

HEADLINE: CONSUMER RATES;
Money-Fund Yields Mixed

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO

 BODY:
Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were down for tax-exempts and unchanged for taxables for the week ended yesterday.
Analysts at Donoghue's noted that everything was pointing up for interest rates until last Friday, when the monthly employment figures were released disclosing a smaller than expected increase. The next month's round of economic data may give more clues about the economy. If the numbers show more weakness, the Fed may be persuaded to ease credit and lower short-term rates. 
Donoghue's seven-day compounded average yield for a taxable money market fund is unchanged at 7.96 percent, while the 30-day average yield declined by one basis point, or hundredth of a percentage point, to 7.98 percent.
Assets of taxable funds declined by $1.2 billion for the week, to a total of $377 billion, with institutional assets down $300 million, to $79.1 billion, and consumer assets off by $900 million, to $297.9 billion.
The average days to maturity of securities held in managers' portfolios remained unchanged at 45.
Among the general-purpose money market funds with assets of more than $100 million that are surveyed by IBC/Donoghue's, Dreyfus World Wide Dollar Money Market fund, distributed by the Dreyfus Service Corporation in Garden City, L.I., showed the best return for the week, with a yield of 8.91 percent, unchanged from last week. The fund has now posted the best return for the better part of two months.
Yields of tax-exempt funds were down for the week ended yesterday, while assets were up about $180 million, to $75.6 billion. Swings in assets of under $200 million are not considered unusual. The average seven-day compounded yield declined five basis points, to 5.74 percent, and about where it was two weeks ago. For investors in a 28 percent tax bracket the equivalent taxable yield is 7.97 percent, and 8.56 percent for those in a 33 percent bracket.
Donoghue's said the Calvert Tax Free Reserve California portfolio, distributed by the Calvert Group, Washington, had the best yield for the second consecutive week. The return was 6.49 percent, down from 6.67 percent the previous week. The yield is about 75 basis points points better than the seven-day average.
By comparison, The Bank Rate Monitor's national index shows that while bank money market accounts yields are slipping, yields on certificates of deposit are growing more competitive. The average money market account fell one basis point, to 6.23 percent.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off Sharply on Fears Of Softening U.S. Economy

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply yesterday against most major currencies as the foreign exchange market grew increasingly concerned about indications that the United States economy is softening.
Traders and currency analysts said the strength of the West German mark and the Swiss franc accounted for much of the dollar's losses, although the dollar also fell sharply against the Japanese yen.
The dollar traded at 1.4020 Swiss francs late yesterday in New York, down sharply from 1.4310 francs late Tuesday. It fell more than 2 pfennigs against the West German mark and more than a yen against the Japanese currency. 
The Swiss franc is being viewed as a safe haven for investors because many other major currencies appear troubled by domestic concerns, said Brian Guidera, a currency trader for the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York.
''It's being seen to be the only logical alternative to the uncertainty elsewhere in the world,'' he said. ''As far as high-yielding currencies go, it's seen as stable.''
Traders also said the Swiss franc was lifted by that nation's relatively high interest rates.
 
Employment Report a Factor
The dollar was viewed as the currency of choice until Friday, when Government figures showed employment growth in April was far lower than economists expected, traders said. That report altered the belief that the United States economy was expanding and that higher interest rates would result.
Higher domestic interest rates increase the relative attractiveness of returns on a nation's currency.
The West German mark also showed renewed strength yesterday. The dollar was trading at 1.6365 marks in New York late in the day, down from 1.6575 marks late Tuesday.
William Harrington, an international economist with the WEFA Group in Bala-Cynwyd, Pa., said the mark had benefited from the recent belief that the union of the currencies of West Germany and East Germany would go more smoothly than originally forecast.
In New York, the dollar fell to 156.50 yen in late trading, from 157.63 yen late Tuesday. Earlier in Tokyo, the dollar closed at 157.03 yen, down 1.02 yen from Tuesday's close, and in London, it was quoted lower, at 156.40 yen.
The British pound rose to $1.6785 in London, from $1.6697 late Tuesday. In New York, the pound fetched $1.6785, up from $1.6705 late Tuesday.
Meanwhile, gold prices rose. Bullion for immediate delivery on the New York Commodity Exchange rose $1.90 an ounce, to $371.90. The Republic National Bank in New York also quoted bullion at $371.90 an ounce as of 4 P.M., up $2 from late Tuesday.
Gold traded at $370.75 an ounce in London late yesterday, up from $369.75 late Tuesday. In Zurich, gold traded at $370.75, up from $369 bid late Tuesday. Earlier, gold in Hong Kong dropped $2.49 an ounce to close at $370.93.

HEADLINE: On Taxes: Rereading Their Lips

 BODY:
PUB-DATE: June 24, 1988
Aug. 18, 1988 ''The Congress will push me to raise taxes, and I'll say no, and they'll push, and I'll say no, and they'll push again, and I'll say to them, 'Read my lips: 'No new taxes.'''- George Bush, in his acceptance speecha t the Republican National Convention.
Jan. 19, 1989 ''The President meant no new taxes as it would ordinarily be understood by ordinary Americans. I think the burden of that is the duck test - if it looks like a duck, it's a duck.'' - Richard G. Darman, budget director, telling Congress the Administration would not disguise tax proposals in euphemisms.
Jan. 22, 1989 Asked in a televised interview how long Mr. Bush's no-new-taxes pledge would last, John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff, said, ''As long as the climate of this country is appropriate for that commitment to stay in place.''

''The President, to my knowledge, has not said that there is no conceivable possibility over a four-year term. What he has said it is his hope that he will be able to extend this as long as possible, and we certainly hope we'll be able to do it this year.''

HEADLINE: RACE AND JUSTICE: A KILLING IN EAST TEXAS - A SPECIAL REPORT.;
Death as a Ripple in Deep Racial Current

BYLINE: By PETER APPLEBOME with ROBERTO SURO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HEMPHILL, Tex., May 8

 BODY:
Loyal Garner Jr. had been dead for only an hour when officials began the fight over his body and over who would rule on how he had died.
Officials in this small town where he had been found comatose on a jail cell floor labeled his death an accident and wanted the body returned quickly. But officials 100 miles away in the city of Tyler, where he had been taken for medical treatment and where he died, thought the death was suspicious and refused.
Last week, more than two years after the 34-year-old black truck driver was beaten to death in this hamlet in the East Texas piney woods, a jury in Tyler convicted three white officers of his murder.
The story of the killing of Mr. Garner on Christmas night 1987 is a story of race and of a legal battle between officials in a backwoods town and those in a small city. 
One jury acquitted the officers of civil-rights violations in a hometown trial that saw white residents cheer the verdict as if celebrating a Friday night football victory. Another jury convicted them of murder.
''There was kind of a line drawn in the dust and you had to get on one side of the line or the other,'' said J. T. Roy, an investigator for the Southern Poverty Law Center in Alabama, a civil rights legal organization. ''And Loyal Garner just became a bartering chip, no matter how brutally he was killed. What mattered was the issue of whether the outsiders were going to win.''
Despite the conviction and an agreement by local officials to pay an undisclosed amount to the Garner family in the settlement of a civil lawsuit, the case lives on in appeals and in the resentment of local whites who feel they have been put under a spotlight for the sort of crime that they feel can and does happen elsewhere.
''I guess this is the only town in the country where this happens,'' a local businessman, Robert Gilcrease, said sarcastically. ''Like a car wreck, it happened. It can happen to you, it can happen to us. People here don't understand why it still gets all this attention.''
Set in a lush landscape of thickets and lakes near the Louisiana line in deep East Texas, Hemphill typifies what a University of Texas English professor, Donald Graham, calls ''the unmythic, unglamorous part of the state.''
This is not the expansive Texas of endless spaces and possibilities; it is a world far more like the Deep South than the West. But if its racial history is distinctly Southern, this is the gritty, outer edge of the South without any illusions of antebellum nobility.
For blacks, who make up about 20 percent of Hemphill's 1,350 residents, life had been a long, silent accommodation with economic and political powerlessness - until, that is, Mr. Garner was murdered, and local blacks for the first time turned to protest marches, even founding a local chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People. The Arrest Clamor, Then Clash In a Jail By the standards of the poor timber town of Florien, La., Loyal Garner's $5.50 an hour job with the parish government was a mark of success.
Married with six children, Mr. Garner came from a well-known and respected family in town. He had never been in trouble with the law. He drank a beer or two socially but no one recalls seeing him drunk. His was a regular Sunday presence at the Pilgrim Star Baptist Church.
On Christmas Day 1987, Mr. Garner and two friends set out on the short drive to Newton, Tex., to pick up an automobile that he planned to overhaul. But on the way, Mr. Garner crossed paths with Thomas Ladner, Hemphill's police chief. A lifelong resident and one of the dominant forces in town, the 275-pound Chief Ladner was respected by many people in Sabine County and was feared by many others.
About 8 P.M., shortly after crossing the state line on the bridge that spans the Toledo Bend Reservoir in his black 1975 Ford custom cab pickup, Mr. Garner was stopped by Chief Ladner and Sabine County Sheriff's Deputy James Hyden. Mr. Garner was arrested for drunken driving and his two companions, Alton Maxie and Johnnie Maxie, were charged with public intoxication.
 
Conflicting Alcohol Readings
The Maxie brothers said Mr. Garner had drunk two beers. No alcohol test was given Mr. Garner and laboratory tests after his death gave conflicting readings on whether he had alcohol in his body. All accounts agree on the events immediately after the arrest.
The three men accepted their arrest peacefully and were not handcuffed when they were put in the back of a squad car.
At the Sabine County jail, a one-story structure just off Hemphill's town square, they were put into a detoxification cell. After a while the three began banging on the cell door, demanding to make a telephone call to their families.
Chief Ladner walked back to the cell and loudly asked who was making all the noise. ''I was,'' Mr. Garner answered. Accounts of what happened next are contradictory.
The Maxie brothers and other inmates said Chief Ladner, without provocation, hit Mr. Garner five or six times with a metal slapjack while Deputy Hyden stood in the doorway with his hand on his gun. The inmates said Mr. Garner was then taken to the jail's processing room where the beating continued, with Sheriff's Deputy Billy Ray Horton in attendance.
 
Reports of Earlier Beatings
The officers said Mr. Garner, drunk and abusive, was hit once in self-defense by Chief Ladner and was then injured in a scuffle as officers tried to restrain him. But their story varied over time.
Former inmates of the Sabine County jail have since said that beatings had taken place there from time to time. But when a jail guard came to work the morning after Mr. Garner's arrest to find him comatose on the concrete floor, it was clear this was serious.
Mr. Garner was taken to the nearby Sabine County Hospital and then to Tyler Medical Center, a larger facility 100 miles away, where neurosurgery could be performed. He died the next day.
Because he died in Smith County, where Tyler is the county seat, and not Sabine County, where Hemphill is situated, officials both inside and outside Hemphill had legal standing in the case. And a tug-of-war began.
A Smith County Justice of the Peace, Bill Beaird, says that about an hour after Mr. Garner died, Sabine County Judge Royce Smith, the top elected county official, called him to say that Hemphill officials had already determined the death was an accident and wanted to come and pick up Mr. Garner's body. Judge Smith said Sheriff Blan Greer could vouch for that.
 
Refuses to Release Body
Mr. Beaird, repeating what a nurse had already told Hemphill officials, politely but firmly said he could not release the body, pending an inquiry. He repeated the same message when Mr. Smith called still again.
''Let me put it to you in plain English,'' Mr. Beaird recalls saying. ''That body ain't leaving here until such time as I get through with it to make some kind of determination or have the information available so I can hold an inquest.''
At his office, Mr. Smith declined to comment.
Mr. Beaird's decision meant that eyes outside Hemphill would view the case, and it set in motion a two-track courtroom drama that is at the heart of the legal issues still surrounding the case.
Within days, an autopsy in Tyler cited a massive brain hemorrhage from repeated blows to the head as the cause of death. Before a week had passed both the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Texas Rangers had heard the Maxie brothers tell their story of the beatings. Soon the Southern Poverty Law Center, known for vigorous civil rights lawsuits, filed the civil suit on behalf of the Garner family that allowed them to take depositions from local officials.
On Jan. 4, Chief Ladner and the two deputies were indicted in Hemphill by the state on felony charges of violating Mr. Garner's civil rights, and they were suspended from duty. Local officials said at the time that a murder indictment would have required proof of an intent to kill.
In Tyler, District Attorney Jack Skeen was aiming for a murder trial. On March 4, a Smith County grand jury indicted the three Hemphill officers for homicide.
When a trial date in July was set in Tyler, an earlier trial, in May, was scheduled in Hemphill.
Mr. Skeen, the Smith County prosecutor, said, ''It seemed to us at the time that the judge in Hemphill was doing everything he could to have it tried down there first.'' The Town An Ingrown Place Defending Its Own Like the old domino players who meet daily under the cedar tree on the square, Hemphill has been a place where little has changed over the years. With its three-story brick courthouse dominating a placid square ringed by aged brick businesses with metal awnings, Hemphill is small enough that any visitor who is not one of the 1,350 residents in town immediately sticks out.
Longtime residents still resent those they call the ''lake people,'' the retirees and newer residents who live along the rich bass fishing lakes nearby. The lake people grouse about the ''piney woods mentality'' of the oldtimers. But otherwise Hemphill lives by its own slow, amiable rhythms far from airports and Interstate highways.
Suddenly, there were satellite trucks from the big city television stations camped out on the square. Not everyone in town liked all the indicted officers, particularly Chief Ladner. But they liked the outside scrutiny even less, and before long the town was rallying around the officers.
 
Officers Were Local Men
Some saw law enforcement under siege. But it was more personal than that. All three officers were local men who were entrusted with keeping the peace, whether it meant investigating a robbery or making sure high school students stayed in line.
And if there were numerous stories of brutality at the jail, the three were as much a part of the local scene as the domino players. The best liked was probably Mr. Horton, a 60-year-old former cattle rancher who had gone into law enforcement after his wife died of cancer a few years earlier.
In rallying around the officers, many residents felt they were simply doing what people in small towns tend to do: helping out neighbors in trouble. The fact that the dead man was an unknown black jail inmate only heightened their natural instincts.
Even though a special prosecutor had been brought in from outside the county, most local blacks assumed from the start there would not be a conviction in Hemphill. And the beginning of the trial in the sweltering, baby-blue third-floor courtroom did little to change their mind.
Judge O'Neal Bacon of the local State District Court refused to disqualify potential jurors who attended a benefit fish fry for the officers. The judge ended up sitting a jury of 11 whites and one black, a housekeeper who worked for one of the white jurors.
 
It's Us Against Them
They heard the conflicting accounts of the events Christmas night. They heard the results of the Tyler autopsy, and they heard Dr. Grover Winslow, a local physician who attends to the jail and who had posted bond for Mr. Horton, testify that Mr. Garner had alcohol and Valium in his body and could have died of some mixture of the two.
In his closing argument, John Seale, a defense attorney from nearby Jasper, made explicit what had been welling up since the day Garner died.
''So what has this case become?'' he asked. ''It's become an indictment, not against these three men, but against Sabine County and everything that has to do with Sabine County.''
The appeal worked. On July 15, the second day of deliberations, to cheers of delight from the packed courthouse, the jury announced it that it had acquitted all three men.
The murder trial in Tyler was to start in a week, but the very day after the Hemphill verdict, defense attorneys moved for dismissal of the murder charges on the ground of double jeopardy, the legal prohibition against trying a person on the same charge twice.
So far, the legitimacy of having two trials has been upheld, with the case now before the United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit in New Orleans.
Last month prosecutors in Tyler began presenting their murder case to a jury in Tyler. But while Mr. Seale in Hemphill had insisted that Hemphill was on trial, Mr. Skeen in Tyler tried to convince jurors of the reverse, that they had to prove that Smith County was capable of providing the justice that Hemphill had not.
The jury in Tyler, which during the oil boom grew to a city of 81,000 that now takes its cues from Dallas instead of the small towns of East Texas, was allowed to see the grotesque autopsy photographs of Mr. Garner that the judge in Hemphill had excluded on the grounds that they were inflammatory. And there were two new witnesses.
Dr. Ronald Donaldson, a Tyler neurosurgeon, gave graphic testimony about the severity of Mr. Garner's wounds. Ronnie Felts, a former Hemphill Mayor, became the only Hemphill official to break ranks and testify for the prosecution. He told of Mr. Ladner's conflicting accounts of the incident.
 
Difference Was the Juries
This time the jury found all three defendants guilty.
In the end, Mr. Seale said, ''The difference was two different juries in two different towns.''
Weeping openly in the courtroom, Mr. Skeen demanded life sentences. ''Establish by your verdict the real meaning of Smith County justice. This is Loyal Garner Jr.'s last chance.''
The jury sentenced Mr. Ladner to 28 years in prison, Mr. Hyden to 14 and Mr. Horton to 10. Officials say that primarily because of prison overcrowding, it is likely they will serve only a year for every 10 they were sentenced to if the guilty verdict stands. The Future Separate Ways In Same Rhythm For a brief instant after Mr. Garner's death it seemed like everything in Hemphill was subject to change.
There was an emotional meeting at a black church in which blacks and whites, for the first time in the town's history, came together to share what they had in common and what still divided them. There was the town's first protest march and the formation of its first chapter of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People.
But two and a half years after he died, Mr. Garner's death divides blacks and whites as much as anything ever did. There are widespread doubts by blacks as well as whites as to whether race had anything to do with his murder. But no one doubts that on the stark, small canvas of Hemphill, its aftermath has become another profile in black and white.
 
For Blacks, an Awakening
For blacks, Mr. Garner's death became a galvanizing event, a reminder of how far they still have to go.
''Sometimes,'' said Will Smith, a black and the pastor of the Fairdale Church of Christ, ''it takes death to bring life. If Loyal Garner's death did anything, it brought an awakening to the people of Sabine County. We're awake now. We're no longer asleep.''
There was no such revelation for whites. Some reacted with hostility, like one businessman who confidently said local blacks would not turn out for the protest march after the acquittal in Hemphill because they knew they would never get a job if they did. But for most, the case remains an isolated incident kept inexplicably alive and blown out of proportion by outsiders.
 
For Whites, Depression
Most whites are genuinely horrified and depressed by the depiction of Hemphill as a town where bigotry lives, noting with much truth that because of the compression of small town life, blacks and whites probably interact more in a place like Hemphill than in most large cities.
''We were made out like we were racists, like black and white don't speak to each other or sit next to each other at the drug store,'' said Mary McNaughten Pritchard, one of the jurors in the Hemphill trial. ''People are people. We think nothing of a black girl being given a ride to a district ballgame by a white family. We're just everyday people, there's no black and white about it.''
But sometimes the old antagonisms surface in an entirely unvarnished form.
Robert Gilcrease was lamenting the town's negative image at his business where he sells plastic fishing lures when a customer strode in and began assailing a visiting reporter for the ''lies'' being written about the town.
''You all keep writing about a 'brutal beating,' '' the customer said. ''I'd say it would take more than three licks to the head to make a brutal beating. Far as I'm concerned, it's just another dead nigger.''
He then offered to provide a first-hand lesson in what a ''brutal beating'' would be like before tearing away in his pickup truck.
 
Some Progress for Blacks
There have been scattered but real signs of progress, the appointment of the town's first black councilman, a black dispatcher hired at the jail, a black 1988 valedictorian at the high school, and a few blacks hired at local businesses.
There are still no black faces behind the counters at the businesses along the square, and other than the routine interractions of daily life, blacks and whites generally go their separate ways just as they always did. When Hemphill had its annual Mayfest, with fiddle music and Frito Pie and the crowning of a Mayfest Queen on the square Saturday, it was hard to find a black face.
Sheriff Greer is still in office and in charge of the jail. A new police chief and deputy sheriffs have been hired to replace the three convicted men.
And there is a new move afoot to help the convicted officers with their legal fees.
Mostly, for blacks and whites, there are just the same old slow rhythms of East Texas, the lunch buffet at Twitty's, the grousing between the original people and the lake people, the banter of the old domino players and the noisy slapping of the tiles on the table at the corner of the courthouse square.
