SECTION: Section A; Page 1, Column 6; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1192 words

HEADLINE: U.S. OFFICIALS URGE BANKERS TO AVOID TIGHTENING CREDIT

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10

 BODY:
In an extraordinary meeting, the nation's top banking regulators urged banking industry executives today to continue lending to creditworthy customers.
Though the regulators did not say so explicitly, their remarks were interpreted as a signal to bankers that the Government does not want to see regional pockets of tight credit throughout the economy.
There have been repeated Government warnings this year about the dangers of real estate lending, but as he went into the meeting, L. William Seidman, the chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, said: ''We are not saying not to lend. We are saying they should use their good judgment.'' 
 
Opening Doors to Bankers
The regulators - Mr. Seidman, Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board, and Robert L. Clarke, the Comptroller of the Currency - told the directors of the American Bankers Association that they wanted to open more lines of communication. They said that at both the national and local levels their doors were open to bankers seeking guidance on lending practices.
Concern about tight credit generally focuses on home-equity loans, loans to small businesses and loans to real estate developers.
The meeting with the banking industry's largest trade group was the first time the three officials have jointly met with bankers.
The meeting comes during growing weakness in important real estate markets, like the Northeast. Regulators have been trying to tighten up on real estate lending standards to avoid a repeat of the savings and loan debacle. In recent years the main growth in bank lending has been real estate-related.
 
Worries on the Deficit
The session also comes as the Government struggles with a ballooning budget deficit, in large part because of the high cost of the savings bailout. Government officials fear the deficit will grow even higher if tight credit pushes rates up.
The Federal Reserve could lower rates but that would not necessarily encourage more lending in the face of lending rules that have become tighter.
Regulators are also aware that the assets of the F.D.I.C.'s banking insurance fund are at a historic low, as a percent of insured deposits. Though the rate of bank failures is running behind that of 1989, one or two failures of major banks could cripple the $13.2 billion fund.
Moreover, there are broader economic worries. The Federal Reserve is concerned about possibly reigniting inflation if regulators send a strong signal to the bankers to lend, lend, lend. Thus, the message today to the bankers was understated, and aimed at nudging rather than pushing them into new, but prudent, lending.
The meeting was initiated by Mr. Clarke, who has come under fire this year for his repeated warnings about real estate lending. Bankers say not only that those pronouncements have made them hesitant to lend, but that the statements have encouraged examiners from the Comptroller's office to be overly rigorous in auditing, forcing some banks to report large losses.
''In any economic environment, there are still good loans to be made,'' Mr. Clarke said after the meeting. ''We need to turn down the rhetoric and get back to the business of banking.''
Representatives of the bankers' group, who briefed reporters after the meeting, said the regulators told the gathering that there were no disparities in their examination standards and that they wanted to clear up any misconceptions or misunderstandings between the regulators and the bankers over lending standards.
Among the bankers at the meeting were Thomas Labrecque, president of Chase Manhattan, and Robert Smith, president of Security Pacific.
Banking executives said that while many of their members had complained that regulators had been putting pressure on them to withhold loans, the consensus of the group was that there was not a nationwide credit squeeze.
''The bankers felt that there is no liquidity crisis in the economy, but that there are areas of a slowdown in lending, tied to a slowdown in the local economy, and that is normal,'' said Donald G. Ogilvie, executive vice president of the bankers' group.
 
Complaints Are Common
Mr. Ogilvie said that in the last two months representatives of his assocation from 27 states have been in to the association's headquarters and in every group there have been bankers who complained about regulators forcing tighter lending policies.
''There are real estate problems in lots of parts of the country, not just in the Northeast,'' he said.
Mr. Greenspan said he did not see strong evidence of a credit squeeze, saying, ''The evidence is quite limited.''
Banking officials said Mr. Greenspan told the meeting: ''The nature of banking is risk-taking. And if you have zero loan losses, then you aren't doing your job.''
Some banking executives said the comments by the regulators were a clear signal that they are concerned about tight credit.
''This signals that the credit crunch is biting too deep,'' said Kenneth A. Guenther, executive vice president of the Independent Bankers Association, another trade group.
 
Tough Examinations
Bankers have complained that examiners who looked at real estate loans a year ago and found no problem are now making banks set aside cash to cover possible losses.
They have told of cases in which examiners insisted that loans that were being repaid on schedule be classified as troubled simply because the banks lacked recent appraisals of the properties serving as collateral for the loans.
Owners of small businesses in particular have complained that they are the ones ultimately harmed. With increasing frequency, they say, banks are withdrawing lines of credit, demanding more collateral and trimming estimates of the value of that collateral.
The regulators do not deny that there is a tightening of credit in important areas of the country. ''Where you have a downturn in the economy, it is inevitable that you are going to have a restriction of credit,'' Mr. Clarke said. But that ''doesn't mean you should freeze up all the lending.''
Some bankers and their representatives said today that in return for more lending activity, they would expect more understanding from the regulators. They say that for them to make more credit available, they cannot be concerned that regulators are going to continue forcing them to take large write-downs on the value of their real estate and small business loans.
Edward L. Yingling, head of the bankers' association's government relations office, said the issue was ''whether the examiners are going to go by the exact numbers, or give a local banker who knows a small-business owner some latitude.''
 
Regional Variations
The lending situation varies greatly from region to region, but is most severe in the Northeast. Large companies, over all, do not seem to be having trouble getting new loans.
Data compiled by the Fed show that lending has grown this year, but at a slower rate than in the past.
Business loans increased $3.1 billion in the first quarter of the year over the 1989 period, slower than the pace that produced almost $18 billion in new loans in 1989.

GRAPHIC: photo: Alan Greenspan, right foreground, Federal Reserve Board chairman, arriving for a meeting yesterday with bankers on loosening credit. With him were Robert L. Clarke, left, Comptroller of the Currency, and Richard Syron, second from left, Federal Reserve chief in Boston. Others were unidentified. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Arabs Agree to Hold Talks in Baghdad

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TUNIS, May 10

 BODY:
Arab countries, increasingly alarmed over the influx of Soviet Jews to Israel, agreed today to hold a summit meeting in Baghdad.
The purpose of the meeting is to consider the influx of Soviet Jews and to lend support to Iraq in the face of Western protests to its effort to develop modern weaponry including long-range missiles and chemical weapons.
It is also likely to address continuing Arab divisions, particularly between Iraq and Syria. But Syria said it would not attend the meeting. 
Also on the agenda will be attempts to reconcile Arab states that favor a settlement with Israel, like Egypt and Jordan, against opponents of negotiations with Israel, including Iraq and Algeria.
Arab and Palestinian officials said the meeting was scheduled for May 28 so that it can be held in advance of the summit meeting between President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and President Bush set for May 30 in Washington.
Syria opposed Baghdad as the site; and Iran, which has not signed a treaty with Iraq after their long war, expressed misgivings.
Until Wednesday, Arab mediators were suggesting Cairo or Tunis as the site for the gathering, but pressure from major Arab countries led by Egypt, Saudi Arabia and Jordan proved decisive in the choice of Baghdad.
Arab diplomats said the reason for favoring Baghdad was the great amount of Arab support for the tough stand adopted by President Saddam Hussein of Iraq in his row with Western countries and Israel. President Hussein is one of the Arab leaders most hostile to Israel.
 
Alarm Over Jewish Influx
The idea of a summit meeting has been discussed over the last few weeks as Arab countries expressed increasing alarm over the influx of Jewish immigrants from the Soviet Union who are settling in Israel and declarations by some Israeli leaders that some of those will be settled in Israeli-occupied territories.
Yasir Arafat, the chairman of the Palestine Liberation Organization, has repeatedly called on other Arabs to adopt diplomatic and economic measures aimed at discouraging Western financial and moral support for the movement of Soviet Jews to Israel, which reached 10,000 last month, according to reports from Israel.
Iraq, for its part, has strongly endorsed the idea of a summit meeting in Baghdad to strengthen the notion of Arab solidarity in its confrontation with the West. The United States, Western Europe and Israel have called for an end to Iraq's effort to develop long-range missiles, chemical weapons and other advanced armaments.
 
Iraq Claims Self Defense
President Hussein has repeatedly asserted that Iraq has a right to develop such weapons to defend itself against attacks by Israel.
In 1981, Israeli planes raided and destroyed an Iraqi nuclear reactor facility. Iraq could not then respond to the Israeli attack because it did not possess an advanced air force or long-range missiles.
Syria, which has been feuding with Iraq for years, has already warned that it will not attend any summit meeting that is held in Baghdad. Today, the official Baath Party newspaper said Damascus's ''announced position is still the same.''
Iran, another bitter enemy of Iraq which fought an eight-year-long war with Baghdad, warned Arab nations that a meeting in Baghdad would only strengthen President Hussein's expansionist ambitions.
Arab diplomats speculated that Iran's alarm at the revival of a wave of Arab support for Iraq has led to Teheran's agreement, announced today, to hold a meeting next Wednesday in Dublin with representatives of the European Community.
European and Iranian officials said the talks will touch on the issue of Western hostages held in Lebanon by pro-Iranian militias and further normalizing of economic and diplomatic ties between Iran and Western Europe.
The representatives of Iran and the European Community will also discuss relations soured by Iran's call for the death of the British author Salman Rushdie, the Teheran Radio said today.

HEADLINE: John Paul, in Mexico, Denounces Birth Control

BYLINE: By CLYDE HABERMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: CHIHUAHUA, Mexico, May 10

 BODY:
Pope John Paul II preached a hard sermon against birth control today in this Roman Catholic country that is struggling to stop its population's explosive growth rate.
While there were no surprises in the Pope's denunciation of contraception and abortion, his remarks had potential political dimensions for Mexicans. Their numbers are growing by about two million a year, straining an already troubled economy. 
The Pope also touched on another essential theme of this trip, relations between the Holy See and the Mexico, which have not had diplomatic ties since the mid-19th century. Antichurch feelings go back many decades to when the Catholic Church was considered an ally of repressive governments. Reflecting the situation is a Constitution from 1917 that includes harshly anticlerical provisions.
One prohibits the church from operating its own schools, and although the ban is honored in the breach these days, the Pope said it was time to get rid of it entirely.
''A person has the right to educate children liberally according to his own religious faith and to create schools to exercise this right,'' he told tens of thousands of worshipers at a service in Chihuahua. ''The laws of the country must recognize this right explicitly.''
The Pope's travels today, the fifth day of his Mexican journey, took him as close as he will get to the United States, with stops in Chihuahua, Mexico's largest state, and Monterrey, an industrial center 100 miles southwest of Laredo, Tex. Tens of thousands of Catholics filled a dusty field here that lay amid jagged red hills, including many transplanted Mexicans who had made the pilgrimage from Texas.
The question of birth control is a touchy one in Mexico, where 40 percent of the population of 86 million are below the age of 15.
The Pope did not directly admonish the Mexican Government for its aggressive efforts at family planning, but he has done so in the past and his criticism this time was implicit.
According to Planned Parenthood, nearly half of married Mexican women use some form of contraception, helping to shrink the population growth rate from 3.5 percent in the mid-1970's to slightly under 2 percent. The Government goal is to bring that down to 1 percent by the end of the 1990's, a challenge made more difficult by the fact that abortion remains illegal.
At the religious service held on a sports field in this cattle and mining center in the north, the Pope strongly repeated the church's stand against any form of birth control.
''If the possibility of conceiving a child is artifically eliminated in the conjugal act, couples shut themselves off from God and oppose his will,'' John Paul said. He continued:
''Society is more sensitive every day to the rights of the child, Nevertheless, the child is still exposed to no small list of maladies,'' including, he said, ''the egoism of a part of society that makes attempts on his life even before birth through the practice of abortion.''

HEADLINE: Court Is Urged To Rehear Case On Ritual Drugs

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10

 BODY:
An unusually diverse coalition of religious groups and constitutional scholars asked the Supreme Court today to reconsider a recent decision permitting states to take legal action against people who use illegal drugs as part of religious rituals.
The petition requesting the rehearing told the Justices that ''every religious group in the country will be profoundly disadvantaged'' by the ''far-reaching holding'' issued last month. The request was made on behalf of two members of an American Indian church in which the ceremonial use of the hallucinogenic cactus peyote has been an important sacrament for centuries.
The 5-to-4 opinion in Employment Division v. Smith, written by Justice Antonin Scalia, rejected the Indians' argument that their use of peyote was protected by the First Amendment's guarantee of the free exercise of religion. 
The opinion said the guarantee did not generally exempt a person from complying with a valid law, even if the law conflicted with a religious belief.
 
Often Asked, Rarely Granted
Requests for rehearings are filed frequently by the losing side, but the Supreme Court rarely grants them. Not since the early 1960's have the Justices agreed to reconsider a case.
Oliver S. Thomas, general counsel of the Baptist Joint Committee on Public Affairs, one of the groups supporting the effort, said at a news conference today that there was only an outside chance that the Court would grant the request. ''But it's our only shot, so we take it,'' he said.
Mr. Thomas and several other lawyers said the coalition hoped at least to make both the public and the Court aware of the dismay that the opinion had provoked.
Among the 15 other organizations participating were the American Jewish Congress, the National Council of Churches, the National Association of Evangelicals, the American Friends Service Committee and the General Conference of Seventh-Day Adventists. Public interest groups not affiliated with religious denominations also joined the effort, including the American Civil Liberties Union and People for the American Way on the liberal side, and the Rutherford Institute on the conservative side.
 
Diverse Groups All Agree
''I seriously doubt that these groups have ever been in the same room together,'' Mr. Thomas said, adding that they all agreed that the opinion was ''disastrous for the free exercise of religion.''
Among the 55 constitutional scholars who signed the petition were Gerald Gunther of Stanford Law School, Laurence H. Tribe of Harvard Law School, Norman Redlich of New York University Law School, Sanford Levinson and Douglas Laycook of the University of Texas Law School, Kent Greenawalt of Columbia Law School and Michael W. McConnell of the University of Chicago Law School.
The focus of the coalition's concern was not so much the outcome of the case as the Court's analysis. Justice Scalia's opinion rejected the principle, included in several of the Court's earlier decisions on the subject, that a governmental action that places a burden on religious observance is unconstitutional unless it serves a ''compelling state interest.''
Both sides in the case had assumed that the ''compelling state interest'' analysis would govern the outcome. Oregon had denied unemployment benefits to the two plaintiffs because they had been dismissed from their jobs for using peyote. The state argued that its interest in enforcing narcotics laws uniformly was ''compelling.'' The Indians argued that it was not.
 
Matter for Politics, Not Courts
But Justice Scalia said the Court's precedents applying compelling state interest ''have nothing to do with an across-the-board criminal prohibition on a particular form of conduct.'' He said American society would be ''courting anarchy'' if the Court endorsed the approach of granting ''constitutionally required religious exemptions from civic obligations of almost every conceivable kind.''
Noting that the Federal Government and many state legislatures had already exempted sacramental peyote from their narcotics laws, Justice Scalia said ''the political process,'' not the courts, should make such choices.
In the petition asking for a rehearing, the coalition warned that such an analysis would permit the Government to ban as non-humane the ritual slaughter required under Jewish law to make meat kosher, the circumcisions practiced by Jews and Moslems, or the use of wine in the Roman Catholic Mass.
The petition, prepared by lawyers for Oregon Legal Services and the American Jewish Congress, told the Court that rehearing was necessary because none of the briefs in the peyote case had even considered the prospect that the compelling state interest test would not be applied.
 
Rehearing Requires a Majority
Under the Court's rules, a majority must agree for a case to be reheard.
Justice Scalia's opinion was joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and Justices Byron R. White, John Paul Stevens and Anthony M. Kennedy.
Justice Sandra Day O'Connor cast a sixth vote in support of the state's position, saying that Oregon had ''a compelling interest in regulating peyote use by its citizens.'' But she refused to join Justice Scalia's opinion, labeling it ''incompatible with our nation's fundamental commitment to individual religious liberty.''
Even if Justice O'Connor supported a rehearing request, however, it would still need the support of at least one of the Justices in the majority.
The Court is likely to act on the request in the next several weeks.
The last case the Court reconsidered was Flora v. U.S., which held that Federal district courts could not hear certain tax refund suits. After the rehearing in 1960, the Court reaffirmed its initial decision, issued in 1958.
But in 1957, a reargument changed the outcome of a case. The Court ruled after rehearing Reid v. Covert that the military does not have court-martial jurisdiction over civilians in peacetime. The initial decision, in 1956, had gone the other way.

Dean Kelley of the National Council of Churches. (Paul Hosefros/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Overboard on Ozone

 BODY:
Every President needs a Darth Vader in the White House to thwart special pleaders and scrutinize even apple-pie issues. President Bush's chief of staff, John Sununu, and Budget Director, Richard Darman, have played this role zestfully in curbing what they see as excessive solicitude for the environment. But in their latest foray, an assault on the international effort to protect the ozone layer, they have simply abandoned all sense of proportion and judgment. 
The U.S. persuaded the world to reach agreement on phasing out production of CFC's, a class of industrial chemicals that destroy the life-protecting layer of ozone in the upper atmosphere. Many developing countries that signed the Montreal protocol of 1987 asked for help in converting to the more costly substitutes, and Washington agreed in principle to provide it.
An international group in Geneva has been working out the details, and proposed setting up a fund to which the U.S. would contribute around $20 million a year. The State Department and Environmental Protection Agency urged the Administration to support the proposal. But Mr. Darman and Mr. Sununu have now instructed that it be opposed.
This is not an intelligent decision, for the following reasons: There is only one ozone layer, and there are a lot of people in India and China. It's in America's own interest for these and other developing economies to abandon CFC's as soon as possible. If the price tag is only $20 million, it's a bargain, particularly as the Treasury is reaping windfall profit taxes of $5 billion from the CFC industry as it phases down. The considerable damage already done to the ozone layer has been caused by CFC's manufactured in the United States. It's not too much to ask that Americans help less-developed countries avoid the same error. Every speaker from other countries at the Geneva conference expressed dismay at the U.S. stand. It's glorious to stand alone against the world when one is right, less so to cling to a position that puts the U.S. in the doghouse of world opinion.
Mr. Sununu and Mr. Darman are said to fear that modest help on CFC's now would lead to greater demands later if the world agrees to take action against the gases of global warming. But that's an issue for the future, to be dealt with on its merits. The threat to the ozone layer, and all living things on the planet, is present and real.
A Secretary of the Interior in the Reagan Administration once suggested that the way to solve the ozone problem was to continue producing CFC's but let people buy sunglasses and sunscreen lotion to protect against the bath of ultraviolet rays. Mr. Bush risks gaining a reputation for equal profundity unless he quickly instructs Messrs. Darman and Sununu to quit trifling with serious issues.

HEADLINE: Albania Reforms, Sort Of

 BODY:
A crack is opening in the fastness of Albania, Europe's last bastion of Communist absolutism. New laws will permit Albanians to travel abroad and to worship deities other than Marx, Stalin and Enver Hoxha, Albania's tyrant from 1944 until his death five years ago. The laws were adopted unanimously, as is always the case in the People's Assembly, and just in time to provide copy for visiting Soviet and American journalists. 
These laws may be only window-dressing to impress Western Europe, whose trade Albania covets. But when an oppressed people scents the possibility of change, rusting shackles can swiftly become intolerable. Albanians are aware of the upheaval in Eastern Europe, thanks to the Voice of America, the BBC and broadcasts from Italy, Greece and Yugoslavia. Even the controlled press has recounted the violent demise of Romania's kindred autocracy.
Meanwhile, the arrogance of the Hoxha era has yielded to nervous placatory gestures. President Ramiz Alia has permitted indirect but unmistakable criticism of the security police, the brutal Sigurimi. He met briefly last November with a leader of the Albanian Orthodox Church based in America, the first such contact of its kind. And Mr. Alia also sought out today's unprecedented visit by the U.N. Secretary General, Javier Perez de Cuellar. All this responds to a growing restiveness that in turn owes something to Communism's one real accomplishment - a jump in Albania's literacy rate from 15 percent to 75 percent. Younger Albanians are palpably weary of stale slogans, desolate public squares and an ox-cart economy. They have begun to question why they are forbidden all forms of religious worship, ownership of automobiles and the right to travel. Hence the tentative concessions, the fiddling with penal laws and the overtures to the once-despised West.
Like their comrades elsewhere, Tirana's rulers face an exquisite dilemma. They talk grandly of ''continuation with more realism.'' But each move away from dogma and isolation erodes party authority. And without fundamental reforms Albania, Europe's poorest country, will become poorer still. No walls can prevent Albanians from learning that their statues of Stalin so visible everywhere are planted on sand.

HEADLINE: Computers and Other Targets: II;
A Lesson From Japan: Experiment

 BODY:
Japan may have stumbled in its highly publicized effort to produce a Fifth Generation computer that can talk to people, but its Government-fostered computer industry puts U.S. companies under ever-greater pressure. Japan is now mounting a challenge to U.S. supremacy in a promising technology, massive parallel processing.
It scares Americans when Japan targets American industries; Japan's computer triumphs have brought new pressure for America to target American industries. Does funneling Federal assistance into commercial technology make sense? 
On one side of the debate, experts urge emulating Japanese Government-business cooperation. The other side resists any governmental intervention in commercial markets as a matter of principle. The polarized passions obscure a middle ground, ripe for debate: Government-encouraged experiments, carefully contained.
Japan's patient 35-year program of promoting its computer industry has conjured up frightening images of a shrunken U.S. industry, with thousands of unemployed engineers and technicians. The reality is much less fearful. For one thing, Japanese targeting efforts like the Fifth Generation Project have no special record of success. For another, there is no certainty that Japanese investments in parallel processing will be more fruitful than those of U.S. corporations.
Even if Japan should commercialize parallel processing first, the U.S. would suffer no economic calamity. American industry would purchase Japanese computers and use them to boost productivity. Living standards here will rise, even if more slowly than in Japan. That said, the question remains: Can't the U.S. do even better by subsidizing research and commercial development?
No, many economists would say. Subsidies, especially in the U.S., can do more harm than good. From industrial planning in the 30's to synfuels in the 70's, Congress has often rewarded the politically powerful, not the economically promising. To economists, no industry is inherently better than another. Computer chips may sound magical, exotic. But a country is just as well off importing its D-RAM's and semiconductors and exporting wheat as the other way around. Without government intervention, countries will produce what they do best. The Saudis pump oil, the U.S. grows wheat, and then the two countries trade.
The case for targeting recognizes that technological discovery is far different from oil derricks and wheat fields. Neither Japan nor the U.S. has a natural advantage when it comes to potential breakthroughs like parallel processing. Victory must be won with ambitious research. But individual businesses might be unwilling to do pioneering research on their own, especially when they might earn only a fraction of the ultimate profits.
That argues for a middle course: Use Government funds to stimulate careful experimentation, within strict limits. The Defense Department's Advanced Research Projects Agency has long fostered such experimentation. The Bush Administration's current hostility to Defense's agency is all the more reason to create a civilian body to subsidize research on promising commercial technologies. But three safeguards would be needed to head off a political boondoggle:
Keep It Small: The rich United States can afford mistakes. A program of, say, $4 billion a year would be peanuts in a $6 trillion economy. If the whole $4 billion is wasted, no one will notice. But if the program turns up an occasional winner, the gains could be immense.
Keep It Small: The Government input for any one project should also be limited, with the private corporations coughing up most of the capital. Companies unwilling to risk their own money should not be allowed to risk the taxpayers'.
Keep It Small: Under no circumstance should Congress evade the experimental purposes here by erecting trade barriers to shelter the targeted industry. Foreign competition is consumers' best protection against artificially created cartels.
The key is to experiment.

HEADLINE: Law School Standards: the Old and the New

 BODY:
To the Editor:
The debate about hiring more minority and women faculty members at Harvard Law School (news articles, April 24 and 26) - and my own Columbia - should not be seen as a struggle between excellence and diversity. Instead, the discussion should focus on what excellence should mean within the context of a law school and its development of a faculty, curriculum and student body.
Do the high standards for new faculty at a Harvard or Columbia require a clerkship with a United States Supreme Court justice, a stint at Cravath, Swaine & Moore or an article published in a prestigious law journal? If so, it's no wonder the ''excellent'' law schools complain that so few women and minority candidates meet their standards. Or is there something else to this idea of excellence at an academic legal institution? I suggest that a law school must actively seek diversity and a different concept of high standards if it is to attain or maintain excellence. 
In its own bulletin, Columbia Law School notes that it has a ''special responsibility'' to provide a program that will enable students to ''use their talent and training for the improvement of society and to create for themselves professional careers that will bring them joy and satisfaction.'' And it suggests that law professors have a unique opportunity to ''lead the way to improving the law in service of social needs.''
I am quite unclear about how Columbia's faculty - with only one tenured black professor and one black associate professor - can begin to ''lead the way to improving the law in service of social needs'' for the community surrounding Columbia -Morningside Heights, or Harlem, if you will - or even for the broader community of this country. I am, however, a little more clear about how a faculty that meets the current standards of excellence can serve to ''improve society'' from the perspective of economically comfortable white people.
If the country's law schools see themselves as having a positive role in the discourse of social change or in simply supporting the discussion, they have no choice but to develop a faculty that has voices from many cultures and experiences. A law school committed to excellence in its task of training future lawyers must recognize that its current use of standards only impedes its ability to serve the broad community reached by the law. These schools must bring in more women's voices, more African-American voices, Latino voices and Asian voices - or their rhetoric of excellence speaks only to a culture of comfort and exclusivity.
 
ELIZABETH DANIEL
 New York, April 27, 1990

HEADLINE: Law School Standards: the Old and the New;
'A Superb Scholar'

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Your April 24 news article about Prof. Derrick Bell's protest over the absence of a black woman on Harvard's law faculty focused on the risk that university hiring decisions made under the pressure of protest might be based on nonmeritocratic criteria. Your subsequent article (April 26) focused on Prof. Regina Austin, a black woman who is a visiting scholar at Harvard Law this year.
We do not intend to comment on the question of university responses to protests or to encourage Harvard Law to hire Professor Austin; but readers should not be left with the impression that the school would depart from its usual standards of quality in considering Professor Austin.
Professor Austin is a superb scholar who writes principally about the law of compensation for injury to persons and property. Her recent scholarship places her in the forefront of an important school of legal thought. It draws from her experience - as a black woman who knows subordination - to illuminate the impact of law on all individuals. 
In considering the role of law in regulating an employer's right to control the workplace and the rights of workers to be free from employer abuse, Professor Austin weighs the impact of the exercise of employer authority on black women - workers who are disproportionately employed as domestics or in other low-wage jobs. She has been equally concerned about the impact of employer harassment on workers generally.
Professor Austin's work is infused with social facts relevant to the legal issues so that the impact of law can be viewed in relation to those facts rather than in a vacuum. Consideration of social, economic or other facts is a well-established tradition in the intellectual history of the law. A student's comment that Professor Austin teaches ''more sociology than law'' must be considered not only in light of beginning law students' lack of sophistication about competing philosophies of law, but also in light of the lingering discomfort of many students about the presence of women and minority members on law school faculties.
Recent studies conclude that university classroom discussion tends to be dominated by students who are members of the groups most privileged by law and society. All too often the views and concerns of women students and students who are members of minority groups are given short shrift or left out of classroom debate entirely. This phenomenon was a subject of consideration at a recent conference sponsored by the Association of American Law Schools and both the Commission on Women in the Profession and the Section on Legal Education and Admissions to the Bar of the American Bar Association.
Comments that Professor Austin failed to call on white male students in a particular class or classes must be evaluated in light of recognized patterns of classroom domination. All professors have a responsibility to equalize and enrich classroom debates by allowing for and facilitating the expression of a diversity of viewpoints. Those who shoulder this responsibility face the difficulties of addressing the conditioned inhibitions of students from subordinated groups and the understandable resentment of those white male students who are discomforted by the loss of privileged status.
The female voice is a relatively new one in law school communities: the voices of women of color are virtually absent from most. In this environment, readers should view with skepticism the suggestion that Professor Austin has engaged in reverse discrimination to over-privilege students from disadvantaged racial and gender groups whose identity she shares.
 
PAULETTE M. CALDWELL
PEGGY C. DAVIS, PATRICIA A. KING
EMMA COLEMAN JORDAN
ELIZABETH H. PATTERSON
 New York, May 4, 1990
The writers are professors of law, the first two at New York University, the others at Georgetown University.

HEADLINE: Liberian Bloodshed, U.S. Diplomacy

BYLINE: By J. Brian Atwood; J. Brian Atwood is president of the National Democratic Institute for International Affairs, which is affiliated with the Democratic Party.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
A war is being fought in Liberia, which has close ties with the U.S., and very few in Washington have taken notice.
Active diplomacy is urgently needed, not only to prevent further bloodshed but to preserve prospects for a democratic political solution.
The war has its origins in corruption, human rights abuses and ethnic tensions exacerbated by the Government of the President, Gen. Samuel K. Doe. 
These problems were particularly acute in Nimba County, a large area bordering the Ivory Coast and Guinea. Abuses of the local population by President Doe's military turned the county into fertile ground for an insurgency.
The leader of the insurgents, Charles Taylor, is a former high official in the Doe Government who fled the country after having been accused of embezzlement. His supporters say he is fighting for democracy, but Liberian democrats are skeptical. It is unlikely, they say, that he possesses either the commitment to democracy or the political leadership necessary to bring about a democratic transition on his own.
The best hope for a peaceful reconciliation would be a negotiated settlement and an agreement to hold elections to determine the nation's new leadership. There is little time. Mr. Taylor's forces are closing in on Monrovia, the capital. Only the U.S. has the influence and leverage needed to achieve a cease-fire and begin negotiations.
In the minds of many Liberians U.S. policy has placed us too close to President Doe. This is the case even though the U.S. has cut back economic and military assistance from a high of $80 million in 1985 to about $10 million last year.
This was done in large part at the insistence of Congress, which required the executive branch to certify that Liberia was making ''significant progress'' in political and economic reform. Even the most creative diplomats and lawyers could find no progress.
The leaders of various political parties and civic groups in Liberia are impressive. Many are living in exile but are prepared to return when they can do so safely. They had looked forward to elections scheduled for November 1991 as an opportunity to topple the Government at the polls. But now it doesn't look as though it will survive until then.
The election in 1985 was widely believed to be fraudulent. Large piles of ballots were seen burning and a significant defeat for President Doe turned out to be a narrow victory after a delayed and manipulated vote count.
The U.S. Government contributed to the legitimization of the result when a statement by Secretary of State George Shultz seemed to endorse the process.
In 1985, the international community did not pay much attention to Liberia. Had international observers been present, the outcome might have been different.
The experience of U.N. observers in Namibia and Nicaragua and large numbers of official and unofficial observers monitoring elections around the globe gives Liberia's democrats more confidence that the 1991 election will reflect the will of the Liberian people.
On May 8, a delegation sent by the Liberian Government was in Washington to seek advice in setting up an electoral system that would inspire confidence. The group said President Doe would welcome international observers of the election. The delegation has much to overcome in convincing fellow Liberians of President Doe's sincerity, but they have made an important beginning.
What is now needed is for all the important actors to negotiate a transition to democratic rule via a free and fair election, roundtable-style and with no conditions.
Such an outcome would establish a moral and political basis for ending the civil war and beginning the reconciliation process.

HEADLINE: ESSAY;
The Big-Gov Right

BYLINE: By William Safire

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Hear that rumbling, grinding, groaning sound? It's the noise of the tectonic plates of the political right, building up ineluctable pressure along the San Darman Fault.
Inflation's rising interest rates, combined with the creeping realization of the cost of the S & L bailout, have made ridiculous recent Bush estimates of the budget deficit.
As a result, the blessed discipline of Gramm-Rudman has imposed a choice on the President and Congress: Accept automatic reductions in spending across the board, make your own cuts or raise taxes.
Raising taxes will cause less voter hollering, incumbents have decided, and so we can expect this package:
The ''bubble'' at the high end of income tax rates will be pricked, raising rates to 33 percent; this will generate enough soak-the-rich satisfaction to permit passage of the capital gains tax cut, a reduction that promises to produce higher revenues the first year. 
But that's only about $7 billion; as much again can be raised from booze (a buck per six-pack of beer, a quarter per bottle of wine), and $5 billion more from a quarter-a-pack whack at cigarettes. Bank depositors should ante up for their costly Federal insurance.
Then comes the big bite: energy taxes. The smart way would be an oil import fee, driving down oil prices and inflation, diminishing OPEC power, pressuring Soviet economic reform and reducing the S & L bailout cost by raising Southwest real estate values.
The easier way is a gasoline tax, warming global hearts by raising the cost of driving and pleasing plutocrats with its regressiveness.
We have just raised $40 billion a year in no-new-taxes. Add a spending cut, mainly from defense, plus a last-minute rejiggering of projections, and presto! Responsibility rampant; le grand compromis historique; coalition government at last.
A motley assortment of irresponsible skinflints, gallus-snapping reactionaries, old neo-cons and new neo-Neanderthals - joined by a few nutty lefties hung up on progressive taxation - will serve as a chorus of muttering naysayers.
Why do I find my views in alignment with the anti-tax demagoguery of these selfish dregs of populist resentment?
A large and growing deficit in prosperous times is a great mistake, leaving no margin of fiscal stimulus in a coming recession. The way to reduce the deficit is to curb the increases in Federal spending, not to raise taxes sure to be used for even more Federal spending.
This position, baldly stated, was not so long ago the will of the people; the taxation barrier was our enforcement weapon. Now a hold-the-line stance against the centralization always in taxation's wake is derided as out of touch, with none so irresponsible to do it reverence.
Wherefore the sudden new consensus of our body politic? Why must the majority accept officialdom's reversion to tax-and-spend medicine -now sugar-coated by the conservative reasoning of fiscal responsibility rather than the liberal rhetoric of human compassion?
Those questions bring us to our groaning tectonic blue-plate special: The conservative majority of the past 20 years is breaking up.
De-cemented by the collapse of Communism; riven by the inclination of Mr. Bush to split the difference with ideological opponents, and strike-slipped by the libertarian-vs.-traditionalist tension of the abortion issue, the serious right wing is shifting its center of gravitas.
The emerging political philosophy is not to be dismissed as moderate Republican me-tooism reborn nor as the easy pragmatism that places process before principle. On the contrary, we may be seeing the unplanned and inarticulate rise of the Big-Government Right.
We thought the Bush philosophy to be: Federal Government has ''a role to play'' in setting education goals, encouraging competitiveness, incentivizing health and child care - but decisions to carry out policy, backed up by decisions to tax and to hold officials accountable, would mostly be local, not national.
But as Mr. Bush's fort - his no-tax pledge - is breached, political control inexorably follows tax revenues toward Washington, where coercion lives under the aliases of ''mandating,'' ''industrial policy'' and ''national standards.''
Maybe a good case can be made for the administrative efficiency of Big-Gov Right. Why are Mr. Bush and his Budget Director reluctant to make it?

HEADLINE: Judge Critical Of Dinkins Over Boycott

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
A Brooklyn judge issued an order yesterday barring demonstrators from picketing within 50 feet of two Korean-American food stores. In doing so, he criticized Mayor David N. Dinkins, expressing regret that the Mayor had not intervened personally to help end the four-month-old boycott that began over a dispute with a black customer.
Mr. Dinkins, under continuing pressure in what some supporters and critics alike say is a test of his powers of conciliation, said he had intervened, by sending top aides to mediate and trying to telephone a lawyer for the protesters.
Moreover, the Mayor said, he would make ''a major, major comment about race relations, tensions in the city and whatnot.'' His aides said later that the Mayor's comments - prompted by the boycott, tension over the Bensonhurst racial murder trial and other disturbing incidents - would come in a speech at 7:30 tonight at City Hall. 
 
Pickets Reject Mediation
''I want to try to put things in perspective,'' Mr. Dinkins said. ''I don't mean to say that I am unconcerned, that things are all rosy in our town. They never have been.''
Justice Gerald S. Held of State Supreme Court made his decision to restrict picketing at the store after two black groups sponsoring the demonstrations rejected his request that city mediators be brought in. The dispute was touched off on Jan. 18 when a black customer complained of being beaten by Korean employees at the Red Apple grocery at 1823 Church Avenue in the Flatbush section.
Demonstrators heeded the judge's order yesterday. Chanting ''Korean merchants must go,'' about three-dozen pickets remained behind police barriers 50 feet from the stores until about 10 P.M. and then left.
In his order, Justice Held praised the city's Human Rights Commission for offering to mediate. But he said he ''regrets the failure of the Mayor of the City of New York to personally intervene and use the prestige of his office and his high standing in the community to convince the parties to bring a suitable end to this dispute.'' Asked for his reaction, Mr. Dinkins said: ''One, I'm pleased that the judge feels that I have a high standing in the community. That's nice. Two, to personally intervene, without knowing what his definition of personal intervention is, let me hasten to say that I have personally intervened.
''I note in that same order,'' Mr. Dinkins added, ''he praises my commissioner, Dennis deLeon,'' chairman of the Human Rights Commission, ''while deploring or condemning or expressing regret - or whatever the appropriate language is - that I have not been there. I wonder who he thinks sent Dennis deLeon.''
The Mayor said, ''If the time comes when it appears that would be helpful, I'm certainly happy to go.'' Mr. Dinkins also took a jab at Justice Held, recalling that the judge once ordered about 400 patients evicted from a Brooklyn nursing home whose owner had been convicted of Medicaid fraud. The eviction order was later overturned.
''He's free to criticize me, of course,'' Mr. Dinkins said. ''Let me say that I did not criticize his judgment with respect to the Cobble Hill situation, when those persons, the seniors, would have been put out had he not been reversed.''
At the same time, Mr. Dinkins said, he was seeking a meeting with Stephen G. James, a lawyer for the protesters. Mr. James met with Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch yesterday but had said that he wanted to talk to the Mayor directly.
Mr. Dinkins also seemed to suggest for the first time that he believed the boycott might be motivated, at least in part, by racial animosity.
 
Race and Economics
''I should say that the persons who oppose the Korean merchants are certainly not monolithic,'' he said. ''There are different agendas. I would suspect that some of it may be racially motivated. Some may be motivated by economic considerations.''
Justice Held's order, which restricts the picketing until he conducts a trial of the dispute, was issued as lawyers for the merchants and the demonstrators continued their legal wrangling.
The judge said in the five-page order that the Police Department is ''authorized and directed by this court to enforce the provisions of this order.''
Mr. James said he would appeal the judge's order as quickly as possible. He said it infringed on First Amendment rights to protest ''systematic disrespect'' that blacks encountered in the two stores. The black boycott seeks to drive the two owners out of the community because of their behavior, he added, but Koreans in general ''are welcome in this area.''
A lawyer for the store owners, Richard A. Izzo, called the judge's decision proper, but said the owners would prefer to have the demonstrators negotiate. He said ''professional instigators'' organized the picketing to ''foment racial strife.''
Justice Held's decision involved a procedural issue of whether legal papers had been properly served on the demonstrators in front of the Red Apple grocery and another store across the street.

HEADLINE: Cost of Budget Delay Is Placed at $18 Million

 BODY:
New York State's delay in adopting a budget will cost New York City taxpayers about $18 million, City Comptroller Elizabeth Holtzman said yesterday.
''It is a tragic waste of money that did not have to happen if the state had gotten its budget act together,'' she said. 
Because the state has been without a budget since April 1, it has been unable to make scheduled aid payments to the city, causing a cash-flow problem.
Ms. Holtzman offered the $18 million estimate after the city sold $900 million in revenue anticipation notes at an interest rate of 6.34 percent. The notes, which will be due June 29, will cost the city about $7 million in interest.
The city has also had to postpone contributions to employee pension funds. Ms. Holtzman said it is obligated to reimburse the funds for the interest they are losing - about $5.3 million.
The remaining $5.7 million of the $18 million, she said, represents interest lost because the city cannot invest aid payments it has not received.

HEADLINE: 2 MEN ARE INDICTED IN MEXICO DUMPING

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LOS ANGELES, May 10

 BODY:
Federal prosecutors in Los Angeles today announced indictments of two men on charges of dumping toxic waste in Mexico in the first instance in which the United States has pursued prosecution of an environmental crime across its southern border.
The indictments, a result of a cooperative investigation between Mexico's environmental agency and the United States Justice Department, provided a counterpoint to recent angry exchanges between the two countries over efforts to halt the narcotics trade.
''This type of cooperation is essential in cases such as this one,'' Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said in a statement issued here. ''The environment knows no national boundaries.'' 
The two men, Raymond Franco and David Torres, were charged with taking 34 drums of toxic waste across the Mexican border and dumping them in Tijuana, just across the border from San Diego. Prosecutors said the barrels contained several chemicals used as paint thinners and cleaning solvents: toluene, xylene, methyl ethyl ketone, acetone ethyl benzene and 1,1,1,trichloroethane.
The officials said they had not identified any companies in the United States that had delivered toxic wastes to Mr. Franco knowing that it would be disposed of illegally. #32-Year Penalty Possible The men were charged with violations of the Federal Resource Conservation and Recovery Act, the law regulating the handling and disposal of hazardous waste. If convicted, they could be sentenced to as many as 32 years in prison.
While officials did not offer an estimate of the amount of toxic material that they believe is illegally shipped to Mexico, they said it is large because of the difficulty and the cost of disposing of toxic waste legally in the United States. Companies pay as much as $1,000 a barrel to dispose of toxic wastes legally, said William Carter, the Deputy District Attorney of Los Angeles County. Mr. Carter said companies were generally charged $500 a barrel for illegal disposal of toxic waste.
Law enforcement officials said toxic waste was often shipped as part of loads of legal products, much of it over routes that are for all practical purposes uncontrolled.
''We suspect a large quantity is going through Texas and down into Mexico that way,'' said Ed Gomez, chief of the Southern Division of the California Highway Patrol.
 
Barrels Hidden Under Scrap
Prosecutors said the two men indicted today had worked together to transport the barrels of toxic waste hidden among loads of scrap materials that are legally disposed of across the border.
Ira Reiner, the Los Angeles District Attorney, said Mr. Franco, who was arrested Wednesday in New York City, ran a business called Ray's Industrial Waste in El Toro, south of Los Angeles. He said Mr. Torres, who has not been arrested, had been involved in the transportation of salvage products between the United States and Mexico.
The officials said that Mr. Franco was an American citizen and that Mr. Torres was a Mexican citizen with homes in Mexico and Orange County.
Federal officials in Los Angeles also announced today that they were creating an interagency task force to fight the movement of toxic waste from the United States to Mexico, characterizing the activity as an international crime with high economic incentives, comparable to the trade in narcotics. The agencies involved are the Federal Bureau of Investigation, the Environmental Protection Agency, the Transportation Department, the California Highway Patrol and the California Department of Health Services.

LENGTH: 1529 words

HEADLINE: LAW;
New Look at an 'Obscure' Ruling, 20 Years Later

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE

 BODY:
Few people would recognize a 20-year-old Supreme Court decision called Goldberg v. Kelly, let alone accord it a place in the pantheon of the Court's major rulings.
But the decision has nonetheless touched the lives of millions of people. Written by Justice William J. Brennan Jr., Goldberg v. Kelly held that welfare recipients are constitutionally entitled to a hearing before their benefits can be terminated. The ruling transformed the administration of government benefits programs across the country and gave the concept of constitutional due process a broader interpretation than it had ever received.
Even in its obscurity, Goldberg v. Kelly remains a landmark. That was the message of a 20th-anniversary celebration last week that drew several hundred lawyers and law professors to Brooklyn Law School for a day of reflection on the origins and legacy of the case and, more generally, on the course of constitutional law. 
The program also served as a reminder that it is not only the most famous Supreme Court decisions - the Brown v. Board of Educations and the Roe v. Wades - that make a difference.
 
How the Case Got Its Start
The conference participants came from as far away as California and from as close at hand as the neighborhood legal services offices and local welfare bureaucracy where Goldberg v. Kelly, a New York case, got its start.
No one was sure of the whereabouts of John Kelly, the disabled welfare recipient who became the lead plaintiff after his grant was cut off without notice when he moved out of the welfare hotel to which his caseworker had assigned him.
Jack Goldberg, whom a group of welfare recipients had sued in his capacity as New York City's Social Services Commissioner, died in 1974.
But Cesar A. Perales, Social Services Commissioner of New York State for the last eight years, was there. Twenty years ago he was a legal services lawyer representing welfare recipients. Now he runs a state welfare system that because of Goldberg v. Kelly holds 800 hearings every working day.
 
Welfare Recipients Prevail
Mr. Perales said welfare recipients prevailed in those hearings 80 percent of the time, persuading the hearing officers to overturn caseworkers' decisions that cut off benefits.
In New York State, Mr. Perales said, ''the constitutional concept of due process is made real more than 75,000 times each year.'' He added: ''Perhaps the most dramatic proof of the institutional saturation of Goldberg precepts is that its protections, once considered radical, are now taken for granted.''
Prof. Sylvia A. Law of New York University Law School recalled that as a new lawyer and ardent rock music fan in the summer of 1969, she gave up a chance to attend the Woodstock music festival in upstate New York to work on the welfare plaintiffs' Supreme Court brief.
She has never regretted her choice, Professor Law said. Goldberg v. Kelly has endured, she said, ''because it's for all of us, for anyone who has a driver's license, a taxi medallion, a license to practice law,'' or any other government benefit that now cannot be arbitrarily withdrawn.
Justice Brennan himself regards the 5-to-3 decision as one of his major achievements. In a 1987 speech to the New York City Bar Association, he spoke at length about the decision as one that ''opened a dialogue that continues to this day about the responsibilities of the bureaucratic state to its citizens.''
 
Putting Passion Into the System
In that speech Justice Brennan said that ''if due-process values are to be preserved in the bureaucratic state of the late 20th century, it may be essential that officials possess passion -the passion that puts them in touch with the dreams and disappointments of those with whom they deal.''
He added, ''Goldberg can be seen as injecting passion into a system whose abstract rationality had led it astray.''
While everyone who spoke at the conference agreed that the ruling was important, not all regarded it as correct.
Richard A. Epstein, a law professor from the University of Chicago, said that while the ruling was one of Justice Brennan's ''most powerful and artistic opinions,'' the holding was probably wrong, a misguided effort by the Federal judiciary to ''micromanage'' decisions best left to the political system.
And while the occasion was an anniversary celebration, the tone was more nostalgic and rueful than celebratory. Many participants spoke of Goldberg v. Kelly as a high-water mark not only of their own careers as young lawyers, but also of a bygone era in Supreme Court history.
 
A Summation, Not a Beginning
The decision was handed down on March 23, 1970, nine months after Warren E. Burger had replaced Earl Warren as Chief Justice. But in its spirit and method, Goldberg v. Kelly was the embodiment of the Warren Court, said Prof. Owen M. Fiss of Yale Law School. Chief Justice Burger dissented from the opinion, as did Justices Hugo L. Black and Potter Stewart.
Professor Fiss, a former law clerk to Justice Brennan and a self-described ''refugee from the 60's,'' said the decision came ''at an unusual historic moment, the end of one era and the beginning of another.'' Although many hoped that the ruling would prove to be the opening gun in a wide-ranging ''due-process revolution,'' he said, it proved instead to be ''not a new beginning, but a summation.''
The decision is not in danger of being overturned by the current Supreme Court, but neither is it likely to be cited as the basis for future rulings.
Professor Fiss said: ''Goldberg v. Kelly was handed down as American culture turned inward and we began to lose faith in the very idea of a public morality. We no longer believed that the Constitution or any other public law was an embodiment of a public morality to be known and elaborated through the exercise of reason.''
Prof. Minna J. Kotkin of Brooklyn Law School, who organized the conference, said the decision ''rests on a world view that seems almost quaintly, some might think naively, liberal in focus.'' She read to the audience a passage from Justice Brennan's opinion that was familiar to nearly everyone in the room.
 
'The Blessings of Liberty'
''From its founding, the nation's basic commitment has been to foster the dignity and well-being of all persons within its borders,'' Justice Brennan wrote. ''Public assistance, then, is not mere charity, but a means to 'promote the general Welfare, and secure the Blessings of Liberty to ourselves and our Posterity.' '' Justice Brennan's quotation was from the preamble to the Constitution.
''When I read these words,'' Professor Kotkin said, ''I think how far we have come over the last 20 years from that view.''
But if many at the conference appeared resigned to thinking of Goldberg v. Kelly as a cherished period piece, one participant exhorted the audience to use it as the basis for a renewed call to arms.
He was Charles A. Reich, now a visiting law professor at the University of San Francisco who is well known as the author of ''The Greening of America.'' But to the group gathered last week, the 62-year-old professor is best known as the author of ''The New Property,'' an article in the Yale Law Journal in 1964 that outlined some of the basic concepts incorporated by Justice Brennan in his opinion.
 
An Aspect of 'Property'
A central thesis of Professor Reich's article was that welfare benefits are not government gratuities that can be taken away at will, but are an aspect of the ''property'' that the Constitution shields against arbitrary government action. The 14th Amendment provides, ''Nor shall any State deprive any person of life, liberty, or property, without due process of law.''
At the conference, Professor Reich said that just as Goldberg v. Kelly had extended the concept of ''property,'' the Constitution now should be interpreted to give enhanced meanings to ''person'' and ''life.''
''Not for a minute should we concede that existence in a cardboard box on a city sidewalk is 'life' in the constitutional sense,'' he added. ''Not for a moment should we allow that a person without heat or shelter during a freezing winter possesses 'life, liberty and property' in the constitutional sense.''
Professor Reich said the definition of ''person'' should include ''what is organically necessary to life, or inseparably a part of the person.''
 
An 'Affirmative Obligation'
The Constitution was written ''when it was sufficient to be left alone,'' he said. But in a complex modern economy in which ''the world is like an expensive hotel where even the smallest needs cost money,'' being left alone puts many people at risk, he said, adding:
''The negative constitutional guarantee of one era becomes the affirmative obligation of another era, not because the words of the Constitution have changed, but because the Constitution cannot be given its true meaning without affirmative action.''
It was a speech that left the middle-aged law professors cheering, as if they were 20 years younger and heading into another Woodstock summer. And their reaction left little doubt that they would choose to stay home and work on the brief.

Law of New York University Law School passed up a chance to attend the Woodstock festival in 1969 to work on the case. (Dith Pran/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Auctions

BYLINE: By Rita Reif

 BODY:
How good will the results be from next week's sales in New York of artworks and prints produced over the last century? This question was on the minds of many of the thousands of collectors, dealers and auctioneers who attended this week's sales of contemporary art - the results of which were disappointing - or who plan to be at the auctions next Tuesday through Saturday of Impressionist and modern art. These major sales have been organized by Christie's, Sotheby's and Habsburg, Feldman, a Geneva-based house.
The bullish expectations for a combined sales total of more than $1 billion for this 13-day series of major auctions was based on the upward spiral of art prices that characterized the 1980's. The combined presale estimate for the May marathon of auctions, which began on Monday and continues through May 19, is $933 million to $1.25 billion. The record total for such a series - $930 million -was reached last November in New York.
This week, the fireworks that have become commonplace in recent seasons were absent from sales of works by Roy Lichtenstein, Willem de Kooning and Francis Bacon. Christie's two-day auction on Monday and Tuesday brought a total of $71.7 million, which was within its expectations of $66.4 million to $94.8 million. Of the 500 offerings, 352 were sold. 
At Sotheby's, 342 works were sold of the 532 presented on Tuesday and Wednesday. That sale totaled $82.2 million, a figure well below the house expectations of $120.6 million to $156.9 million.
The art to be presented next week goes on view this weekend and includes masterpieces by Vincent van Gogh, Pierre Auguste Renoir, Wassily Kandinsky, Amedeo Modigliani, Edouard Manet and Marc Chagall. Both houses are offering properties from major collections assembled by Robert Lehman, a financier who was chairman of the Metropolitan Museum of Art at his death in 1969; John Hay Whitney, financier, publisher, sportsman and ambassador; Siegfried Kramarsky, a German-born New York banker and philanthropist; Lydia Winston Malbin, daughter of the industrial architect Albert Kahn, and Margaret Ryan, the widow of John Barry Ryan Jr., an heir to a New York fortune in tobacco, railroads and banking.
 
Van Gogh and Renoir
The two artworks generating the greatest advance interest carry the highest presale estimates - $40 million to $50 million each. Van Gogh's ''Portrait of Dr. Gachet'' is to be auctioned from the Kramarsky collection in the sale at Christie's at 7 P.M. on Tuesday; Renoir's ''Moulin de la Galette'' from 1876 is being sold by Mr. Whitney's widow, Betsey Cushing Whitney, at Sotheby's on Thursday at 7 P.M. The art historian John Rewald, an adviser to the Whitneys for 40 years and the curator of the collection, describes this cafe scene as ''possibly the finest work Renoir painted.''
A number of dealers interviewed said the finest works in these sales would probably bring the prices expected, or slightly less. Others may not find buyers if the prices are too high or the material not fresh.
Stephen Hahn, a New York dealer, said: ''The extraordinary things will probably sell quite well - but probably not on the upper level of what the auction houses expect.''
Diane Upright, director of the Jan Krugier gallery in Manhattan, said: ''What happened this week is very healthy. Strong prices were paid for strong works of art. But there was also a serious questioning of works of lesser value.''
Julian Agnew, a London dealer, agreed. ''There is going to be a flight to quality,'' he said. ''The things that are new to the market and are thought by the market to be exceptional will continue to do well.''
Mr. Agnew said he expects the buying to be more erratic in these sales because the number of buyers has declined by 20 to 30 percent. ''The gamble element is much more prominent when the market is weaker,'' he said.
 
Inflated Estimates Don't Work
Desmond Corcoran, a London dealer, said he applauded the week's resistance to ever higher prices, and was distressed at the increased number of artworks estimated to sell for $10 million or more. ''When the estimates are a bit too high they don't work,'' he said. ''There are a lot of beautiful pictures in these sales, and most of them are fresh to the market. Then you see on the bottom of the page all these prices that start with 10. I don't know whose fault it is, whether the owners are too greedy or whether they are encouraged by the auction houses.''
Jeffrey Deitch, a Manhattan dealer, said he was delighted with the art sales this week. ''I continue to be completely optimistic,'' he said. ''This whole speculation game had to slow down. It was a cloud hanging over the serious art market. I'm happy that we see a little bit of the speculative froth taken off, so the art market can return to what it was -dominated by informed and passionate buyers.''
Arnold Glimcher of the Pace Gallery on East 57th Street said he was ''anti-auction'' because the houses manipulate the art market. ''How can they manufacture prices for works of art they sell?'' he asked. ''They put estimates on works that are four and five times what they are sold for in galleries. It makes collectors feel they can't buy things except at these prices.''
 
Five From Lehman Collection
The first auction next week at Christie's offers 81 works estimated to sell for $248.5 million to $334.9 million. The sale will offer, in addition to van Gogh's portrait of Dr. Gachet, five works from the Lehman collection - a van Gogh self-portrait and four paintings of women by Modigliani, Toulouse-Lautrec, Renoir, and Kees van Dongen - valued in all at $40 million to $60 million. Mrs. Ryan's ''Bench'' (1881), by Manet, a sun-filled geranium-brightened garden, is estimated at $20 million to $25 million. Christie's will also auction a classic diamond painting from 1925 by Piet Mondrian, a crisp rendering in red, blue, yellow, black and white that is expected to bring $12 million to $16 million.
Christopher Burge, president of Christie's in New York, said he did not know whether the contemporary-art sales reflect problems in the American economy: ''Whether American buyers may be more strapped than foreign buyers, who will be more active in next week's sales.''
When asked whether the reserves on artworks - the prices below which they will not be sold - will be lowered in next week's sales, Mr. Burge said: ''We are trying to in some areas where it might be prudent. We are looking to see whether some things may have been overpriced.''
David J. Nash, who heads fine-art sales at Sotheby's, said that reviewing reserves goes on before every sale, and that this sale is no exception.
 
An Odoriferous Brancusi Egg
The value of the art in the evening sessions of these auctions is wide ranging, and one of the more unusual offerings at Sotheby's on Wednesday at 7 P.M. is a painted egg by Constantin Brancusi, which is estimated to sell for $6,000 to $8,000. According to Sotheby's catalogue, ''The Kiss,'' as the egg is called - its four images painted in silver and black depict the artist's 1908 sculpture of the same name - was completed ''certainly by 1952.'' The egg was presented as a gift to Mrs. Malbin that year by the previous owners. The egg, now cracked and odorous, stands in a small glass cup, covered by a glass dome to contain the smell.
The egg is one of the more humble in the Malbin collection of 93 Futurist and modern works in the sale. At the other end of the price scale in this collection, which is estimated to bring $56.5 million to $74.8 million, is Brancusi's ''Blond Negress,'' a golden-hued bronze from 1928 that is estimated to sell for $8 million to $10 million, and Leger's ''Woman in an Armchair,'' which is expected to sell for $10 million to $12 million.
Sotheby's is to be the setting for the sale of three noted paintings from the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum -Kandinsky's ''Fugue,'' from 1914; Modigliani's ''Boy With a Blue Jacket,'' from 1918, and Chagall's ''Anniversaire,'' from 1923. The museum is selling these paintings, valued in all at $22 million to $31 million, to help finance its planned multimillion-dollar purchase of more than 200 Minimalist and other works from the collection of Count Giuseppe Panza di Biumo.
Habsburg, Feldman is to auction 78 works on Monday at 7 P.M. at the Regency Hotel, Park Avenue at 61st Street. Among the works by Claude Monet, Renoir, van Dongen and Leger, with a total value of $35.4 million to $47.1 million, is van Dongen's oil on canvas ''The Dancers - Revel and Coco,'' from 1906, which is expected to sell for $2 million to $2.5 million.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:
The Economy
In an extraordinary meeting, the top U.S. banking regulators urged banking executives to continue lending to creditworthy customers. Their remarks were interpreted as a signal to the banking community that the Government does not want to see regional pockets of tight credit throughout the economy. [Page A1.] 
Americans took out $2.6 billion more in consumer credit than they paid off in March, as borrowing to buy automobiles rebounded from February, the Government said. [D4.]
Apparel stores continued to outperform the rest of the retailing industry in April, helped by sales of Easter and spring merchandise. [D4.]
New York's legislative leaders scrapped a plan to impose sales taxes on services like management consulting. [B3.]
 
 
 
Companies
Cummins Engine's chairman has rid his company of a threat posed by a large dissident shareholder who could have upset the turnaround plan set in motion several years ago. [D1.]
Rules aimed at limiting insurers' ''junk bond'' ownership were approved by representatives of state regulatory agencies. [D1.]
Bell Atlantic and the Treasury said they had settled a dispute over whether the company had misled the Government. [D1.]
Donald Trump has arranged to sell his 282-foot yacht in Japan for about $110 million, Wall Street executives and a lawyer close to the deal said. [D3.]
Defying a veto threat, the House passed a measure that would require companies to grant workers up to three months of unpaid leave for the birth of children or to tend to ill family members. [B6.]
Wellcome has dropped its plans to develop and sell a drug for heart attack victims in the wake of a jury decision that the drug infringes patents held by Genentech. [D3.]
 
International
Japan's first commercial venture to launch private satellites is planned by some of the nation's largest industrial and electronics companies. [D1.]
Helmut Kohl said the East German Government must agree to major economic changes in the proposed state treaty before currency union. [A12.]
Animosity by Americans toward Japan has become ''a tidal wave'' despite recent market-opening moves, Carla Hills told Congress. [D2.]
 
 
 
Markets
The Treasury wrapped up its refunding auctions by selling $10 billion worth of 30-year bonds at yield levels well below what most analysts had thought possible little more than a week ago. [D1.]
Stocks barely advanced, even on signs that interest rates could be on the way down. The Dow rose 5.63, to 2,738.51. [D6.]
The dollar gained ground against the yen and the pound, but it fell to two-year lows against the Swiss franc and mark. [D13.]
Grain and soybean futures closed mostly higher in quiet trading. Copper was mixed, energy futures were mostly lower. [D13.]
