HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Bond Sale's Yields Defy Predictions

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The Treasury wrapped up its quarterly refunding auctions yesterday by selling $10 billion worth of 30-year bonds at yield levels well below what most credit market analysts had thought possible little more than a week ago.
Bids at the auction produced an average yield on the new bonds of 8.84 percent, up from 8.50 percent at the last bond sale on Feb. 8. Yesterday's yield was the highest on a new 30-year bond since the auction of May 11, 1989.
After reviewing the results, dealers said the auction was a success, but not a resounding one. Nevertheless, a week ago traders were expecting that yields of 9 percent or more would be needed to sell the securities. 
 
Effect of Employment Data
That view was abruptly altered by the release on May 4 of April employment data that were much weaker than anticipated. The figures, by indicating a lack of inflationary pressure in the economy, sparked a strong rally in Treasury prices last Friday. That development put market participants in a much more positive frame of mind as the refunding auctions began.
Just under $20 billion worth of bids were placed for the $10 billion in securities that were sold - about an average demand, dealers said. Demand at a bond auction is seen to be strong when the so-called ''coverage'' ratio is greater than 2 to 1.
Dealers said that bidding at the auction was helped by the dollar, which firmed yesterday against most major currencies after sliding sharply on Wednesday. The sudden weakness in the dollar helped drive up yields on the $10 billion worth of 10-year notes sold on Wednesday. [Page D13.] Bidding by the Japanese The dollar rose against the yen yesterday, but that was apparently not a factor for the Japanese, who placed bids on an estimated $2.5 billion worth of bonds, or about 25 percent of the issue. In the past, Japanese bids for more than 30 percent of a new Treasury bond auction were not uncommon.
Even though the base of potential investors is different, yesterday's sale also suffered in comparison with Tuesday's auction of three-year notes and Wednesday's sale of 10-year notes. Bids at those auctions reached record proportions. ''This one was not quite as strong as the other two auctions,'' said James A. Capra, a senior vice president at Shearson Lehman Government Securities.
Nevertheless, the issue traded well after the results of the 1 P.M. sale were announced at about 3:45 yesterday afternoon. In late trading, the bond was offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.81 percent.
''There was a lot of speculative interest in the securities, but legitimate investor interest from Asia in this issue was probably the lowest I have seen in the five years I have been here,'' said William M. Brachfeld, an executive vice president at Daiwa Securities America Inc.
Since the start of the year, rising interest rates in Japan and Western Europe have acted as a powerful disincentive for big Japanese financial institutions to purchase dollar-denominated fixed-income securities.
 
Benefits for Secondary Market
The positive auction results and the firmer dollar had a salutary effect on prices in the secondary market for Treasury securities.
By late in the day, the Treasury's 8 1/2 percent bonds due 2020 were offered at a price of 96 15/32, up a quarter point, to yield 8.83 percent.
Among note issues, the 8 7/8 percent two-year notes were offered in late trading at 100 11/32, up 2/32, to yield 8.67 percent.
The securities that were auctioned earlier in the week also fared well.
In when-issued trading, the 8 5/8 percent three-year notes auctioned on Tuesday were offered at a price to yield 8.72 percent. And the 8 7/8 percent 10-year notes sold on Wednesday were offered on a when-issued basis at a price to yield 8.81 percent. At the 10-year auction, the securities had an average yield of 8.88 percent.
Short-term Treasury bill rates eased slightly.
In late trading, three-month bills were offered at a discount rate of 7.69 percent, down 4 basis points, or hundredths of a percentage point. Six-month bill rates fell by 5 basis points, to a late offered rate of 7.70 percent. And one-year bills were offered at 7.72 percent, down 4 basis points.
 
Producer Price Data Today
Although economists doubt there will be unpleasant surprises, the market's firm tone could be jolted by retail sales and producer price data to be released this morning.
To the market, the April producer price figures are likely to be the day's most important numbers. In advance of the release, most economists were projecting a modest rise of two-tenths of a percentage point for last month's producer prices. A significantly higher number would rekindle fears about inflation.
In the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds, dealers said that prices of most issues rose by about one-eighth point on fairly thin trading. Meanwhile, prices in the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds posted healthy gains of between three-eighths and one-half point, traders said.
In other developments, the Federal Reserve Board reported yesterday that all three measures of the nation's money supply fell during the week ended April 30. The report had no impact on credit-market prices.

HEADLINE: New Arena for Japanese Business: Space

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: TOKYO, May 10

 BODY:
After years of sitting on the sidelines of the space business, some of Japan's largest industrial and electronics companies are joining forces in the country's first commercial venture to launch private satellites into orbit, Government and industry executives say.
The move will place Japan's newest rocket, the H-II, into direct competition with Europe's Arianespace and commercial services in the United States, China and the Soviet Union.
Aerospace is one of the few high-tech areas where Japan has traditionally lagged behind other nations, and the move to enter the commercial space business seems certain to draw political fire from abroad. Only last month, the United States and Japan ended a trade dispute over the Japanese Government's role in developing communications satellites; the Government is also paying for the development of the H-II.
With the field so crowded, there are strong fears here that Japan may be too late and its rockets too expensive to pose a serious competitive threat - unless the Government or the companies act to reduce vastly the cost of a launching. 
The companies involved are among Japan's biggest and best known. They include NEC, Toshiba, Nissan, Hitachi, Fujitsu, Kawasaki Heavy Industries, Ishikawajima-Harima Heavy Industries and Mitsubishi Electric.
The 13-company consortium, which has yet to be formally announced, is led by Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, and as many as 77 companies are eventually expected to share the risk in the effort, a Mitsubishi spokesman said. Mitsubishi is also building the H-II rocket, the first in the 20-year history of Japan's civilian space agency to be developed without a great deal of American technology.
The H-II is still under development, and the first launching is not scheduled until early 1993 - a year later than planned because of unexpected troubles with the rocket's liquid fuel engine. But the consortium appears to be positioning itself to begin launching services as soon as the rocket is successfully tested by the National Space Development Agency of Japan, which is known here as Nasda and plays a role similar to that of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration in the United States.
The Japanese space agency has welcomed the move as a way of decreasing the cost of the H-II by increasing the number of rockets that will be ordered from Mitsubishi.
 
Concerned About Demand
''It is certainly not too early to think about providing our rockets to international markets,'' Masato Yamano, the president of Nasda, said in an interview at his office here on Wednesday. But he cautioned, ''There are many nations already providing this kind of service, and I don't know if there is enough demand.''
Mr. Yamano estimated that it would cost more than $100 million to build and launch an H-II, making it significantly more expensive than the competition. But if the cost can be lowered, the most obvious potential users are some of Japan's own satellite and communications companies, which until now have been using France's Ariane service.
The new rocket initiative may have been bolstered earlier this year when an Ariane rocket exploded over the Atlantic just after launching, destroying two Japanese communications satellites.
''The hope is that in the future Japanese companies will choose to launch their satellites here,'' a Mitsubishi spokesman said this week.
The private space launching business blossomed after the loss of the space shuttle Challenger on Jan. 28, 1986. With the shuttle program grounded, there were fears that scores of payloads, mostly communications satellites, would have no way into orbit.
But several countries moved quickly. While other nations prepared to turn their rockets into commercial space vehicles, however, Japan held back, in part because its current H-I rocket is not powerful enough to carry large satellites.
 
'We Sat on Our Hands'
''It was very frustrating,'' a Japanese space scientist here said recently. ''Even China was launching satellites, while we sat on our hands.'' He was referring to China's successful launching last month of an American satellite, after President Bush decided to make an exception to current sanctions against that country.
Though most of Japan's past rockets have been the space equivalents of compact cars, the H-II will be the first to move up to mid-size. It is capable of launching a two-ton satellite into stationary orbit, or a 10-ton satellite into low earth orbit. But That is significantly smaller than the payload capacity of the Titan III or the Titan IV, two of the most powerful American rockets.
Under Japan's plan, the new company - to be formed in July - will buy the H-II from Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, the prime contractor. Initially, the company will sell those rockets to the space agency for the Government's own launchings. Using the company as a middle man, the Government can order several rockets at once, which in turn should reduce the cost of producing them. But the company will also begin offering the same rocket technology to private clients. Still, it is not clear how the Japanese consortium will be able to offer a competitive launching service without absorbing huge losses or receiving significant Government subsidies.
So far, no such subsidies appear to be in the offing. ''Direct subsidies would be very, very difficult under the current political situtation,'' said Maskazu Yoshida, the deputy director of the space division of Japan's Ministry of International Trade and Industry.
Other countries subsidize their rocket programs. Indeed, many of the rockets themselves, including those used in the United States, were originally developed by the military. But because of a ban on producing offensive weapons imposed after World War II, Japan's military has no rockets, so the cost of development has been borne by the civilian space agency.
 
U.S. Complaints
But the United States is particularly sensitive to Government subsidies in Japan. It was just such a subsidy that led the United States to complain that Japan was giving an unfair advantage to its satellite industry, financing research and development for satellites that would ultimately be used for commercial purposes. In the meantime, the United States said, the Japanese Government was refusing to purchase American-made satellites, even though several of them have been sold to private industry in Japan.
Japan denied the charge and said its satellite program, called CS-4, was chiefly for research purposes. But last month, in the rush to settle the ''301'' trade issues, named for the section of the trade act that could bring sanctions on a nation deemed to be an unfair trader, Japan backed down.
Japanese newspapers have speculated in recent days that the satellite agreement may have sped plans to commercialize the H-II. The prospect that fewer Japanese-made satellites might be launched by the Government or private industry, the Nihon Keizei Shimbun suggested recently, made it more imperative to find outside users for the H-II.
The H-II is a two-stage, liquid-fueled rocket with two solid-rocket boosters strapped on to provide extra power to lift it out of the atmosphere. The rocket is 161 feet long, or slightly longer than one of the giant solid-fuel booster rockets used on the American space shuttle, and 13 feet in diameter.
The project to develop the rocket was proceeding smoothly until last year, when one of the liquid-fuel engines blew up. The problem was traced to design flaws. A more recent test of the repaired rocket was successful, but the project was set back by a year.
''We think we are now back on track,'' said Mr. Yamano of Nasda.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Pressures Mount For a Budget Deal

BYLINE: By Leonard Silk

 BODY:
POWERFUL forces have been pushing the President and the Democratic leadership of Congress toward a deal to cut the widening budget deficit, even if that involves an increase in taxes. The deficit could soar to well over $200 billion in the fiscal year 1991 as a result of lower revenues, higher interest payments and a bigger bill for bailing out savings and loan institutions than the Administration expected.
Thus, the most powerful force for a deal is coming from the worsening deficit and its threat to the national economy and business interests.
The Business Roundtable, a forum of top executives of major corporations, addressed a letter a month ago to key members of Congress declaring: ''In the brief period of the past decade, we have amassed trillions of dollars of debt; we have regressed from being the largest creditor nation in the world to the biggest debtor; we have witnessed the Federal deficit absorb over half our net private savings; we have become increasingly dependent upon foreign capital, inexorably ceding our influence over both our domestic and international policies. And we have embarked upon a course which cannot be sustained without high cost - economic, social and human.'' The Roundtable urged ''all responsible political leaders to seize this opportunity to forge a consensus for comprehensive deficit reduction.'' 
President Bush has been trying to respond to such pleas. Weeks ago, he sent budget director Richard G. Darman forth, like a dove of peace, to persuade the leaders of both parties in Congress to meet with him to work out a budget consensus.
The Democrats were willing to talk, provided they would not be branded with the blame of trying to force a tax increase on the President. And Mr. Bush seemed ready to yield on taxes, provided the Democrats did not attack him for abandoning his election promise not to raise taxes.
But this ''no fault'' deal seems to be falling apart. Conservative Republicans are more ferocious than the Democrats in going after the President should he drop his ''read my lips, no new taxes'' promise. And some liberals are willing to let the Republicans stew in their own juice, as the budget deficit soars.
Indeed, the main threat to President Bush's hopes for being a two-term President may not be higher taxes but the soaring deficit, rising interest rates and a steep recession that would come before the 1992 election.
But would a deal to shrink the budget deficit by the $100 billion or more now required by Gramm-Rudman for the coming fiscal year not itself endanger the economic expansion? Keynesian analysis suggests that with the economy already weak, so big a cut would cause a recession.
But Mr. Bush's conservative economic advisers believe it is possible to keep the economy growing without inflation by measures to increase saving and investment: that is, by cutting the budget deficit, reducing taxes on business and capital and easing monetary policy.
Cutting the deficit, according to this analysis, would bring down interest rates and give a thrust to business investment. At the same time, it would help reduce the value of the dollar in the foreign exchanges, spurring American exports.
Although Mr. Bush's advisers believe that the best way to cut the deficit would be simply to reduce public spending, they recognize that the cuts would be huge and could be a political liability. And they are also willing, for the sake of deficit cutting, to make a deal with the Democrats even if that involves some tax increases.
Cutting the deficit is also important to enable the Federal Reserve to get out of its box. The Fed can hardly ease money lest it aggravate inflation, and it is afraid to tighten money lest it worsen the danger of recession. But, as Harold van Buren Cleveland observes in a study, ''Recasting Europe's Economies:'' ''With public deficits reduced, there is room for a more accommodating monetary policy to help channel the savings released by the public sector into private investment.''
Mr. Bush's right wing has thus far rejected any deal involving tax increases; yet a deal may still lie ahead. It is still too soon to know what that deal would look like. Agreement can probably be reached on increases in excise taxes, but almost certainly not on personal income taxes across the board. A national sales tax or value-added tax can almost certainly not be negotiated at this time because the preparatory work for it has not yet been done.
Mr. Bush may be able to get the cut in the capital gains tax he seeks, but only in exchange for eliminating the ''bubble'' in the personal income tax schedule by raising the top rate to 33 percent from 28 percent for taxpayers earning more than $200,000 a year. On the spending side, the contending parties appear close enough to make a deal on military cuts for fiscal 1991. On Capitol Hill there is talk of a pending deal to take Social Security off budget, though that would necessitate modifying Gramm-Rudman targets and extending the time period for achieving budget balance.
For any of this to happen, the political crossfire in Washington will have to be halted. But it is proving as difficult to get a budgetary truce in Washington as a lasting military truce in Beirut.

HEADLINE: Hills Defends White House Move on Japan Trade

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10

 BODY:
The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, told Congress today that despite recent moves by the Japanese to open their markets, the animosity toward Japan in this country had become ''a tidal wave and you have to run very fast to be in front of it.''
Her testimony before the House Energy Committee's Subcommittee on Commerce, Consumer Protection and Competitiveness tested the temper of Congress this election year on the exemption of Japan from the ''Super 301'' sanctions of the 1988 trade law and on protectionism in general.
This was the trade chief's first appearance before Congress since the Bush Administration decided on April 27 to drop Japan from a list of countries subject to reprisal tariffs because of their unfair trade practices.
 
Possible Election Issue
If the economy should fall into a recession, then recriminations against the Administration over softness toward Japan could become a major election issue, Democratic and Republican pollsters agree. 
Subcommittee members, facing re-election battles in what could be a deteriorating economic climate, challenged the decision and Mrs. Hills's explanation behind it - that Japan was making a ''remarkable transformation'' in ''abandoning support for protectionism.''
Representative Don Ritter of Pennsylvania, the subcommittee's senior Republican, said the United States was getting ''crumbs off a big cracker.''
The subcommittee's chairman, Doug Walgren, a Pennsylvania Democrat, accused the Administration of ''failing to implement the law the way Congress intended.''
Representative Howard C. Nielson, Republican of Utah, alluded to the ''belief of many members of Congress'' that Japan was not cited because President Bush did not want to undermine the newly re-elected Japanese Prime Minister, Toshiki Kaifu. After meeting with Mr. Bush in March, Mr. Kaifu had pledged to make trade liberalization the highest priority of his cabinet.
 
Japan's Reputation
In her testimony, Mrs. Hills noted that there was pent-up American hostility toward Japan because its markets had been closed for so long. ''Japan is going to suffer for a while for its reputation, even when it begins to open up,'' she said.
Mrs. Hills said that because of this animosity, the Japanese needed to ''try to move much more rapidly.''
In defending the President's trade decision, Mrs. Hills mentioned the increased concern of Japanese consumers about high prices; the series of recent agreements with the Japanese that would open their markets in telecommunications, supercomputers, satellites and wood products, and the sweeping changes that were promised in Japanese economic society under the so-called Structural Impediments Initiative undertaken by the two governments last year.
She also noted that American exports to Japan rose twice as fast last year as those to the rest of the world and they exceeded the total exports to West Germany, France and Italy.
 
'Farther and Faster'
''Japan has moved farther and faster on outstanding trade issues that any of our trading partners this year,'' she told the subcommittee.
Noting that foreign partners consider it ''offensive'' to be cited by the United States as unfair traders, Mrs. Hills said Japan's support was needed to achieve a successful conclusion in the Uruguay Round of global trade liberalization talks.
More than 105 countries are participating in the four-year-old effort to strengthen the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, the world's free-trade charter. An agreement is being sought to widen markets in agriculture and services and to improve protection for patents, copyrights and other so-called intellectual property.
Mr. Walgren, the subcommittee chairman, called on the Administration to join in efforts to extend the Super 301 provision of the 1988 legislation, which expires this year. But Mrs. Hills showed little sympathy for the idea because it limited the Administration's discretion.
Besides citing countries for unfair trade practices, the law requires the Administration to establish trade objectives and creates rigorous deadlines for these objectives to be met.

HEADLINE: Foreign Landowners

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10

 BODY:
Foreigners continue to own just under 1 percent of the nation's agricultural land, a level that has varied little over the years, the Agriculture Department said today. The department's Economic Research Service made its 1989 end of the year review of reports under a 1978 law requiring foreigners to register American agricultural land holdings. As of Dec. 31, 1989, about 12.9 million acres of agricultural land were owned by foreigners, an increase of 263,273 acres from a year earlier. Of the land owned by foreign interests, 46 percent was forest land, 18 percent cropland, 31 percent pasture and other agricultural land, and 5 percent agricultural land not under cultivation.

HEADLINE: Consumer Credit Rises

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 10

 BODY:
Americans took out $2.6 billion more in consumer credit than they paid off in March, as borrowing to buy automobiles rebounded from February, the Government said today.
But with the dampening of economic growth this year, consumers have been borrowing less since January. The first quarter had an annualized growth rate of 2.7 percent, which compares with 7.6 percent for all of 1988 and 8.5 percent for 1987. 
The Federal Reserve said consumer credit in March increased at a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 4.4 percent, up from a scant one-tenth of 1 percent rise in February. The February figure represented a sharp revision from the 5.7 percent rate estimated earlier and made the month the weakest in a year.
Credit grew at a 3.7 percent annual rate in January, rather than the earlier estimate of 6.4 percent, the Fed said.
 
Less Appetite Seen for Borrowing
Sandra Shaber, an economist with the Washington consulting firm Futures Group, said the economy had been expanding for so long, seven and a half years, that consumers had less appetite for expensive items purchased with loans.
''I think there also has been an erosion of consumer confidence,'' she said. ''People are worried.''
She continued, ''They read in the paper that the unemployment rate went up or that interest rates are going up.''
Automobile loans in March advanced $1.8 billion, a 7.5 percent annual rate, after falling at a 5.2 percent rate in February and advancing at only a 1.7 percent rate in January.
 
Rise in Credit Card Debt
Credit card debt rose by $2 billion, or a 12.1 percent annual rate, in March, up from a 4.7 percent rate a month earlier.
Loans by banks, savings and loans and credit unions that were not secured by real estate were down $1.2 billion, a 7.2 percent rate, after climbing at a 3 percent rate in February.
Borrowing for mobile homes rose $17 million, a scant nine-tenths of 1 percent annual rate, after rising at a 1.7 percent rate in Fenruary.
The various changes left total consumer debt at the end of March at $721.5 billion.

HEADLINE: Dow Is Up Only 5.63 Despite Rate Outlook

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Stocks barely advanced yesterday, even after results of the Treasury's $10 billion bond sale showed that interest rates could be on the way down.
When final returns came in a quarter-hour before the 4 P.M. closing, the average yield on the bellwether 30-year issue stood at 8.84 percent, a level viewed as favorable for stocks.
Volume on the New York Stock Exchange swelled to 158.5 million shares - the first time trading had been that strong since early April. But the Dow Jones industrial average rose only 5.63 points, to 2,738.51. Advances outnumbered declines by 847 to 601. 
 
'Speculators Weren't That Quick'
''Maybe speculators weren't that quick on the trigger,'' said Robert H. Stovall, president of Twenty-First Advisers Inc., ''but it's still positive.''
He maintained that with the interest rate under 9 percent, ''We could see very favorable price and volume action'' today.
He noted, too, that buying was strong in such industry leaders as A.T.&T., I.B.M., General Motors, NCR and AMR.
A.T.&T. rose 3/4, to 41 1/4, on 1.4 million shares. I.B.M. added 1 1/8, to 112 3/8, on 1.8 million. G.M. tacked on 3/8, to 46 3/4, on 1.3 million shares. NCR rose 1/4, to 68 1/8, on 292,500. AMR rose 3/8, to 63 3/8, on 438,700 shares.
Among other blue chips, Eastman Kodak, the third-most-active Big Board stock, rose a point, to 39 1/8, on 2.1 million shares. Commenting on Wall Street estimates that Polaroid's patent-infringement suit could cost $1 billion, Kay Whitmore, Kodak's incoming chief executive, said at the annual meeting Wednesday that the company ''can handle anything within what the Street talks about.'' He said there were no present plans to sell assets to meet the cost.
 
Stirring Talk by G.E. Chairman
John Welch, the chairman of General Electric, gave a stirring speech to analysts on Wednesday, and G.E. rose 1/2, to 67 1/4, on 2.6 million shares.
Westinghouse Electric fell 2, to 72, after reaching a new 52-week low of 71 1/4, on 1.1 million shares. Paul E. Lego, president of Westinghouse and soon to become chairman, met with analysts in Palm Beach, Fla., last Tuesday, but some analysts seemed disappointed.
''People went away concerned with the new leadership of the company in a very difficult competitive environment,'' said Robert W. McCoy Jr., electrical equipment analyst for UBS Securities Inc. He said that despite rumors that Westinghouse might be interested in buying Sundstrand, an aerospace parts company, no mention was made of the situation. Sundstrand, which reached a high of 75 1/2, closed unchanged at 74 1/4.
 
Commodity Research Index Dips
In another sign that stocks may soon rise, the Commodity Research Bureau index - which reached a new 1990 high of 247.79 on Wednesday -fell 0.17 point, to 247.62.
Stuart Shinbein, senior technical editor of the research bureau, said that he was advising commodity traders that ''we've now approached a point where profit taking outweighs staying with bullish positions.''
''If the index goes down,'' he said, ''that's a plus for bond prices,'' which in turn would be a plus for stocks because stock and bond prices generally rise and fall together.
In other strong moves, ITT rose 2, to 54 3/4, in heavy trading after the conglomerate told analysts that it might sell part of its 37 percent stake in Alcatel, the European telecommunications company, to Compagnie Generale d'Electricite of France. The ITT stake could be worth as much as $3 billion, analysts said.
 
Gains for Drug Stocks
Bristol-Myers Squibb, which rose 1/2 Wednesday, touching a new 52-week high then, rose another 7/8, to 59 3/8, on 1.7 million shares and reached a new 52-week high of 59 5/8.
Drug stocks, buoyed by the market rise, advanced briskly. American Home Products rose 3/4, to 50 7/8. American Cyanamid rose 5/8, to 53 3/4, after its Lederle Labs said it had won marketing rights to a new hypertension agent developed by the Elan Corporation. C. R. Bard rose 3/8, to 17 3/8; Johnson & Johnson 3/8, to 58 3/4; Eli Lilly 5/8, to 69 5/8; Medtronic 1 1/8, to 71, and Millipore 1 1/8, to 31 7/8.
Columbia Gas System, thought to be a target of the Coastal Corporation, fell 2, to 45 5/8, after Oscar Wyatt, Coastal's chairman, told stockholders at the annual meeting that it had ''no plans'' to add to its shares.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Firmer Against Yen; Swiss Franc Continues Rise

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
The dollar gained ground against the yen and the British pound yesterday, but it fell to two-year lows against the Swiss franc and West German mark.
The dollar had fallen sharply on Wednesday against all four currencies.
Investors continued yesterday to flock to the Swiss franc, sending the dollar to levels not seen since April 1988. In New York trading, the dollar fell to 1.3915 Swiss francs, down from 1.4020. 
''It's the Swiss leading the way here and it has been for the last 48 hours,'' said Andrew Elliott, a foreign-exchange dealer at the Chase Manhattan Bank in London.
The Swiss currency moved higher in overseas trading, and dealers struggled to assess whether talk that $2 billion had been sold to buy Swiss francs was more than a rumor.
''It may have happened,'' said Bob Morrissey, a senior trader with the Bank of Boston. The franc has been rising, the traders said, because of high Swiss interest rates, strong Asian demand and the increasing view of the franc as a ''safe haven'' currency.
The dollar finished mixed in Europe and initially rose when trading shifted to the United States. But the American currency fell back when the traders, ''who retain an overwhelmingly bearish outlook, sold into the dollar's strength,'' said Marc Chandler, an analyst with MMS International Inc. in Chicago.
The traders are also nervously awaiting the Government's release today of the Producer Price Index and retail sales figures, both for April, which are expected to point to an economic slowdown.
If that is the case, Mr. Chandler predicted that there would be ''further dollar declines because there is no reasonable expectation'' that the Federal Reserve would raise interest rates.
Higher interest rates stem the inflation, but also enhance the dollar's attractiveness by making American fixed-income securities more valuable for investors.
The belief that the economy is slowing also worked to push the dollar down against the West German mark to levels not seen since January 1988. It fell in New York to 1.6325 West German marks, down from 1.6365.
Against the Japanese currency, the dollar rose, ending the trading day in New York at 156.73 yen, up from 156.50 yen on Wednesday.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with those on Wednesday, included: 5.5115 French francs, up from 5.5100; 1,202.75 Italian lire, down from 1,203.25, and 1.1703 Canadian dollars, up from 1.1660.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold prices fell after rising overseas.

HEADLINE: India Rejects U.S. Talks

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, May 10

 BODY:
India today rejected talks with the United States over removing India from the American list of countries singled out for unfair trading practices.
India is not going to be ''intimidated or policed'' by anybody on the issue of a country's sovereignty and economic independence,'' the Commerce Minister, Arun Nehru, told Parliament. 
It was the first time that Indian officials have openly rejected negotiations with the United States over the trade issue.
On April 27, President Bush cited India under a 1988 law that provides for economic sanctions if protective trade barriers are not eliminated. Mr. Bush removed Japan and Brazil from the list, leaving India the only country on it.
India has refused to modify its restrictive trade policies, which are intended to protect domestic industries by limiting foreign investment and imposing high import duties.
Under the 1988 law, Washington could levy tariffs of up to 100 percent on goods imported from a nation judged an unfair trader.

HEADLINE: U.S. Chip Index Is Unchanged

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, April 9

 BODY:
Sales of computer chips to the United States market declined in April, but the semiconductor industry's leading indicator remained constant, an industry group said today.
 
The Semiconductor Industry
Association, based in Cupertino, Calif., reported a book-to-bill ratio of 1.09 for the three-month period that ended in April, the same as in March and up from a revised figure of 1.08 in February. 
The ratio compares orders with shipments and is considered a leading indicator of the industry's performance. A ratio of 1.09 indicates that for every $100 worth of product shipped, $109 was ordered, indicating that demand has continued to rise.
At $1.28 billion, three-month orders for April were up 1 percent from $1.27 billion for the period ending in March and down 2.7 percent from the figure posted a year ago, which was $1.31 billion.
Three-month average shipments for April totaled $1.17 billion, up slightly from March's $1.16 billion. At $1.11 billion, United States market shipments for April were 14.2 percent lower than March's $1.30 billion.

HEADLINE: PRODUCER PRICES FALL 0.3% IN SIGN INFLATION IS EASING

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE

 BODY:
The wintertime jump in the nation's inflation rate appears to be wearing off, and inflation seems to be settling back to the moderate level that has prevailed over the last two years, a Government report indicated yesterday.
The Labor Department said its index of prices covering a wide range of products ready for sale to retailers fell by three-tenths of 1 percent in April, mostly because of sharp drops in food and energy prices. But excluding these volatile categories, the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods rose a mild two-tenths of 1 percent, continuing a trend that began in February.
Two other reports reinforced the perception that inflation was coming down - employment numbers released last week showed a rise in the unemployment rate, to 5.4 percent from 5.2 percent, and the Commerce Department reported yesterday that retail sales fell by six-tenths of 1 percent in April. 
 
'On Just the Right Track'
''What a difference a week makes,'' said David Jones, senior vice president of Aubrey G. Lanston & Company, a Wall Street bond house. ''Before the unemployment numbers, the fear was that the economy was too strong, inflation too high and the Fed might raise interest rates. But now it appears the economy is on just the right track.''
The stock and bond markets appeared to agree, shaking off fears of inflation or recession. The Dow Jones industrial average jumped 63.07 points yesterday, to a near-record 2,801.58, and prices of Treasury securities surged, bringing interest rates down. The rate on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 8.66 percent, from 8.83 percent the day before. [Pages 31 and 34.] Rightly or wrongly, the markets concluded that the Federal Reserve Board was not likely to raise or lower interest rates, which is the Federal Reserve's way of fighting inflation and recession, respectively. The reasoning of the markets is that the latest data portray an economy neither strong enough to push inflation higher than its average level for the last two years, nor so weak that it is likely to fall below that level.
''We are heading back to a normal inflation rate,'' said Donald Ratajczak, an inflation forecaster at Georgia State University - normal being annual rates since 1987 of 3 percent to 4 percent for the Producer Price Index and 4 percent to 5 percent for the Consumer Price Index. The winter spurt drove the producer index's average above 5 percent in the first quarter and the consumer index above 8 percent.
The producer index, a harbinger of inflation at the consumer level, had risen sharply from October through January but has fallen since then. April's drop was the biggest, prompting many economists to predict that the consumer index for April, due out Wednesday, would also begin to ease, after having risen sharply in the first quarter.
But now the special factors that made prices jump early are disappearing. A freeze in December pushed up energy prices in January, but they have been falling since February. Farmers in Florida replanted their fields in January, after the frost, and today they are flooding markets with vegetables, making prices plunge, the Labor Department said. Tomatoes, for example, fell by 73.3 percent in price from March to April.
And apparel prices, which rose sharply with the introduction of spring fashions early in the year, are no longer going up, mostly because consumers are overly cautious, surveys show.
 
Very Sharp Reversal
The April decline in the producer index came after a drop of two-tenths of 1 percent in March and no movement at all in February. The three-month trend is a very sharp reversal of the 1.8 percent increase in January and the rise of six-tenths of 1 percent in December.
But more important, the so-called core producer price index, one that measures prices of finished goods excluding the volatile food and energy sectors, has risen by steadily smaller amounts since February - four-tenths of 1 percent that month, three-tenths in March and the two-tenths in April. That brought the rise over the last 12 months down to 3.5 percent from 4.4 percent in March and 5.1 percent in February.
There were some price increases in April, of course. Prices rose for some foods, among them beef, fish, eggs, coffee and pasta. Pharmaceuticals, tobacco, toys, soaps and detergents also became more costly.
Although auto prices fell by nine-tenths of 1 percent, gasoline prices went up by 2.2 percent, to $1.03 a gallon at self-service stations and $1.20 at full-service stations, reflecting a predictable springtime rise in highway travel.
But over all, energy prices dropped 1.7 percent after declining in the two previous months, largely because of a 5.5 percent decline in natural gas costs.
The prices of machinery and other new factory equipment also rose.
 
Two Reasons Cited
Nigel Gault, senior economist at DRI/McGraw-Hill, an economic consulting service, cited two reasons for the higher cost of capital equipment: stepped-up manufacturing to fill export orders and a push to automate, thus cutting labor costs. Rising wages have helped sustain average inflation rates above 3 percent for the producer index and above 4 percent for the consumer index, many economists say.
Another index, one measuring producer prices at the intermediate level, rose a modest one-tenth of 1 percent. A jump in the cost of construction materials more than offset declining prices for steel, industrial chemicals, paperboard, some fabrics, aircraft engines and parts.
But the index for crude prices, measuring goods at the very first stage of production, was inflationary. Although this index fell over all in April by three-tenths of 1 percent, because of sharp drops in crude oil and raw-food prices, the index without food and energy rose by 2.2 percent after having risen by 2 percent in March. From November through February, it had fallen.
Robert Giordano, co-director of economic research at Goldman, Sachs & Company, said the rise might be a result of growing demand from manufacturers as they rebuilt inventories of some metals, among them copper and aluminum. The upward trend at the crude level would have to continue for several more months before it became an inflationary factor, he added.

HEADLINE: Bush, Trying to Quell Tax Debate, Insists Budget Talks Will Be Open

BYLINE: By MAUREEN DOWD, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: KINGSVILLE, Tex., May 11

 BODY:
Trying to quell the storm caused by the remarks of his chief of staff, President Bush insisted today that he was willing to discuss everything, including taxes, in the upcoming budget negotiations.
''There's no conditions, and that's the way it is,'' he said aboard Air Force One at the beginning of a trip to give a commencement address at Texas A&I University here in South Texas before going on to speak in South Carolina and Virginia. ''That's the way it's going to be, and that's the way it must be.''
In his first public remarks on the debate that has raged in Washington this week over the widening deficit, Mr. Bush said he would ignore the tension over the budget meeting next week and follow some advice from his mother. 
''Tomorrow there'll be another tidal wave, so keep your snorkel above the water level and do what you think is right,'' the President said. ''That's exactly what my Mom told me when I was about 6. Do your best. Do your best. I'm trying hard. Stay calm.''
 
A Signal of Reassurance
Mr. Bush tried to send a signal of reassurance to Democrats and Republicans who were upset over the remarks of his chief of staff, John H. Sununu, indicating that the White House was not interested in discussing new taxes with Congress.
Mr. Sununu was quoted in The Washington Post on Thursday as saying that the President's promise to discuss the budget with no preconditions about taxes simply meant that Democrats were free to propose taxes and the White House had the ''prerogative to say no, and I emphasize the 'no.' ''
Mr. Sununu, thinly disguised in The Post's account as ''a senior White House official,'' made his comments on the way home from Costa Rica, where he was attending the inauguration of its President, Rafael A. Calderon Jr. Mr. Sununu was clearly trying to appease a number of Republican members of Congress who were outraged by Mr. Bush's seeming willingness to bend on his campaign pledge of ''no new taxes,'' and some nervous Republican senators who wrote the President to suggest that an election year might not be the best time to back away from his promise.
 
Democratic Fears Exacerbated
But Mr. Sununu's comments backfired because they exacerbated Democratic fears that the White House was trying to draw them into a trap set up to blame them for a tax increase.
''We view this incident as an extremely serious one because it could, if repeated, threaten the success of these talks,'' the House Speaker, Representative Thomas S. Foley of Washington, said Thursday.
A similar view was expressed by Representative Leon E. Panetta, a California Democrat who is chairman of the House Budget Committee. ''We just can't continue to have this kind of sniping and political warfare going on at the same time we're trying to deal with a serious problem,'' he said.
Asked today if Mr. Sununu was in trouble for his remarks, the President replied: ''That's silly. So stupid.''
 
'Steady as She Goes'
''None of these Congressmen are in trouble either,'' he added, referring to the lawmakers in both parties who criticized plans for the budget talks. ''I'm approaching it very openly, and I recognize the controversy swirling around from one statement or another. But look, stay on track, steady as she goes. And be open, deal frankly with people and deal in the way I've said.''
The President, who strives for collegiality and consensus in governing, was clearly annoyed at the barbs flying back and forth between the White House and Capitol Hill. But, in an effort to calm the debate, he advised everyone to speak openly.
''Say what you think, Democrats, Republicans, back-benchers, columnists,'' he said. ''But I think the President has a certain responsibility to stay cool. Make clear to people that he's dealing in good faith and do my best.''
As far as possible tax increases, Mr. Bush said, ''I'm not going to show you my hand, and I haven't seen a lot of hands laid down on the Hill.''
 
Response From Bentsen
Senator Lloyd Bentsen, the Texas Democrat who heads the Senate Finance Committee, who was traveling on the plane with the President, indirectly criticized Mr. Sununu in referring to the budget meeting. ''I think it's back on track - as long as we keep these fellows in line who are trying to redefine it,'' Mr. Bentsen said.
Asked by reporters if he still believed the President was sincere in proposing the meeting, Senator Bentsen replied, ''I give him the benefit of the doubt.''
If Bush advisers were worried about the President's looking insincere, they were just as worried about his looking sincere - in putting taxes on the table - and would thus be accused of waffling.
Watching a clip of the television entertainer David Letterman making a joke Wednesday night about the President's new stance, ''Read my lips: I lied,'' a senior adviser cringed and murmured, ''That's harsh.''
In the days since Mr. Bush met with Congressional leaders from both parties at the White House last Sunday, his budget director, Richard G. Darman, and his press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, have said gloomier-than-predicted economic forecasts were forcing the Administration to reconsider all possibilities for cutting the deficit.
''We're not dealing in a crisis mentality,'' Mr. Bush said when asked about the deficit. ''But we've got a major deficit problem. We've got a law that says where it has to be.''

HEADLINE: A President Strong on Civil Rights

 BODY:
To the Editor:
''Dream, Yes, but Restore Rights'' (editorial, April 10) was an unjust criticism of President Bush's civil rights policy.
The President has a record of strong support for civil rights dating back over 40 years. From 1948, when he headed a drive for the United Negro College Fund at Yale, to his current support of several key pieces of civil rights legislation, President Bush has been a leading figure in the quest for racial equality. 
In just 15 months of the Bush Administration, there have been several outstanding legislative achievements. Last November, the President signed Public Order 101-180 (ii), extending the tenure of the Civil Rights Commission. He was also a strong supporter of the Hate Crimes Act, which was signed into law this week.
The President is also determined to help eliminate bias and bigotry by removing barriers to opportunity; he has asked Congress to increase funding for several important programs. The requested budgets for Head Start and aid for Historically Black Colleges and Universities have increased $500 million and $60 million, respectively. The President's new HOPE initiative, a program aimed at giving all people basic shelter and affordable housing, is budgeted at $4 billion over three years.
The President has also met with civil rights leaders on a number of occasions to discuss issues of critical concern to us all; from the drug plague that is poisoning our youth to the economic empowerment and development of minorities.
In other areas concerning civil rights, the President is an ardent supporter of the Americans with Disabilities Act, potentially the most sweeping anti-discrimination legislation in 24 years. He has also condemned, on numerous occasions, attacks on the civil rights of AIDS patients. Your criticism of the President's commitment to civil rights is unfounded. For more than 40 years, he has been an influential leader in the struggle to bring civil rights to all Ameri-cans.
 
DAVID F. DEMAREST JR.
 
Assistant to the President
 
for Communications
 Washington, April 25, 1990

TYPE: Letter

HEADLINE: Albany: Better, but Still Ducking

 BODY:
Budget-making this season in Albany continues to give New Yorkers a most discomfiting insight into the failings of their political leaders. With the budget already more than a month late, the state's top elected officials are still ducking the chance to do things right.
The latest offense came on the heels of a welcome show of common sense. Responding to strong business pressure, Gov. Mario Cuomo and legislative leaders agreed to drop a destructive plan to impose sales taxes on the healthiest segment of the state's troubled economy - services like advertising, public relations and management consulting. But after retreating from that folly, they embraced a new hodgepodge of taxes. 
The new package is an improvement over the discarded plan. But it isn't nearly as prudent or fair as broad-based taxes, like a surcharge on the personal income tax or an increase in the gasoline tax. The proposal includes a higher highway-use tax for large trucks, a 5 percent tax on car rentals, an increase in hotel and motel taxes and an increase in taxes paid by importers or processors of petroleum products - a small gas tax in disguise. To his credit, Assembly Speaker Mel Miller did propose a surcharge on the personal income tax. But he faced formidable opposition from Ralph Marino, the Senate majority leader. Mr. Marino has consistently thwarted budget negotiations this year, long refusing to face the reality of the state's growing budget deficit. He insisted that unspecified budget cuts would do the job, but still pressed for unreasonable increases in school aid. At least the Governor has acknowledged the reality of a budget deficit that, since January, has grown by an estimated $2 billion to a projected $4 billion. But he hasn't exercised forceful leadership.
One result is a budget that doesn't deal equitably with the effects of an economic slump that's hitting the whole Northeast. Another result is needless expense. Local governments have to borrow to make up for unavailable state aid; such borrowing costs millions in interest.
That could have been avoided had someone shown gumption in Albany. But leveling with the public and imposing unpopular taxes takes political courage - a commodity in short supply in this state election year.

HEADLINE: Oregon's Brave Medical Experiment

 BODY:
Last week the state of Oregon announced that it would curtail many medical services for the poor -but the move does not demonstrate hardheartedness so much as hardheaded compassion. In a brave experiment, the state hopes to make basic medical services more widely available with intelligent rationing of health care.
America's biggest health problem is the cost of treatment, now nearly $540 billion a year and an astonishing 11.1 percent of the gross national product. That impinges on publicly funded health insurance programs, especially Medicaid, which pays bills for the poor. While Washington sets broad guidelines and shares the cost, states have great discretion over eligibility and coverage. 
At present, Oregon residents with incomes at 58 percent of the poverty level qualify for Medicaid. (Nationally the level is less than 50 percent, and in some states as low as 17 percent.) Oregon would raise that level to 100 percent, thus making health coverage available to many more families. But it can do so, the state says, only by setting priorities.
Thus state officials have prepared a list of 1,600 medical procedures, balancing costs against how many people they would benefit. Other factors -how much a person would gain from major surgery, for instance, and the preferences of Oregonians -were also considered. Ailments and injuries above a line to be drawn by the State Legislature will continue to be covered by Medicaid. Those below will not be. All Medicaid coverage for the aged, disabled and the blind, no matter what the procedure, will continue as it has.
Before the state can go ahead with changes in its Medicaid coverage, however, it must get a waiver from the Federal Government. Oregon's Congressional delegation plans to introduce legislation in the Senate and House of Representatives soon. Controversy is certain.
Representative Henry Waxman, chairman of the House subcommittee governing Medicaid, warns against ''fool[ing] ourselves into thinking there's a lot of fat to be cut from coverage of the most vulnerable people.'' And states that devote little of their budgets to Medicaid might find the Oregon plan a handy way to cut coverage of diseases that are both expensive to treat and lacking a constituency - AIDS being an obvious example.
An argument could also be made that the Oregon initiative amounts to no more than a Band-Aid for the serious ailments of America's health care system. Some are sure to argue that discussion of rationing in Oregon can only distract from the larger debate over national health insurance.
Nonetheless, Oregon deserves credit for confronting the urgent issue: how to reconcile increasingly expensive medicine with finite funds and a seeming infinity of ills.

HEADLINE: Interior Secretary Questions Law on Endangered Species

BYLINE: By WARREN E. LEARY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11

 BODY:
Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. says Congress should consider modifying the Endangered Species Act so that protection of animals and plants is balanced against benefits to society from certain kinds of development.
Mr. Lujan's spokesman, Steven Goldstein, said the Secretary thinks Congress should determine whether the law is being used for its intended purpose, protecting wildlife, or as a tool against development. ''It is the Secretary's opinion that the Endangered Species Act should be used as a shield but not as a sword,'' Mr. Goldstein said.
Mr. Lujan's assessment was originally made in an interview on Thursday with The Denver Post. Mr. Lujan was attending a conference today at Mesa Verde National Park, near Durango, Colo., and not available for interviews to elaborate on his proposal, Mr. Goldstein said. 
Environmentalists immediately criticized the remarks, saying that the Secretary was supposed to be the primary protector of wildlife.
 
Lack of Commitment Charged
''The Secretary of the Interior seems to be equating the Environmental Species Act, one of the most critical laws on the books, with the law that says you shouldn't remove the tags from your mattress,'' said Peter Dykstra, a spokesman for Greenpeace. ''The fact that the act is unambiguous is the very reason for its success.''
The National Wildlife Federation and others said Mr. Lujan's remarks demonstrated that the Bush Administration was not showing leadership on the environment and lacked commitment to endangered wildlife.
In the interview with The Denver Post, Mr. Lujan said he had been frustrated by the use of the law to stop beneficial development projects.
He was quoted as saying that a subspecies of red squirrel was holding up construction of a $200 million telescope on Mount Graham in Arizona and that 16 squawfish had stopped a needed water project in the Southwest.
 
Misuse of Federal Act Cited
''There are people who make it their life's work protecting endangered species and their motives are laudable and sincere,'' said Mr. Goldstein. ''But there are others who occasionally use the Endangered Species Act to stop economic progress or development because they oppose a particular project, and that's what Mr. Lujan's upset about.''
The spokesman said it would be inaccurate to say that Mr. Lujan wants to weaken the law, just because he wants to make it more flexible. For example, Mr. Goldstein said, if an endangered species exists in more than one region, do all habitats need equal protection? Or if there are numerous subspecies of an endangered animal, does each need to be preserved where it is found, or could some be moved?
In The Denver Post interview, Mr. Lujan cited the Mount Graham red squirrel as an example of a subspecies that was blocking construction of an astronomical observatory. He was quoted as saying: ''Do we have to save every subspecies? The red squirrel is the best example. Nobody's told me the difference between a red squirrel, a black one or a brown one.''
The Secretary was quoted as saying that he was required to enforce the law and would do so, but that the law was ''too tough'' and should be changed.
 
Reminded of Watt, She Says
Jay D. Hair, president of the National Wildlife Federation, said: ''We are incensed that the very Cabinet official whose job it is to be the country's front-line protector of endangered wildlife would make such outrageous statements.
Mr. Hair said fewer than 100 of the Mount Graham red squirrels remain today and Mr. Lujan's comments about them were ''insensitive at best.''
Faith Campbell, a senior scientist with the Natural Resources Defense Council, said Mr. Lujan's suggestions evoked those of former Interior Secretary James G. Watt.
''Congress and the American public rejected Mr. Watt's efforts to weaken the Endangered Species Act and we expect them to reject Secretary Lujan's proposals as well,'' she said.
Sydney J. Butler of the Wilderness Society said: ''Species and subspecies are being eliminated at a faster rate now than at any time since the disappearance of the dinosaurs. Mr. Lujan has an immense responsibility to save endangered wildlife, and he, more than anyone, should understand the requirements of the law.''

HEADLINE: Evolution in Europe;
Dubcek in Washington: Slovak With a Message

BYLINE: By R. W. APPLE Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11

 BODY:
Alexander Dubcek, the father of the Prague Spring, came to Washington today, not as the leader of a free Czechoslovakia, as he had thought likely for a fleeting moment last fall, but to remind Americans that Slovaks as well as Czechs carried out the revolution of 1989.
After a meeting with Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d, Mr. Dubcek went on to a lunch with members of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, where he appealed for most-favored-nation trade status for Czechoslovakia, which would give his country rights on a par with those of America's best customers. He said Czechoslovakia had fulfilled all economic and political conditions for that.
He also said he expected all Soviet troops to leave his country no later than the end of next year. 
Now the leader of the National Assembly, Mr. Dubcek, gray-haired and slightly tentative in his movements at the age of 68, retains his distinctive aquiline profile after more than two decades in exile. His manner is wary, and an aide said, ''His life has made him a little nervous about reporters.''
 
'Unaffiliated Politically'
He describes himself as ''unaffiliated'' politically, though still a Communist, but he wore today on the lapel of his black three-piece suit the red-white-and-blue V symbol of Public Against Violence, the Slovak equivalent of Prague's Civic Forum.
Senator Claiborne Pell of Rhode Island, the panel's Democratic chairman, was perhaps the ideal host for the lunch; as a young Foreign Service officer, he opened the United States Consulate in Bratislava, the capital of Slovakia, in 1948, so he knows all about the tensions between the Czechs and the Slovaks, which flared recently in a protracted quarrel about whether there should be a hyphen in the nation's name.
Mr. Dubcek made no mention of Slovak nationalism, though his aides emphasized it. Nor, for that matter, did he ask for American aid; he had said in Canada earlier this week that joint business ventures were more desirable, because ''loans would just have to be paid for by our children and grandchildren.'' And he said nothing about his personal situation or emotions.
Recounting his country's attempt to break the Stalinist vise in 1968, an attempt he led and Soviet tanks crushed, Mr. Dubcek said: ''We made an attempt 21 years ago to break the Stalinist system in Czechoslovakia. We didn't fail, but we had limits forced on us. We were broken by military force.''
 
An Electrifying Moment
''But it is impossible for violence to win forever,'' he told the senators. ''It may win for a certain time but not forever. Change might have come sooner, but nevertheless it came.''
For an electrifying moment, as that change swept the streets of the old Czech capital last year, it seemed it might put Mr. Dubcek back into power. On the evening of Nov. 24, while he stood on a balcony above Wenceslas Square, more than 200,000 people shouted ''We want Dubcek!'' But the students and intellectuals who made the revolution prefered Vaclav Havel, the playwright who is now the Czech President.
Mr. Dubcek was eventually installed by Mr. Havel in the Government's No. 3 position, partly as a link to the failed earlier revolution, partly as a concession to Slovak feelings. But the older man's role is definitely a subordinate one, and his reception in Washington made that quite plain.
He is to see Vice President Dan Quayle, but not President Bush. He is to be given an honorary degree at American University on Sunday, and an award at the International Human Rights Law Group's dinner on Tuesday, but there will be no dramatic speech on Capitol Hill.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Alexander Dubcek, right, leader of the Czechoslovak National Assembly, in Washington yesterday with Senator Claiborne Pell, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee. The Senator displayed a gift he received while working in Czechoslovakia as a Foreign Service officer in 1948. (Jose R. Lopez/The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Nairobi Journal;
An Envoy Who Starts Fires to Get Things Started

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, May 11

 BODY:
Smith Hempstone, the American Ambassador to this East African nation, was not bashful about coveting the job. He recounts approaching George Bush before he won the Presidential election and saying quite bluntly, ''When you are President I would like to be your Ambassador to Kenya.''
A former executive editor of The Washington Times and a columnist with a definite conservative point of view, Mr. Hempstone had the correct political qualifications, and, as it turned out, appropriate, although dated, knowledge.
For eight years in the 1950's and early 60's he traveled through Africa, including a period as a correspondent for The Chicago Daily News in Kenya, when he wrote about its transition from colony to independent nation. 
In the six months since his return, this time as a diplomat, Mr. Hempstone has broken the traditional diplomatic mold. Gray-haired and 60 years old, he greets weekend visitors on the back porch of his residence in plaid shirt and khaki shorts.
 
Hot Political Debate
He was quick to tell the Kenyan Government that if American business investment was going to return, something had to be done about the pervasive corruption, a subject more delicate in Kenya than human rights. Then last week, he stepped into a heated domestic political debate.
To a speech that an aide had written about the economy, Mr. Hempstone added a sentence: that in handing out economic assistance, Washington would give preference to those nations that ''nourish democratic institutions, defend human rights and practice multiparty politics.''
Almost any mention of multiparty politics in this one-party state draws furious responses from the leaders of the ruling party, the Kenya Africa National Union, including its head, President Daniel arap Moi.
Mr. Hempstone made it clear that he was reflecting official Washington's point of view and not his own. But Mr. Moi took offense and effectively told him not to meddle.
The controversy grew and threatened a project dear to Mr. Hempstone, an American-Kenyan trade show. It was the first in Kenya's 27 years of independence, and President Moi was to open it. After Mr. Hempstone's multiparty comments, the President threatened to back out, and the Ambassador had to engage in some backstage diplomacy.
Mr. Moi not only appeared, but in a carefully crafted speech on Wednesday he avoided the shrill language that had marked his attacks on the multiparty proponents. He encouraged the debate and said Kenya was not wedded to the past, a greater concession to the possibility of change than had come from any senior Government official.
A senior staff aide at the American Embassy said, ''For the first time the Government is on the defensive.'' A Kenyan Government official said that many Kenyans, yearning for a substantive rather than a name-calling debate on how Kenya should mold its political system in the wake of democratization in Eastern Europe, were grateful to Mr. Hempstone. ''He is our friend,'' the offical said.
While Washington had been clear about the need for political change in Africa, Mr. Hempstone is the only American Ambassador on the continent to have publicly raised the matter. ''It's ironic,'' he said, explaining that he is probably the most conservative American envoy in Africa.
 
Reshaping of Politics
Mr. Hempstone said he was not sure whether Western models of democracy were appropriate. It is probable, he said, that new political parties will form along tribal lines, a common fear expressed by African opponents of the idea. Further, Africa did not have the same historical background as the developed world.
At a Washington meeting last month of American Ambassadors in Africa, Mr. Hempstone was cast as the devil's advocate on a panel arguing the merits of multiparty systems. ''I said that multiparty systems will not necessarily lead to Jeffersonian democracy and one-party systems do not necessarily lead to represssion or lack of political freedom. I found myself defending Kenya -which I do.''
Nevertheless, he has chosen to raise the issue. He says he is only doing it because he wants Kenya to get the best from the United States, and he fears Congress will cut aid if there are not political reforms.
Not one for protocol, Mr. Hempstone turned up for a visit recently to a family-plannning project in rural Kenya wearing shorts, shirt and tennis shoes.
And he drew even more attention when he visited a prominent Kenyan politician, Shariff Nassir, in the coastal city of Mombasa. Mr. Nassir gave the Ambassador the usual arguments for a one-party state. Rather than remain diplomatically silent, Mr. Hempstone forcefully articulated the American policy.
The influential Weekly Review, a news magazine, observed that Mr. Hempstone's rebuttal to the powerful Mr. Nassir was ''a fleeting breach of protocol.''
Mr. Hempstone was not troubled by the magazine's criticism. ''I'm not a diplomat,'' he said with a chuckle.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Smith Hempstone, the United States Ambassador to Kenya, with Shariff Nassir, chairman of the ruling Kenya Africa National Union Party in Mombasa. Mr. Hempstone recently opened a debate in this one-party state by championing the cause of multiparty politics. (Adam Hussein/Daily Nation)

HEADLINE: CONSUMER'S WORLD;
Businesses Offering Variant on H.M.O.'s

BYLINE: By BARRY MEIER

 BODY:
Already beset by a confusing system of health care, consumers are now being offered yet another medical plan - a re-invented health maintenance organization.
In the past three years several of the country's biggest employers, among them the American Telephone and Telegraph Company, Allied-Signal Inc. and Southwestern Bell, have been working with insurers to create networks of physicians and hospitals for their employees to use.
The reason is simple: tighter control over the services that doctors perform for employees and their families means lower costs for the companies. But some medical experts fear that the new programs represent a further emergence of cost as the chief criterion for determining employee health care. 
 
Networks in Varied Forms
 As with H.M.O.'s, the new networks, which are being organized for the employers by insurance companies, come in varied forms. Some use established H.M.O. clinics and doctors, while others rely on networks of physicians who act as ''gatekeepers,'' consulting with insurers before undertaking medical procedures or recommending specialists. Some programs reward doctors financially for limiting services and costs.
These new networks, which are being called preferred-provider organizations, managed-care programs or hybrid H.M.O.'s, will let employers track both spending and treatments much more closely.
For consumers, the plans may be a mixed blessing. On the positive side, they provide more flexibility than H.M.O.'s because employees can use doctors who do not belong to the network and still have the program pay part of the cost. But because companies will rate the programs partly on the basis of cost, health experts worry that care quality may suffer.
''It scares me,'' said Dr. David Brook, the deputy director of the health services program for the Rand Corporation in Santa Monica, Calif. ''We are unleashing very powerful financial incentives without any standards.''
Any shift in employee health plans is likely to have broad impact. Of Americans under the age of 65 who have health coverage, 3 of 4 receive it through an employer, according to the Health Insurance Industry of America, a trade group.
''There is tremendous interest by companies in these kinds of programs,'' said David Polk, an assistant vice president for marketing in the employee benefits division of the Aetna Life and Casualty Company in Hartford. Aetna is one of the insurance companies organizing the networks; others are Cigna and Prudential Insurance.
The trend toward hybrid programs comes amid slowing consumer interest in traditional H.M.O.'s. Between June 1988 and July 1989 new enrollments in traditional H.M.O.'s rose by only 3.6 percent, the smallest annual gain since 1976, when such statistics were first collected, according to Interstudy, a health care research company in Minneapolis. There are about 32.5 million H.M.O. members nationwide, about 25 percent of them in California, Interstudy reported.
Some consumers, younger workers or those with several children, are pleased with H.M.O.'s, which offer benefits like preventive medical care. Sarah Marmor Labarthe, a 24-year-old paralegal who lives in New York City, said her H.M.O. ''reminds me of the type of clinic that I used to go to at college.''
But the medical care of these younger and generally healthy workers may cost less than the flat enrollment fee, making the H.M.O. program a poor investment for the employer. Older workers, whose medical costs run high enough that they more than offset such fees, have tended to be unwilling to give up their own doctors or the notion that they should be able to choose the doctors they want.
Two years ago Allied-Signal Inc. decided to eliminate both H.M.O.'s and traditional insurance coverage wherever possible, and offered its 85,000 employees a natiowide network of doctors and hospitals assembled for the company by the Cigna Corporation, said Michael Ascolese, a spokesman for Allied-Signal, which has its headquarters in Morristown, N.J.
A top official at a union representing Allied-Signal workers said the decision to accept the company's plan was simple. ''They said that if we wanted to, we could go out and buy our own insurance, but they were not going to supply another plan,'' said James McHale, president of the Oil, Chemical and Atomic Workers International Union local that represents workers at an Allied-Signal chemical plant in Philadelphia. About 45,000 Allied-Signal workers are already taking part in the new network, Mr. Ascolese said.
Under the Allied plan, employees pay $10 for each visit to a doctor in the system. Should they choose to go outside it, they pay a deductible and part of the bill, though an employee's out-of-pocket medical expenses are capped at about $1,000 a year. Mr. McHale said most employees in Philadelphia seem pleased with the plan, although some concerns remain about acute care.
''If I had a heart attack and needed a bypass operation,'' Mr. McHale said, ''I'd throw the $400 deductible up to get the doctor I want.''
Even as companies adopt the new programs, major questions about them remain. Health care officials acknowledge, for example, that there is little information showing that the hybrid H.M.O.'s will provide savings. And they may not be protected by the same government regulations as H.M.O.'s, officials said.
''The public probably thinks that regulators are checking up on the adequacy of these networks and the credentials of providers, but they are not,'' said Joyce Gallimore, director of the Bureau of Alternative Delivery Systems for the New York State Department of Health. So far, only the systems that use existing H.M.O. networks will be subject to equal scrutiny, Ms. Gallimore said.
 
Reviewing the Doctors
 Mr. Polk, the Aetna official, said companies police physicians in their networks by checking credentials and conducting consumer satisfaction surveys. ''We know the aberrant physicians,'' he said.
A.T.&T. is now surveying employees in an effort to assemble a network that includes many doctors that they now use, according to Laura Unger, president of Local 1150 of the Communication Workers of America in New York City.
While the union supports the effort, some employees are skeptical. ''Who is going to be checking these doctors out?'' asked Ronald A. Tyree, an A.T.&T. communications technician.
Dr. Brook of the Rand Corporation and other health experts also wonder how companies will make decisions about competing systems.
''They have close to zero information to work with,'' he said. ''I suspect such decisions will be made capriciously and financially.''

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Show Plunge of 0.6% for April

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11

 BODY:
Retail sales, held back by another big drop in auto demand, fell by six-tenths of 1 percent in April, the biggest setback in six months, the Commerce Department reported today.
The department said that sales fell to a seasonally adjusted $148.64 billion last month after a decline of two-tenths of 1 percent in March and no change in February.
Disappointed private economists, who had been hoping for a small rebound in activity, warned that the lackluster sales would be likely to translate into slower economic growth in the months ahead as businesses faced growing inventories of unsold products. 
 
Recovery in Eighth Year
 Consumer spending, which accounts for two-thirds of overall economic activity, has been the driving force during much of the recovery, now in its eighth year, a record for peacetime.
''We have now had three months in a row of weak retail sales,'' said Allen Sinai, chief economist of the Boston Company. ''The consumer is fading from the scene.''
Sandra Shaber, senior economist at the Futures Group, said that at this stage of the recovery there was little pent-up demand left. ''The most disturbing trend here is the weakness in department store sales,'' she added. ''That's a pretty good indicator of the overall mood'' of consumers.
Analysts said that unless consumer spending weakened further, the country should still be able to avoid a recession, although the predicted overall growth, as measured by the gross national product, would expand at a sluggish pace of 2 percent this year.
 
Largest Drop Since October
 The April decline was the largest monthly drop since a 1.4 percent plunge in October. The March and April declines marked the first time in almost three years that retail sales had posted consecutive monthly declines.
The biggest drag on activity came from auto sales, which dropped by 2.7 percent. It marked the sixth time in the last seven months that car sales had fallen. Analysts said that was particularly worrisome because it was coming at a time when auto companies were offering heavy incentives to reduce inventories.
''The consumer has clearly backed off,'' said David Wyss, an economist at DRI/McGraw Hill, a consulting company in Lexington, Mass. ''The incentives are costing car companies a lot of money and sales are still weak.''
 
Weakness in Other Areas
 Even without the big drop in car sales, spending in other retail areas was weak. Sales at general department stores were off by seven-tenths of 1 percent in April after an even bigger 1.2 percent drop in March. The late Easter had been expected to help sales in early April.
Sales at hardware and building supply stores dropped by 2.6 percent in April after a decrease of eight-tenths of 1 percent the previous month.
Sales at gasoline stations fell by 1 percent. Restaurant sales were off by two-tenths of 1 percent while sales at speciality clothing stores were down by 1.9 percent.
In the only major areas showing gains, sales at furniture and home furnishing stores edged up by four-tenths of 1 percent while sales at drugstores posted a 1.2 percent increases.

HEADLINE: Candy Plant Plea Denied

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11

 BODY:
A United States Government panel today turned down a request by the Swiss candy maker Jacobs Suchard Ltd. to establish a special foreign trade zone for its Chicago plant so that the plant could save money by importing sugar at world prices.
The Foreign Trade Zone Board denied the request by Suchard for its subsidiary E. J. Brach & Sons on the ground that such a move would disrupt United States sugar-pricing policy, a spokesman for the panel said. American sugar prices are kept at levels well above the world market through a quota system.
Suchard has threatened to move the plant out of the United States if the special status is denied. ''Naturally we're disappointed in the decision,'' said Terri Kaminski, a spokeswoman for Brach's. ''At this time, we haven't determined what our next steps will be regarding the plant.''
The decision followed the issuing of an opinion by the Agriculture Department that granting special status to the plant would ''result in adverse consequences to domestic sugar prices,'' a Commerce Department spokesman said.
Brach officials have said the company could save $20 million annually if the status were granted and the plant could import lower-cost sugar.
