HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
Stroh Is Interested In Acquiring Heileman

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: DETROIT, May 11

 BODY:
The Stroh Brewery Company said today that it was interested in acquiring the G. Heileman Brewing Company, a unit of Bond Corporation Holdings, the beleaguered company of the Australian entrepreneur Alan Bond.
''The Stroh Brewery Company would certainly like to be the acquirer of Heileman,'' said George Kuehn, Stroh's senior vice president and general counsel. ''We think it would be a good fit.''
A combination of Stroh and Heileman, which makes Colt 45 Malt Liquor, would create the nation's third-largest brewing company.
Mr. Kuehn refused to say whether Stroh had been in direct talks with Heileman, Bond or bankers for the companies. A Heileman spokesman said the company was skeptical of Stroh's ability to make a bid and accused Stroh of weak management, an uncertain direction and an eroding distributor network.
G. Heileman, based in La Crosse, Wis., was acquired by Bond in 1987 for $1.3 billion. In addition to Colt 45 Malt Liquor, Heileman makes Old Style beer, J. Schmidt, Iron City and other beers.
The Bond business empire has been on the brink of financial collapse since the beginning of the year, fighting off creditors in several court actions as it struggles with debts estimated to exceed $5 billion.
Bond Corporation Holdings is one of Australia's largest companies. In November it reported a loss for the iscal year of $733 million. The company is Australia's second-biggest beer maker, and it also has interests in mining, real estate and communications.
Stroh, a privately held company based in Detroit, makes Stroh's, Old Milwaukee, Schlitz, Schaeffer and other beers.
The Anheuser-Busch Companies and the Philip Morris Companies' Miller Brewing unit are the first and second largest brewers, respectively.

HEADLINE: Your Money;
The 'Kiddie Tax' And Summer Jobs

BYLINE: By Jan M. Rosen

 BODY:
With summer approaching, many students would like to find summer jobs. Some parents, on the other hand, being vaguely aware of the ''kiddie tax,'' are concerned about the effect that might have on the family's finances.
Not to worry, financial experts say. A summer job can bring many benefits, and the kiddie tax applies only to unearned income. Dividends and interest above $1,000 earned on assets held in the name of children under age 14 are taxed at the parents' marginal rate, generally 28 or 33 percent. 
Income earned by children of any age is taxed at their own rate - generally the lowest rate, 15 percent - as is unearned income for children 14 and older. This means that young people can earn some of the money they need for personal expenses or a college education and pay little or no taxes; nor are their earnings likely to have any substantial effect on their parents' taxes.
It also means that it can be advantageous for parents who own a business or have a professional practice to employ their children. The children can learn about the business, and the money they earn is shifted into their lower tax bracket.
''Of course, you can't let them go to the beach and pay them,'' said Herbert Paul, senior tax partner of Mahoney Cohen Paul & Company, an accounting firm in New York. ''But if they come into your office or factory, you can pay them a reasonable rate of compensation.''
For a responsible youngster, that need not be the very lowest wage , he continued. But it does have to be reasonable for the job performed. There are many things a student can do competently - fill in for the switchboard operator, receptionist or porter; for a secretary or bookkeeper if the young worker has office skills, or do manual labor.
Tamara G. Telesko, a vice president of the Chase Manhattan Bank's private banking division, said she had received many questions from clients about children working. ''It makes sense for them to earn money on their own,'' she said. ''It encourages the work ethic, and it gives them a feel for whether that is the kind of job they would like.''
Many young people have idealistic visions of what jobs are like, she added, and summer work can help them focus more realistically on what they want to prepare for in college.
Ms. Telesko noted that like any single taxpayer, a student was entitled to a standard deduction of $3,250, so that much could be earned before any tax was due. If the child takes his or her own personal exemption, $2,050 for 1990, even more can be sheltered from taxes, but the parents could not then take a dependency exemption for the child, even if they provided more than half the child's support. Since that exemption is phased out for upper-income taxpayers, shifting income by employing the child can be particularly advantageous for them.
Julian Block, a tax lawyer in Larchmont, N.Y., pointed out that Social Security taxes could also be an important consideration. For low-income people, that tax bite is far more onerous than income taxes - both employee and employer must pay 7.65 percent on the first $51,300 earned this year.
But sole proprietorships and husband-wife partnerships get a break when employing their children. Social Security taxes do not have to be withheld if the children are under age 18, according to the I.R.S. Code section 3121(b)(3)(A). Before 1988, this break applied to children under age 21 and to spouses, he noted, but that is no longer the case.
With the cost of college today - around $6,000 a year for state schools and more than $13,000 for private institutions - it is important for both children and their families to put aside as much as possible, Ms. Telesko said, without undue anxiety about the kiddie tax.
The kiddie tax results from the Tax Reform Act of 1986. Under it, the first $500 of a child's unearned income is tax-free and the next $500 is taxable at the child's rate. For most children, in the 15 percent bracket, only $75 in taxes would be due on the first $1,000 of dividends and interest. Since $1,000 is the earnings on $12,500 invested at 8 percent, transferring that much money to a child, can bring a big tax saving to a family. Parents in the 28 percent bracket would owe $280 in taxes on that amount of earnings; those in the 33 percent bracket would owe $333.
Series EE savings bonds can be excellent vehicles for college savings. Investors can elect to receive the interest after the child is age 14 so that it is taxed at the child's rate. And taxpayers with adjusted gross income of $60,000 or less who buy Series EE bonds issued after 1989 and redeem them to pay for their own higher-education expenses or those of a dependent will owe no tax on the interest. The exclusion is phased out for those with incomes of $60,000 to $90,000.

LENGTH: 907 words

HEADLINE: Dow Gains Points; Volume Up

BYLINE: By ROBERT J. COLE

 BODY:
Falling interest rates and growing signs that inflationary pressures are on the way down helped lift stock prices sharply yesterday in the heaviest trading in five months.
The Dow Jones industrial average -buoyed by solid advances in blue chips like Coca-Cola, Boeing, Du Pont, I.B.M. and Woolworth - advanced an impressive 63.07 points, or 2.3 percent, to 2,801.58.
The Dow now stands only 8.57 points, or three-tenths of 1 percent, away from the record of 2,810.15 set on the first trading day of 1990. The key market barometer also advanced a solid 91.22 points for the week. 
 
Broader Indexes Not Near Record
 Analysts cautioned, however, that the broader Standard & Poor's 500 index remained 2.2 percent below its all-time high, set in October, while the Nasdaq composite index, which measures the smaller stocks, stood 9.8 percent below the high it set in October.
But in a move that - if it continues - could mean a much brighter stock market on the way and much bigger commission checks on Wall Street, volume on the New York Stock Exchange soared to more than 234 million shares, the highest since it topped 240 million in December. Moreover, 1,282 stocks advanced while only 339 declined.
''Money's coming into the market,'' said Peter G. Grennan, senior vice president of Shearson Lehman Hutton. ''You don't want to be left on the sidelines on this one.''
''Interest rates look like they're going lower,'' he said, ''and the economy is growing moderately. These are two very, very bullish ingredients for higher stock prices.''
 
'Investors Are Less Worried'
 Maury Harris, chief economist at Paine Webber, said stock prices were strong ''because interest rates are down, commodity prices are down, producer prices are down and so are retail sales.'' He continued, ''So stock and bond prices went up because investors are less worried about inflation.''
In a cautious forecast tied to bonds, which generally determine what happens to stocks, he said, ''Chances are that in the near term, the bond market can do better because of continued good news on inflation.'' Less inflation, he explained, takes the pressure off interest rates so that ''bonds become less competitive with stocks.''
Barely 10 days ago, Wall Street investors worried that with interest rates rising well beyond 9 percent and Japanese interest in the United States bond market supposedly falling away, the American stock and bond markets might have to batten down for a long time. But in a move that apparently took much of Wall Street by surprise, Japanese buying, while somewhat weaker, has not fallen away. As a result, interest rates have not had to be pushed to the sky to attract investors.
Last week the bellwether 30-year Treasury bonds yielded 9.02 percent, enough to lure investors away from stocks. By Thursday, in the Treasury's $10 billion sale of 30-year bonds, the yield had slid to 8.84 percent, but not yet enough to lift the Dow more than 5.63 points. But by yesterday, old 30-year Treasury bonds yielded 8.66 percent and the new ones just sold yielded 8.63 percent, enough to convince investors that interest rates were indeed dropping rapidly.
Expectations of still further declines in interest rates, in turn, toppled the value of the dollar against the Japanese yen and, for a while, against most European currencies. The prospect of a cheaper dollar helped raise stock prices for dollar-sensitive stocks because cheap dollars mean that American products become less expensive abroad. Stocks also advanced for American companies producing overseas, because when they convert foreign currency back into dollars, their profits will be higher.
International Flavors, for example, which produces heavily outside the United States, rose 2, to 63 1/2; Upjohn, benefiting from heavy foreign production and wild takeover rumors, rose 1 1/8, to 38 7/8. Caterpillar rose 2 1/2, to 66 1/4. Procter & Gamble was up 1 3/4, to 75 3/8. Colgate-Palmolive gained 1 1/8, to 61 3/8.
Pepsico rose 2 1/4, to 69 5/8, and Coca-Cola 3 1/4, to 83 1/4, both in heavy trading. Both also hit new 52-week highs yesterday, Pepsi at its closing price and Coke at 83 1/2.
Boeing, a big exporter of aircraft, advanced 2 5/8, to 78, after hitting a 52-week high of 78 1/8. Almost 1.5 million shares changed hands, too few to make the Big Board list of the 10-most-active stocks.
 
Drug Companies Strong
As major exporters or big foreign producers, drug companies and other health-care companies were particularly strong yesterday. Pfizer rose 3 3/8, to 60 5/8; Warner Lambert 2 1/4, to 111 1/2; Bausch & Lomb 2 3/8, to 63, and Eli Lilly 2 1/8, to 71 3/4.
The strong rise may not have caught money managers entirely by surprise. Analysts said that asset allocators, a group of professionals who advise investors where to put their money, were telling people to take money out of bonds and to put it into stocks.
Robert Moseson, president of Performance Analytics, a Chicago retirement fund consultant, said that 10 days ago he had advised his 250 clients with $35 billion in the market to put 80 percent of their money into stocks and the rest into short-term cash equivalents. Just a month earlier, he said, he was advising them to keep 25 percent in the stock market and the rest in cash equivalents.
Among the averages, the S.&P. 500 rose 8.18, to 352.00; the Nasdaq composite 4.90, to 438.10, and the Amex market-value 3.58, to 352.50.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Posts Sharp Drop Against Yen

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER

 BODY:
The dollar fell sharply against the Japanese yen yesterday, reflecting some improved confidence in Japan and the follow-through of the dollar's steep decline against the West German mark and other European currencies earlier in the week.
The decline against the yen began in Tokyo, where the dollar tumbled by 2.60 yen. Trading volume was at twice its average levels, and the Nikkei 225 index on the Tokyo stock market rallied by 531.88 points, to 31,512.14.
The dollar then continued to fall in Europe and in New York, spurred in part by the unexpected decline of three-tenths of 1 percent in the Producer Price Index in April. 
 
Rally Against Other Currencies
 By the end of trading, the dollar rallied, in part on profit taking, against the mark and most other European currencies and ended above Thursday's levels. Against the mark, the dollar rose to 1.6380, from 1.6290 on Thursday, when it was at its lowest level in two years.
But against the yen, the dollar finished at 152.70, just above its low for the day, 152.63 yen, and down sharply from 156.60 on Thursday. Despite the fall, the dollar is still far stronger against the yen than other currencies. This is just the lowest level for the dollar against the yen since mid-March.
Traders were hard pressed to explain the dollar's surprising four-yen drop in one day because there was little news to force the move.
But the overall climate for the dollar has changed significantly since the Government released a weaker-than-expected employment report for April last Friday. And it is possible that it just took longer to bring down the dollar against the yen because of the yen's weakness against all major currencies this year. The weakness reflects uncertainties about the health of Japanese markets and the direction of Tokyo's economic policy.
The American employment report showed a much weaker economy than expected. Consequently, traders have shifted to a view that the Federal Reserve is likely to hold interest rates where they are or even lower them.
Before that report, the forecast had been for higher rates, which would help support the dollar by attracting foreign investment for dollar-denominated securities.
 
German Move Expected
 ''The scales have been tipped with the expectation now that the Fed is not tightening and with the expectation that the West Germans will still be tightening in the future,'' said Nicholas Sargen, director of international bond research at Salomon Brothers in New York.
The drop of the Produer Price Index and the decline of six-tenths of 1 percent in retail sales for April, which were also reported yesterday, added fuel to the argument that interest rates would not rise. The price report showed lower inflation than expected, which could ease the concern of the Federal Reserve. It has concentrated its interest rate policy on fighting inflation. The slowing growth reflected in the retail sales report could also strength the argument of some, including Bush Administration economists, that interest rates should be lowered.
The dollar also weakened when some of the uncertainties around the monetary union of the two Germanys were cleared up. The Swiss franc rose sharply, backed with high interest rates and by rumors that Japanese holders of Swiss bonds had to buy billions of francs to pay off the bonds. It also drew many foreign investors, who saw it as even a safer bet than the mark.
Traders said the rise of the yen against the dollar yesterday was also helped by the charts that many traders use to help them predict the course of currencies. On these charts, the dollar fell through several key points against the yen, which just added to the selling pressure on the dollar.

HEADLINE: News Analysis;
Jawboning the Bankers

BYLINE: By NATHANIEL C. NASH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 11

 BODY:
Despite a clear signal to the banking community that regulators did not want the industry to close its lending spigot, bankers are likely to remain cautious and require proof of a more accommodating regulatory environment before they make large amounts of extra credit available.
Bankers and industry analysts said today that they hoped the message delivered on Thursday by the Government's three top regulators would filter down to Government examination staffs. They said examiners had come down hard on bank lending practices in recent months, prompting some industry executives to accuse the regulators of arbitrarily imposing new, tougher standards and risking a credit squeeze.
This attitude is likely to mean no quick end to a tightening of credit that has not occurred on a nationwide basis but is happening in some regions, like New England. Instead, the bankers are taking a wait-and-see attitude. 
''This will take a little time,'' said William H. Brandon Jr., president of the First National Bank of Phillips County in Helena, Ark. ''I don't think you can do in one meeting too much more than start a process.''
Some bankers said they would wait until their annual audit to see if the regulatory environment had changed before they would feel safe to lend more freely. Others said they would be able to pick up early signals from the industry's grapevine, from discussions with other bankers and from their experiences with examiners.
But in general they welcomed the encouragement to continue lending.
''The motive is a very positive one,'' said John R. Reed, chairman of Citicorp, who said that during the last week he had visited three dozen of the bank's largest real estate customers in California and Texas, and concluded that there was undoubtedly a slowdown in lending for large office buildings and housing. Those markets are ''relatively weak and will be for a while,'' he said.
The meeting Thursday put the directors of the American Bankers Association together with Alan Greenspan, chairman of the Federal Reserve Board; L. William Seidman, chairman of the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation, and Robert L. Clarke, Comptroller of the Currency. The session underscored the basic and somewhat divergent concerns of the regulators.
 
Comptroller Under Fire
 For Mr. Clarke, the meeting was intended as a show of unanimity among the three regulatory agencies. He and his staff of examiners have come under intense criticism in recent months, first for being overly lax in their supervision of lending practices in New England, and then, after the troubles of the Bank of New England, for clamping down so hard that even viable small businesses in New England have not been able to get loans.
Bankers say that once the problems with real estate lending in New England became evident, Mr. Clarke sent in examiners from Texas, who had just handled the failures of many of that state's biggest banks. Some bankers still refer to the Texas examiners as the Comptroller's storm troopers.
It is true that the evidence of examiners being tough is for the most part anecdotal and many banks say they welcome tough scrutiny of their books and lending practices. But officials of the bankers' group say that in just the last two months, representatives from 27 state associations have come to the group's Washington headquarters complaining that overly tough examiners are forcing banks to restrict credit.
The regulators themselves acknowledge that their examiners are being tougher, but they argue that in economically weak areas that is appropriate and to be expected.
 
Offering Reassurances
 Still, the criticism of Mr. Clarke -specifically that he was pursuing more restrictive policies than the Federal Reserve or the F.D.I.C. -prompted him to initiate the meeting, Government officials say. The idea was that the three regulators could tell bankers that there is fundamentally no difference in the way their agencies are examining banks.
The Fed's concerns, however, went beyond just the problem of tighter credit in some parts of the country. The central bank wanted to avoid any possibility that the growing publicity about a cutback on lending could develop into a full-blown credit squeeze and bring economic growth to a standstill.
While the Fed could itself lower interest rates in an effort to generate more lending activity by banks that would have been considered a much too drastic step at this point and would have far-reaching implications on other sectors of the economy. Fed officials say that raising and lowering interest rates is too blunt an instrument for solving problems in just one or a few economic sectors.
Thus, Mr. Greenspan engaged in his own form of understated jawboning, telling banks it was permissible for them to take risks, which is the essence of banking.
''The meeting was more than a banking-regulation issue to the Fed,'' said Edward L. Yingling, head of government relations at the bankers' group. ''I would read the meeting as saying not necessarily that they believe there is a credit crunch now; they would not tell you that even if they did believe it. But there must be some concern that down the line you could have a problem. And there has to be a concern about the current atmosphere that has been created.''
 
Some Benefits Seen
 Mr. Seidman said today in a telephone interview that he felt the meeting was beneficial, especially since the bankers seemed to agree that there was no widespread shortage of credit. And he predicted that the meeting could produce more lending.
''I would think it would push them a little in that direction, although most bankers will be making those decisions based on their own best judgment, and that is the way we like to have them do it,'' he said.
Still, banking experts predict it will be a while before small businesses, which have been hurt the most by tighter credit, will be getting a warm reception again from their local bankers.
''Bankers are not going to start backing off very quickly and not until they have a clear sense of what the examiners are going to do with their institutions,'' said Bert Ely, a financial consultant in Alexandria, Va. ''I think it is months before any overzealousness by examiners is going to work itself out of the system.''

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MAY 12, 1990

 BODY:

 
 
The Economy
 The wintertime jump in the inflation rate appears to be wearing off, and inflation seems to be settling back to the moderate level that has prevailed over the last two years, a Government report indicated. ''What a difference a week makes,'' one analyst said. ''Before the unemployment numbers, the fear was that the economy was too strong, inflation too high and the Fed might raise interest rates.'' [Page 1.] Despite a clear signal to the banking community that regulators did not want the industry to close its lending spigot, bankers are likely to remain cautious and require proof of a more accommodating regulatory environment. News Analysis. [31.] The F.B.I. has a backlog of 234 referrals and complaints of large-scale fraud involving the nation's financial institutions, data show. [32.] Retail sales fell by 0.6 percent in April, the biggest setback in six months, the Commerce Department said. The department said that sales, held back by another big drop in auto demand, fell to a seasonally adjusted $148.64 billion last month after an 0.2 percent decline in March and no change in February. [42.] 
 
 
 
Companies
 Peabody Coal received a bid from Amax, which wants to buy all of the coal company for $1.25 billion. Hanson then raised its offer for the 55 percent stake it does not already own. [31.] Blackstone Capital has agreed to buy 65 percent of the Howard Johnson and Ramada franchise system for about $200 million. [31.] A vote against increasing pensions for G.M. executives, including Roger Smith, will be cast by the Michigan State Retirement System, which holds 8.8 million G.M. shares. [42.] Procter & Gamble has pulled $1 million in advertising from a Boston TV station because it broadcast commercials saying that buying the company's Folgers coffee helps bring ''misery, destruction and death'' in El Salvador. [1.] VSI pleaded guilty to conspiracy and agreed to pay $18 million in fines and costs to settle Federal charges that it had schemed for 15 years to falsify test reports on parts. [8.] Stroh Brewery said it was interested in acquiring Heileman Brewing, a unit of Bond Corporation Holdings, the beleaguered company of the Australian entrepreneur Alan Bond. [33.] National Data's stock price plunged 40 percent after it told investors it would report an operating loss. Analysts had estimated a profit of about 47 cents a share. [33.]
 
 
 
Markets
 Stock prices rose sharply, helped by falling interest rates and growing signs that inflationary pressures are on the way down. Trading was the heaviest in five months. The Dow advanced 63.07 points, or 2.3 percent, to 2,801.58. [31.] The dollar fell sharply against the yen, reflecting improved confidence in Japan and the follow-through of the dollar's steep decline against the mark and other European currencies earlier in the week. [31.] Interest rates plunged as prices of Treasury securities soared, largely on new evidence that the economy was softening. [34.] Grain and soybean futures prices closed mostly lower as traders reacted negatively to the latest Agriculture Department crop reports. [39.]
 
 
 
Today's Columns
 Patent issues are too difficult to be decided by people with little experience in evaluating complex technologies, critics are saying after the failure of a jury to agree on damages for the inventor of the intermittent windshield wiper. HEADLINE: 'This City Is Sick of Violence': Dinkins's Address

 BODY:
Following are excerpts from a transcript of Mayor David N. Dinkins's address, ''An Affirmation of Tolerance and Respect,'' at City Hall last night, as recorded by The New York Times:
 
 Thank you all. Thank you. First of all, let me thank you all for coming this evening on such short notice. I thank also the city's broadcast organizations for their ready acceptance of my request for this time to communicate with you. And to those who were unable to attend due to religious observances, I trust that my message will reach them through other means. For I know that all who share this city and who love this city are deeply committed to the cause for which we gather tonight.
Last year I spoke to you about a campaign to bring us together. It was a cause that touched a yearning deep inside each of us, to come together in an affirmation of respect - respect for ourselves, for each other and for this city that we call home. 
My friends, that campaign did not end last year. It was only just begun. Together we've tasted a tiny piece of the sweet substance called hope. Yet again and again we're confronted by the bitterness of hate.
So we're gathered tonight here at the seat of government, to reaffirm our commitment, to renew our mission, and to reassess and reassert a simple truth: All of us want to live our lives in peace and dignity - free to walk any street and shop in any store, at any time, in any neighborhood, without fear of force or violence.
 
'Never Lead by Dividing'
As I've said to you before, I am the Mayor of all of the people of New York. And my administration will never lead by dividing, by setting some of us against the rest of us, or by favoring one group over others.
At the same time, and in the same spirit, we will never allow any group or any person to turn to violence or the threat of violence, to intimidate others, no matter how legitimate their anger or frustration may be.
The most basic purpose of government is to protect public safety, to enforce the law amidst the chaos and confusion of urban life. That is a mission I am prepared to meet - and I will do whatever is necessary and whatever is right to maintain the public order and public safety.
Ours is a rule of law. And tonight as I speak, two groups of 12 people sit in Brooklyn deliberating upon whether the law should punish two young men for the killing of Yusuf Hawkins.
I cannot affect their decision; it must be made on the basis of the evidence presented in court and none other. And that process, the jury process, is still the fairest and best method of judging our fellow citizens that anyone has ever come up with in the history of humanity, regardless of the verdict in any particular case.
 
Bensonhurst 'A Painful Passage'
This trial has been a painful passage for our city. And there will be more. But one thing is for sure: No verdict can undo the damage that has been done on that devastating night last August. The hate that was unleashed upon Yusuf Hawkins can never be called back. The pain that ripped through his body, his family and the city can never be fully healed, and his sacrifice must never be forgotten.
The senseless death of Yusuf Hawkins was a hateful crime, and anger must not lead us to hate. This was a crime committed by individuals. All of Bensonhurst did not commit this crime; rather, a few people committed this crime in Bensonhurst. We must absolutely, categorically reject the despicable notion of group guilt. We abhor those who preach it, and we must be mindful that predictions of violence and anger tend to be self-fulfilling.
We must be on guard against such impulses and we must isolate them and condemn them.
 
'We Must Repress Our Rage'
When a lawyer, defending an accused person - no matter how unpopular - is assaulted on the courthouse steps, all of us have been assaulted, because our system of justice is the best guardian of civilized society.
Hopefully, those individuals responsible for the death of Yusuf Hawkins will feel the strong arm of the law. But whatever the outcome, as we have so many times over so many years, we must repress our - our rage, channel our energies and come together to make this tragedy transforming.
I've already seen far too much pain and far too much hate in my lifetime. This city is sick of violence. And we're aching, and we must heal the pain.
Most in this town don't have it easy. People work hard and scrape by. We love our families and we try to build a life of comfort and happiness. Housing costs too much. The environment seems unsafe. The daily pounding of the prospect of crime takes its insidious toll.
And we all know that despite all we're doing a lot of things aren't getting better. Crack and AIDS are tearing away at the very fabric of our city. The economy of the region and the nation is likely to get worse before it gets better.
 
Abandoned by Washington
And we have simply been abandoned by the national Government in Washington. That you ought to applaud. [Applause.] They have abandoned us, you know. Hopefully they will come back and reclaim us. Three hundred twenty-five to $500 billion to bail out savings and loans, and no money for housing and AIDS and drug wars and the like.
As such frustrations build and pressures mount, people are more likely to lash out. In tough times child abuse increases, alcohol abuse rises and the bonds of civility and decency fray.
Unfortunately some small-minded people prey upon these pressures, spreading a message not of unity but of division, and fixing the blame not on the social and economic challenges we share, but on those who are alien or different.
I challenge all of the people of the city to reject these calls to bigotry, because if the bigots succeed in spreading their poison, it's nobody's fault but our own.
Right now, each of you must look into your own hearts, in your own families. Look honestly at yourselves and your own communities and ask whether you can be swayed by prejudice and what you're doing about it. And no matter how much government can do, government cannot substitute for the content of our character.
Let us not permit the prejudice of a few in Flatbush, in Bensonhurst or anywhere else, to silence the good will of the rest of us.
 
'It's an Old Story'
It's an old story, a cycle of immigration and discrimination that's as old as this city itself.
In the mid-19th century, gangs of native New Yorkers attacked Irish immigrants right here at Broadway and Park Row.
Irish-Americans lashed out at African-Americans in the bloody draft riots of 1863, leaving many lynched at the same time as our nation fought to free them from slavery.
In the 1870's, the Chrystie Street Gang rampaged against Italians and Jews.
During the Depression, Jews were assaulted for advocating that this country intervene in Europe to fight the facists and save the Jews.
Historians tell us that no group of European Americans has been as battered and as bruised as Italians. And African-Americans have never been free of the fear of attack.
 
'Our Greatest Strength'
Our diversity is our greatest strength, but again today it threatens to become our greatest weakness. New times bring new Americans who become new targets. And recently, too much venom has been injected into the lives of some of our newest Americans: Asian-Americans, especially Korean-Americans.
This prejudice is by no means limited to one community or one conflict. Remember, not too many - not too many years ago, some members of a community were up in arms, defiantly protesting a Korean grocery in their neighborhood - on Park Avenue.
Some Korean-Americans new to the ways of their new world may mistakenly offend others or overreact to what they perceive as provocation, and my Commissioners of Human Rights and Consumer Affairs will be holding workshops for all retailers to learn about consumer rights.
But that's not at the heart of this recent wave of anti-Asian sentiment.
Vincent Chin, in Detroit, was a young Chinese-American who lived. And some beat him because - beat him to death, I might add - because they thought he was Japanese, because they felt their jobs were threatened by Japanese competition.
They weren't after Vincent Chin per se. They would have come after any Asian just as Yusuf Hawkins could have been any African-American who happened down the street that night.
I oppose all bigotry against anyone, anywhere. I abhor it. I denounce it and I'll do anything - anything right - I'll do anything right and anything effective to prevent it.
Yet sometimes, denunciation and confrontation are simply not solutions - they may make us feel better, or some other folks feel better - just to make a bad situation worse.
 
'There From the Beginning'
I have clearly stated my views about the conflict between African-Americans and Korean-American store owners on Church Avenue in Flatbush. I oppose any boycott based on race. I've instructed officials of my government to intervene and to facilitate settlement of this dispute. We've been there from the beginning, and this situation will be resolved. . . .
 
* * *
 But whatever happened in that incident did not warrant the sort of ongoing intimidation boycotts can be. Boycotts can be an appropriate and effective response. But this one is not, and the vast majority of the people in the community know it. They know it and they believe that it ought not go on. We cannot tolerate any boycott based on race.
And so tonight I say publicly what my representatives have said privately to all parties in this dispute: that I am personally prepared to mediate, to resolve this in a constructive, peaceful way.
I call upon all involved to set aside their intransigence, to come and to sit down to settle this, and to settle it now. My personal commitment is absolute. I will bear any burden, walk any mile, and I am confident that we will be able to settle the situation through mediation and conciliation.
But please understand, this is bigger than just one boycott in Brooklyn. We must recognize that individual incidents are not isolated, but interconnected - that we must work constantly to strengthen the fabric of our diverse people and solidify the bonds of our mosaic.
And we must recognize as well that the solution is not only rhetorical, not only a function of moral guidance but a fundamental rule of government -fundamental role of government. We must perform not just in the face of crisis and conflict but every day. . . .
 
* * *
 'Media, Too, Must Join In'
 The media, too, must join in. [Heavy applause.] Very good, terrific, terrific. I could not be more delighted with that response.
I mean the media's got to join in in many ways, among them with public service announcements and programming that fights bigotry by teaching tolerance. . . .
 
* * *
 The future of this city belongs to the children of this city - all of the children of this city. And whether they or their families come from Korea or Cambodia, from Haiti, Honduras or the Soviet Union, New York is again, as it always has been, a city of immigrants.
They - they come in droves, from Ireland and India, from Jamaica and Japan, from Ecuador and El Salvador, and up from the red clay hills of Georgia, the Mississippi Delta and the streets of Memphis and Mobile. We came to escape czars and dictators, hunger and deprivation. Our people - all of our people - share a common ancestry of oppression and a common aspiration to leave that history behind and to embrace the full promise of America.
The children of the oppressed must now turn to each other as allies and neighbors instead of turning on each other as enemies.
 
Life in a Little Boy's Eyes
Tonight - tonight one of those children, a boy whose family fled from Papa Doc's Haiti, lies in a bed at New York Hospital. He's a cute little kid, a tough little rascal named David Opont. And like the city in which he lives, young David is suffering. He's scarred, and he struggles to overcome the damage that anger has inflicted upon him.
When I visited him, I saw life in his eyes. Despite all he's seen, David's eyes are wide open, looking not behind him in fright, but ahead in the fond hope that he will heal and move on.
Let us tonight resolve to make his story our story. For Little David Opont, we can emerge from the flames of anger to face a future of health and happiness.
So let's emerge from our pain not bitter but proud; let us walk together towards the future, following our hopes and not our fears.
And David, when you get up out of your bed and you're back home with your family, we want you to live in a city at peace with itself. We're going to quit tearing ourselves apart and begin the long, hard work of sewing our city back together.
If you can struggle and survive, David, so can we. Your wounds will heal and so will ours. David, we're going to do it for you, buddy, and for all like you, because you are our future.
Thank you all. God bless you. And keep the faith.

HEADLINE: U.S. SHOWS DOUBTS ABOUT GORBACHEV AND FUTURE PACTS

BYLINE: By THOMAS L. FRIEDMAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 12

 BODY:
More than at any time since President Bush took office, a deep sense of uncertainty has settled over the Administration about President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's prospects for success and his ability to conclude the broad range of Soviet-American arms-control agreements sought by Washington.
Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d leaves for Moscow on Monday for a final round of negotiations with Soviet leaders that should determine whether the May 30 summit meeting between Mr. Bush and Mr. Gorbachev will be a boon or a bust for Soviet-American relations.
Mr. Bush announced a new effort to help Eastern Europe today, saying he would try to export his ''thousand points of light'' through a new Citizens Democracy Corps to strengthen the emerging democracies. [Page 10.] Prepared for the Worst Administration officials still hope that major progress in arms control is possible, but they are prepared to come home empty-handed. 
A number of factors have left Administration officials wondering how much power or inclination Mr. Gorbachev has to conclude the far-reaching nuclear, conventional and chemical disarmament agreements that Washington hoped would be largely completed by the time of the summit meeting. Those factors include recent shifts in his relationship with his military establishment, the turmoil in the Baltic republics, the weakening of the Soviet economy and the possibility of a split at a scheduled July congress of the Soviet Communist Party.
Bush Administration officials are already trying to diminish expectations, apparently seeking to cushion the negative publicity if this week's trip goes badly, and to make any breakthroughs appear that much more dramatic.
 
U.S. Setting a Later Scenario
''It is not the end of the world if you don't conclude these agreements now,'' a top Administration policy maker said. ''If we don't do it at this summit, we will have plenty of other things to discuss. If these arms control agreements make sense for both sides, they will emerge at some point.''
Nevertheless, American officials are complaining about Mr. Gorbachev's ''foot dragging'' and asking themselves whether he will sign treaties that would force him to scrap 50 percent of his long-range nuclear weapons and 40,000 of his tanks, and reduce his chemical arsenal from 50,000 tons of poison gas to 500 tons.
''We have no real idea just how much pressure he is under,'' a senior Administration official said.
''For all of the glasnost and democratization and perestroika, we know as little today about high politics in the Soviet Union as we did in the Brezhnev regime. It is as opaque to us now as it was 10 years ago in terms of who is doing what to whom, who is cutting what deals, where the pressure is, the interpersonal dynamics of the top dozen leaders.''
The Bush foreign policy team began to have serious doubts about Mr. Gorbachev's intentions and room for maneuver after April's meeting in Washington. The Soviet Foreign Minister, Eduard A. Shevardnadze, sought to reopen a number of key arms control issues that the American side thought had been resolved during Mr. Baker's previous visit to Moscow in February, and to introduce new issues that had not even been on the table before.
During the April meeting, State Department officials said, Mr. Shevardnadze clearly took a back seat to Soviet military officials in his delegation when arms control was discussed, and since then Mr. Gorbachev seems to have gone out of his way to behave in a conciliatory manner toward the army.
 
Promotion of General
He even promoted the Defense Minister, Gen. Dimitri T. Yazov, to the honorific rank of marshal after declaring four years ago that no one else would ever be elevated to such status.
Speaking of where the Soviets were in February on many of the important arms control issues and where they are today, a senior Administration official said: ''The Soviets are going to have to march back a long way, and we are going to have to spend a lot of time on these issues. I think that this trip will be an important bellwether of the extent of the constraints on Gorbachev.''
Administration officials say that the American intelligence agencies and Government experts on the Soviet Union have at least four different explanations of Mr. Gorbachev's recent behavior, and they hope that this trip will help them determine which is correct.
The first explanation, a senior official said, ''is that the military complained that they were being excluded from the arms control negotiations and that the civilians had made a bad deal.''
''So Gorbachev said to them, 'You think you are so smart, you run the deal,' '' he said.
The army negotiators, however, were unable to get the American side to accept their demands. Since then, Mr. Baker and Mr. Shevardnadze have been quietly exchanging proposals through diplomatic channels and during one brief encounter last week in Bonn on how to overcome the main arms control disputes still outstanding.
 
Problems That Remain
Administration officials are eager to see whether Mr. Shevardnadze will have regained his lead position when they resume the formal talks in Moscow next week.
These remaining disputes are over how to limit air and sea-launched nuclear cruise missiles and long-range bombers covered by the proposed Strategic Arms Reduction Treaty; how to limit conventional fighter-bombers covered by the pending conventional arms reduction treaty in Vienna, and whether the United and States and the Soviet Union should be allowed to keep small stockpiles of chemical weapons even after the signing of an international treaty banning poison gas.
The second explanation of Soviet conduct, the senior official said, is that Mr. Gorbachev ''sees the nationalities problem exploding and the very real possibility of significant domestic unrest - strikes and so forth in the next few months. He sees just how much he is going to need the army. So he promotes Yazov to a marshal, makes several nice speeches about the military.''
By this analysis, the official added, Mr. Gorbachev has concluded that with the increasing prospect of domestic turmoil, ''it is more important to know that when he beckons the army will come than it is to ice a deal with George Bush.''
 
The Disruption Theory
A third explanation, the official said, is that the Soviet governing system is in such a state of flux - with the Communist Party weakening and new, but still undefined, power centers emerging - that all forms of authority other than Mr. Gorbachev himself have been frayed. In this analysis, Mr. Gorbachev is being inundated with thousands of small decisions every day, and may simply have not had the time or energy to focus on the arms control agenda, and will now.
A fourth explanation, another official said, is that ''everyone is over-psychoanalyzing Gorbachev and building far more complex theories about what is going on than is reality.''
The reality, he added, is that ''this is the end game in the arms control negotiations and there is always tense jockeying over the final compromises. The military has always had a strong influence in Soviet arms control policy. That is nothing new.'' As a Soviet affairs expert at Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Stephen M. Meyer, argued in a recent article, ''We have become too used to an overly compliant Gorbachev regime, one that seemed prepared to fulfill our every wish.
 
The Wily Gorbachev Theory
''When at last we are confronted with Soviet policies we do not like, we hunt for dark forces that are gaining sway over the the forces of good. But we are only fooling ourselves. Mikhail Gorbachev is going to pursue policies that he believes to be in the best interests of his country - not ours.''
Proponents of this last theory say that Mr. Gorbachev may be trying to exploit Western concerns over his political health precisely to squeeze more out of Washington at the negotiating table.

HEADLINE: News Analysis;
Dinkins, the Volume Up In a Speech on Race, the Mayor Responds To Complaint That He Hadn't Said Enough

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM

 BODY:
New Yorkers long used to a vocal white mayor some had blamed for racial tensions were suddenly grappling last week with a quiet new black mayor some blamed for not doing more to ease the turmoil.
Faced with a spate of disparate racially charged incidents, Mayor David N. Dinkins was also confronting a test of the very image that helped elect him as New York's first black mayor - that of a healer who could hold together the fractious city he calls a gorgeous mosaic. He set the challenge the day after a black teen-ager was shot to death in predominantly white Bensonhurst last August, saying, ''The tone and climate of this city does get set at City Hall.''
Now, with two juries weighing the Bensonhurst case and blacks boycotting two Korean-American groceries in Flatbush, Mr. Dinkins has been hearing conflicting advice as well as criticism. Former Mayor Edward I. Koch, the Brooklyn judge presiding over the grocery dispute and a range of others have questioned the tone Mr. Dinkins had set, saying he should have been more vocally and visibly involved. 
Implicit in much of the criticism was a suggestion that because of his reputation and his being black, Mr. Dinkins should have particular power to resolve disputes like the one between a manager and a black customer that led to the boycott of the groceries.
 
Confrontation vs. Concilitation
''I think it is true that some feel that any involvement that has as one of its components African-Americans, that I'm supposed to have some especial ability to sway,'' he said at one point last week. ''In this particular circumstance involving these particular people, my judgment at the moment is it would not assist'' to go to the store and cross the picket line.
''Some people think that confrontation is superior to conciliation,'' he said Thursday. ''I disagree.''
But also implicit in the criticism was an impatience with the Mayor, a sense that he may have swung so far toward conciliation as to have created the impression of inaction. ''Everybody for a long time would have been accustomed to precisely what Ed Koch said he would do,'' said Simon P. Gourdine, general counsel for the National Basketball Association's Players Association. ''That simply would have told people where Mayor Koch stood on the issue and that that's the choice he had made.
 
'A Different Style'
''We now have a different mayor with a different style,'' Mr. Gourdine said. ''People have elected this mayor saying we want the volume to be turned down, and so he's been turning the volume down and working behind the scenes, and now people are saying: 'Say something to us.' ''
He added: ''I think Mayor Dinkins has every desire and the will to conduct the healing process. But for anybody to think it can be done overnight, those people are naive.''
Responding to the clamor that he had turned the volume too low, the Mayor turned it up Friday night, making a televised appeal for racial unity and public order that was carried live from the City Council chamber on almost every commercial station in town.
''We gather tonight,'' he said, ''here at the seat of government, to reaffirm our commitment, to renew our mission and to reassert a simple truth: All of us want to live out lives in peace and dignity, free to walk any street and shop in any store, at any time, in any neighborhood, without fear of force or violence.''
Mr. Dinkins said unequivocally that he was prepared to mediate the boycott personally and urged the parties ''to settle this, and to settle it now.''
Still, one of the Mayor's senior aides said after the speech: ''What comes next is what matters, and there's an issue at hand. We'll see if he can settle it.''
 
Praise From Koch
How best to do that remains uncertain. In the speech, Mr. Dinkins said he would press for a series of measures to stiffen penalities for hate crimes, foster tolerance, teach merchants about consumers' rights and help small businesses.
Mr. Koch praised the speech and said Mr. Dinkins ''has a more indirect style more acceptable to some people than mine, and I hope in this case it has greater success than a more direct one that some of us were urging.''
Mr. Koch's praise was all the more noteworthy since he and Mr. Dinkins had spent the week sparring over style.
 
'Anger Out There'
One of Mr. Dinkins's senior aides said of the Mayor on Friday: ''I think he thought that because he came in with a different tone, there'd be a lessening of anger. But there's a lot of anger out there.''
The adviser said one big problem was that quiet negotiations on the boycott led by Deputy Mayor Bill Lynch took too long. In a slow news week, amid the May television ratings sweeps, public attention to the dispute increased, newspapers editorialized about it and it became even more difficult to resolve.
The Mayor and his advisers also took pains to say that the ''particular people'' in the Flatbush case are not monolithic. The protesters come from two main groups, but even a lawyer who represents them in court says he cannot speak for them all. Moreover, Mr. Dinkins has been careful to suggest that both sides probably deserve some blame in what he sees as an understandable clash of cultures, races, economic power and expectations.
The dispute is particularly delicate for Mr. Dinkins because one of the boycott's original leaders is Robert C. (Sonny) Carson, a self-professed ''anti-white'' community organizer who once worked on Mr. Dinkins's mayoral campaign.
 
Carson Disavowed
Mr. Dinkins later disavowed Mr. Carson, who was convicted in 1974 of kidnapping a man he accused of stealing money and artifacts from a small Brooklyn museum. But his involvement and remarks haunted Mr. Dinkins's efforts. Some critics have suggested that Mr. Dinkins could end the boycott if he simply condemned Mr. Carson, and have implied that he has not done so out of fear of him.
The Mayor's aides say the reality is much more subtle, and involves Mr. Dinkins's instinctive reluctance to tell any people anywhere, especially the disparate groups of black citizens with whom he has built a delicate alliance in Brooklyn, whom their leaders should be.
Mr. Dinkins is quick to remind people that he has condemned blacks with whom he has differed in the past, principally the Rev. Louis Farrakhan. Several times last week the Mayor dismissed as irresponsible comments by the Rev. Al Sharpton suggesting that racial violence could follow anything less than a murder conviction of the Bensonhurst defendants.
Archibald R. Murray, executive director of the Legal Aid Society, said Mr. Dinkins had ''promised to bring the different elements of the city together, and I think he has been doing that by establishing a kind of atmosphere of caring.''
''But I think the public always wants more, no matter how much you give,'' Mr. Murray added. ''New Yorkers are just simply extraordinarily demanding people.''

HEADLINE: 60 New Members Elected to Academy of Sciences

BYLINE: Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 12

 BODY:
The National Academy of Sciences, the 127-year-old private organization that advises the Government on science and technology, has elected 60 new members.
The election brings the Academy's membership to 1,601 scientists and engineers. Fifteen nonvoting foreign associates were also elected; their number is now 272.
Election to the Academy is considered one of the highest honors that can be accorded an American scientist or engineer. The society said the new members were elected ''in recognition of their distinguished and continuing achievements in original research.'' 
The Academy was chartered by Congress in 1863, in an act of incorporation signed by Abraham Lincoln.

PUB-DATE: May 13, 1990,

SECTION: Section 1; Part 1, Page 19, Column 1; National Desk

LENGTH: 516 words

HEADLINE: VIRGINIA GOVERNOR SEEKS DIVESTITURE

BYLINE: By B. DRUMMOND AYRES Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: NORFOLK, Va., May 12

 BODY:
Gov. L. Douglas Wilder today ordered all Virginia state agencies and institutions to divest themselves of business investments in companies that are not ''substantively free'' of economic activity in South Africa.
State officials estimate that such holdings amount to more than $750 million. Much of the money was invested by the agency that pays pensions to retired state employees. 
Mr. Wilder said people should support the efforts of South African blacks to end apartheid with the same vigor and enthusiasm that they support freedom in China and Eastern Europe.
''If we are to participate in the extension to all peoples of the freedoms and liberties which we hold dear, we must take concrete actions which reflect our support,'' said Mr. Wilder, the first black ever elected governor of a state, in a commencement address at Norfolk State University, a predominantly black institution. ''The freedom sought in South Africa is no different from the freedom sought in East Germany, in Poland and in Lithuania.''
 
Similar Steps Elsewhere
About half the states, including a number in the South, have taken steps to divest themselves of South African economic interests in the past 10 years. Hundreds of cities, counties and colleges have also divested such assets. The aim is to put economic pressure on South Africa to disassemble its apartheid system of racial separation.
Proponents of divestiture say the economic pressure is beginning to show results. They cite South Africa's recent easing of some racial strictures and the release of Nelson Mandela from prison. They also point to the Pretoria Government's opening of talks with Mr. Mandela, the dominant figure in the struggle against apartheid, and other black leaders, with the goal of sharing power with blacks.
With the divestment order today, the Governor did more than take a human rights step of considerable significance in the state that was once the centerpiece of the old Confederacy.
The move was also expected to help Mr. Wilder fend off critics who charge that the middle-of-the-road economic and social stand that helped him win the governorship are beginning to have a harmful effect on the needy, particularly blacks.
 
Criticism From Jackson
The Rev. Jesse Jackson, the two-time Democratic Presidential aspirant who has verbally sparred with Mr. Wilder in recent months, has suggested that what Mr. Wilder calls ''mainstream politics'' might well leave the poor and needy in a economic and social ''backwater,'' or even a ''cesspool.'' Some supporters see the clashes between the two men as a reflection of their rivalry to be regarded as the leading black politician in the country.
Mr. Wilder did not directly address those critics today in his commencement address. But he has insisted that ''mainstream politics are both economically sound and socially responsible.''
The Governor said in an interview shortly before he spoke that his order would undoubtedly bring him new criticism from many conservatives. ''But my order is the right thing to do, the moral thing to do,'' the Governor said.

HEADLINE: Two Oregons Collide in Race For Governor

BYLINE: By TIMOTHY EGAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: PORTLAND, Ore., May 10

 BODY:
Ever since Neil Goldschmidt, long considered one of the leading Democratic lights of the West, made a surprise announcement that he would not seek a second term as Governor of Oregon, the list of candidates to succeed him has been as varied as this state's scenery.
But the talk of the governor's race has been about something that will not appear on the primary ballot on Tuesday: the northern spotted owl, a small nocturnal bird whose existence experts say is threatened by logging, the state's leading industry.
Last month, a panel of Federal scientists recommended curtailing logging on Federal lands by about 30 percent to protect the owl. The move could cripple some of Oregon's struggling mill towns and put thousands of loggers out of work. 
But in an indication of just how much this growing state has changed in recent years, the proposal to protect the owl was hailed by the state's leading newspapers and is supported by at least half the people of Oregon, some polls show.
 
How to Reconcile Two Oregons
Trying to reconcile the two Oregons - one dependent on the traditional industry of cutting old trees, the other involving an environmentally concerned, mostly urban population - is the toughest task facing the next governor.
The leading contenders are Barbara Roberts, a Democrat who is Secretary of State and who is running unopposed in the primary, and David Frohnmayer, the State Attorney General, who is well ahead of six little-known rivals in the Republican primary.
The 49-year-old Mr. Goldschmidt has been a dominant force in Oregon politics for 20 years; he was Mayor of Portland at the age of 33 and Secretary of Transportation under President Jimmy Carter at 39. Even his closest advisers had expected him to seek re-election, and the state was shocked when he announced in February that he would not seek a second term, explaining that his marriage was breaking up and that he wanted to devote time to his personal life.
During Mr. Goldschmidt's time in office, Oregon has emerged from a long recession associated with the timber industry and has further developed other segments of its economy through international trade, tourism, agriculture and hundreds of new businesses, most of them high-tech. The state has also become a haven for people who have fled the urban woes of California for the Northwest.
 
Significant Changes
Oregon, Washington and Idaho were among the nation's top five states in job growth over the last two years. As the population has increased to slightly less than 3 million from 2.6 million in the past five years, the political makeup has also changed.
''Californians aren't moving here because they want to cut down trees,'' said Paddy McGuire, executive director of the state's Democratic Party. ''They're moving here because they want to live by them.''
The 49-year-old Mr. Frohnmayer, whose brother John is chairman of the National Endowment for the Arts, had announced plans to run for governor before Mr. Goldschmidt bowed out.
A Harvard graduate, Rhodes scholar at Oxford and former law professor at the University of Oregon, Mr. Frohnmayer calls himself ''a Republican moderate who defies ideological labels.'' A father of five he has attracted criticism from the right wing of his party in Oregon by supporting abortion rights.
He says the spotted owl recommendation, if carried out, would be ''catastrophic'' for Oregon. When he proposed further study of the issue, Ms. Roberts responded, ''The patient is bleeding to death and Dave wants to get a second opinion.''
 
'Restore One Oregon'
Although one-sixth of Mr. Frohnmayer's recent campaign contributions came from the timber industry, he says he wants to be a bridge between environmentalists and loggers. In recent polls, he leads all other candidates by about 12 points.
''I want to restore one Oregon,'' he said.
Ms. Roberts, who is 53, is a fourth-generation Oregonian, known as an energetic and feisty campaigner. Mr. Frohnmayer plans to spend about $3 million on the race and may have twice as much money as Ms. Roberts, but she says her energy will carry her to the Governor's mansion.
She has accused Mr. Frohnmayer of pandering to fears about losing logging jobs. Referring to a recent loggers' rally in Portland, where spotted owls were hanged in effigy and fights broke out between timber workers and environmentalists, Ms. Roberts said: ''How is Dave Frohnmayer supposed to be a bridge when he took part in the biggest environmental-bashing rally I've seen in years? They worked those poor timber workers into a froth.''
She said the solution to the timber crunch was to get the mill towns to do more, like making furniture and finished wood products with the state's timber.
''I'm not talking about putting timber workers on welfare, but we have to face reality,'' she said. ''This is the fastest-growing region in the country.

HEADLINE: China Waits Anxiously for Ruling On Its Trade Status With the U.S.

BYLINE: By SHERYL WuDUNN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: BEIJING, May 11

 BODY:
A highly charged issue is looming in relations between the United States and China, and it has Chinese officials and intellectuals concerned over their future, their standard of living and their contacts with the West.
The issue is most-favored-nation trading status, and the concern is over whether the United States will renew favorable treatment on tariffs to China. By June 3, President Bush will make a recommendation to Congress for a vote, and Chinese officials and business executives are worried that Mr. Bush might not recommend renewal or that Congress would block it.
As a clear gesture of conciliation toward the United States, China announced Thursday that it had released 211 political prisoners, and had earlier lifted martial law in Lhasa, the capital of Tibet, but diplomats reacted cautiously. They said it was not clear whether one or two actions would be enough to ease American indignation at political repression in China. 
 
Benefits of Trade Status
China, which exported about $12 billion worth of goods to the United States last year, has benefited enormously in the last decade from most-favored-nation status, which gives Chinese exports the same relatively low tariffs of 10 percent to 25 percent that the United States imposes on goods from most other countries. If the status were revoked, China would have to pay up to 90 percent duty on some items, mostly apparel, toys and electronics.
''If most favored nation is not renewed in June, and if Congress approves, then it could hurt both countries,'' Wei Mingyi, president of China International Trust and Investment Corporation, said in a recent interview. ''Trade between the two countries could be set back by 20 to 30 years.''
The issue comes a year and a half after China began an austerity plan that has left the economy virtually stagnant, with zero industrial growth in the first quarter this year compared to the same period last year. Inflation is down and growth rose slightly in April, but some Chinese and Western economists say it will be a tough task to stimulate the economy significantly again without bringing back inflation, which reached double digits in 1989.
 
Threat to China's Exports
From China's point of view, the threat to its exports could not come at a worse time. Revocation of most-favored-nation status could cut China's exports to the United States by about 50 percent in the first year, and more in the following years. This would mean a decline in China's exports of about $6 billion in the first year alone, amounting to about 11 percent of its total exports last year of $52.5 billion.
Trade between China and the United States has soared in recent years, and last year it rose by 43 percent over 1988 to $17.8 billion. But trade frictions between the two countries could rise regardless of whether most-favored-nation status is revoked, because of China's mounting trade surplus with the United States. In the first two months of this year, its trade surplus with the United States was $1.3 billion, or 79.2 percent higher than the surplus for the same period last year, according to statistics from the United States Department of Commerce.
At that rate, American economists estimate, China's trade surplus with the United States could reach $11 billion this year, possibly making it the country with the second highest trade surplus with the United States, after Japan.
A small minority of Chinese intellectuals interviewed say they are so disillusioned with the Government that they support revocation of most-favored-nation status, but the great majority appear to favor continuation of the trade benefits.
 
'Torn Over the Issue'
''We feel torn over the issue,'' a Chinese researcher said. ''On the one hand, we want the United States to punish the Chinese Government for what it did. But on the other hand, we know that such a punishment would affect our own personal lives, and frankly, we don't like the thought of having to endure the suffering.''
Most intellectuals say the Chinese Government would retaliate, probably at first by raising tariffs or restricting American imports, such as wheat and technology and equipment. But their anxieties go far beyond the impact on trade between the two countries. They say the Chinese Government would close its doors at least slightly to the world, restricting travel to America, cutting cultural exchanges and access to a wide range of Western things from books to fashions to ideas.
It is uncertain how the revocation of most-favored-nation status would affect Chinese politics. On the one hand, it would hurt the economy and perhaps increase the pressure within the leadership for the removal of Prime Minister Li Peng, who is in charge of the economy.
On the other hand, many Chinese say that the most likely outcome is that the hard-liners would seize the occasion to begin a campaign for self-reliance instead of openness, and encourage a new wave of anti-Americanism.
''It will deal a blow to the reformers,'' said a Chinese businessman. ''It will foster an anti-Western attitude.''

HEADLINE: Silver-Lined Defeats Worry Thatcher's Party

BYLINE: By CRAIG R. WHITNEY, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LONDON, May 12

 BODY:
For Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, even bad news brings some respite these days.
Retail prices rose 9.4 percent over the 12 months that ended April 10, the Central Statistical Office reported on Friday. It was the highest rate of increase since the year that ended in May 1982. But since the figure was lower than the 10 percent forecast the previous day by the Bank of England, stock market prices rose on Friday, and the Government maintained that its anti-inflation policies were working. 
The Government has found other silver linings. Mrs. Thatcher's Conservative Party won only 27.9 percent of the vote in the nationwide elections for local councils on May 3. But it took majorities in several important London districts, which encouraged the Prime Minister to believe that her Government had finally turned the corner.
But victories like these have not ended an incipient revolt by Conservative members of the House of Commons against her leadership of the party, several members of Parliament said in interviews this week.
Backbench Conservative members of Parliament like Tony Marlow, who describes himself as a Thatcherite, and Barry Porter, also previously regarded as a loyalist, have been saying that it is time for her to make way for someone more popular.
''The Iron Lady might be susceptible to metal fatigue,'' Mr. Marlow wrote in The Independent newspaper recently. This week he said he saw no reason to reconsider his words after the mixed results in the local elections.
''Someone more popular'' is generally taken to mean Michael Heseltine, the former Defense Secretary who resigned from Mrs. Thatcher's Cabinet in 1986 after she refused to accept his advice to keep a British helicopter company in European hands rather than let an American company buy it. But as long as Mrs. Thatcher has shown a determination to brook no challenge to her leadership, Mr. Heseltine has not issued one.
Some people thought he had done so in an article on Thursday in the Times of London. In the column, Mr. Heseltine spelled out ways that the Government could modify one of Mrs. Thatcher's most unpopular measures, the per capita community charge on local government services known as the poll tax. The tax, which is set at the same rate for dukes and dustmen by local government councils, was generally viewed as the cause of the Government's poor showing in the recent vote.
Mr. Heseltine said he accepted the idea that everybody should pay a fair share of the costs of paving the streets and collecting the garbage, but argued that the tax should be modified so that the rich paid more than the poor.
Pressed on Thursday night on a television broadcast by the British Broadcasting Corporation, Mr. Heseltine backed off from an open challenge. ''I think Mrs. Thatcher will lead the party into the next election,'' he said. ''I think the Conservatives will win it. That is my position.''
That view is held more firmly at 10 Downing Street, the Prime Minister's office. One official there said that public opinion polls, which had shown the opposition Labor Party leading by more than 20 percent in recent months, had begun to register a shift in support to the Conservatives in April.
People close to Mrs. Thatcher said that she dismissed the opposition from Mr. Marlow and Mr. Porter as insignificant. A former minister suggested that her view was incorrect and that an open move to challenge her could be expected this summer, or by the autumn at the latest.
Mrs. Thatcher does not have to call an election until mid-1992, and her close aides say that she will wait for inflation and 15 percent interest rates to decline before she puts her fate to the country. Others speculate that her husband, Denis, now 75 years old, might prevail on her to bow out.
Both Conservative and Labor members of Parliament agree that public anger over the poll tax is fiercer than any discontent they have seen since Mrs. Thatcher first took office in 1979.
''The pressure to do something about it will continue,'' one Conservative legislator said. ''I've got to worry about keeping my own seat in the next election, not just getting her re-elected.''

LENGTH: 555 words

HEADLINE: U.S. and Mexico Take Aim at Drug Chemicals

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MEXICO CITY, May 12

 BODY:
Spurred by a new American law aimed at crippling the ability of drug cartels to manufacture narcotics, the United States and Mexico are stepping up efforts to prevent thousands of tons of American-made chemicals needed to produce cocaine, heroin and other illegal drugs from flowing into Mexico.
In recent years, Mexico has emerged as a major transit point for the chemicals used by Colombian and other South American drug traffickers to transform coca paste into cocaine. The result is a flourishing chemical black market, in which the Colombian cartels, using dummy companies and multiple suppliers here, pay up to 10 times normal prices for crucial products like acetone and toluene. 
A Central Intelligence Agency study showed in 1988 that Mexico's imports of such ''precursor'' and ''essential'' chemicals increased 1,160 percent from 1983 to 1986 while Mexico's economy grew by 2.5 percent. The 1986 total, the report said, was 31,439 metric tons, compared with 7,924 tons for Colombia and 7,240 tons for Brazil, whose industrial base is twice Mexico's. A metric ton is 2,204.62 pounds.
The rise in Mexico's imports of these chemicals, which are normally used to make explosives, foam mattresses and cosmetics, coincides with strict controls on ether and acetone shipments imposed by Colombia and neighboring countries beginning in 1982 and with increased vigilance in the United States. Mexico has become the destination for about 30 percent of all exports of chemicals from the United States, including some 20 chemicals whose sale abroad is now regulated by a new law.
Under the law, formally known as the Chemical Diversion and Trafficking Act of 1988, American chemical companies must notify the United States Drug Enforcement Administration of regular foreign customers who purchase ''threshold'' amounts of the chemicals. If the D.E.A. determines there is reason to believe that the foreign company is diverting the chemicals to drug producers, it can order shipments suspended immediately.
The legislation went into effect on Nov. 1, 1989, and has been accompanied here by a parallel Mexican Government effort. Javier Coello Trejo, Mexico's Deputy Attorney General for the Investigation and Combat of Narcotics Trafficking, said agreement was reached at a meeting last year that the United States and Mexico needed to do more to halt the flow of chemicals and that the new law would provide a convenient mechanism.
''The manufacturers of these precursor chemicals are basically in Germany and the United States,'' Mr. Coello Trejo said in a recent interview. ''What we have to do is have a greater exchange of information and deeper investigation, without touching the legitimate companies.''
Mr. Coello Trejo said the focus of the effort here, with eventual D.E.A. participation, would be private companies.
Gene R. Haislip, head of the D.E.A.'s Office of Diversion in Washington, said in a telephone interview: ''There needs to be a more thorough liaison with the companies in Mexico who import or produce these chemicals. And by liaison I don't mean having a chat; I mean getting their lists of customers and investigating them.''
Officials of both countries said the chemical control effort has not been affected by tensions over the killing in Mexico in 1985 of a D.E.A. agent, Enrique Camarena.
