HEADLINE: ART VIEW;
The Modern Charts Its Course Step by Step

BYLINE: by John Russell

 BODY:
For quite some time now, a nine-word-question - ''What will become of the Museum of Modern Art?'' - has been rumbling around the art world like a freight train overheard in the dark. Ever since the great first generation of the museum's founders, supporters, curators and miscellaneous adherents began to thin out, that question has been asked.
Since the arrival in the late summer of 1988 of Kirk Varnedoe as the museum's director of painting and sculpture in succession to William S. Rubin, it is on him, above all, that speculation has been fixed. Who he is, what he stands for, what he is likely to do - all have been put into question.
It is, of course, perfectly true that he, if anyone, now has the power to reorient the museum in whatever directions seem to him best. Any indication of what he has in mind is therefore of very great interest. 
If he has not been in a hurry to make his intentions known, it is doubtless in part because the monumental exhibition called ''Picasso and Braque: Pioneering Cubism'' for which Mr. Rubin was responsible was until lately on view at the museum. That exhibition cast a very long shadow - a revised version of it can be seen, by the way, at the Kunstmuseum in Basel, Switzerland, through the middle of June - and it could be seen as the apotheosis of the High Modernism with which the museum is associated. (By High Modernism, I mean an art of supremely high quality that existed in its own right, in purely esthetic terms, and was neither the adjunct nor the derivative of any ideology, whether political or religious.) It is conceivable that someone else could have originated that exhibition in some other place, but we are at liberty to doubt it. The alliance of Mr. Rubin's lifelong ruminations, intellectual stringency and powers of persuasion with the museum's strategic advantages would be very difficult to duplicate. The closure of that exhibition marked the end of an era that did honor to the notion of the American museum as a center of pure scholarship and inspired reinterpretation.
The survey of European art from 1907 till 1940 in the painting and sculpture galleries on the second floor of the museum has been the sanctuary and prime exemplar of that same High Modernism ever since the museum was reopened in 1985. In that context, Matisse, Picasso and Miro are the museum's longtime favorites. Others much to the fore include Mondrian and De Chirico, Leger and Brancusi, Braque and Malevich, Duchamp and Klee and the young Dali.
Order and reason, limpidity and proportion are paramount. Heroes are present. Villains are not. If any of the artists in question ever had a dry or a dull period, they have them offstage. This is a stage on which no one goofs. Visitors leave convinced that this was a period in which all went well. They also leave convinced that within the walls of the Museum of Modern Art all can be seen to have gone well.
This corresponds to the stately, Eurocentric world view with which the museum opened its door in 1929. It was with Cezanne, Gauguin, Seurat and van Gogh that it greeted its first visitors, and it is with those same four painters that it greets them today. From them, all else is believed to have followed. In that matter, it has always been taken for granted in the Museum of Modern Art that the museum got its priorities right from the start and has no reason to change them.
In recent years, the tenets, and even the very existence, of High Modernism have been under attack. High art has come to be regarded by many students and scholars as something that inevitably and ineluctably has social, historical, political or spiritual origins. Not to realize that Monet's paintings of poplars and grain stacks were prompted by the state of the French economy and that Mondrian had throughout his life a theosophical orientation was thought, in their view, to have missed out on something of fundamental importance.
Given the climate of the times, and given the fact that a new man - any new man - could turn out to be an enemy within the gates of the museum, anxiety might have been widespread. Even the title of Mr. Varnedoe's first major exhibition, ''High and Low: Modern Art and Popular Culture,'' which will open Oct. 7 at the museum, reads as a challenge to those who feel that high art should be spared any such contamination. But it is Mr. Varnedoe's special gift that, although he can look at 20th-century art of all kinds and all periods in a new way, he does not feel obliged at the same time to trash the old ways.
There is among the new acquisitions at the museum which Mr. Varnedoe views with special enthusiasm a recent and very large painting of two shoes by Elizabeth Murray called ''Dis Pair.'' The shoes are those of a very young person, but the monumentality of their treatment lifts the image clear of the nursery, These are heroic shoes, with elements almost of fortress and turret. They are also shoes that double, almost, as human beings who seem to stalk one another, not quite embracing but quite possibly with that in mind.
Between heroism and domesticity, the scales are nicely balanced. Between abstraction and a distilled and heightened figuration, the dialogue is one between equals. To lead a double life of that sort was for many years to be excluded from the modernist canon. But Elizabeth Murray is one of the artists who have proved that that particular taboo has had its day. That Mr. Varnedoe should stand behind this painting has a topical importance - as do, for that matter, any number of the recent drawings acquisitions that can be seen in the drawings galleries. John Elderfield, who is in charge of drawings at the museum, is himself no mean champion of High Modernism, but his current show of ''Drawings From the 80's'' is completely ecumenical in tone.
In any case, we shall by the end of this year have a much clearer idea of what Mr. Varnedoe may have in mind for the Museum of Modern Art with ''High and Low: Modern Art and Popular Culture.'' Meanwhile, we can walk into the bookstores almost any day now and come out with his new book, which is called ''A Fine Disregard: What Makes Modern Art Modern'' and is published by Harry N. Abrams.
It is not for me to pre-empt either the content or the impact of ''A Fine Disregard.'' But the title happens to be fundamental to his spring-heeled, inquisitive and trenchant views on modern art. The specific ''fine disregard'' of which he writes was not demonstrated by this artist or that, but by a young Englishman called William Webb Ellis.
On the playing fields of Rugby School, in the year 1823, William Webb Ellis was playing what is called in England association football, or soccer. Fired by what the stone plaque at the school calls ''a fine disregard'' for the rules of the game as they then existed, he decided that there were better things to do with the ball than kick it around. Forthwith, he picked it up in his arms and ran with it. From this glad aberrancy was born the game of ''rugger,'' which in its pure form flourishes in England to this day.
Mr. Varnedoe tells this story with evident enjoyment, and he writes as someone who has actually made a pilgrimage to the primal scene. Not only that, but the first two illustrations in his book are, first, of the field in question and, second, of the plaque that commemorates Ellis's inspired departure from the rules.
It could be no more than a fragment of autobiography. But it is Mr. Varnedoe's contention that the makers of modern art were men and women who, in effect, picked up the ball and ran with it, while all around them were still stuck with kicking it. The book begins with William Webb Ellis, and it also ends with him. Of the makers of the art we call ''modern,'' Mr. Varnedoe says that ''they echo what Ellis demonstrated in 1823: that if you want to do something really important, the answer is not over the horizon. It is often right under your nose, lying right at your feet. And what the modern tradition says is that you do not get anywhere by kicking that around. You pick it up and run with it.''
As he sees it, there was in the great achievements of modern art an element not of literally high-flown ambition but of ''transforming the world by using what lay at hand.'' Kirk Varnedoe beyond a doubt will bring the Museum of Modern Art into a new climate of interpretation that will have been nurtured in part by himself. But this is not to say that existing sources of wonder will be rejected.
It has long been known, for instance, that at the time when they were working very closely together Picasso and Braque used to call one another Wilbur and Orville, after the brothers Wright whose inventions were all the rage at the time. This has often and rightly been linked to the use in a Picasso of 1912 of the slogan, ''Our Future Is in the Air.''
But Mr. Varnedoe suggests that ''what they found thrilling about the Wright brothers had nothing to do with the view their airplane offered from overhead. The truly astonishing thing was that two mechanics from Dayton, Ohio, had solved a problem that had beaten Leonardo da Vinci. A challenge that had fascinated man since before mythology had been licked by two tinkerers who put their machine together using bicycle parts.'' What Picasso and Braque were doing in 1912 was, of course, precisely the same. When they made great art, it was with the leavings of the cafe table and yesterday's newsprint. The fact that Kirk Varnedoe can take the parallel between Picasso and Braque and Orville and Wilbur and make something new of it shows that he too can pick up the ball and run with it. The spirit of 1823 on the playing fields of Rugby School is still in being. Long may it live!

GRAPHIC: Photo: Elizabeth Murray's ''Dis Pair''-a balance of heroism and domesticity that once meant exclusion from the modernist canon (The Museum of Modern Art)

HEADLINE: Buying the Right to Pollute

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Barry Commoner is right (''Free Markets Can't Control Pollution,'' April 15). You cannot reduce pollution by selling the right to pollute. But he is only half right. The free-market solution doesn't involve selling pollution permits, rather it lets polluters buy off-site pollution reduction. It allows those polluters who can cut back most cheaply to do so first and most. This allows those polluters whose task is most expensive to buy pollution reduction from the low-cost pollution reducer. That will save jobs, keep costs down, raise capital for further pollution reduction and avoid the kind of coercion contrary to the spirit of our democracy.
Mr. Commoner is clear and forthright about the costs of continued pollution, which are unbearably high. But he fails to consider the gargantuan cost of totally retooling every aspect of American life. It's a big expensive job that has to be done. Lets do it in a way that is least destructive to our way of life. Lets try to cut back on pollution at as low a social and economic cost as practical. We can leave the wastefully expensive ''solutions'' to the Pentagon.
 HENRY JASEN
Seattle, April 16

HEADLINE: Currency;
A Bad Week for the Dollar

 BODY:
It was a bad week for the dollar. First, on Wednesday, it dropped sharply against the West German mark, the Swiss franc and other European currencies. Then on Friday, the other shoe fell, as the dollar plummeted against the Japanese yen. The dollar has been weak against the mark and most Europen currencies all year but strong against the yen. The move last week was triggered by a change in sentiment about interest rates in the United States. Until last week, the odds favored an increase in rates. Now the betting is for no change or maybe even a decrease. Friday's inflation report, showing a decline of three-tenths of 1 percent in the Producer Price Index for Finished Goods, just reinforced the belief that interest rates might actually decline.

HEADLINE: MARKET WATCH;
Wall Street Is Celebrating Despite Tax Talk

BYLINE: By Floyd Norris

 BODY:
Nobody ever went broke underestimating the fiscal irresponsibility of American politicians.
That sentiment, with apologies to H. L. Mencken, summarized a prevalent Wall Street reaction to last week's new round of tax talk in Washington. With signs of economic weakness becoming more apparent, the betting among many traders is that the Government and the Federal Reserve are more likely to find ways to stimulate the economy than to restrain it by raising taxes or interest rates. 
The result was an old-fashioned buying stampede on Friday, after the Government put out the latest economic statistics, saying that retail sales were weak, especially for the durable goods where purchases can be deferred, and inflation was tame.
The Dow Jones industrial average, having risen steadily for a couple of weeks, shot up 63.07 points, to 2,801.58 that day, on the highest volume of 1990. That is less than nine points from the Dow's record high, set on Jan. 2, and is the best daily gain in a year. Smaller stocks rose less sharply, and are nowhere near their highs, but they rallied nonetheless.
The bond market led the way up for stocks, with the new 30-year Treasury bond yielding just 8.63 percent, down from the 8.84 percent it fetched at the auction just the day before, as the Treasury's quarterly refunding ended on a positive note.
Just how long this buoyant spirit will last may be another question. Only two weeks ago, bond rates were above 9 percent, stock prices were weak and most market seers thought those trends would continue. Now the opposite convictions prevail.
Proof that George Bush is serious about raising taxes could change that rosy outlook, which is why some traders took comfort from White House leaks that the whole effort was a move to trap the Democrats, followed by statements from Democrats that they were not wed to the idea of higher taxes.
While fiscal responsibility is always praised on Wall Street, raising taxes now would be likely to further slow the economy.Bond traders might like that, but it could instill recession fears in the stock market, fears that might not be offset even if there were the accompanying good news of a cut in capital gains taxes.
Economic weakness would, in another era, have been a reason to cut taxes. But having run huge deficits in good times, the Government now faces rapidly escalating deficits as the slow economy depresses tax revenues. The legacy of the Reagan era may be a Government that found it necessary to borrow and spend when the economy could have gotten along without the stimulus, only to cut back when business activity needs a boost.
But even without a tax increase, the dollar could prove to be the wild card that deflates market sentiment. Almost overlooked in the celebration Friday was the fact that the dollar was falling nearly as rapidly as stock and bond prices were rising. A Treasury bond now is worth fewer Japanese yen or Swiss francs than before the rally began May 4.

HEADLINE: FORUM;
Leave the Stock Index Futures Alone

BYLINE: By WILLIAM P. ALBRECHT; William P. Albrecht is a commissioner at the Commodity Futures Trading Commission.

 BODY:
In New York and Washington these days, there is a lot of grumbling about stock index futures. These are contracts to buy or sell the value of a stock index, like the Standard & Poor's 500, on a future date at a price established when the contract is entered into.
One argument in particular that has captured attention is that, at 10 percent, margins on these indexes are too low, causing turmoil in our markets. This argument is not new. After the stock market crash in October 1987, there was a great clamor to raise margins on stock index futures. Then, as the issues were analyzed, and as the market calmed down, pressure diminished. Now, the proposal has resurfaced The ostensible reason for raising margins keeps shifting. The proponents of higher margins started with concern over financial integrity, then shifted to volatility, and are now pushing the rather slippery notion of the need for harmonization. None of these arguments hold water. 
* Financial integrity. The purpose of margins on futures contracts is to protect the financial integrity of the market by insuring that both parties to a contract fulfill their obligations. This system works very well and no investor lost money due to default in the futures market in either October 1987 or October 1989.
* Volatility. To reduce volatility, we must reduce speculation in index futures by raising margins, proponents say. While this line of reasoning may sound plausible, neither economic theory nor the extensive statistical analysis conducted to date provide any support for the idea that index futures increase price volatility in the underlying cash market. In fact, they overwhelmingly indicate exactly the opposite: On Oct. 19, 1987, for example, the largest price declines occurred when index arbitrage volumes were at their lowest.
* Forced selling to meet margin calls. Even if stock index futures do not usually increase volatility, the proponents of higher margins claim they do in times of market stress. But if this were true, wouldn't we see a net close-out of futures positions on high-volatility days? In fact, on both Oct. 19, 1987, and Oct. 13, 1989, just the opposite was true - on balance, people were moving into stock index futures.
* Harmonization. Reason has taken its toll among some, and many proponents of higher margins no longer rely upon the volatility rationales. Instead, they push for higher margins in order to ''harmonize'' them, claiming that the link between the stock market and the stock index futures market requires that there be a link between margins on stocks and margins on index futures. Margins do not have to be the same, the argument runs, but they should be harmonized; strangely enough, this always means that stock index futures margins should be higher.
These critics argue that the difference between stock margins of 50 percent and those of stock index futures margins is inequitable. It is important to note, however, that the stock margins actually required of professionals are only about 20 to 25 percent. Thus, a more accurate comparison of margins is 25 percent to 10 percent. Wholly different margining systems have evolved in the futures and securities markets. The futures system provides for daily settlement of positions and continuous adjustment of margin levels to take into account market volatility. The system for margining stock transactions permits up to five days for settlement, and margin levels are not adjusted to account for market volatility. The fact that no one is suggesting that the futures margining systems be harmonized in these other respects suggests that something may be right with the existing system.
There really is no proven case for raising margins. Much of the support for this proposal comes from those in the securities industry who believe their financial woes would be cured by imposing higher costs on their competitors in the futures industry. Even if they are right about the cause of their problems (and I do not think they are), the solution is surely not to raise margins. All this will do is shift futures business overseas.

LENGTH: 2021 words

HEADLINE: Rouse's New Strategy: Mixed Use and 'Remerchandising'

BYLINE: By CLAUDIA H. DEUTSCH

DATELINE: COLUMBIA, Md.

 BODY:
Most of the time, Mathias J. DeVito is an even-tempered man. But lately, there is a surefire formula for getting a rise out of him: Repeat some of the things analysts are saying about the Rouse Company, the real estate development firm he has headed since 1979.
Suggest that Rouse, with a breakup value at least $10 a share higher than the $24-or-so price its stock is stuck at, is prime takeover material. Or that its new mixed-use project - hotels, office buildings and shopping centers in Phoenix - is a sure loser. Or that it does not know how to operate outside a narrow Northeast corridor.
To Mr. DeVito, a tanned, well-groomed man who looks far younger than his almost-60 years, all those speculations can be summed up in one word: ''Nonsense!'' To hear him tell it, Rouse is a national company whose skills extend readily into mixed-use projects and the only people thinking takeover are hopeful arbitragers. 
Still, there is one Wall Street concern that he cannot dismiss: The days of rampant growth for Rouse's specialty - regional malls and urban centers like Boston's Faneuil Hall - are over. ''It would be hard to find a major market that doesn't have sufficient retail space by now,'' Mr. DeVito conceded. So for the last three years Mr. DeVito has been rethinking Rouse's 50-year strategy of constantly building new malls. Now, he says, Rouse's growth will come from ''managing and remerchandising things that have already been built - by us or someone else.''
Indeed, Rouse already has begun sprucing up many of its older centers and fine-tuning their tenant mix to make sure they aren't trying to sell merchandise at upper-class prices in neighborhoods that have gone downhill. Rouse has a contract to manage Underground Atlanta, a festival center that, despite a past history of losses, is now thriving. And Rouse has acquired a portfolio of more than $1 billion in new properties, most of it through joint-venture agreements with the Cigna Corporation and the Teachers Insurance and Annuity Association.
With the T.I.A.A., Rouse spent $500 million to acquire McCormick & Company's real estate subsidiary, which owns 90 office buildings and more than 500 acres of land. Rouse and the T.I.A.A. have also bought about a dozen shopping centers. Rouse and Cigna, meanwhile, have spent $250 million to buy three large centers, and have another $250 million earmarked to buy more.
In keeping with Rouse tradition, Rouse's partners are putting up most of the money. One reason: Rouse has always found heavy debt to be anathema. Part of it is just a management bent to shy away from overfinancing. But part of it also is fear of raising shareholder's ire.
''Any developer should think twice before taking on a lot of debt, but when you're a public company it is even more important to manage conservatively,'' said David L. Tripp, Rouse's director of investor relations.
That constraint has pluses as well as minuses, Mr. DeVito said. ''The public format forces us to marry risk-taking with strong financial controls,'' he said. ''And that protects us from the vices, the excesses of entrepreneurship.''
Marketplace realities may be enough to curb Melvin Simon & Associates, Ernest W. Hahn Inc., and many of Rouse's privately held competitors. ''Cost of funds is up, consumer spending is down, land is more expensive, so returns are going to be lower than they were five years ago,'' said Kevin E. Benson, chief executive officer of the Trizec Corporation, the huge Toronto real estate company that owns Ernest Hahn and a good chunk of Rouse.
Thus, analysts suspect most of Rouse's competitors will follow Rouse's example. ''The whole real estate business is evolving out of development and into acquisition, management and finance, and my sense is that Rouse is further along the curve than the rest,'' said Robert A. Frank, an analyst with Alex. Brown & Sons who recommends Rouse stock as a long-term buy.
For Rouse, more than for any of its competitors, shifting gears from building to managing requires a wrenching cultural change.
James W. Rouse founded the company in 1939, primarily to do mortgage banking. He took it public in 1957 in order to raise money to build shopping centers.
From the first, Mr. Rouse, an idealist cum businessman, wanted to help revitalize old cities. The way to do it, he felt, was to create large, clean shopping and entertainment centers that would lure people back to downtown areas. City officials loved the idea - and proved it with funding and tax abatements.
Rouse's first such festival center - or ''urban marketplace,'' Mr. DeVito's preferred term - was Faneuil Hall in Boston. It opened to applause in 1976, and was followed in 1980 by Baltimore's Harborplace. Rouse has 14 such centers now, the latest being Pioneer Place in Portland, Ore., as well as 54 large malls and seven smaller ones.
All of Rouse's projects are known for art shows, promotions and other local activities that bring people in to browse, perchance to buy. Although restaurants and clothing chains are the bread and butter of the shopping centers, Rouse goes after local merchants, too. A few years ago it put movable carts in some centers for local entrepreneurs to sell their wares. If their merchandise didn't sell, not much was lost; if it did, the seller usually opened a full store in the mall.
Rouse's retail tenants are a loyal lot. The Limited, for one, has more than 200 stores at Rouse centers. ''Rouse knows how to turnJU their centers into hubs of community activity and they are excellent marketers,'' said George R. Sappenfield, The Limited's director of real estate.
The chief executive of another large retailing chain, who requested anonymity, said: ''Too many developers worry exclusively about the financial stability of tenants, so you wind up with boring centers full of shoe stores. Rouse brings in offbeat tenants, and that makes their centers more interesting.''
Still, no one is certain that just because Rouse is good at running Eastern mega-malls, it will be successful at the projects it is trying now. ''What does Rouse know about mixed-use offices?'' Mr. Frank asks.
Burland B. East 3d, an analyst with Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards Inc., has similar concerns. ''Till now, 90 percent of their business has been in the East,'' he said. ''Now they're in Phoenix, in Seattle. Take a fish out of its pond, you lose something.'' Indeed, there is good reason to believe that Rouse's old formulas may no longer work. Mr. Rouse, who left his company in 1979 to form a non-profit development concern, has been trying to draw stores and visitors to a new center in downtown Toledo. Neither group is particularly interested.
Some real estate experts say what ails Mr. Rouse in Toledo will ail Rouse Company centers in Phoenix and in New York. ''In Phoenix, like Toledo, the downtown isn't viewed negatively - it is just irrelevant,'' said David J. Habert, senior associate for the Project for Public Spaces Inc., which does research into the use of public spaces. ''And introducing yet another shopping experience in Manhattan is redundant,'' he said.
It is exactly this kind of pessimism that gets Mr. DeVito's dander up. He points to the Gallery, Rouse's wildly successful mixed-use building near Harborplace, which houses offices, a hotel, and an array of stores. ''How can anyone suggest we don't know how to run anything but malls?'' he asks.
He notes that Manhattan's South Street Seaport is in the red only because of huge cost overruns and delays when it was built, and that sales per square foot are brisk. He concedes that Rouse lost a major tenant for its Phoenix center when Merabank Savings and Loan, which was to occupy 42 percent of one of the office buildings, pulled out of the deal, but the Pinnacle West Capital Corporation, Merabank's parent, has taken the space.
Even the lackluster performance of Rouse's stock is due to perceptions beyond Rouse's control. The real estate bloodbath that has swept the country has been far worse in residential and office space than in retailing space. Still, ''every major bank with real estate exposure is taking nine figure writedowns in the past 12 months, with the result that trying to sell real estate stocks is like trying to sell cancer,'' said Mr. East.
Maybe so, but Rouse has one thing that could make shareholders take notice: Columbia, Md., a thriving city of some 73,000 people that Mr. Rouse conceived and built. His idea was that a new city, comprised of a series of small villages not centered around one big downtown, could avoid the problems that older cities have.
Columbia has done that, and admirably so. In fact, for the last few years, many of the profits that Rouse has shown have been from selling land in Columbia. Now Mr. DeVito has made Columbia the one exception to his manage-don't-build strategy. Rouse has all but stopped selling land in Columbia, and is instead hoping to develop it itself. ''Columbia is one of the few places left that is under-retailed,'' said Danice S. Taylor, a Rouse sales representative.
Stopping the land sales hit earnings badly. Although Rouse's 1989 revenues were $495 million, up from $461 million in 1988, net earnings were only $9.7 million, down from $20 million the year before.
Rouse insists that earnings from its operating retail properties, measured before depreciation and deferred taxes, are a better indication of its financial health. And indeed, those earnings have been growing at a compound rate of more than 17 percent for the last 10 years. Last year, they topped $60 million, up from $51 million in 1988.
With a few exceptions like New Orleans, where a stagnating economy has killed retail sales, Rouse's centers continue to do well. ''Gas lines, credit crunches - I haven't seen the economic scenario yet that has given them a punch in the nose,'' Mr. DeVito said. Robert C. Adler, an analyst with Goldman Sachs who recommends that his clients buy Rouse stock, offers a simple reason: ''A well-situated regional mall just cannot be duplicated,'' he said.
Whether Rouse's past successes can be, though, remains to be seen.
 
 
 
A RUN AT ROUSE SEEMS UNLIKELY
The kind of depressed earnings and share prices hitting Rouse right now should be strong attractants for takeover sharks. After all, Rouse's stock is selling at a good $10 a share below the company's breakup value, and Rouse has no poison pill.
But no one is expecting an imminent run at Rouse. The reason: The majority of Rouse's stock is in friendly hands.
Management and directors own about 15 percent of the company, with Rouse Chairman Mathias J. DeVito himself holding about 700,000 shares. The Trizec Corporation, the huge Canadian real estate developer, owns about 25 percent. Trizec must give Rouse six months' notice if it wants to increase its stake above 27.5 percent; Rouse, in turn, must give six months notice if it wants to put in a poison pill. Neither Mr. Mathias nor Kevin E. Benson, Trizec's chief executive, plan to change the status quo any time soon.
Another 20 percent of Rouse is owned by about a dozen large institutions, who fully understand the breakup value of the land and shopping centers that Rouse owns, and would be unlikely to tender their stock for anything below that value. ''Even if this company were put into play, it wouldn't wind up being a bargain for anyone,'' Mr. DeVito said.

The New York Times

PUB-DATE: May 13, 1990,

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2, Column 3; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1627 words

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIARY

BYLINE: By ALLEN R. MYERSON

 BODY:
COMPANIES
 
Partying, the Fed's Way
 
Federal Reserve Board chairmen have never tired of repeating William McChesney Martin's definition of their role: ''To take away the punch bowl just as the party gets going.'' Now comes the current chairman, Alan Greenspan, to urge bankers to keep partying even without the punch bowl. He joined other top regulators on Thursday in asking bank executives to continue lending to sound customers, rather than strangle the economy with tight credit. ''The nature of banking is risk-taking,'' Mr. Greenspan reportedly said. ''And if you have zero loan losses, then you aren't doing your job.'' The bankers responded with complaints about the regulators' previous party-pooping: warnings about imprudent real estate loans; tougher restrictions on small-business loans; Federal auditors swarming over the bankers' books, forcing them to take losses. Neal Soss, chief economist at First Boston, says the Fed would rather have banks provide more credit than risk easing its own interest rates. ''A little bit of action on all the levers,'' he said, ''is probably better than relying too much on any one of them.'' 
 
 
Whichaway Was That?
 
Like an unruly hospital patient who sticks his thermometer into ice water one day, hot coffee the next, the economy has been sending conflicting signals. On Friday, it was reported that inflation and economic growth had cooled. Producer prices for April were off three-tenths of 1 percent; retail sales off six-tenths of 1 percent. A couple of weeks ago, the economy and prices appeared to be near boiling. ''We seem to be doing a complete about-face,'' said William V. Sullivan Jr., director of money market research at Dean Witter Reynolds. The worried relatives in this case are the traders who propelled rates on Treasury bonds past 9 percent early this month. Rejoicing at Friday's news, they sent rates down to about 8.66 percent as the stock market soared 63.07 points.
 
 
Tax, Here Comes Thy Sting
 
In the movies as in politics, the unpalatable or unwholesome seeks refuge in euphemism. Everyone knows what adult entertainment is, and soon everyone will know the meaning of budget talks to proceed, in the President's words, with ''no conditions.'' Conditions and preconditions ruling out tax increases dropped faster than Washington's cherry blossoms amid estimates last week of a 1991 budget deficit as high as $165 billion.
 
 
Uncle Sam's Sale Days
 
Anyone trying to sell a Houston house, a Miami hotel or a Denver condominium had better do it fast lest the Government dump similar properties next door. The Resolution Trust Corporation decided last week to allow markdowns on its $16 billion-plus inventory of real estate from troubled savings and loans. The sales have been going slowly, with delays costing taxpayers $250 million a month.
 
 
Rate Break for the Treasury
 
No credit-market calamities in the Treasury's quarterly auctions. The Government sold $31 billion in notes and bonds at rates higher than in February, but lower than market watchers had feared.
 
 
 
ECONOMY
 
 
Just Wait for Icahn's Act II USX X stays intact; Carl C. Icahn stays in touch. Mr. Icahn conceded last week that the company's stockholders had voted down his plan to get rid of the steel business but stay in the energy business. Mr. Icahn, the company's largest shareholder, said his scheme would make USX stock soar; the company's partisans said it would merely help a corporate raider cash in his stake at a huge profit. Bryan Jacoboski, an analyst at PaineWebber, says that USX might eventually compromise by selling some of the steel operation to the public without spinning it off entirely. One way or another, he said, the company will still have to reckon with Mr. Icahn. ''He's not going to disappear,'' Mr. Jacoboski said. ''There will definitely be another act.''
 
 
The Dime Has a New Chief
 
Remarkable how little attention Richard D. Parsons got last Monday for becoming the first black chief executive of a financial institution as large as the Dime Savings Bank of New York. But Mr. Parsons, 42, is just as happy: ''I don't like to blow that horn,'' he said. He would sooner speak of having been counsel to Nelson A. Rockefeller as both Governor of New York and Vice President, or his former partnership in a law firm that served the Dime, or his plans for expanding the Dime's size without expanding its risks. With $11.7 billion in assets, the Dime, is regarded as one of the healthiest savings and loans in the Northeast. It avoided lending to construction projects and leveraged buyouts, but some mortgage loans have soured. Look for the Dime to pursue more consumer business and more acquisitions.
 
 
The Mass Market Work Station
 
The work station - the heavy-duty desktop computer favored by scientists and engineers - is elbowing its way into the personal computer market. Price is key; Wall Street analysts said that Sun Microsystems Inc. plans to introduce a powerful model this week that will sell for $5,000, about the cost of some high-end personal computers but faster, with whiz-bang graphics. They expect the work station to be a hit with major corporations, whose quantity discounts will pull the price down to about $3,000. Mark D. Stahlman, an analyst at Alex. Brown & Sons, says that the company has attracted orders to install several extensive work station networks. He predicts that Sun will provide hardware for companies that might otherwise have bought personal computers. ''They are in a unique position to win large commercial bids,'' he said. Rivals - including Hewlett-Packard's Apollo division, which sells a less powerful work station for under $4,000 - say they are ready to match whatever Sun offers.
 
 
In Brief
 
Cats can be environmentally correct, too. Alpo Petfoods Inc. said last week that its cat food will contain only tuna caught with nets that don't snare dolphins as well.
 
*
 
The natin's largest coal company is the subject of a bidding war. Amax Inc. bid $1.25 billion for the Peabody Coal Company on Friday. Hanson P.L.C. of Britain, which owns 45 percent of Peabody, offered $725.6 million for the rest.
 
 
 
INTERNATIONAL
 
Ponying Up for the I.M.F.
 
The International Monetary Fund's agreement last week to add $60 billion to its loan pool looks as much like the start of a debate as the end. United States reluctance in three years of negotiations helped delay an agreement on higher fund contributions initially scheduled for completion in 1988. Several I.M.F. members say the new money will be inadequate to save third world nations from their staggering debts or convert Eastern Europe into a modern market economy. ''They've already been too niggardly in the amounts they've made available.'' said C. Fred Bergsten, director of the Institute for International Economics. The United States has agreed to consider increases in financing in 1993. If the talks take as long as the last round, they might best begin tomorrow.
 
 
Super-Concorde, Super Price
 
British Aerospace and the French Aerospatiale had hoped to sell 300 Concordes. They sold 13. On Wednesday, they came out with plans to build a plane that could fly twice as far with twice the passengers, and cost more than four times as much to develop. The original Concorde has fallen victim to the unforeseen. Much higher fuel prices made its flights economical only for European and Wall Street royalty; a short range kept it from linking Asia with other continents, and its noise kept it from flying from coast to coast in the United States. As for the super-Concorde, it would take super-long to develop - five years for research, eight for production and at least two for testing. Who can say that a $9 billion to $14 billion bet on what the world will be like in the year 2005 will turn out any better than the $2 billion bet on the situation in the 1970's?
 
 
Forget German Inflation, O.K.?
 
West German officials declared last week that fretting about any inflation resulting from reunification is verboten. Fie on the bond traders who have beaten down West German debt on fears of inflation. Even Karl Otto Pohl, president of the nation's central bank, has joined the pacification and soothing squad. A few months ago, he was positively alarmist, saying that rapid currency union with East Germany was sure to unleash new, inflationary demand for West German goods. Politicians rushed along the reunification process anyway. Last week, Mr. Pohl assured International Monetary Fund representatives that a common currency ''will not lead to unreasonable inflation pressures.'' Some economists are revising their views likewise, after discovering that the East Germans might have too little money to make any blessed difference.
 
 
Wyoming in New York
 
From Bauhaus to our house to the Ginza: Tom Wolfe, the writer, turned up in a panel discussion last week to compare New York, whose business culture he has written about exhaustively, with Tokyo, which he has just visited. He found Tokyo far more crowded but far cleaner. ''New York looks like Wyoming compared to Tokyo, and yet there is no litter,'' he said. ''I went to the Tokyo Stock Exchange, and there was the same frenzy, but there was no paper on the floor. There were people who catch it before it hits the floor.'' But Kazuki Kasuya, a leading Japanese magazine editor, said his nation was eagerly absorbing New York's influence the way it once adopted Buddhism from China. ''New York has become the city of admiration,'' he said, where young Japanese dream of going ''to be recognized as world-class artists or businessmen.''

Copyright 1990 The New York Times Company 
The New York Times

PUB-DATE: May 13, 1990,

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1, Column 2; Financial Desk

LENGTH: 2860 words

HEADLINE: Are We Eating Our Seed Corn?

BYLINE: By JOHN HOLUSHA

 BODY:
It was a moment of triumph for John F. Welch Jr., the chairman of the General Electric Company.
To the plaudits of securities analysts in New York last November, he declared that G.E. would purchase up to $10 billion worth of its own stock over the next five years, the single largest gesture of its kind in history. Buying the stock, Mr. Welch said, was a better way to generate value for shareholders than taking a ''wild swing'' on an acquisition or investing in new technology.
Wall Street apparently agrees. Mr. Welch has since been hailed as a tough-minded, results-oriented manager, and G.E. shares have climbed by more than 23 percent, to about $68, compared with the 3 percent rise in the Standard & Poor's 500. A company's stock price usually rises after a buyback because, with fewer shares in circulation, its earnings-per-share ratio is likely to improve. 
But many economists, scholars, executives and other experts on American industrial policy say that financial engineering of this sort is often indicative of short-term thinking and a lack of confidence. They say it is sapping the nation's global competitiveness.
Rather than buying stock, they say, chief executives like Mr. Welch should be investing in new products and processes to keep home-grown inventions from being wrested away by more efficient producers abroad. And they should be plowing money into leading-edge technologies and into basic research to develop products not even imagined today.
Otherwise, companies in Europe and Asia will surpass the United States, as they have done in consumer electronics, machine tools and semiconductors. And that could endanger America's wealth. ''If we are not willing to get to a long-term orientation, we are going to lose one strategic industry after another, and that has implications for our standard of living,'' said Representative Mel Levine, a Democrat from California.
Corporate America's preoccupation with quarterly results emerged as a serious irritation in the 1980's. But some experts believe the 90's may provide an opportunity for change. Hostile takeovers and ''junk bond'' financing, which drove companies to keep their stock prices aloft to avoid being a target of predators, have fallen out of favor. And institutional investors, politicians, economists and the industries themselves are stepping forward with their pet incentives for change.
But the remedies will need to be potent. Industrial America, some experts believe, has lost its vision and nerve. ''Deep down, there is a defeatist attitude in this country about manufacturing,'' said Andrew Grove, the president of Intel Inc., a world leader in computer chip manufacturing. ''Part of the justification process for investments includes figuring out how to compete with the Japanese. There have been few success stories.''
Perhaps nothing is more symptomatic of this malaise than the growing popularity of stock repurchases. ''The attitude is to throw up their hands,'' said Michael Borrus, a professor at the University of California at Berkeley. ''They figure, 'If I cannot compete, at least I can boost my stock price.' ''
But the buybacks, critics warn, hurt all companies by shrinking the pool of available capital. Shareholders who sell their stock after a buyback-induced price rise reinvest only about a third of the proceeds, estimated Fred Branfman, director of Rebuild America, a lobbying organization in Washington that advocates increased industrial investment.
''It is now clear that a lot is lost to consumption - to swimming pools and things like that,'' said Lester Thurow, dean of the Sloan School of Management at the Massachussets Institute of Technology.
What also disturbs some economists is that the practice is no longer just a novelty among the dozen or so companies the nation depends on to lead innovation. Among them are G.E., International Business Machines, the Ford Motor Company and General Motors - companies that by virtue of their size and brainpower are best equipped to do battle in the global war zone.
 
A Balancing Act
 To be sure, the leaders of these companies believe they are doing what is best for their businesses and shareholders - balancing short-term financial considerations against longer-term goals. Most say they are adequately financing research and development and spending enough on new plants and equipment.
It is difficult to compare investment levels from company to company. One may spend less than another on research, but may use those dollars more efficiently. And critics empathize with chief executives' philosophical balancing act.
But they wonder if the money companies are devoting to buybacks wouldn't be more wisely spent strengthening their businesses. When they examine particular buybacks, critics often speak of missed opportunities.
* G.E. might have pursued consumer electronics like television and other high-risk markets rather than withdrawing to concentrate on areas where competition is more limited.
* Instead of sinking more than $10 billion into a series of stock purchases, I.B.M. might have lunged more aggressively into the critical supercomputer segment or pursued the laptop computer market.
* To help shore up its shrinking market share, G.M. could have used the $2 billion it has spent on stock since 1987 to build cars with more distinctive designs.
* The Chrysler Corporation, which has spent $1.4 billion on stock since 1984, could have developed its own subcompact cars rather than buying them from Japan.
* Instead of spending what could approach $1 billion on stock, Honeywell Inc. might have stuck it out in the computer market and in semiconductor manufacturing.
* Apple Computer, which said in March that it would add five million shares to its repurchase program, lacks innovative new products.
Like G.E., these companies contend that the stock repurchases were the best available use for surplus cash. Each said their objective was to increase shareholder value by acting as a steady buyer for their shares.
Mr. Welch declined to be interviewed for this article. But discussing G.E.'s vitality, Joyce Hergenhan, vice president for public relations, asserted that the company has remained at the forefront of businesses in which it has chosen to compete. ''We are world leaders in medical imaging,'' she said. ''We are world leaders in gas turbines. We are world leaders in plastics. Do we have to be in Walkmen and panty hose as well?''
Clearly, companies have also been spooked by the corporate raiders. Chief executives have been forced to make shareholder returns their top priority over the last decade or risk an uninvited takeover. And for the United States, a company like G.E. is worth more whole than broken into pieces, sold to raise cash by a raider.
Indeed, stock buybacks and other defensive acts are ''an unfortunate corollary of the takeovers and mergers and financial manipulations of the last few years,'' said Ira Magaziner, a management consultant who counts G.E. among his clients.
Several academic researchers say that German and Japanese companies still eagerly invest in new technologies because they are managed by executives who are technically oriented rather than by financial engineers like those who came to power in America in the 80's. ''If you look around the world, the companies that innovate are run by people who are technically competent and who are excited by technology,'' said Richard Rumelt, an associate professor of business policy at the University of California at Los Angeles. ''Look at the early days in Silicon Valley. The people there measured themselves by their technology. When industry passes into the hands of people who are more interested in money than in innovation, it loses something important.''
Some say that to save money, some cost-conscious chief executives have encouraged their research departments to focus on projects most likely to pay off. It's just starting to affect research spending. According to the National Science Foundation, investment in research and development declined by nine-tenths of 1 percent last year, the first drop since 1975.
 
Bottom-line Orientation
 Jack Welch was educated as a scientist but made a name at G.E. for his relentless pursuit of the bottom line. Unlike many companies that have bought back stock, G.E.'s operating performance has been exemplary, with earnings increases in every quarter of the 80's.
Since he took over as chief executive in 1981, Mr. Welch has shed businesses that were not either dominant commercially, funded by the Pentagon or immune from international competition, like its NBC television network. Indeed, in announcing the buyback, Mr. Welch said G.E. is more interested in adding ''niches'' to existing enterprises, like jet engines, electric power turbines and medical electronic equipment, than in exploring new frontiers.
He said niches would give G.E. ''high barriers to entry'' by competitors, thereby enhancing profitability. ''No one will change the aircraft business overnight,'' he said. ''It is not like television or appliances. The environment won't spring any surprises on us.''
To build a fortress G.E., Mr. Welch sold all mass-market manufacturing lines, except large appliances and light bulbs. Gone are the small appliance and television units, fields dominated by the Japanese and Europeans, where G.E. said it had no hope of becoming No. 1 or No. 2, Mr. Welch's goal for all divisions.
But some say that criterion is misguided. Michael Porter, a Harvard Business School professor who specializes in the nature of competition, says market share is not a measure of a company's profitability. ''Look at B.M.W. and Mercedes-Benz,'' he said. ''They are not No. 1 or No. 2 by any measure, but they are among the most profitable in the industry.''
Others view G.E.'s exit from consumer electronics as a grave defeat for the United States. ''Consumer electronics is the driver at the cutting edge of technology,'' said Representative Don Ritter, a Republican from Pennsylvania.
Consumer electronics, after all, is considered an ideal market to hone design and manufacturing techniques. ''Strong competition in this industry provides a major impetus for the development of new design and manufacturing technologies,'' said Susan Walsh Sanderson, a professor at Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute in Troy, N.Y., in a recent study on the outlook for manufacturing in this country. ''The same design and manufacturing techniques provide the basis for many other product lines, including computers, instrumentation and defense electronics.''
But the cutthroat competition in consumer electronics seems to petrify G.E. Discussing the pricing of its CAT scanners and other medical-imaging devices, Bobby J. Bowen, an executive of the company's medical systems groups, said recently, ''Thank God they are not consumer electronics, but low- and medium-end products come close to it.''
 
Distinguished Past
 G.E. has a reputation for technological success. At its laboratories in Schenectady, N.Y., Charles Steinmetz once explored the basic character of electricity and Irving Langmuir made discoveries in surface chemistry that won a Nobel Prize.
But the company's research is now directed toward its existing lines of business, and critics fear the strategy limits the possibilities of a major breakthrough. ''When it limits itself, when companies in Europe and Japan are not bound by the same limits, that has national implications,'' Mr. Magaziner said.
G.E. responds by noting that last year its researchers were granted 275 patents, more than any other year in its history. It says research and development spending in key technology businesses has increased 78 percent since 1984.
Of course, no one company can excel in all fields. And even its critics concede that G.E. is a world leader in such areas as aircraft jet engines and medical-imaging equipment.
Nevertheless, the company has walked away from some technologies being pursued feverishly in Europe and Japan. As the largest American manufacturer of locomotives, G.E. has evaluated the magnetic levitation technology for railroads, but decided not to proceed with the research, according to Walter L. Robb, senior vice president for corporate research and development. And the company dropped out of robotics research when the market softened.
''A new appliance for our major appliance division is more important than a new game,'' Mr. Robb said.
Equally troubling to economists is G.E.'s level of investment in research. Not counting the money from the Federal Government for research, G.E. spent only $1.3 billion, or about 2.4 percent of its revenues, on those efforts last year. That is well below the 3.2 percent national average for all companies in 1988, the latest year for which the National Science Foundation has figures.
According to Ms. Hergenhan, G.E.'s spending is below the industry average because large parts of the company, including its financing and broadcasting operations, do not conduct laboratory research. Taken as a percent of only its product sales, G.E.'s average, without Government contracts, is 3.3 percent.
G.E., however, spends less than many hard-charging Japanese companies. The Honda Motor Company, for instance, budgets 5 percent of anticipated sales each year, regardless of its profit level. The NEC Corporation, which is working on telephones that will do instantaneous language translation, sinks 7 percent of annual sales into the laboratory.
''It would be interesting to compare Jack Welch with Akio Morita,'' the chairman of the Sony Corporation, said Robert B. Cohen, an economist associated with the Economic Policy Institute in Washington. ''Morita is investing in the next generation of video chips, memories and the miniaturization of devices. If the Japanese have a breakthrough in something like magnetic levitation trains, we will be left in the dust.''
 
A MASS-MARKET SUCCESS
Motorola Inc. has taken its licks at the hands of the Japanese. But it has succeeded in mass markets from which other American companies have retreated by using imaginative research, rapid product introductions, a devotion to quality and the latest manufacturing methods.
Competition from Japanese companies drove Motorola out of the television and radio businesses. But the company has found new niche markets, like mobile communications, cellular telephones and pagers and specialized microchips, in which to compete. Its lightweight pagers are best sellers in Japan, outdoing such Japanese giants as NEC, Matsushita and Casio. Its pocket-size Microtac cellular telephone is lighter and smaller than anything else on the market, sending competitors abroad scrambling to match it.
This spring, Motorola, which spent about 8 percent of its sales on research last year, is scheduled to introduce a new wristwatch-style pager that will time-stamp incoming messages and store as many as eight of them. It is expected to be more convenient than anything offered by the Japanese.
''We have learned there are answers'' to manufacturing problems that have caused others to shift production overseas or abandon business segments, said Robert W. Galvin, Motorola's long-time chief executive. ''The technology of operations and manufacturing has revolutionized itself in America over the last 10 years.''
Motorola's attention to quality, in fact, won it the Federal Government's Baldridge Award for outstanding quality in 1988. To improve the components it buys, the company now insists that suppliers apply for the prize.
 
PUSHING FOR R.&D.
What would persuade companies to spend more on innovation and less on stock buybacks? One inducement may already be in place. Chief executives should be less inhibited about their spending now that corporate raiders appear to be weakening. But some say their fears would be allayed further if antitrust laws were tightened to restrict takeovers.
Others believe that loosening those laws to permit joint manufacturing consortiums would spark innovation by reducing costs.
Tax reform has always been a popular solution among industries. Some executives say companies that devote resources to technologies of national importance could be given credits.
A few blame Federal tax policy for encouraging a short-term orientation. ''Taxes are very important to a company like I.B.M. or G.E.,'' said George N. Hatsopoulos, a one-time M.I.T. professor who built the Thermo Electron Corporation into a $500-million-a-year company by emphasizing research. ''If their price/earnings ratio is low, they become interested in leveraging their company and buying back stock to raise it. Since interest on borrowed money is deductible, it does not cost very much. And you get an immediate return.''
Investments that yield increased dividends and capital gains are more expensive and time-consuming. ''Look at Eastern Europe,'' he said. ''Breaking in there may take 5 to 10 years and impact earnings now. The Japanese routinely do this; American companies cannot. That is why we are losing the war in international competition.''

HEADLINE: Market Sees That Junk Bonds Are, Well, Junk;
Venture Capital

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In ''The Perils of Bashing Junk Bonds'' (editorial, May 1), you once again misjudge the situation. While Michael Milken may well be a ''financial genius,'' the fact remains that junk bonds are not the only source of capital for emerging companies.
The United States, Britain, Europe and Japan have huge venture capital pools available to emerging companies, and in some cases to start-ups. Traditionally the capital infusion takes the form of equity participation, although it may be structured as debt with warrants, or convertible (bond) debt. In addition you say that emerging companies should not look to banks, insurance companies, pension funds or Wall Street for capital. This is just incorrect and misleading. Almost all pension funds, insurance companies and banks have venture capital arms that are active in arranging capital for emerging companies and in some cases start-ups. As for Wall Street, the new-issue markets have traditionally been the source of new capital; most of this takes the form of equity, which it should, although the market has recently been in the doldrums. 
The one factor that makes junk bonds such a ''killer'' weapon is that interest is deductible to the issuer, thus making all citizens a party to the big gamble when companies choose to issue junk bonds for takeover operations. Why not advocate that companies be allowed to pay dividends before taxes? Then you would really see some capital formation.
I think you misunderstand the whole junk bond circus. While there may be a place for junk bond financing, as you argue, it is for economic reasons different from what you apparently believe. The destruction of the credit worthiness of dozens of large and small corporations by the issuing of ''junk'' to finance leveraged buyouts is a disgrace that should not be allowed to happen again.
 
ALBERT MOORE
 Augusta, Me., May 3, 1990
The writer, retired chairman of Burgess & Leith, stockbrokers, is a director of Maine Capital, a venture capital company.

HEADLINE: Market Sees That Junk Bonds Are, Well, Junk

 BODY:
To the Editor:
In ''The Perils of Bashing Junk Bonds'' (editorial, May 1), you suggest that we not allow the conviction of Michael Milken to blind us to the good that junk bonds have done to promote economic growth. But however one comes out on that debate, we should at least start from an accurate factual base; the editorial ignored many facts and bent others.
In my view, the junk bond market is now comatose not because of the disappearance of Mr. Milken but rather because the marketplace has finally recognized that junk bonds are, well, junk. Contrary to the thrust of the editorial, junk bonds began innocently enough, but by the mid- 1980's were being used largely to finance takeovers in one way or another. Second, the quality of the bonds deteriorated sharply. By 1985 it was simply not the same reasonably good junk that had been sold, in much smaller quantities, at the beginning of the decade. 
There should be no disagreement about these facts. Drexel Burnham Lambert's own 1989 report on the high-yield market shows that only 17 percent of the dollar value of the junk bonds floated in 1988 were for internal growth or general refinancing. Seventy-one percent were either to finance or refinance acquisitions or leveraged buyouts. Of the remaining 12 percent, which were for recapitalizations, a substantial portion were probably takeover related.
Barrie A. Wigmore, a limited partner at Goldman Sachs, did a widely credited study of all registered junk bond offerings from 1980 to 1988. According to Mr. Wigmore, while only 11 percent of the dollar value of the offerings in 1980 were ''merger related,'' more than 75 percent were merger related in every year beginnng in 1985. Moreover, while the companies issuing these junk bonds were earning their interest charges almost twice over in the first three years of the decade, companies issuing new junk bonds in the years 1986-88 were, on average, earning less than 75 cents on the dollar of their interest charges. They were under water from day one. Worse yet, Mr. Wigmore found that the average volume of junk bonds in these later years was 25 times greater than it was in the year 1980, when the junk was still pretty good.
One thing further: MCI was not an upstart when it first turned to Drexel for financing. MCI s s using a spspected ovestment banking firm and would have continued to do so if Drexel had never appeared on the scene. The notion that emerging businesses can find financing only by issuing zero-coupon bonds and other paraphernalia is simply not correct. Let's have a vigorous debate, but let's also get the facts straight.
 
LOUIS LOWENSTEIN
 New York, May 3, 1990
The writer is Simon H. Rifkind Professor of Law, Columbia University.

HEADLINE: Rewards of Public Service Are Growing

BYLINE: By MARTIN TOLCHIN

DATELINE: GRANTS, N.M.

 BODY:
TO some, it seemed like business as usual: the nation's largest owner and operator of private prisons purchased 40 acres from a group of local officials, including a State Senator who was instrumental in persuading the Legislature to approve a contract with the company to build and operate a women's prison on the site.
The politicians purchased the land for $95 an acre in 1964 and sold it to the Corrections Corporation of America for $3,500 an acre in 1988. One local real estate agent said that land here sold for $250 to $1,500 an acre, while a local legislator not connected with the deal said that there had not been enough sales recently to put a value on the acreage.
Business people who deal with local government have long done favors, including financial ones, for local officials whose decisions can make or cost them millions. Nine decades have passed since George Washington Plunkitt, the turn-of-the century Tammany boss, coined the phrase ''honest graft,'' the legal use of one's contacts and influence for personal enrichment. His maxim: ''I seen my opportunities and I took 'em.'' 
 
Local Business
But while Plunkitt's smoke-filled rooms have gone the way of horse-drawn carriages and gas lamps, experts say that ''honest graft'' continues to thrive.
''Even though the focus on ethics and conflicts of interest and influence peddling is on Washington, the reality is that it is mainly in local communities where economics and politics come together so clearly,'' said Thomas E. Mann, director of governmental studies at the Brookings Institution. ''That's been true for a very long time in a range of enterprises.''
For example, an expert on cable television franchises, who asked not to be identified, recalled, ''During the great cable franchising period, between 1976 and 1984, when more than 500 franchises were granted, if you wanted your application to be seriously considered you would be expected to give an equity share to the right people, coinciding very precisely with the principal contending political factions.''
Law firms often serve as a conduit to political power. Since the election in 1980 of Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, Republican of New York, his brother Armand's law firm has grown from a modest-sized practice to one of the largest and most influential on Long Island. The lawyer has used the Senator's staff to obtain information for a client about a $100 million Navy contract and has used the Senator's office to ask the Department of Housing and Urban Development to approve $5.9 million in grants for an upstate project represented by his brother's law firm. There have been no allegations that the transactions involved any illegality.
In some places, the trend toward privatization, and contracts with private companies that provide public services from waste removal to incarceration, means more opportunities for local officials.
The Corrections Corporation of America provides a case in point. The company owns or operates 17 prisons, jails and detention centers housing 5,000 Federal, state and local prisoners. It has given an array of benefits to local officials, and contracted with the companies of local officials for landscaping, extermination and moving services.
Peggy Wilson, the company's vice president for communication, confirmed all of those transactions, but said: ''Each of those instances has its own circumstances. None of it has to do with vote-buying.''
Although nobody claims that the dealings are illegal, critics contend that they end up compromising local officials' independent judgment. ''C.C.A. has a pattern of co-opting public officials who are responsible for deciding whether to privatize or not, and with whom,'' said Gordon Bonnyman, a staff attorney with Legal Services of Middle Tennessee who has opposed the company several times.
The company counters that local public officials and leading business people are often the same people. ''The politically active people in a community are the ones in business,'' said Nick Franklin, C.C.A.'s lobbyist and chief representative in New Mexico and a former Democratic state chairman.
The land purchased here was one of five sites considered by the company. The land was purchased from a group of local officials, including State Senator Joseph A. Fidel, a Democrat, who took an important role in persuading the Legislature to approve the prison contract.
''C.C.A. chose our site because of the availability of power, water, sewers and natural gas,'' said Mr. Fidel. ''This had nothing to do with my support for the prison. I wanted to bring jobs to this area.''
Stuart Butler, director of domestic and economic policy studies at the Heritage Foundation, a conservative think tank in Washington, acknowledged the temptations that privatization posed. ''That's just the way the world is, the way local government often works,'' Mr. Butler said.
The ''petty corruption'' in contracting ''is a symptom not of privatization but of local government,'' he said. ''The solution is not to end privatization but to have closer scrutiny of the bidding process. Everything should be more open.''

SECTION: Section 4; Page 3, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1181 words

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Catching Up With Change In Eastern Europe: First Steps and Second Thoughts

 BODY:
THE transformation of Eastern Europe is moving off the streets and into the political chambers, but the speed of change is still dizzying. As the emerging democracies seek their own identities, they are also trying to determine their places in a Europe whose Western powers are already faced with the challenges of creating a new community by 1992. Here, compiled from reports by New York Times correspondents, is a country-by-country update on the evolution.
 
Albania
This small Balkan country, probably the poorest in Europe, appears to be on the brink of emerging from a rigid Communist system in power for 45 years. In the past week, Albanian officials have announced that they will ease restrictions on foreign travel and allow some religious observances. 
The change is being carried out by President Ramiz Alia, a Communist who has decided that Albania cannot isolate itself any more. But in Albania, where Stalin is still revered and the highly educated leadership stands in stark contrast to workers who farm with hoe and shovel, there are still powerful obstacles to liberalization.
 
Bulgaria
Outside the Soviet Union and Albania, Bulgaria is the only country where a Communist Party - now renamed Socialist - is still in charge. In elections in June, the party faces its first real electoral battle in more than 40 years, squaring off against a coalition of 16 parties.
The former Communist Party has undertaken a series of reforms since the ouster last November of the longtime party boss, Todor Zhivkov, and the new leadership is allowing democratic rights to seep in.
Opposition parties claim their election message is blocked from reaching those areas outside Sofia where many conservative voters say they do not really see the need for more than one party. The opposition hopes revelations about postwar Communist atrocities will shock voters out of their complacency.
 
Germany
The drive to German reunification has settled into two overlapping tracks. Domestically, with local elections past, the overriding issue is monetary union, now scheduled for July. But East Germans are worried about the effect on their property values and pensions, and are concerned about unemployment once their dilapidated industries are cast into capitalist competition.
Externally, the opening ''two plus four'' meeting among the Germanys and the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain and France demonstrated that the talks to determine the shape of unification will be more like ''one plus five.'' The one will be the Soviet Union, looking for a continued role in Europe.
Despite all the barriers to unification, there is a growing sense that there is no alternative, and the sooner the better. Officials in Bonn are talking of all-German elections next year, or even this year.
 
Hungary
Having crossed the hurdle into democracy, Hungary now must make its economy conform to the laws of the market without creating turmoil. The Hungarian Democratic Forum, a center-right party that won last month's elections, has promised a controlled dismantling of the bloated state-owned sector. The new Prime Minister, Jozsef Antall, has pledged that his Government will speak out on behalf of Hungarians everywhere, making some of Hungary's neighbors nervous, but the Forum insists it is concerned only for the cultural and minority rights of Hungarians in Romania, Czechoslovakia and Yugoslavia.
In the first days of the newly elected parliament, the main opposition party called for Hungary's withdrawal from the Warsaw Pact, but the Forum says it is not the time for abrupt changes in relations with the Soviet Union.
 
Poland
In Poland, the excitement of the revolution has been replaced by the more mundane details of making it work. Politically the most advanced of the emerging democracies, Poland is the first to see results from a free-market economy. Overtures to the West have been met with pledges of investment, prices are down and stores actually have goods on the shelves, but the push to close inefficient factories has led to unemployment and crime is up. The question of where Germany unification will leave Polish borders still causes uneasiness, despite assurances that nothing will change.
The ambitious program to create democracies at the local level culminates in elections later this month. But Solidarity is splitting into rival factions, and Lech Walesa, who may or may not be running for President, says the revolution is stagnating.
In neighboring Czechoslovakia, where national elections are coming up next month, the anger that was absent at the beginning of the revolution is showing up now as ethnic strife and petty squabbling that threatens the alliance that brought President Vaclav Havel to power.
 
Romania
Romania is having the rockiest transition to democracy. With one week left before the May 20 elections, some have doubts that this Balkan country of 23 million people will make it. Much of the political debate has taken place on the street, particularly in Bucharest, where crowds form at the first sound of a rhythmic chant. Violence has crept to the surface in the increasingly bitter confrontation between the ruling National Salvation Front and the two main opposition parties. The front's leader, Ion Iliescu, is the favorite to be elected president, but it may have to form a coalition government.
All the parties favor a gradual transition to a market economy, phasing out the giant factories that had been favored by the late dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. Romania has no debt at all, a distinction earned by depriving its citizens over many years but a factor in its favor as it searches for foreign investment.
 
Soviet Union
Mikhail S. Gorbachev hoped to set the pace for democratization in Europe, but instead he has fallen behind. The impression, probably stronger in the West than in Moscow, is that the nation is heading for a fall. Even with rank-and-file defections and local elections shrinking the Communist Party, the party still has considerable power, including an enduring patronage network comprising the only experienced managers in the country. Mr. Gorbachev has been building his own presidential power base, but at least for now, he needs the party to run things.
It is now sinking in that the Baltics, where Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia are insisting on sovereignty, are a harbinger of the every-man-for-himself attitude that is likely to touch not only republics but also regions of coal miners and oil workers. The continuing collapse of the economy is an argument for a market economy, but that means unemployment and rising prices. Reformists gaining power in the cities see these places as potential laboratories for radical democracy, but for Mr. Gorbachev they are also a glaring reminder that he and his party do not have such a popular mandate.
As Mr. Gorbachev heads to the summit meeting with President Bush later this month, he has the United States on his side, even if those Soviet citizens who are increasingly disenchanted with his leadership are not.
