SECTION: Section 4; Page 2, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 890 words

HEADLINE: THE WORLD;
Write Off Castro? The Odds Change

BYLINE: By HOWARD W. FRENCH

DATELINE: MIAMI

 BODY:
AS Communist dictatorships tottered and fell in Eastern Europe last year, a natural question was whether the 31-year-old Cuban regime of Fidel Castro would soon be next.
In a climate of heightened expectations, Florida's Governor created a commission to study the impact of the democratization of Cuba on his state. An influential Cuban-American lobby began planning a new constitution for the country, while supporters of much-disputed American television broadcasts to the island began to argue that uncensored news and images of life in the United States could tip the balance against Mr. Castro.
While these efforts are continuing, a more sober assessment of Cuba's future has emerged in recent weeks. The Soviet Union has made it clear that it has no plans to end or greatly disrupt its heavily subsidized trade with Cuba, and Mr. Castro has taken crafty propaganda advantage of the broadcasting scheme, exploiting the theme of United States interference in Cuban affairs. 
''I do not share the view here in Miami that this is something imminent, that Castro will soon be gone,'' said Lisandro Perez, chairman of the Cuban Studies Committee at Florida International University in Miami. ''He has got his basic apparatus in place, and I don't see the possibility of some sort of popular uprising.''
Many experts note that while May Day has never been a more somber occasion for Communists in Eastern Europe, in Havana as many as 800,000 people marched past Mr. Castro's reviewing stand in the Plaza of the Revolution, many of them shouting ''Viva Fidel!''
Translating such shows into deeply felt and sincere popular support is difficult in a tightly controlled society like Cuba, but students of the country believe that despite growing economic problems, the 63-year-old President's popularity remains high.
''People are talking about their frustrations: 'We have to work harder and the buses do not come and the lights go out at least once a week' - a lot of that kind of thing,'' said Wayne Smith, who heads the Cuban Studies program at Johns Hopkins University.
''But Castro reminds me a lot of Ronald Reagan,'' Mr. Smith said in an interview after he returned from a recent trip to Cuba. ''The same polls that would indicate that the American people had serious doubts about matters of policy would give Reagan a high personal approval rating. A lot of Cubans think the country's economic problems are not Castro's fault.''
 
Successes at Home
Many experts point to Cuba's recent successes in biotechnology, including the marketing of a hepatitis vaccine, and rapidly increasing trade with Latin America as signs that, with continued Soviet support, the Cuban economy could be resuscitated.
Indeed, many university students interviewed recently in Cuba blamed the political upheavals of Eastern Europe, more than their leader, for the country's growing shortages of food and other basic items.
Even many of those frustrated by the repetitiveness of the government's pronouncements and the restrictions on individual freedoms seemed prepared to wait out Mr. Castro's tenure, however long, before demanding radical change.
''He can't be any different than he is, and that is sort of sad, but he is our leader and we have reason to be proud of him,'' one student said. ''But after Fidel none of those around him have earned our respect. They will all have to go.'' On this point, however, there is much room for disagreement.
''I think that if Castro were to disappear suddenly, that is to say die naturally, there would be a great flowering of political debate,'' said Gillian Gunn, a senior associate at the Carnegie Endowment for International Peace in Washington. ''I don't think we would see the revolution self-destruct. There would be a great effort toward a show of national unity to discourage the U.S. from trying anything.''
''Then there would be a very profound and deep debate about some of the basic assumptions underlying the governmental system,'' she said. ''Maybe the whole society will decide it doesn't like socialism and wants to be like, say, Costa Rica. I personally don't think it will go that way - it would be more on the order of real disgust over the way the Cuban press is not a press, or questioning of the electoral system.''
Many experts say it would be a mistake to assume that hordes of Cubans are eagerly waiting to be liberated by returning exiles from the United States, where more than 1 million Cuban-Americans live.
 
Blacks Have Advanced
Carlos Moore, a Cuban-born sociologist, said that under Mr. Castro Cuba's blacks have materially benefited and slowly climbed the social ladder. At the same time, the country as a whole has become blacker because of the overwhelmingly white waves of emigration to the United States.
Blacks in particular, he said, would rally around Mr. Castro, or a successor regime, if it appeared that the financially powerful, predominantly white Cubans of Miami were a serious threat to their social position.
Mr. Perez of Florida International University said, ''Regrettably, the Cuban-American exile community sounds to many Cubans as if they represent the old order. A lot of people in Cuba benefited from the redistribution of the 1960's and 1970's and I don't believe they are going to welcome anything that reminds them of the past.''

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1, Column 1; Week in Review Desk

LENGTH: 1320 words

HEADLINE: Decoding Bush's Signal On Taxes

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN his first 15 months in the White House, amassing his 70 percent popularity rating, President Bush never once suggested that prospects for the economy were anything but rosy, never mentioned that the budget deficit was a problem that would prove painful to solve and never even hinted that his campaign pledge of ''no new taxes'' was other than the guiding beacon of his Administration.
All that changed last Sunday night, when the President invited Congressional leaders to the living quarters at the White House and said he wanted to enter budget negotiations with ''no preconditions.'' The news that Mr. Bush was prepared at least to discuss higher taxes turned Washington politics, which had been unusually placid this year, into a caldron.
No one was sure what the President's intentions were. Many Republican legislators and candidates for election in November accused Mr. Bush of ceding the one issue, taxes, that separated them from Democrats. Some Democrats worried aloud that their leaders were walking into an ambush in which they would propose higher taxes and Mr. Bush would reject them out of hand. 
White House aides spoke with many voices, further muddying the situation. John H. Sununu, the chief of staff, told reporters that if the Democrats wanted to propose higher taxes, that was fine, but the President would veto them. Marlin Fitzwater, the press secretary, said the Sununu comment was ''crazy.'' But then Vice President Dan Quayle said, ''Sununu was just reflecting what the President's instincts are, what his stated policies are.''
Mr. Bush himself said nothing on the subject in public until Friday, when he insisted, ''There are no conditions, and that's the way it is.''
Did that mean that he is prepared to accept a tax increase in the negotiations that begin Tuesday? ''I'm not going to show you my hand,'' he said.
Mr. Bush called for the negotiations, his aides said, because his top economic advisers had finally conceded that only with serious belt-tightening could fiscal chaos be avoided. In January, the President sent Congress a budget with wildly optimistic assumptions about economic growth and interest rates. If those estimates had proved accurate, only $36 billion in spending cuts or revenue increases would have been required to bring the deficit to $64 billion in the fiscal year that begins Oct. 1, as required by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget balancing law. That might have been done without tax increases or reductions in spending for popular programs. But the President's initial budget offering was like a player heaving a mid-court basketball shot just before the buzzer. If the shot goes in, it wins the game. If it misses, the player is none the worse for trying.
Not surpirsingly, tax receipts have been lower than the Administration anticipated and interest rates on Government bonds have been higher, so the initial Bush budget proposal quickly became obsolete.
By last month, Richard G. Darman, Mr. Bush's budget director, was saying that at least $45 billion and possibly $60 billion in deficit-reduction measures would be needed to meet the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings target. Last week, he said the figure could go as high as $100 billion if annual outlays and income from the savings and loan bailout were counted. If the target is missed, across-the-board spending cuts will go into effect automatically in almost every Government program except for Social Security payments and welfare benefits. If it is missed by $60 billion, the result will be cuts as deep as 20 percent in some programs beginning in October.
''That means a breakdown in Government,'' an Administration official said. ''It means no inspectors to check the baggage at Kennedy Airport. It means no F.B.I. agents to investigate cases. It would be intolerable.'' The law forced small, hardly felt cuts this year, but nothing of the size that is now possible.
Mr. Bush needed negotiations for three other reasons. First, the savings and loan bailout, which could eventually cost tens and maybe hundreds of billions of dollars, was not contemplated when the budget balancing law was enacted, and the bailout process does not lend itself to the law's accounting procedures. Here's why: When the Government spends money to liquidate failed thrift institutions and pay off the depositors, that increases outlays. When it sells the assets of the seized institution, the proceeds are counted as income. But the liquidations and the sale of assets do not necessarily come in the same fiscal year, so some years the deficit might appear artificially high or low. Both the White House and Congress want to remove those transactions from the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings calculations, but to do so would require a change in the law.
The second factor involves the view of many in both parties that Social Security should also be removed from the budget law's calculations. But because Social Security receipts are so much higher now than expenditures, the deficit reduction required would have to be much higher if the retirement program were excluded. Thus the target would have to be adjusted, which would require rewriting the law.
The third factor is the military budget. The improved relations with the Soviet Union and developments in arms control negotiations have led even the highest military officials to acknowledge that Pentagon spending can be lower in the next fiscal year than the Administration anticipated in January. The House and Senate are prepared to vote sharp cutbacks, but the President does not want to give Congress complete control over the Pentagon budget.
From Mr. Bush's perspective, all this meant that negotiations with Congress were essential. But Democrats, who control Congress and are gun-shy from years of attacks on the tax issue, and were unwilling to come near the negotiating table as long as the President was publicly inflexible about taxes. So he said he would listen to talk about new taxes, although he never said he would accept them.
The prevailing view of Administration and Congressional budget experts is that about $25 billion in taxes, user fees and other revenue measures will probably be needed to close the budget gap. Mr. Bush would like to delay offering his plan for raising the money as long as possible. But the Democratic lawmakers, determined to have the President make the first move on taxes, will try to force Mr. Bush's hand. Like a poker player nervous about his opponent's propensity to bluff, Senator Jim Sasser of Tennessee, chairman of the Budget Committee, said the first question he would ask the President is, ''What's your proposal?''
Mr. Bush's proposal surely will not include a rise in income tax rates. If he offers any higher taxes at all, he will probably stick to new levies on alcohol, tobacco and, possibly, oil imports and gasoline. But if he remains determined to have a cut in the capital gains tax rate, he may have no choice but to accept a higher income tax rate for the group that would be the chief beneficiary of the capital gains tax cut - those who earn more than about $200,000 a year and who, because of a quirk in the tax code, now pay a lower rate on money they earn in excess of around $200,000 than do taxpayers with less income.
But all that is speculation, and the outcome of the negotiations may be months away. Both sides say they would have to agree on what deficit target they were shooting at and on what to do about the savings and loan and Social Security questions before addressing the substantitive issues of taxes and spending.
Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, the Democratic leader, offered this cautious note when asked whether Republicans could blame Democrats for any tax increase: ''It's premature to speculate on what might be in the agreement, and then to speculate on top of that speculation as to what someone might say about that speculative agreement.''

HEADLINE: A Rough-Hewn Maine Seaport

BYLINE: By JANE HOLTZ KAY; Jane Holtz Kay, author of ''Preserving New England'' (Pantheon), writes the Design Notebook column for The Times.

 BODY:
Portlanders have a homing instinct. Stay at a bed-and-breakfast and your host regales you with the tale of the descendant who came back to see how time had transformed the old family place into the Pomegranate Inn. Stand at the top of the plunging staircase at the Morse-Libby House, known today as Victoria Mansion, and its director recalls the Libby granddaughter's return to tell how ''Grandpa Libby'' struck fear in the hearts of youngsters who might venture down its historic slide. Tall tales and small: they underscore the intimacy of this urban landscape where history is biography.
Portland is at once historic and quixotic, banal and boutique-y. It is tinged by worldy Boston but tangibly Down East. Above all, though, the coastal city of southern Maine is that much-abused adjective: real. Its sense of place is as diverse as the assorted folk and assorted architecture at home in the four-season city. People who summer in the untamed state return to settle in its urban nexus. So do strangers and neighbors. Portland's settlers have always had this geographic and personal plurality. ''Many emigres (largely from Massachusetts) turned their attention to the place, which afterwards was known as the beautiful town by the sea,'' a city history recorded the settlement after the Revolution. 
Beautiful sea, briny sea, but most of all, working sea define the gritty 362-year-old city. The rough-hewn quality of the seaport - visible from the blue cranes of the Bath Iron Works on the eastern end of the waterfront to the scrap metal loading dock on the west - accounts for the city's honesty. ''Keep the Port in Portland,'' declares the slogan to keep the working waterfront. No candle-and-curio seaport, Portland retains, indeed flaunts, its salty origins as a functional, profitable part of daily life.
A balance between poverty and prosperity has insured the survival of the city's richly heterogeneous architecture. Surveying Congress Street, the long spine of the city, you are as likely to see a superscale cutout of a rose on the 1962 facade of Bernie's Fashions at No. 492 as the aged Flemish bricks of the 1785 Wadsworth Longfellow House at No. 487; the stern concrete of the 1979 Portland Library at No. 455 not far from the roseate commercial buildings of the late 1880's restored to gentrified perfection. You can find a Woolworth's or a shoe repair shop along with I. M. Pei's trendy Portland Museum of Art.
To those on a summer stopover, Portland is the Old Port Exchange. Tourists meander in the circle, or square, of the Old Port. From the rumpled waterfront of Commercial Street where the ferryboats plume out to Casco Bay's islands, visitors head inland, shopping along the axis of Exchange Street, the parallel Market and Temple Streets, and the cobbled side streets.
Since 1965, with the fixing up of the Thomas Clapp building on the corner of Exchange and Federal Streets, the Old Port has had its streetscape mended gradually, building by building. ''A collective process of the work of many individuals,'' Earle G. Shettleworth Jr., director of the Maine Historical Preservation Commission, described the restoration of the former commercial district. The ''for lease'' signs papering some windows record the stalled revival and economic downturn of New England, but Portland's architecture is delightful and its shops sprightly. The route along Exchange Street to City Hall offers a splendid walk and vista - past craft and cable-knit sweater shops, between the twin open spaces of Tommy's Park, with its mural and a parking lot (soon also to be a park), to the crest where John Carrere's and Thomas Hastings' formidable gray City Hall of 1909 looks down on this array of 19th-century architecture.
No New England city of Portland's size (65,000) boasts the range and quality of landmarks, and no New England city of any size, short of Boston, offers its ''kinetic textbook of architecture,'' in the words of the Maine author and attorney Philip Isaacson. The visitor can follow the four walking tours described in booklets issued by Greater Portland Landmarks, a private group. The organization's helpful maps will take you beyond the Old Port to Congress and State Streets and the Western Promenade; from old clapboard dwellings to ponderous Victorian mansions, from elegant churches to handsome business blocks.
Whether vernacular (the three-decker house, New England's blue-collar delight); high style (the Gothic J. J. Brown House at 387 Spring Street in the Western Promenade, moved from downtown for a Holiday Inn); madeover 19th-century wharf buildings (like the Thomas Block on Commercial Street), or postmodern (the Museum of Art, sloping to the context of the Greek Revival House behind) - whatever the moment in time, architectural buffs will find a sample of styles. And of time, places, and condition of the buildings, for good and ill: the blank windows of a former laundromat overlook the bronze sculpture of Henry Wadsworth Longfellow at the intersection of State and Congress Streets; the phantom letters of ''Salvation Army Industries'' still etched on a brick building look out over the refurbished Armory in the Old Port.
The most striking of Portland's historic houses, and a prime contender for New England's must-see mansion, is the Victoria Mansion on Danforth Street, built for Ruggles Sylvester Morse (1816-93). A Maine native, he returned to bring the public flamboyance of his New Orleans hotels to this private dwelling. His amazing Italianate brownstone house was in the vanguard in its day (1859) and remains so. Twin sinks in the master bedroom and an Oriental smoking room nearby are novelties; the striking staircase, painted murals, carved marble fireplaces, decorative details and spacious and opulent formal chambers are testimony to the longstanding esthetic of the client and his New Haven architect, Henry Austin.
The hero of Portland architecture is John Calvin Stevens. The buildings of his 60-year career from 1880 on dot the city and his handsome Shingle Style homes reflect the shipping and lumbering fortunes of their original owners. These grand residences can be traced on Bowdoin Street in the Western Promenade section, which still provides the close-to-city living that draws a new generation of the affluent. The city's broader architecture can be explored with the solid book, ''Portland'' (published by Greater Portland Landmarks; $19.90 at local bookstores), or just pick favorites while wandering the streets. For robust splendor, I'd choose the granite Custom House on Commercial Street; for a fantasia of ecclesiastical forms, the vivid St. Lawrence Congregational Church on Congress Street; for charm the clutch of Queen Anne brick houses tucked into the grassy slope of Western Promenade.
The clearest way to get your overall bearings is the classic way: by land and sea. And the best vantage point is the Munjoy Hill Observatory, 221 feet above the shore in a lively ethnic neighborhood on the Eastern Promenade. The visitor to the crowded waterfront misses one of the most entrancing aspects of Portland: a peninsula three miles long virtually swallowed by the sea. To survey the stunning topography of this complex and curving little city, drive to Munjoy Hill's observatory up Congress Street on the Eastern Promenade. When the flags are flying, the doughty wooden survivor of 1807 is open and offers a spectacular view as far as the White Mountains. Climb the breath-stealing staircase of this structure, tilting under the weight of its 183 years. Peer 360 degrees around at the wraparound waters of Portland harbor and the Back Cove, and you understand why water ruled this city for three centuries.
The view from the crest of the Observatory also lets you grasp the other memorable element of Portland's topography: its sandwiching between two greenswards, the Eastern and Western Promenades. A century ago the Olmsted brothers, landscape architects, took these promenades and the three other existing parks of the peninsula - Deering Oaks, the dilapidated Back Cove and the tiny Lincoln Park - and linked the chain into a plan. Like the Boston ''Emerald Necklace'' park system devised by the Olmsted firm, Portland's plan provided a place for play and turned the noxious waters of the Back Cove into Baxter Boulevard. Sometimes shabby and sometimes not quite realized, these oases remain, ready to respond to new environmental concerns, and like the city at large protected by a preservation ordinance that takes effect in August.
Stand on the green slopes of the Promenades, your back to the historic houses of the shore, your eyes to the sea. Visit the smaller parks, where yesterday and today coexist. And once again you have the sense of connections that still endure, the linkages in place in place and time that enrich Portland's historic - and genuine - urbanity.
 
LODGING, DINING AND SHOPPING
 
Where to Stay
 The queen of the bed-and-breakfasts is the six-room Pomegranate Inn (49 Neal Street, Portland, Me. 04102; 207-772-1006). In the Western Promenade's residential district, it has splendid eclectic furnishings and contemporary art. From Memorial Day to mid-October a double room is $95, including a full breakfast; the rest of the year it is $85. All rooms have baths, phones and color television.
The 95-room Portland Regency Inn (20 Milk Street, Portland, Me. 04101; 207-774-4200), a restored Armory conveniently situated in the Exchange, is about to complete a remodeling of its public areas. The hotel has a nightclub and a health club with steam room and sauna, whirlpool and exercise equipment. Double $90 to $110.
The 184-room Sonesta Hotel (157 High Street, Portland, Me. 04101; 207-775-5411) has two restaurants, a fitness center with sauna and weight machines and a rooftop lounge overlooking the city. Doubles start at $70 ($85 from July 9).
 
Where to Eat
 The Cafe Always, with 35 seats (47 Middle Street; 207-774-9399) serves dinner from 5 to 10 P.M. Tuesday to Sunday (open seven nights a week from the end of June). The menu changes daily; recent choices included lobster with Thai curry coconut sauce, $19.95; wild mushroom ragout with grilled polenta, $12.95; grilled sweetbreads with pancetta and a balsamic vinaigrette, $18.95. Full bar. A three-course dinner for two, with a bottle of wine, about $60.
Street and Company (33 Wharf Street; 207-775-0887) is a 36-seat restaurant that serves dinner every night from 5 to 10 P.M. Seafood is the specialty; choices include grilled marinated tuna, $14.95, linguine with calamari in a white sauce, $10.95, and salmon en papillote with fresh herbs, $13.95. Beer and wine are served. A three-course dinner for two, with a bottle of wine, about $50.
 
Things to See
 The Victoria Mansion (109 Danforth Street; 207-772-4841) is open June 1 to Oct. 12 from 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Tuesday to Sunday. Admission $4.
 The Wadsworth-Longfellow House (485 Congress Street; 207-772-1807) is open June 1 to Oct. 11, 10 A.M. to 4 P.M. Tuesday to Saturday. Admission $3.
 The Portland Observatory (138 Congress Street) is open Friday to Sunday in June, Wednesday to Sunday in July and August and weekends in September and October. Hours are 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. on Saturday, 1 to 5 P.M. on other days. Admission $1.50.
Greater Portland Landmarks (165 State Street, Portland, Me. 04101; 207-774-5561), a private nonprofit historic preservation organization, offers popular tours of neighborhoods, Casco Bay islands, parks and other areas of southern Maine. A schedule of summer tours may be obtained by calling or writing in early June.
 
Things to Buy
 The shopping is as good as summertime New England provides, with supplies for the kitchen at the well-equipped Whip and Spoon (161 Commercial Street; 207-774-4020); contemporary furniture and home accessories at Dimora (26 Exchange Street; 207-775-7049), and crafts at Abacus (44 Exchange Street; 207-772-4880).

HEADLINE: Four Inns at twohundredsomething;
New Hampshire: John Hancock never slept at this inn

BYLINE: By MARIALISA CALTA

 BODY:
The town of Hancock, nestled in the Monadnock region of southwestern New Hampshire - a part of the state that tourism boosters like to call the Currier & Ives corner - boasts 47 buildings on the National Register of Historic Places. One of them, the 10-room John Hancock Inn, is said to be the oldest continuously operating inn in the state.
A three-story clapboard building with white columns and narrow porch, the inn has been taking in guests since 1789, when it opened on a coach route connecting Boston and Montreal. The many additions reflect the changing architectural fashions of its tenure. The original building, for example, was designed in the Federal-Greek Revival style, while the mansard roof, added in 1875, is an example of French Second Empire. The portico is Colonial Revival. The inn never actually was host to John Hancock, the flamboyant signer of the Declaration of Independence for whom the town was named in 1779. He owned much of the land in this agrarian community, but never visited the town. But in its earlier years the inn was the setting for many gala parties, according to Gloria J. Neary, collection custodian for the Hancock Historical Society. According to Mrs. Neary, at least one elderly resident recalls horse-drawn sleighs parked end-to-end on Main Street as people gathered for a wintertime dance. The original ballroom, in which music was amplified by blown-glass sounding bottles concealed in the ceiling, has been divided into two bedrooms, and a second ballroom, converted into an apartment, serves as the private living quarters for the innkeepers, Pat and Glynn Wells, who purchased the inn in 1973, and their two children. 
The inn, situated on two acres of grounds, has entered the 90's as an unpretentious establishment, simply furnished with a mixture of early American and country Victorian antiques and reproductions. The bedrooms feature painted wood floors scattered with hooked and braided rugs, and comfortable beds, some with canopies, covered with jacquard spreads. Our double-bedded room was quiet, despite the inn's location by the side of the village's main road. The shallow, nonworking fireplaces and the old-fashioned wash basins found in several rooms lend a period atmosphere, but the heating is central and the bathrooms modern, with efficient plumbing. Each room has a private bath. The public rooms are air-conditioned in the summer. There is a television in a third-floor sitting area, and bookcases in the hall are stacked with books and board games.
One bedroom, appropriately known as the mural room, showcases a country scene painted in the early 1800's by Rufus Porter, an itinerant artist, and restored some 65 years ago. Fragments of a Porter mural can be found in the closet of another bedroom, and a chambermaid's closet contains stenciling done by Moses Eaton, a local artist of the same period. Eaton's designs have been reproduced in one of the inn's three dining rooms.
The inn's kitchen offers undistinguished food at moderate prices. Dinner offerings, billed on the menu as New England fare, include chicken turnovers, duck with black currant sauce, baked scrod, fettuccine primavera and sirloin with peppercorn sauce. The duck was fatty and bland, the sirloin acceptable. Pecan pie was good. There is a short wine list with several California selections. A dinner for two, including appetizers, entree, wine and desert, costs about $60. Breakfast for two runs about $12, though on our visit the French toast was limp and the sausage greasy. The service, on a recent visit, was friendly but not intrusive, and guests felt at ease lingering over their coffee and dessert long after other diners had left. The main dining room had nondescript decor and was badly lighted. Lunch is also served in the breakfast room and in the bar, a den-like room with large, working fireplace and tables made out of old wooden bellows.
For the gastronomically ambitious, Twelve Pine, a takeout shop at 1 Summer Street in nearby Peterboro, serves multi-ethnic dishes; a picnic lunch for two is $12.
The town of Hancock itself, with its many examples of 18th- and 19th-century architecture, demands leisurely examination. The bell of the Federal-style Congregational Church, manufactured by Paul Revere's sons, tolls hourly; ''a comforting sound,'' said Mrs. Neary, ''once you get used to it.'' The white clapboard schoolhouse still holds grades 1 through 4, and a former tavern houses the Hancock Historical Society, with its collection of early American tools and furniture. The collection is open on Wednesday and Saturday in July and August, but otherwise can be seen by appointment. The cemetery contains the 1826 grave of Jack Ware, a freed slave who told of being stolen from his African homeland by ''a white man in a fine buggy'' who carried him off ''like a hawk would a hen.''
The town's economy was revitalized in 1878 with the coming of the railroad, and by the early 1900's Hancock had become a popular summer retreat for Bostonians. Hancock has a classic town common, a library, a small market and two antique shops - one specializing in antique lighting and the other in crafts, furniture and the work of local artists.
Other area attractions include Norway Pond, a short walk from the inn, the nearby Harris Center for Conservation Education and the many seasonal activities such as foliage tours, swimming, hiking, canoeing and skiing. Cultural activities include theater and concerts in nearby communities. The region is also home to a burgeoning number of restaurants featuring French, Asian, new American and other cuisines.
 
*
 At the Hancock Inn (Main Street, Hancock, N.H. 02339; telephone 603-525-3318) rates are $72.50 a room, double occupancy, excluding meals.

HEADLINE: Beaufort, a Town That Rose Again

BYLINE: By CECILY MCMILLAN; Cecily McMillan owns a house on St. Helena Island, near Beaufort, S.C.

 BODY:
In March 1936 the photographer Walker Evans, who was documenting poverty in the South, found himself in Beaufort, S.C., facing an undeniably beautiful 18th-century frame house. The delicate carving around the door frame, the detailed corner moldings and elaborate cornices recalled an era of high style and craftsmanship.
But this day, its columned, two-story portico was worn bare of paint and patched with handmade signs advertising the businesses inside.
There was an art school, a fish market, a fruit and vegetable stand and a stenographer. Some faded lettering suggested former tenants. A sign declared, ''General Lafayette spoke from this porch 1824'' (actually, he spoke in 1825). Below it hung a bundle of spotted bananas. 
The picture Evans took in Beaufort that day, which is in the Library of Congress collections, showed a little town making do in a setting where the once-bright life of the Old South seemed all but snuffed out. Beaufort's past, tattered though it appeared, looked more substantial than its future.
Today the biggest sign on that house proclaims its name - the John Mark Verdier House - and its listing on the National Register of Historic Places. The paint doesn't dare peel. The commercial life has spread up and down Bay Street and along a half-dozen lateral streets. Colorful awnings shade the sidewalk, and wooden barrels planted with pansies, ivy and impatiens stand along the curbs.
Prosperity has come to Beaufort and has liberated it from just making do. Gone is the store that sold cigarettes for a nickel apiece; unheard of the old way of repainting the house - one side every couple of years. The ingenious economies of the cash-poor town have all but disappeared. They are not to be found in the groomed yards of the historic district, in the glossy bed-and-breakfast lodgings, in the modish boutiques or restaurants on the river.
But if prosperity has forced these habits out of service it has also memorialized them. Today Beaufort's ''poor but proud'' years, which lasted here and all over the South from Reconstruction to the end of World War II, have a place in its history, just as the antebellum years have theirs. Poverty, it turns out, was just another phase in the history of this small town.
Beaufort has been a small town for a long time. Spanish explorers came to the area 100 years before the Pilgrims landed at Plymouth Rock. French, Scottish and English settlers followed, and by the time of the Revolution, Beaufort was a center of the scattered plantation world where slaves harvested rice, indigo and corn. By century's end, the newly invented cotton gin, the successful cultivation of long-staple cotton on the sea islands, and a growing slave population, contrived to launch Beaufort into its heyday - a 60-year spree of building, buying, expanding and high living that ran until about lunchtime on Nov. 7, 1861, when Union soldiers demolished the Confederate port defenses.
It is the legacy of these years, the architectural accomplishments they produced and the disastrous decline they precipitated, that impresses every visitor to Beaufort. As in Charleston, the buildings, the old houses and churches stand as they did, now restored, lived in, once again playing a central role in community life. And as common as morning dew is the small-town Southerner's pride in and preoccupation with history, with explaining Southern ways. In Beaufort, there's a story for every piazza - and probably someone nearby to tell it. The past not only informs the present, it seems to populate it.
If you want a thoughtful introduction to Beaufort's history, or to examine the roots of its style, the Historic Beaufort Foundation operates two house museums: the John Mark Verdier House (801 Bay Street) and the George Parsons Elliott House (1001 Bay Street). The Verdier House - the house Walker Evans photographed - was fully restored in 1976, to represent the apogee of Beaufort style. The Elliott House (circa 1844) is partially restored. The Arsenal Museum (713 Craven Street) housed in the pre-Civil War Gothic-style military building, offers an informal, eclectic view of life in old Beaufort by means of household objects, clothing, documents, natural history specimens and prehistoric Indian artifacts.
Downtown Beaufort is snugly clustered along the river, now a section of the Intracoastal Waterway, and it appears from a distance much as it did when plantation bateaux, cotton barges and steam-driven packets berthed at its wharves. A few miles distant the river enters Port Royal Sound, considered by navigators since the days of Christopher Columbus to be one of the most accommodating harbors on the southern coast. From the Bay Street bluff to the Atlantic Ocean lie hundreds of acres of unpolluted marsh and tidal estuaries, habitats for dozens of species of birds, fish and shellfish.
This proximity to the water, or as they say in Beaufort, to the ''weather,'' gave rise to a predominant style of architecture that had its roots in the plantation houses of Barbados. Many houses are set high on foundations made of brick or tabby, a mixture of sand, oyster shells and lime prepared by slaves. Some of these raised basements are arcaded, like the upstairs piazzas, to capture the prevailing southwest breeze. The effect is like a kite held aloft, suspended above the ever-present ballast of humid Lowcountry air.
The densest concentration of Federal, Georgian and Greek Revival period houses is to be found on The Point, Beaufort's old neighborhood to the east of Carteret Street. Here stand about five dozen historic houses of exceptional architectural quality, most of them built with cotton profits, many of them accompanied by elaborately landscaped, if not formal, gardens.
Bay Street, laid out in the early years of the 18th century, runs west along the river. Its houses, including an unusual one (1211 Bay Street), which combines the native skill of tabby building with a graceful, restrained Palladian portico, form an elegant front line behind which fall narrow streets lined with lovely smaller houses and churches. The graceful interior columns of St. Helena's Episcopal Church suggest the relative simplicity of Colonial-era architecture in a town where embellishment is more common. Its shady, walled cemetery, abundantly landscaped with indigenous plants and full of mockingbirds, is a good place to rest.
An impressionistic history lesson can be obtained by making all of downtown Beaufort your classroom. Maps are available for free at the Chamber of Commerce (1006 Bay Street), where children and adults may rent bicycles ($4 an hour, $15 a day) or pick up a recorded cassette tour ($6). Horse-drawn carriage tours start here on the hour seven times a day from 10 to 4 ($7 for adults, $4 for children).
At a time when the sheer scale of city life produces fatigue, Beaufort's small size is a relief. A visitor can fold into its routine and take up casual citizenship without doing much more than exploring the downtown historic district, resting on a porch swing, casting a shrimp net, hunting for fossilized shark's teeth, or eating outdoors as the sun sets. Subtle pleasures can be found in simply observing the comings and goings of small town life. Visitors to Beaufort this summer may even see Barbra Streisand or Nick Nolte, who will be there filming ''The Prince of Tides,'' a movie based on the best-selling novel by the Beaufort native Pat Conroy.
Local people usually spend their free time on the water. Hunting Island State Park, with three miles of beach and a 115-year-old lighthouse with stairs to the top, is about 30 minutes away by car. Families of deer forage in full view in its maritime forest and clapper rails, herons and raccoons feed all day in the marsh. More than 125 bird species have been sighted here. In nearby Port Royal, a brand-new town boardwalk spans the marsh at the confluence of the Beaufort River and Battery Creek. Shark's teeth lie scattered, half-buried on the sandy shore. From a high platform aerie huge container ships can be seen coming and going at the commercial port.
The tides still influence life in Beaufort, though few livelihoods depend on them anymore. Get to know them and you will come to recognize the change of smell in the air, the shifting of the breeze, the movement of shore birds and the best hours for fishing. Times of highs and lows for a week, measured at several locations, are listed daily in The Beaufort Gazette, which appears in curbside newspaper boxes at about 2 P.M.
To talk over fishing strategies and to purchase basic tackle, step into Fordham Hardware (701 Bay Street). A bell jingles as you enter. The worn-smooth stone floor, the display windows and shelves stuffed and strung with merchandise, the bins of seed and nails, and the sweet, musty smell endow Fordham's with the authenticity of outdoor labor that slick gardening catalogues crave.
Three-quarters of the way back, by the counter, are dip nets, cotton line and weights for catching fish and crabs. A good setup costs about $6. Monofilament shrimp nets, four-and-a-half-feet in diameter, a good size for beginners, cost $36. Beaufort Hardware (723 Bay Street), run, like Fordham's, by a local family for a couple of generations, sells fishing gear at comparable prices. Nonfishermen might enjoy a radio-controlled wooden sailboat or airplane. The recommended bait for crab is chicken necks, the older and more pungent the better; shrimp you encircle by stealth.
If you are traveling with children, at least one of them will encrust a sneaker with sandy, souffle-like ''pluff'' mud from the creek. Lipsitz department store (825 Bay Street), another small-town emporium whose type has all but disappeared, can help. Members of the Lipsitz family will sell your family footwear, jeans and sweats while a chatty pet mynah bird diverts the younger set.
Across Bay Street is the Waterfront Park, whose playground, landscaped green and harbor promenade are well-suited for games of catch or tag, or just walking. Cruise ships dock on scheduled stops, shrimp trawlers and sailboats tie up periodically and tugboats accompanying loaded barges follow a slow, steady course. Near the playground is an informative photo display depicting rural folk art and traditions.
Hours of the day elicit their own pictures in Beaufort. In the early morning, they are noiseless and unpeopled. One might frame the massive stone pillars, mottled with age, at 411 Craven Street; another, the broad arc of oak branches on a tree in the yard of 1 Laurens Street, the house featured in ''The Big Chill'' and ''The Great Santini.'' At first dark of a spring evening, lamplight makes eyes of windows in houses on King Street. The fading light of sunset on the Bay Street bluff silhouettes the painted balustrades, railings and shutters of the houses facing south. When you return to your lodgings or walk to dinner, you will carry with you the scent of Confederate jasmine, still lingering in the warm air.
The world of sea island plantations whose slaves helped create Beaufort's antebellum wealth, and the vast geography of water in which Beaufort is just a dot, can best be seen a short distance from town in the direction of the beaches or Port Royal.
In the 1890's the historian Henry Adams would board a little steamer packet to ride to a house on the beach where, with a party of Washington friends, he would roast oysters, paint in watercolor and catch crabs. Today Highway 21 will carry you to Hunting Island State Park. If beachcombing and sunbathing aren't enough, the lighthouse can be climbed or bikes ridden on roads that weave through the maritime forest. At high tide the beach disappears due to severe erosion. Or walk the length of Paradise Pier - 1120 feet - which reaches into Fripp inlet at the south end of the island.
Or your way you may want to stop for lunch at the Shrimp Shack, a small, rustic restaurant on the side of the road, across from the owner's excellent dockside fish market. Or if the tide is low and coming in, cast a net from Cowan Creek bridge, or in the big bend at Village Creek, two popular fishing spots. Or visit Penn Center on St. Helena Island.
Penn was established in 1862 as a school for the newly-freed slaves by two female abolitionists and has remained a proud center of community life ever since. The York W. Bailey Museum (open Monday to Friday, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M.) displays artifacts from Penn's educational mission, past and present, and objects confirming the close ties between African and slave life, which has produced a culture called Gullah. Community singing sessions, open to the public, feature a program of spirituals and readings. They take place at 7:30 P.M. every third Sunday from September to May.
The crescent beach off Sixth Street in Port Royal, locally referred to as The Sands, and its adjacent marsh boardwalk, are about seven miles from Beaufort. The boardwalk and 45-foot-high viewing tower offer a panoramic view of the harbor, of Parris Island, the Marine Corps Recruit Training Depot, and of freighters like the Repap, which carries raw materials for glossy paper coating to Canada, and returns with the paper.
As Beaufort has become more prosperous it seems able, for the first time, to praise its small town roots as much as its Old South status. The Lowcountry Ledger, a new, thoughtful and determinedly local weekly newspaper, runs a column called ''Old Times Are Not Forgotten.'' It is a compilation of old newspaper items that chronicle church picnics, socials, the pranks of local boys and 100-year-old business gossip. It is a charming celebration of small town life. It never mentions the Old Families or the Old South.
The editor says it is the most popular feature in the paper.
 
 
 
A VISITOR'S GUIDE TO BEAUFORT
 
Getting There
 The closest airport to Beaufort is at Savannah, Ga., just under an hour's drive by car. Charleston Airport is about 90 minutes away, but it's a pretty ride to Beaufort on Highway 17, the old coast road through the rural Lowcountry marshes and former rice fields.
 
What to See
 Following are some of the sights of the area. The area code is 803.
 The Greater Beaufort Chamber of Commerce has a visitor center at 1006 Bay Street. More information: Post Office Box 910, Beaufort, S.C. 29901; 524-3163.
 The John Mark Verdier House museum (524-6334) is open Tuesday to Saturday from 11 A.M. to 4 P.M. The George Parsons Elliott House museum is open Monday to Friday from 11 A.M. to 3 P.M. Admission is $3; $2 for students, $5 for both houses.
 The Beaufort Arsenal Museum, 713 Craven Street (525 7471), is open 10 A.M. to noon and 2 to 5 P.M. weekdays and 10 A.M. to 12 P.M. Saturday. Donations welcomed.
 Hunting Island State Park (1775 Sea Island Parkway, St. Helena Island, S.C. 29920; 838-2011) is open from dawn to dusk. Admission is $2 a car. The brand-new visitors center, with displays of flora, fauna and old photographs, is open daily from 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Ask about reservations for cabin rental here; camping sites must be secured at the campground. Fishing fees are $1.50 per rod at Paradise Pier. Rods and tackle are available for rent ($10) and there's bait for sale.
 
Where to Stay
 Beaufort's recent prosperity has brought a variety of lodgings to the area.
 The proprietors of the Rhett House Inn (1009 Craven Street; 524-9030) who used to be in the New York fashion business, have converted an antebellum house a block back from the river into an eight-room bed and breakfast with a look that wears well in the hot weather. There's lots of natural light, antique furniture, pretty patterned fabrics and a library table piled with glossy magazines. Double rooms start at $80, including breakfast; $15 extra for a third person in the room. No children under 5.
The Trescot Inn (500 Washington Street; 522-8552) has six rooms priced from $65 for double occupancy, including breakfast. Its second-story veranda, which is nearly 50 feet long and 12 feet wide, overlooks drifts of azaleas, cedar trees and vine-covered fences in the Point neighborhood. No children under 12.
There are three bedrooms in the Old Point Inn (212 New Street; 524-3177) with Victorian touches such as lace curtains and gingham-style wallpaper that correspond with the turn-of-the-century date of the house. From the upstairs porch you can see the boat traffic and the twinkling lights of Ladies Island. Rates, including breakfast, start at $55 for a double room.
The Best Western Sea Island Inn (1015 Bay Street; 524-4121) has a convenient downtown location, attractively decorated rooms and a pool. Through the high season to Oct. 31, rates start at $58 for a double room. The Cafe is open for Continental breakfast every and lunch every day except Sunday.
 
Places to Eat
 Nearly every menu in Beaufort includes locally caught seafood. Following are some of the more popular places: The Gadsby Tavern (525-1800) and Plum's (525-1946) open out onto the Waterfront Park and are loose, informal places, especially at lunch. Gadsby's often features live acoustic music Friday and Saturday night. Lunch prices are about $4 to $6 for entrees or a good soup-and-salad combination. At Plum's there are hefty sandwiches (from about $2.50 to $5) and homemade ice cream starting at $1.30.
For dinner, The Steamer on Highway 21 on Ladies Island (524-1755) is the most popular place in town, with consistently good seafood dishes and oysters by the bucket. It's noisy and service can be slow. Entrees from about $10, depending on the specials.
Wilkop's Whitehall Inn (524-0382) also just off Highway 21 on Ladies Island and The Anchorage at 1103 Bay Street (524-9392) are more formal. The Anchorage has rooms of dark paneling, Wilkop's is set in a lovely live oak grove facing the river. Menus emphasize local seafood, especially shrimp and crab, and there are full wine lists. Dinner for two runs about $40 to $50, including wine. The Shrimp Shack (838-2962) on St. Helena Island or the Dockside (524-7433) in Port Royal offer abundant platters of seafood, slaw and hush puppies. The Dockside is right on the water and offers one of the prettiest sunset views around. Entrees are from $8.50; from about $5 at the Shrimp Shack.

HEADLINE: Stone Symbols Of Shaker Permanence

BYLINE: By SUSAN ALLPORT; Susan Allport's book ''Sermons in Stone: The Stone Walls of New England and New York,'' will be published by W. W. Norton & Company in October.

 BODY:
As I approached the Shaker village in Canterbury, N.H., from the south, I became aware of its stone walls at the same moment I spotted the white clapboard buildings. They vie for your attention: the simple buildings surrounded by shade trees and perched on top of a high hill, and the lichen-encrusted, gray-green walls built with stones the size of which I had never seen before in a wall. Some of the stones extend well over a yard in every dimension; they weigh more than 4,000 pounds each. The walls, I discovered, have been impressing visitors for almost 200 years.
''The Shaker land is easily known by its superior cultivation, and by its substantial stone wall fences,'' John Finch, the English economist reported after visiting Canterbury in the 19th century. Earlier, in 1799, when Timothy Dwight, Yale University's peripatetic president, passed through the village, he wrote that, ''everything about them was clean and tidy . . . Even their stables, the fences which surround their fields, and the road which passes through their village are all uncommonly neat.''
The Shakers, a religious, celibate sect who got their name from the frenzied dancing that accompanied their worship, built walls wherever they had land to fence and stone to fence it with, but those at the Canterbury village are particularly remarkable because of the quantity of stone the wall builders there had to work with. 
Canterbury, north of Concord, has some of the rockiest land in all of New England. It was once the home of 300 Shakers, who lived, worked and worshiped in its 100 buildings and farmed 6,000 acres. Today it is still a living Shaker community, but only 22 buildings, 600 acres and two Shaker sisters still remain. The fields lie fallow and the village functions primarily as a museum where visitors can take a 90-minute guided tour of some of the buildings and industries, then wander through the grounds and watch skilled artisans re-create many 19th-century Shaker crafts.
Afterward they can lunch (or dine later on by candlelight) in the old Shaker Creamery on such traditional Shaker fare as squash biscuits with blackberry honey butter and roast loin of pork with forest mushroom gravy. Such an excursion could easily occupy most of a day.
Shakers are best known today for their inventions and their sparse but graceful furniture, yet their walls speak every bit as eloquently as these other objects of Shaker beliefs and practices. Though built of the same glacial debris as most of New England's walls, the walls at Canterbury bear about as much resemblance to the garden-variety, hastily constructed field wall that one sees everywhere in this stony part of the world as a well-built boat resembles a leaky dinghy. With their enormous stones and careful construction, these walls will not need repairing every spring when winter frosts have finished heaving the earth about. No, these are walls that time will not move, let alone frost. Embedded in them, it seems, are the basic tenets of the Shakers, the idea that labor was consecrated and that every object should be made as if the maker would die tomorrow but the object must last a thousand years.
Much of the history of the Shaker movement can also be read in these walls. When Ann Lee, founder of the sect, led her small group to the New World in 1774, she sought to bring Heaven to earth by creating a perfect and orderly society founded on good tillage. At first, the Shakers could afford to buy only rocky, unproductive land such as that in Canterbury, but in a matter of years, they turned this unpromising terrain into well-ordered fields bordered by substantial walls.
Shakers succeeded where many other self-subsistence farmers failed because of their fervency (farming, to them, was a way of delivering the earth from evil; every stone taken out of the ground and placed in a wall was a step in that direction) and the advantages of their communal husbandry: the fact that they farmed with a large labor pool. The benefits of this labor force can be seen particularly well in the area of fencing. Whereas an individual farmer began fencing his land first with logs, then stumps, then rail fences, only getting around to building stone walls after decades or generations of farming, at Canterbury, the Shakers had the manpower to fence early and almost exclusively in stone.
The wall that lines Shaker Road to the south of the village, the one with the exceptionally large stones, dates to 1793, just a year after the Shaker community at Canterbury was founded. By the 1850's, the community's entire 6,000 acres had been cleared, divided and fenced in stone.
According to ''The People Called Shakers,'' by Edward Deming Andrews (Oxford University Press), a Philadelphia visitor, W. S. Warder, once asked the community, ''How do you and your neighbors manage about fencing?'' He was told that ''little difficulty was encountered. We make ours good, and they generally follow the example; if they do not quite do their part, we do a little more than ours, and in time they come tolerably near to what they ought to be.''
Strolling through the village, visitors can sense the same pride in superior craftsmanship - especially in the stonework. Here, the granite that the glaciers left behind was used to make not only walls but also to shape numerous other objects that in less stony areas or in the hands of a less industrious people might have been made out of wood. Among the handsome frame buildings are finely chiseled gateposts, door frames, stoops and steps, sluiceways and walkways, which, had they been made of wood, would have rotted long ago.
As it is, they stand today as symbols of the permanence that the Shakers sought, a permanence that eluded them as the sect, once the largest American utopian society, went into decline after the Civil War.
Well-built as these walls and stone objects are, for me, one of their most unusual features lies not in their construction but in the fact that a great deal is known about when they were built and by whom. This feature alone distinguishes them from most of the stonework in New England, an area where walls were so commonplace and so little remarked upon that they are now the anonymous epics of earlier times. I have been frustrated by the lack of written material, and so I was delighted to discover at Canterbury journals and a tradition of oral history rich with the lives of wall builders. There is a pleasant paradox here. Believing that individuals should devote their lives to the good of the community, Shakers rarely signed anything they made. Yet because they so appreciated good craftsmanship, their journals are filled with accounts of talented workers and the objects they created.
In the journal of the Shaker leader Henry Blinn, for instance, is the story behind a plot of land known as Ezekiel's meadow, named for brother Ezekiel Stevens who died in 1836 after singlehandedly clearing and fencing this especially difficult piece of land, the exact location of which is not known today. Stevens was known to say that ''it is better to wear out than to rust out,'' but he worked so hard that the Shakers' worldly neighbors circulated the story that he had been forced to clear the land as a penance for sins he had committed.
In the same journal is the story of a wall builder who died as the result of a blow from his own stone hammer. In 1836, brother Elijah Fletcher hit his knee with his heavy hammer and had to be confined to the house for nine months. Finally his leg was amputated. ''He was conscious during the operation & bore it like a hero,'' Blinn notes, but he died three weeks later.
Blinn writes, too, about the hand-chiseled, stone watering trough that stands empty today at the foot of the hill below the village and was much admired by Nathaniel Hawthorne in his story ''Canterbury Pilgrims.'' In this story, two young Shakers who are running away from the celibate sect to marry stop at the trough to drink and there meet a band of world-weary travelers. Hawthorne describes the trough as ''the work of neat hands and considerate art''; Blinn tells us that the hands were those of the Shaker brother Micajah Tucker who placed the trough at the foot of the hill in 1831.
Tucker was certainly the most notable of all the community's masons. According to Blinn, he chiseled out most of the slabs that form the granite walkways in the village (walkways that have been keeping Shaker shoes dry and mud-free since they were laid in the 1830's; ''1835'' is inscribed in one of the stones on the southernmost pathway). Tucker also made most of the gateposts and many of Canterbury's remarkable stone stoops - four or five steps chiseled out of a single granite boulder.
The stoops leading up to the chapel and on the south side of the carriage house were made by Tucker, while that in front of the family dwelling was the work of the unfortunate Elijah Fletcher.
Micajah Tucker is also a good example of the tradition of oral history at Canterbury. Although he died in 1848, his work is remembered and praised by Shakers today. Eldress Bertha Lindsay, one of the two Shakers still living at the village and the last remaining Shaker Elder or Eldress anywhere, has been blind for 30 years, but she can still list and describe Tucker's accomplishments. Moreover, she says she can distinguish the objects this mason made by their exceptionally smooth surface. ''Fletcher's steps are nice, she notes, ''but they're a little rougher.''
Bertha, who came to the Shakers as an orphan in 1905, was also able to solve for me the mystery of another wall on the property. This is the one that lines Shaker Road as it runs north from the village to the Shaker cemetery, a wall that is puzzling because it lacks the enduring quality of Tucker's work or the walls leading up to the village.
The wall is in good condition, but it is made not of enormous granite blocks but, rather, of much smaller stones - one-man stones, a mason might call them because they are light enough for one man to lift. When I first saw the wall, I assumed it had been built with rocks picked out of fields cultivated in potatoes or some other root crop, an operation that involves clearing the fields of even small stones. But my rationale was wrong. The wall was built by a one-armed man in the 1800's, said Bertha. ''The stones are small because he couldn't handle bigger ones,'' she explained, adding an understatement that sums up much of the legacy of the Shakers and the reason so many of us are drawn today to the objects they made: ''He must have been very dedicated to what he was doing.''
 
VILLAGE VISITS
 
Getting There
 
The Canterbury Shaker Village (Canterbury, N.H. 03224; 603-783-9511) is about 18 miles north of Concord. It can be reached from Interstate 93.
The village is open daily to Oct. 20 from 10 A.M. to 5 P.M. Entry fee ($6.75, $3.50 for children 6 to 12) includes a guided tour.
 
Activities
 The village offers year-round events and workshops, including candlelight dinners and tours. The dinners are on Friday and Saturday evenings and, in midsummer, Thursday. Some upcoming events: Farm Day (June 2) Herb Day (June 23).
 
Where to Stay
 There are two good bed and breakfasts within 10 minutes of the Shaker Village: the 200-year-old Wyman Farm in Loudon (603-783-4467) and The Inn at Loudon Ridge in Loudon (603-267-8952). At the farm, the rate for double occupancy is $40 to $60 a night; at the inn, it is $50 to $65. Breakfast is included at both places.
