HEADLINE: A Negative Vote On Affirmative Action

BYLINE: By Shelby Steele: Shelby Steele is an English professor at San Jose State University in California. A collection of his essays, ''The Content of Our Character,'' will be published in August.

 BODY:
IN A FEW SHORT YEARS, WHEN MY TWO children will be applying to college, the affirmative-action policies by which most universities offer black students some form of preferential treatment will present me with a dilemma. I am a middle-class black, a college professor, far from wealthy, but also well removed from the kind of deprivation that would qualify my children for the label ''disadvantaged.'' Both of them have endured racial insensitivity from whites. They have been called names, have suffered slights and have experienced first hand the peculiar malevolence that racism brings out of people. Yet they have never experienced racial discrimination, have never been stopped by their race on any path they have chosen to follow. Still, their society now tells them that if they will only designate themselves as black on their college applications, they will probably do better in the college lottery than if they conceal this fact. I think there is something of a Faustian bargain in this. 
Of course many blacks and a considerable number of whites would say that I was sanctimoniously making affirmative action into a test of character. They would say that this small preference is the meagerest recompense for centuries of unrelieved oppression. And to these arguments other very obvious facts must be added. In America, many marginally competent or flatly incompetent whites are hired every day -some because their white skin suits the conscious or unconscious racial preference of their employers. The white children of alumni are often grandfathered into elite universities in what can only be seen as a residual benefit of historic white privilege. Worse, white incompetence is always an individual matter, but for blacks it is often confirmation of ugly stereotypes. Given that unfairness cuts both ways, doesn't it only balance the scales of history, doesn't this repay, in a small way, the systematic denial under which my children's grandfather lived out his days?
In theory, affirmative action certainly has all the moral symmetry that fairness requires. It is reformist and corrective, even repentent and redemptive. And I would never sneer at these good intentions. Born in the late 1940's in Chicago, I started my education (a charitable term, in this case) in a segregated school, and suffered all the indignities that come to blacks in a segregated society. My father, born in the South, made it only to the third grade before the white man's fields took permanent priority over his formal education. And though he educated himself into an advanced reader with an almost professorial authority, he could only drive a truck for a living, and never earned more than $90 a week in his entire life. So yes, it is crucial to my sense of citizenship, to my ability to identify with the spirit and the interests of America, to know that this country, however imperfectly, recognizes its past sins and wishes to correct them.
Yet good intentions can blind us to the effects they generate when implemented. In our society affirmative action is, among other things, a testament to white good will and to black power, and in the midst of these heavy investments its effects can be hard to see. But after 20 years of implementation I think that affirmative action has shown itself to be more bad than good and that blacks - whom I will focus on in this essay - now stand to lose more from it than they gain.
In talking with affirmative-action administrators and with blacks and whites in general, I found that supporters of affirmative action focus on its good intentions and detractors emphasize its negative effects. It was virtually impossible to find people outside either camp. The closest I came was a white male manager at a large computer company who said, ''I think it amounts to reverse discrimination, but I'll put up with a little of that for a little more diversity.'' But this only makes him a half-hearted supporter of affirmative action. I think many people who don't really like affirmative action support it to one degree or another anyway.
I believe they do this because of what happened to white and black Americans in the crucible of the 1960's, when whites were confronted with their racial guilt and blacks tasted their first real power. In that stormy time white absolution and black power coalesced into virtual mandates for society. Affirmative action became a meeting ground for those mandates in the law. At first, this meant insuring equal opportunity. The 1964 civil-rights bill was passed on the understanding that equal opportunity would not mean racial preference. But in the late 60's and early 70's, affirmative action underwent a remarkable escalation of its mission from simple anti-discrimination enforcement to social engineering by means of quotas, goals, timetables, set-asides and other forms of preferential treatment.
Legally, this was achieved through a series of executive orders and Equal Employment Opportunity Comission guidelines that allowed racial imbalances in the workplace to stand as proof of racial discrimination. Once it could be assumed that discrimination explained racial imbalances, it became easy to justify group remedies to presumed discrimination rather than the normal case-by-case redress.
Even though blacks had made great advances during the 60's without quotas, the white mandate to achieve a new racial innocence and the black mandate to gain power, which came to a head in the very late 60's, could no longer be satisfied by anything less than racial preferences. I don't think these mandates, in themselves, were wrong, because whites clearly needed to do better by blacks and blacks needed more real power in society. But as they came together in affirmative action, their effect was to distort our understanding of racial discrimination. By making black the color of preference, these mandates have reburdened society with the very marriage of color and preference (in reverse) that we set out to eradicate.
When affirmative action grew into social engineering, diversity became a golden word. Diversity is a term that applies democratic principles to races and cultures rather than to citizens, despite the fact that there is nothing to indicate that real diversity is the same thing as proportionate representation. Too often the result of this, on campuses for example, has been a democracy of colors rather than of people, an artificial diversity that gives the appearance of an educational parity between black and white students that has not yet been achieved in reality. Here again, racial preferences allow society to leapfrog over the difficult problem of developing blacks to parity with whites and into a cosmetic diversity that covers the blemish of disparity - a full six years after admission, only 26 to 28 percent of blacks graduate from college.
Racial representation is not the same thing as racial development. Representation can be manufactured; development is always hard earned. But it is the music of innocence and power that we hear in affirmative action that causes us to cling to it and to its distracting emphasis on representation. The fact is that after 20 years of racial preferences the gap between median incomes of black and white families is greater than it was in the 1970's. None of this is to say that blacks don't need policies that insure our right to equal opportunity, but what we need more of is the development that will let us take advantage of society's efforts to include us.
I think one of the most troubling effects of racial preferences for blacks is a kind of demoralization. Under affirmative action, the quality that earns us preferential treatment is an implied inferiority. However this inferiority is explained - and it is easily enough explained by the myriad deprivations that grew out of our oppression - it is still inferiority. There are explanations and then there is the fact. And the fact must be borne by the individual as a condition apart from the explanation, apart even from the fact that others like himself also bear this condition. In integrated situations in which blacks must compete with whites who may be better prepared, these explanations may quickly wear thin and expose the individual to racial as well as personal self-doubt. (Of course whites also feel doubt, but only personally, not racially.) What this means in practical terms is that when blacks deliver themselves into integrated situations they encounter a nasty little reflex in whites, a mindless, atavistic reflex that responds to the color black with negative sterotypes, such as intellectual ineptness. I think this reflex embarrasses most whites today and thus it is usually quickly repressed. On an equally atavistic level, the black will be aware of the reflex his color triggers and will feel a stab of horror at seeing himself reflected in this way. He, too, will do a quick repression, but a lifetime of such stabbings is what constitutes his inner realm of racial doubt. Even when the black sees no implication of inferiority in racial preferences, he knows that whites do, so that - consciously or unconsciously - the result is virtually the same. The effect of preferential treatment - the lowering of normal standards to increase black representation - puts blacks at war with an expanded realm of debilitating doubt, so that the doubt itself becomes an unrecognized preoccupation that undermines their ability to perform, especially in integrated situations.
I believe another liability of affirmative action comes from the fact that it indirectly encourages blacks to exploit their own past victimization. Like implied inferiority, victimization is what justifies preference, so that to receive the benefits of preferential treatment one must, to some extent, become invested in the view of one's self as a victim. In this way, affirmative action nurtures a victim-focused identity in blacks and sends us the message that there is more power in our past suffering than in our present achievements.
When power itself grows out of suffering, blacks are encouraged to expand the boundaries of what qualifies as racial oppression, a situation that can lead us to paint our victimization in vivid colors even as we receive the benefits of preference. The same corporations and institutions that give us preference are also seen as our oppressors. At Stanford University, minority-group students - who receive at least the same financial aid as whites with the same need - recently took over the president's office demanding, among other things, more financial aid.
But I think one of the worst prices that blacks pay for preference (Continued on Page 73) has to do with an illusion. I saw this illusion at work recently in the mother of a middle-class black student who was going off to his first semester of college: ''They owe us this, so don't think for a minute that you don't belong there.'' This is the logic by which many blacks, and some whites, justify affirmative action - it is something ''owed,'' a form of reparation. But this logic overlooks a much harder and less digestible reality, that it is impossible to repay blacks living today for the historic suffering of the race. If all blacks were given a million dollars tomorrow it would not amount to a dime on the dollar for three centuries of oppression, nor would it dissolve the residues of that oppression that we still carry today. The concept of historic reparation grows out of man's need to impose on the world a degree of justice that simply does not exist. Suffering can be endured and overcome, it cannot be repaid. To think otherwise is to prolong the suffering.
Several blacks I spoke with said they were still in favor of affirmative action because of the ''subtle'' discrimination blacks were subject to once they were on the job. One photojournalist said, ''They have ways of ignoring you.'' A black female television producer said: ''You can't file a lawsuit when your boss doesn't invite you to the insider meetings without ruining your career. So we still need affirmative action.'' Others mentioned the infamous ''glass ceiling'' through which blacks can see the top positions of authority but never reach them. But I don't think racial preferences are a protection against this subtle discrimination; I think they contribute to it.
In any workplace, racial preferences will always create two-tiered populations composed of preferreds and unpreferred. In the case of blacks and whites, for instance, racial preferences imply that whites are superior just as they imply that blacks are inferior. They not only reinforce America's oldest racial myth but, for blacks, they have the effect of stigmatizing the already stigmatized.
I think that much of the ''subtle'' discrimination that blacks talk about is often (not always) discrimination against the stigma of questionable competence that affirmative action marks blacks with. In this sense, preferences make scapegoats of the very people they seek to help. And it may be that at a certain level employers impose a glass ceiling, but this may not be against the race so much as against the race's reputation for having advanced by color as much as by competence. This ceiling is the point at which corporations shift the emphasis from color to competency and stop playing the affirmative-action game. Here preference backfires for blacks and becomes a taint that holds them back. Of course one could argue that this taint, which is after all in the minds of whites, becomes nothing more than an excuse to discriminate against blacks. And certainly the result is the same in either case - blacks don't get past the glass ceiling. But this argument does not get around the fact that racial preferences now taint this color with a new theme of suspicion that makes blacks even more vulnerable to discrimination. In this crucial yet gray area of perceived competence, preferences make whites look better than they are and blacks worse, while doing nothing whatever to stop the very real discrimination that blacks may encounter. I don't wish to justify the glass ceiling here, but only suggest the very subtle ways that affirmative action revives rather than extinguishes the old rationalizations for racial discrimination.
I believe affirmative action is problematic in our society because we have demanded that it create parity between the races rather than insure equal opportunity. Preferential treatment does not teach skills, or educate, or instill motivation. It only passes out entitlement by color, a situation that in my profession has created an unrealistically high demand for black professors. The social engineer's assumption is that this high demand will inspire more blacks to earn Ph.D's and join the profession. In fact, the number of blacks earning Ph.D's has declined in recent years. Ph.D's must be developed from preschool on. They require family and community support. They must acquire an entire system of values that enables them to work hard while delaying gratification.
It now seems clear that the Supreme Court, in a series of recent decisions, is moving away from racial preferences. It has disallowed preferences except in instances of ''identified discrimination,'' eroded the precedent that statistical racial imbalances are prima facie evidence of discrimination, and, in effect, granted white males the right to challenge consent degrees that use preference to achieve racial balances in the workplace. Referring to this and other Supreme Court decisions, one civil-rights leader said, ''Night has fallen . . . as far as civil rights are concerned.'' But I am not so sure. The effect of these decisions is to protect the constitutional rights of everyone, rather than to take rights away from blacks. Night has fallen on racial preferences, not on the fundamental rights of black Americans. The reason for this shift, I believe, is that the white mandate for absolution from past racial sins has weakened considerably in the 1980's. Whites are now less willing to endure unfairness to themselves in order to grant special entitlements to blacks, even when those entitlements are justified in the name of past suffering. Yet the black mandate for more power in society has remained unchanged. And I think part of the anxiety many blacks feel over these decisions has to do with the loss of black power that they may signal.
But the power we've lost by these decisions is really only the power that grows out of our victimization. This is not a very substantial or reliable power, and it is important that we know this so we can focus more exclusively on the kind of development that will bring enduring power. There is talk now that Congress may pass new legislation to compensate for these new limits on affirmative action. If this happens, I hope the focus will be on development and anti-discrimination, rather than entitlement, on achieving racial parity rather than jerry-building racial diversity.
But if not preferences, what? The impulse to discriminate is subtle and cannot be ferreted out unless its many guises are made clear to people. I think we need social policies that are committed to two goals: the educational and economic development of disadvantaged people regardless of race and the eradication from our society - through close monitoring and severe sanctions - of racial, ethnic or gender discrimination. Preferences will not get us to either of these goals, because they tend to benefit those who are not disadvantaged - middle-class white women and middle-class blacks - and attack one form of discrimination with another. Preferences are inexpensive and carry the glamour of good intentions - change the numbers and the good deed is done. To be against them is to be unkind. But I think the unkindest cut is to bestow on children like my own an undeserved advantage while neglecting the development of those disadvantaged children in the poorer sections of my city who will most likely never be in a position to benefit from a preference. Give my children fairness; give disadvantaged children a better shot at development - better elementary and secondary schools, job training, safer neighborhoods, better financial assistance for college and so on. A smaller percentage of black high school graduates go to college today than 15 years ago; more black males are in prison, jail or in some other way under the control of the criminal-justice system than in college. This despite racial preferences.
The mandates of black power and white absolution out of which preferences emerged were not wrong in themselves. What was wrong was that both races focused more on the goals of those mandates than on the means to the goals. Blacks can have no real power without taking responsibility for their own educational and economic development. Whites can have no racial innocence without earning it by eradicating discrimination and helping the disadvantaged to develop. Because we ignored the means, the goals have not been reached and the real work remains to be done.

HEADLINE: DESIGN;
Spain: Spires in the Sky

BYLINE: By Carol Vogel

 BODY:
SCAFFOLDING HAS BECOME an integral part of Spain's urban landscape. So have construction crews, churning up clouds of dust and dirt. On almost every major street in cities like Madrid and Barcelona, buildings shrouded in green plastic resemble giant packages waiting to be unwrapped.
Most of the unveilings won't take place for another two years, however, as Spain races to rebuild its cities by 1992. This deadline is spoken about patriotically, and with an almost progandalike defiance by everyone from Government officals and architects to shopkeepers and hotel managers. In many offices, calendars posted in the halls even have a countdown to January 1992 printed in the lower right-hand corner. 
And with good reason. That is the year when the European community becomes a region of unrestricted trade. And Spain, which joined the community in 1986, is working overtime to bring itself up to the level of its economic colleagues. It is also the year when Barcelona will be the host of the Olympic Games and when the World's Fair will be held in Seville. Underlying these scheduled events, however, is a far bigger scheme. During the 36-year reign of Francisco Franco, who died in 1975, Spain was perceived as a backward country. But now, with its stable democracy, the country is booming economically. Not only has the Spanish Government launched ambitious plans to rebuild its cities and infrastructure - highways, railroads and ports - but foreign investment has poured into Spain from Western Europe, the United States and Japan at the rate of more than $10 billion per year. Tourism is up, as well.
But just how good is it for a country to be building so much so fast? ''The wheels are turning too quickly,'' says Estanislao Perez-Pita y Junquera, a Madrid-based architecture company whose office is bursting with commissions, including the renovation of a large public library, an archeology museum and the Spanish Embassy in Vienna. ''We don't have time to think what we're doing. It's overwhelming. Spain is trying to catch up with the rest of Europe after being in the dumps for 50 years. And we're trying hard. But there's little thinking behind all these efforts. That's my biggest concern.'' According to Salvador Gayarre, the architect who designed the controversial new I.B.M. building in Madrid and who is currently working on an extension to Madrid's Senate building: ''We're not trying to compete with New York or Paris. It's more basic than that. There's a general consciousness to improve our quality of life.''
In the process, however, quality may suffer. ''There are weaknesses connected with such fast growth,'' concedes Tomas Llorens, the director of the Reina Sofia Art Center in Madrid, the national museum of contemporary art housed in an 18th-century hospital that is also undergoing major renovations. ''The quality of building is not always what it should be. And the artistic side of architecture can get lost.''
Interestingly, however, top architects from all over the world have accepted large commissions in Spain, particularly in Madrid and Barcelona. In Barcelona alone, the list reads like a ''Who's Who in Architecture.'' For example, Arata Isozaki has come from Japan to design a new sports arena, while the Milan-based Gae Aulenti is transforming the interior of the National Palace into a museum of Catalan art. The New York architect Peter Eisenman is designing a hotel on the outskirts of Barcelona, and Norman Foster of London is building a Tower of Communications. ''There's a spirit and an energy that's contagious,'' says Richard Meier, the New York architect who has designed the new 130,000-square-foot Museum of Contemporary Art in Barcelona. ''The acceration of efforts has been good. Like any major endeavor, there will be mistakes, but the overall scheme is staggering.''
Gentrification differs from place to place. In Barcelona, the Olympics is simply an excuse to revitalize the entire city, opening it up to the sea in an effort to make it the Mediterranean capital. As a city, Barcelona has a history of radical transformations. This is the third in less than a century, the last occurring in 1929 for the International Exposition. The city also has a long and honorable heritage as a design capital - home to the architect Antonio Gaudi and to Mies Van Der Rohe's Pavillion. Currently, Josef Acebillo, the head of city planning, is continuing to make Barcelona an international design mecca. In addition to the Olympic facilities, the city is building museums as well as hotels, which will be greatly needed to house the muitudes expected to come to the Olympics. And throughout the city, more than 200 parks, plazas and streets are being rehabilitated or designed from scratch, complete with more than 50 sculptures by such celebrated artists as Ellsworth Kelly, Roy Lichtenstein, Richard Serra, Eduardo Chillida, Beverly Pepper and Xavier Corbero.
''Barcelona, like London, is a domestic city, and we're trying not to change that feeling,'' Acebillo says. ''We want to purposely juxtapose the old architecture with the new.''
Indeed, the mix of buildings is particularly interesting, as foreign architects are adapting their designs to fit in. While Richard Meier's museum will have a white porcelain and enamel facade - the pristine modern esthetic that is Meier's signature no matter where he builds - he says his design is ''right for its place.'' The architect is having the white porcelain and metal enamel panels made in Spain. Inside, Meier has made adjustments he felt were necessary given the good European craftsmanship available. He chose plaster walls because Spain is well-known for its good plasterers. Were the building in the United States, Sheetrock would have been his preference. The building will also have a concrete rather than a steel frame.
This International-Style building is not far from the Olympics stadium designed by a group of Spanish and Italian architects, including Federico Correa, Alfonso Mila and Vittorio Gregotti. Situated on a plateau of Montjuich Mountain, the facade could not be more different from Meiers's museum. The architects renovated the original neo-classical exterior and entrance gate of the 1929 stadium. Inside, however, there is a totally modern facility that seats 60,000 people and has tall, tubular lights and a custom-designed glass booth for the King, Juan Carlos.
In Madrid, this same international melding of styles is apparent. But the two cities differ drastically in their approaches. Barcelona, being smaller, is far more homogenous in its planning efforts. Its residents also have a very proud, nationalistic spirit that pervades all their designs. Madrid, on the other hand, is a more cosmopolitan and sophisticated city, and its architects are more individualistic. Moreover, the city's transformation is due as much to the the influx of major corporations now investing in Spain as it is to public projects. I.B.M., for example, commissioned the Madrid-based architect Salvador Gayarre to design a large office building. ''It's the most technologically advanced building in Spain,'' says Gayarre. ''Everything is computer controlled.'' The design, a post-modern facade of brick and granite, boasts a peaked glass dome. It is composed of two strips of offices built around an interior courtyard connected by two bridges. Another addition to the Madrid landscape has been designed by John Burgee Architects from New York for Prima, a group of Kuwati investors. It features a pair of glass-and-aluminum towers 27 floors high. This is an unusually large project, about 1 million square feet.
Madrid's new public commissions are large, too. Near the Prado, for example, the Madrid architect Rafael Moneo is renovating an early 19th-century building to house the Baron Hans Heinrich Thyssen-Bornemisza art collection. ''We're providing a new look and structure,'' says Moneo, ''but still keeping the old features.'' Moneo is also working on the renovation of the railway station in Madrid as well as a new airport for Seville.
Another public building much in the Spanish news is a large round structure that, at first glance, resembles a prison with its rows of tiny windows. This is only the outer layer of a large and dramatic public housing project designed by Francisco Saenz de Oiza, at 71 still one of Spain's most popular and innovative architects. Housing has become a large problem as Madrid has experienced a 200 percent population boom over the last five years. About his design, Oiza says, ''Architects are all Don Quixotes; they're looking to building the impossible dream.''
Just how successful their dreams are, however, is a matter of debate. ''We're all living for 1992, and that's an unnatural situation,'' Oiza adds. ''What's good is the way it's awakening our cities architecturally.'' Oriol Bohigas, the former head of city planning for Barcelona, is in favor of such fast change. ''A quick transformation is better,'' he says. ''One of the problems with American cities is that they are forever in a state of flux.'' But building so much at the same time means that everything will age simultaneosly. Of the few projects finished in Barcelona, for example, there is already graffiti on the walls of some of the public parks, and cracks are appearing in the concrete. Will these cities be able to maintain the projects they have so lovingly built? ''An even bigger question is what will happen in January of 1993,'' says Estanislao Perez-Pita y Junquera, the Madrid architecture company. ''There's such a big push for '92 that no one is thinking about the recession that will inevitably occur in the future.''

LENGTH: 1461 words

HEADLINE: FASHION;
Spain: Hot to Be the New Spot

BYLINE: By Ruth La Ferla

DATELINE: Spain

 BODY:
Show time is 10 minutes away and workmen are still swarming the stage of the Palacio de Congresos, Madrid's official fashion theater. The name of Manuel Pina, one of the city's premier designers, appears on a wall at the rear. There, to the staccato of hammering, Pina's logo is being wreathed in a tangle of roses and barbed wire. A kinky touch, the wreath is an apt metaphor for the rigor and the romance of Spanish design. But its last-minute placement is also indicative of the sketchy, sometimes improvisational nature of Spain's attempt to become the latest hot spot on the international fashion circuit.
Americans trickling into Spain in pursuit of fashion novelty were greeted by mild confusion. At the Salon Cibeles, Madrid's semiannual fashion fair, show invitations were unnacountably scarce. Programs were haphazardly circulated. And visitors were left to fend for themselves in a last-mintue scramble for seats that afforded a passable view of the runway. 
Still, no one seemed to mind. Hopes ran high that the expansive cultural climate and buoyant economy of post-Franco Spain would give rise to a fashion renaissance as well, andto a degree, those hopes were justified. Madrid and Barcelona, Spain's dueling fashion centers, are host to a band of designers whose talents have only begun to surface. Some, like Pedro del Hiero or Francis Montesinos, have sold their fashions domestically for more than a decade. Others, like Roser Marce, Adolfo Dominguez or Antonio Miro, have successfully marketed their work abroad. Nearly all expect that with the Seville World's Fair and the Barcelona Olympics in 1992, events expected to draw a large influx of foreign visitors, their names will become, if not exactly household words, at least as familiar as that of Sybilla Sorondo, Spain's most famous fashion defector.
Sybilla's emergence - she has been heralded as the first fresh wind to blow out of Spain since Cristobal Balenciaga - and her subsequent departure for Milan, hint simultaneously at Spain's creative riches and the problems confronting designers there. The strength of Spanish fashion is its abundant variety. An expanding constellation of new names and ideas has lured a number of investors to embark on joint ventures with the Spaniards to produce collections for export. These days, the Japanese are the most avid consumers of Spanish style, while American appetites have scarcely been whetted. But that may soon change. This month, the Chicago Apparel Center showcased Spanish fashion in a runway show for consumers. And next fall, Bloomingdale's will begin a storewide Spanish promotion. Representatives of Neomode, the development arm of the GFT Apparel Corporation, which distributes and manufactures a number of European and American labels, recently scoured Madrid and Barcelona for marketable new names.
The choice of Spain was obvious, says Neomode's director, Pablo de Echevarria-Navarro. ''In relatively virgin territory there is much greater design diversity.'' Indeed, the country that has produced Manuel Pina, an exponent of fetishist fashions, from black leather bustiers to spike-heeled, thigh-high boots, has also spawned Jesus del Pozo, whose fragile creations will be distributed by Neomode in the United States.
Slight and taut-faced, with a nervous vein pulsing in his temple, del Pozo says he seldom travels, sees no fashion shows, reads few foreign magazines and works with the solitary dedication of a friar. Yet his collection, wrought with rich fabrics like organza, velvet and marbleized gazar, balances voluminous shapes with lean ones in a manner uncannily reminiscent of Italy's Romeo Gigli.
Gigli disciples abound in Spain, prompting the frequent charge that nothing original arises there. ''Romeo Gigli, Giorgio Armani and Sybilla are the inspiration of so many Spanish designers, and the Spaniards don't even knock them off well,'' carped one recent visitor, a New York department-store executive.Nor is Gene Pressman of Barneys New Yorkimpressed with Spanish design. ''A lot of it has been done before.'' he says.
Deja vu notwithstanding, Spain has produced a flurry of divergent fashion directions. Avant-gardistslike Jordi Cuesta, Angel Schlesser or Devota y Lomba show collectionsreplete with long, slender, high-waisted dresses, voluminous smocks poised over reedy skirts and tent-shaped jackets with dramatically swollen collars. Some of these looks are as regal as Renaissance portraits; others are demure, and still others, with their sullen colors and leaden proportions, are simply dour. Spain is, after all, the land of nuns and black-clad widows. But, as Francis Montesinos well knows, it is also the land of gypsies, toreadors and flamenco. The Valencian-born designer for Montesinos-Alama revels in such images, plundering them for his shows. His line, influenced by regional costume as well as cultural kitsch, is rife with gypsy-fringed shawls, kerchiefs, corset-laced tops and bouffant gingham skirts. Similarly, Jose Victor Rodriguez Caro and Jose Luis Medina del Corral (Victorio & Lucchino) have turned for inspiration to their native Seville. Their ethnically flavored, form-fitting tops and flounced lace skirts were great hits with American buyers.
Style took a baroque turn in the hands of Manuel Pina, who festooned his evening dresses with spiraling mohair, and Joaquim Verdu, a Barcelona-based devotee of so-called futurist fashion. At the Gaudi Mujer, Barcelona's fashion fair, Verdu's models, strapping girls with broad shoulders, assaulted the runway wearing jackets with enormous scrolled lapels. Others seemed to vanish into high satin collars that recalled Flash Gordon's villainous Emperor Ming.
The fantastical bent of Verdu's designs are sure to be lost on most Spanish career women. Enamored of foreign labels, they have yet to discover the talent on their own shores.
Those who have, tend to favor classicists like Roberto Verinno, whose trim riding jackets, shearling coats, jodhpurs and creamy cabled sweaters could give Calvin Klein a run for his money. Nacho Ruiz also courts an affluent working woman. Like many of his fellow Catalans, Ruiz exhibits in Madrid in the hope of attracting an international following. Such defections have only fueled the already intense rivarly between Madrid and Barcelona, as each city vies to become Spain's style capital. So far, it is Madrid that has profited most from the Spanish Government's efforts to promote its designers abroad - part of a sweeping move to encourage exports. Spain underwrites the Salon Cibeles's runway presentations at a cost of about $300,000, compared with $30,000 provided by the Catalan government to produce the Gaudi's shows.
Madrilenos tend to dismiss the Gaudi as a ''local fair,'' but the Catalans are by no means vanquished. Catalonia produces about 60 percent of the nation's textiles and is an important apparel-manufacturing center. In order to modernize its factories, making them more responsive to market demands, the Government is channeling funds into the apparel industry. It is only a matter of time, believes Anna Birules Bertran, director of promotion for the Catalan Department of Industry and Energy, before Barcelona becomes a fashion capital on a par with Milan. ''You must remember,'' says Birules, ''that it was Lombardy's industry that made Milan what it is.'' Yet Spain has an image problem, a legacy of the Franco era. Still perceived as the product of a third-world country, to some minds Spanish fashion remains syonymous with poor fabrics, spotty deliveries and shoddy workmanship. Carol Rollo of Riding High was one of the first New York merchants to carry Sybilla. In those days, before Gibo, Jean-Paul Gaultier's manufacturer, produced Sybilla's designs, Rollo says, ''We had to straighten every hem and run up every seam.''. ''But,'' she adds a little wistfully, ''at least it was affordable.''
Nowadays, at retail prices ranging from about $250 to well over $2,000, Spanish fashions are no bargain. And American retailers are understandably skeptical about Spain's prospects here. Skeptical but hopeful. One has, after all, to start somewhere. Kalman Ruttenstein, senior vice president for fashion direction at Bloomingdale's, remembers his first visit to Giorgio Armani's Milan studio in the early 1970's. ''Armani,'' he recalls, ''was making jackets at the time that had no bottoms to go with them. But it didn't matter. They had a great look.'' Ruttenstein is not suggesting that Spain has produced an Armani - yet. Or that Madrid is about to nudge Milan out of fashion's spotlight. The future, however, is rich in possibilities. ''Show me a city that can develop three strong talents,'' Ruttenstein says, ''and people will go there in hordes.''

SECTION: Section 7; Page 41, Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 1100 words

HEADLINE: Minor Differences Mean a Lot

BYLINE: By MICHAEL IGNATIEFF; Michael Ignatieff is a Canadian historian living in England.

 BODY:

CONTINENTAL DIVIDE
The Values and Institutions of the United States and Canada.
By Seymour Martin Lipset.
337 pp. New York: Routledge. $29.95.
Viewed from the United States, the differences between Americans and Canadians may seem very minor. Viewed from Canada, they form the crux of an identity. To paraphrase Freud, Canadian identity is a national form of the narcissism of minor difference. 
Lament for the imminent disappearance of cultural and political distinctiveness has been a standard refrain among Canadian nationalists since the 1960's. In the 1989 national election, which turned on the issue of free trade with the United States, many Canadian intellectuals argued as if the test of patriotism were how soon a person thought the free trade deal would destroy Canada as a country. Yet Canadians did vote in favor of the party supporting the free trade treaty, indicating that ordinary Canadians were more confident about their country's future than the doom-saying intellectuals.
Given that Canadians disagree violently about their future viability as a people, Seymour Martin Lipset's ''Continental Divide,'' a patient and careful study of the differences between the cultures of the two countries, is bound to trigger debate in Canada. Whether it will do the same south of the border is another matter. Americans have never been exactly riveted by Canadians, and they may have to be convinced that they have anything to learn by looking northward. Yet this is the core of the book: it is addressed as much to Americans as to Canadians, and its message is that at a time when Americans are uncertain about their role in a changing world, their future as an economic power, even their ethnic and racial identity, they might regain a clearer sense of themselves if they took a long hard look in the Canadian mirror.
The first thing they will see is that, unlike Canadians, they have a mission. Indeed, with the collapse of the Communist quest to revolutionize the world, America remains the only nation on earth - with the possible exceptions, ironically, of Iran and Libya - that holds on to a messianic self-image. Mr. Lipset quotes the great American historian Richard Hofstadter's remark: ''It has been our fate as a nation not to have ideologies but to be one.'' There is no Canadian ideology. From the American point of view, this deprives Canadian history of the drama and tragedy of a destiny. From the Canadian point of view, the absence of a national mission is a blessing. It makes possible an ironic and self-deprecating detachment, coupled with a certain ability to see the world as it is.
A sense of destiny gives Americans a confidence, an ebullience, a willingness to take risks that Canadians can only envy. Yet having a mission can be a form of blindness. As Mr. Lipset writes, ''Americans, more than other western peoples, tend to view international politics in nonnegotiable moralistic and ideological terms.'' Thus while many Americans seem disposed to see the triumph of democracy in Eastern Europe as a victory for their system, Canadians are more likely to observe that for many Eastern Europeans the model to emulate is actually something like their own largely social democratic polity. America is far from being the beacon the whole world wants to be led by.
Mr. Lipset's close comparison brings out just how exceptional the United States is. No society is so religious as America, or so quick to politicize moral issues. No society spends more on law and order or gets so little of either for its money. It is the Canadian pattern - a secular culture, hierarchical, law-abiding and deferential - that is more typical of Western societies. Again, Canada conforms to the European norm in the place its political culture accords to trade unionism and to socialist or social democratic third parties. In America, trade union allegiance is declining and third parties get nowhere.
In the Canadian mirror, America's image of itself as the most democratic country on earth becomes unfocused. True, Americans elect judges, district attorneys and a host of other public servants who in Canada and Europe are appointed bureaucrats. Ordinary citizens have much greater power in the United States to initiate legislation through referendums than in other countries. Yet if America affords more opportunities to be a good citizen, participation rates are lower in elections in the United States than they are in those of Europe and Canada. And because of the absence of third parties in America, the range of political alternatives to choose from may be narrower than many realize.
Yet Mr. Lipset's mirror is not meant only to show Americans in a negative light. Canadians will not find the comparisons of their country with the United States very flattering either: less expenditure on research and education than in America, less private philanthropy, a much more cautious attitude toward economic innovation and risk taking. Much of this is standard fare in the litany of Canadian self-deprecation, but Canadians may be surprised to learn that despite their cherished image of themselves as being less dogmatic about government intervention in the economy than the Americans, in fact, American regulatory agencies are much more aggressive and effective in controlling business than Canadian ones are.
''Continental Divide'' is welcome because in its quiet, carefully documented way it chips away at self-flattering illusions on both sides of the border. And instead of simply documenting differences between the two countries, Mr. Lipset, an American political scientist and sociologist at Stanford University's Hoover Institution, traces those differences back to the beginning. Americans remain children of the successful Revolution of 1776, Canadians of the failed counterrevolution of 1783 (when, the author notes, elites ''attempted to create a conservative, monarchical, and ecclesiastical society'') and the trek northward of those colonists loyal to England. ''America,'' Mr. Lipset writes, ''reflects the influence of its classically liberal, Whig, individualistic, antistatist, populist, ideological origins. Canada, at least from a comparative North American perspective, can still be seen as Tory-mercantilist, group-oriented, statist, deferential to authority - a 'socialist monarchy.' '' There is a lesson in this for those pessimists who think that cultural differences will be obliterated in the global village. For more than a century, America and Canada have proved just how enduring the narcissism of minor difference can be.

HEADLINE: First Step, Reinstatement Cave Spurned

 BODY:
To the Sports Editor:
There has been a fair amount of talk recently about Pete Rose and the Hall of Fame. My own opinion is that all the talk is very much premature.
There is one simple statement of fact: the man is banned from baseball. How can you justify giving baseball's highest honor to a man who can't even put his foot in the clubhouse in Cincinnati, in Shea Stadium, and indeed not even any clubhouse in any major or minor league city all across the nation? He must first go through proper channels and get himself reinstated by the commissioner. 
It may come soon or it may never come. That decision is up to the commissioner. Then, and only then, should the pros and cons be debated as to Pete Rose's entry into baseball's highest honor, the Hall of Fame.
 
DON SCHMIDT
Plainfield, N.J.
To the Sports Editor:
I was disappointed to read Nelson Bryant's ''Filming a Big Game Hunt'' (The Times, April 15), promoting some movie about African hunting. Frankly, I didn't think he would still glorify this kind of slaughter, even if it does stir up nostalgic memories of the panda-shooting Roosevelts.
In my opinion, hunters are even more despicable than poachers because of their respective motives. One resorts to killing as a (wretched) way to produce revenue. The other seeks to transform a beautiful animal into a lifeless bloody pulp strictly for entertainment. That's the bottom line.
Today, anyone can go into an African game park and ride within a few yards of these same wild animals. The cape buffaloes just stand there, and the lions don't even look at you.
It's a shame that certain countries like Botswana continue to allow hunting because these economically depressed nations cannot bring themselves to turn down the revenue that some rich zealots are willing to pay for their grisly sport.
The real heroes of the African bush are individuals like Jane Goodall, John Goddard, George Schaller or the late Dr. Bernhard Grzimek and Diane Fossey: people who have devoted their lives to saving the animals of Africa, not killing them.
Regarding Bryant's intimation about man's still-lingering primordial instincts from the cave, I would suggest that this is 1990. It's time to come out of the cave.
 
DANIEL SAMUELS
Armonk, N.Y.

HEADLINE: Give It a Rest

 BODY:
To the Sports Editor:
The $25,000 fine levied by the N.B.A. commissioner, David Stern, against the Los Angeles Lakers for resting their starters against the Portland Trail Blazers is one of the most crass examples of bureaucratic dictating evidenced in sports.
Yes, N.B.A. basketball is a business, a successful business, because of its inherently competitive, fast-paced action with the most gifted athletes of any sport. Unfortunately for the athletes, the demands of the 100-plus games (with playoffs) result in career-ending injuries and premature physical damage. Resting important players before the championship series is prudent, logical coaching.
The playoffs represent the N.B.A.'s highest television ratings, thus the highest potential revenue. It makes economic sense to keep N.B.A. stars healthy and rested to achieve maximum performance and insure audience satisfaction.
Stern's Roman-gladiator approach is nearsighted and an insult to intelligent fans. The best long-term success of the league lies in healthy, long-term playing careers of the players.
This type of policy will undo a lot of hard work and sacrifice. I urge Stern to discontinue this policy, and others that aren't in the players' best interests.
 
JERRY LIPSCOMB
San Diego

LENGTH: 662 words

HEADLINE: Real Estate Slump Yields Fewer Agents

BYLINE: By The Associated Press

 BODY:
CONNECTICUT'S housing slump is depressing not only prices but also the number of agents selling real estate these days.
The number of licensed agents swelled to 39,000 in the boom years of the 1980's. But the Connecticut Real Estate Commission, which mailed 35,000 forms for agents to renew their licenses last year, said only 22,500 had done so by Monday. Old licenses expired April 30. 
''It's a sign of the marketplace. The market has slowed down considerably,'' said Commission Director Larry Hannafin, who also attributed the drop in renewals to a tripling of license fees last year.
 
Thinking Twice
Officials said there are still plenty of agents to help people buy and sell homes. But part-time agents who entered the business during the boom years may be thinking twice, now that the economy has slumped and licenses are more expensive.
''A lot of those people who entered the market when it was hot probably found they couldn't survive, or didn't choose to survive, when things got back to normal,'' said Jeanette Newton, executive officer of the 330-member North Central Connecticut Board of Realtors in Enfield. She said membership has dropped about 5 percent since last year. Connecticut's housing market took off in the 1980's, as people put their paychecks into housing and developers tried to cash in on the region's booming economy. The number of new units authorized grew from 10,855 in 1981 to a high of 30,163 in 1986, while the price of a new home grew from $79,920 in 1980 to $206,813 in 1988, according to figures from the state Department of Housing.
 
'Feeding Frenzy'
''The activity we saw, it was like a feeding frenzy with fish in '86,'' said Bett McCarthy, executive director of the Greenwich Board of Realtors ''That's not the norm.''
But the market has slowed in the last two years, due partly to a glut in housing and partly to higher prices that have discouraged people from buying.
''If they bought their houses in '85 or '86, they haven't seen that much of an appreciation, so they're going to wait for the next appreciation to come and then they're going to sell,'' Ms. McCarthy said.
 
6 Percent Drop
Just as the booming market led to an increase in real estate agents, the slumping market is making some leave. The Connecticut Board of Realtors said membership has slipped about 6 percent, from 17,600 last year to 16,500 today.
Some agents were also dismayed when brokers' fees were increased last year from $100 to $308. Fees for salespeople, who are brokers' apprentices, increased from $75 to $233.
''I think that was just kind of a double whammy for those who had been holding licenses and were in it to make an occasional deal,'' Ms. Newton said.
 
Agent Education
Mr. Hannafin said some agents were also discouraged by a requirement that in even years like 1990, they prove they have improved their real estate knowledge by either taking a test or spending 12 hours in the classroom.
But full-time professionals are staying in the business because they know the ups and downs of real estate and will weather the current storm, said Frank Green, president of the Stamford Board of Realtors.
''Because of the entire economy, people are probably taking a wait-and-look-and-see attitude,'' he said. ''But we in the industry realize now is the time to buy real estate, and I think that's one reason why you don't see a lot of the realtors dropping out of the market.''
Not all areas have seen a drop in agents. The decline appears less severe in Fairfield County, where housing is so expensive that agents can still make a living even when they sell fewer houses.
The number of agents in Hartford has also remained steady at 3,000, said Pat Branciforte, director of member services for the Greater Hartford Association of Realtors.
Agents say business is picking up; spring is traditionally the busiest season for real estate because the weather is better and the school year is about to end.

PUB-DATE: May 13, 1990,

SECTION: Section 12NJ; Page 18, Column 1; New Jersey Weekly Desk

LENGTH: 549 words

HEADLINE: The Casinos' Search For Older Workers

 BODY:
It was with amusement that I read the comments by Patrick Killian, director of casino economics for the Casino Association, in the article ''Casinos Seek Answers to Scarcity of Employees'' (March 25). Mr. Killian was bemoaning the difficulty of getting people to work in Atlantic City's casinos - particularly older people.
As Mr. Killian stated it, ''Hey, we need help; we've helped you, now you help us.'' It must be wonderful to be so inwardly focused that you are blind to the world around you. 
I would like to bring Mr. Killian into the real world with the following points:
The senior citizens owe the casinos nothing. The casinos exist to make a profit for the casino owners, and they pay taxes to the state and Atlantic City for the privilege of operating a gambling concession.
If senior citizens are feeling altruistic, I would think they would get a lot more satisfaction out of volunteering for day care centers, hospitals and crisis centers rather than a casino, where they can watch dissolute wretches throwing their money away. Ugh!
Mr. Killian may be director of casino economics, but he knows nothing about people economics. Let me give him a short course in Eco 101. If a retired person on Social Security who is under the age of 65 takes a job, he must give up 50 cents of every dollar earned over $6,840. That means that all earnings over $6,840 are taxed at a 50 percent rate.
In addition, he must pay Social Security tax at about 7.65 percent, state tax at 2.5 percent and, if he has a decent pension and investments, Federal tax at 28 percent. If you add it all up, it comes to an effective tax rate of 88 percent, leaving our poor pensioner with 12 cents on each dollar earned over $6,840 and sore feet.
Now for the economics lesson. If people are taxed at a rate of 88 percent, they will do one of three things: (a) hide the income, (b) spend more time looking for tax shelters than generating income or (c) not bother to work.
Since (a) and (b) are not available to these senior citizens at the casino (no off-the-books payments here), the only alternative is (c). So why work? If Mr. Killian is serious about getting senior citizens to work at the casinos, I suggest he stop cursing the darkness and get busy lighting some candles. For example:
* Start a bus service, so the senior citizens do not have to drive at night and do not have to spend money on automobile upkeep and maintenance. At the same time, he will be doing something good for the environment.
* Lobby Congress to eliminate the ludicrous and outdated 50 percent penalty on Social Security payments due on earnings over $6,840.
* Provide decent working conditions, and treat people with respect and dignity so they will look forward to coming to work.
Anyway, I thought Mr. Killian was even funnier than the Sunday comics in my local newspaper.
 
MARTIN KLADKO
 Bridgewater

HEADLINE: THE GUIDE

 BODY:

 
COUNTY FUTURE
A familiar former political figure will address the yearly meeting of the Friends of Scarsdale Parks at 7:30 P.M. Thursday. Alfred B. DelBello, the County Executive from 1974 to 1983, has been invited to talk about ''Westchester Beyond 2000.'' The meeting is to be held at the Scarsdale Public Library and is free to the public.
Mr. DelBello is a partner in DelBello Lynch Associates, a consulting firm in Yonkers that specializes in the development and operation of integrated solid-waste, medical-waste and recycling systems, and municipal and corporate financial advisory services. He is also chairman of the State Senate Advisory Committee on Solid Waste and a director of the Westchester County Land Trust. 
His talk will focus on the use of innovative planning and development that might steer Westchester away from its course of continuing urbanization.
In addition to his three terms as County Executive, Mr. DelBello served as a Yonkers City Councilman from 1966 to 1970 and as its Mayor from 1970 to 1974. He became Lieutenant Governor of the state in 1983, and he has been active in more than a dozen organizations seeking improvements in the environment, education and government.
 
TRADE TIPS
A conference called ''Success in Exporting: Mastering the Essentials'' has been organized by the World Trade Club of Westchester. The conference will be held from 8:30 A.M. to 2 P.M. Wednesday at the Holiday Inne Crown Plaza in White Plains. Marcia E. Glenn, director of economic research for Kraft General Foods, will be the keynote speaker on the subject of ''New Horizons for World Trade.''
Practical advice on how to succeed in the international marketplace will be offered by 10 additional speakers, including Paul Homsy, a lecturer for the Wharton Graduate School of Business at the University of Pennsylvania and specialist in international corporate and real-estate transactions for foreign investors in the United States and for American companies abroad.
Among the other speakers are William Hindon, vice president and national sales manager for the global services division of Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company; Joel Barkan, New York District Director of the United States Department of Commerce International Trade Administration.
Also, Edward Marwell, founder and chief executive officer of Curtis Instruments of Mount Kisco, manufacturers of electro-chemical timing instruments and speed controls, with subsidiaries in France, Germany and Great Britain; and Marlene Rossman, president of Rossman, Graham Associates, a marketing and sales consulting firm in Manhattan and adjunct professor of marketing at Pace Graduate School of Business.
A fee of $75 covers the conference, materials, continental breakfast and lunch. Call 948-6444 to register.
 
PODWAL EXHIBIT
Mark Podwal, a Harrison physician, maintains a parallel career as an artist. Forty-six of his drawings are on exhibit until June 10 in the Museum Gallery of the White Plains Public Library at 100 Martine Avenue. ''Ink and Inking: Mark Podwal, Master of the True Line,'' as the show is called, was mounted by the Mount Holyoke College Art Museum, and it is accompanied by an illustrated catalogue containing as essay by Cynthia Ozick, the noted author.
Mr. Podwal is the principal illustrator of the works of Elie Wiesel, including ''Six Days of Destruction,'' published by the Paulist Press in Mahwah, N. J.; ''The Golem,'' published by Summit Books in Manhattan; and the 20-volume ''Elie Wiesel Collection,'' published by Gerecor in New Rochelle. He is a frequent contributor of graphics to The New York Times Op-Ed page, and he has illustrated his own books, titled ''A Jewish Bestiary'' and ''A Book of Hebrew Letters,'' published by the Jewish Publications Society in Philadelphia.
In 1982 Mr. Podwal designed the United States Holocaust Memorial Council Medal, and in 1985 he created the Congressional Gold Medal presented to Mr. Wiesel by President Reagan in 1985.
Gallery hours are from 9 A.M. to 9 P.M. Mondays through Thursdays, 9 A.M. to 6 P.M. Fridays, 9 A.M. to 5 P.M. Saturdays, and 1 to 5 P.M. Sundays.
 
SPRING DANCE
Dancers in the Northern Westchester Center for the Arts Spring Dance Concert, at 4 P.M. Saturday in the John Jay High School Auditorium, range in age from 7 to adult. Original choreography by Mimi Wallace, Susan Tallis and Lida Gaschke includes interpretations of ''Peter and the Wolf'' and ''Coppelia''; ''Variations on a Scotch Theme'' by Beethoven; ''Dance Caprice,'' based on a Vivaldi concerto, and dances set to jazz themes.
Ms. Wallace, director of the center's Performance Workshop for Children, is a former soloist with the San Francisco Ballet Company and she served as a dancer and assistant to the choreographer Peter Gennaro in the Broadway production of ''Annie.''
Ms. Gaschke appeared on Broadway in ''The Pajama Game'' and ''Pal Joey,'' and with the American Ballet Theater. Ms. Tallis trained with the American Ballet Theater in Manhattan and she was a principal dancer with the Rocky Mountain Ballet Ensemble in Colorado.
John Jay High School is on Route 121 in Cross River. Tickets cost $7, children $5. Call 232-5740 for reservations or more information.
 
'ART IN BLOOM'
Flowers - alive, on canvas, in photographs and as subjects for lectures - are the elements in a garden show called ''Art in Bloom,'' sponsored by the Katonah Museum of Art at the Lasdon Estate and Park on Route 35 in Katonah.
Among the 40 floral paintings, drawings and photographs selected for exhibition from the Reader's Digest Collection are works by Robert Mapplethorpe, Frank Stella and Andy Warhol. Botanical prints, professionally designed floral arrangements, garden furniture and decorative accessories will be displayed in the mansion against a backdrop of antique furnishings. Outdoor arrangements and potted plants will adorn the pool, terrace and tennis court, and a collection of bonzai, topiary, orchids, herbs, silk and dried flowers, azaleas and rhododendrons will be on display.
A gift shop, lunch and attendance at seminars carry an extra charge, except for a seminar from 1 to 5 P.M. Thursday by Barbara Damrosch, a landscape designer, which is free. Seven others, held each morning at 10 or 11 A.M. and each afternoon at 1, 2 or 3 P.M. cost $20 and $25 and cover a variety of topics from ''Masterpieces for the Tabletop'' with Frank Laning, an instructor and consultant for the American Institute of Floral Designers, to ''Herb Gardening in Five Seasons,'' with Adela Grenier Simmons, owner of Caprilands Herb Farm in Coventry, Conn.
Visiting hours are from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Thursday through next Sunday, and the admission charge is $5. Call 232-9555 to register for a seminar or to obtain more information. $90ELEANOR CHARLES

HEADLINE: River Pact Urged for 154-Mile Greenway

BYLINE: By TESSA MELVIN

 BODY:
RIVERFRONT communities along the Hudson must cooperate to protect a region so threatened by unplanned development and loss of open space that it could become ''the largest suburb ever built in New York State,'' a state commission reported last week.
But with proper local planning, the authors of the report say, municipalities in the Hudson River Valley, could provide appropriate economic development and protect open land while creating a l54-mile-long ''greenway,'' a network of preserves and parks with open corridors linking the two and stretching from New York City to Albany.
The time has come for the Hudson River Valley ''to think regionally and to act regionally,'' the draft report by the Hudson River Valley Greenway Council said, to preserve a ''sense of place'' in a region where only 4 percent of the 3.9 million acres are protected, where remaining farmland is expected to disappear within 35 years and where one-third of the 42 townships along the river have no public access to it.
 
Council Formed in 1988
The report of the council - appointed by the Governor in 1988 and consisting of 19 members, including state commissioners, heads of ecological organizations and political leaders - outlines a series of steps that communities in the 12 affected counties, including Westchester, must take to preserve the area's cultural identity and natural resources. 
Chief among those steps is the creation of a Hudson River compact to be established among the 82 municipalities bordering the river. Participants in the compact would draw up a series of local plans outlining their own Greenway priorities and guidelines and then work together to address issues of regional planning, public access, economic development including agriculture, natural-resource protection and education. The compact would be enacted by the State Legislature if approved by a referendum of Hudson River Valley communities.
The draft study, compiled after a series of public hearings held regionwide, is now being circulated among municipal and county leaders.
It will be the subject of a second round of hearings, after which the final report will be submitted to Gov. Mario M. Cuomo in November.
 
Intelligent Development Is Sought
''We are trying to make local governments aware of how important their riverfront properties are to the whole state,'' George E. Pataki, an Assemblyman from Peekskill and member of the Greenway Council, said last week. ''The idea is not to discourage development but to encourage development that is intelligently planned. We are not saying 'don't develop housing in the Hudson Valley,' but we are saying the housing built on the river should be limited.''
The specific trail that would constitute the Greenway is an attempt to embrace open-space planning, Mr. Pataki said, adding: ''If the trail is surrounded by high-rises and massive development, it will lose much of its impact. What we are trying to do is to preserve the beauty of the natural habitat up and down the river.''
The compact would provide a way for counties facing each other across the river, as for example Westchester and Rockland Counties do, to discuss the mutual impact of their respective development plans and for a newly constituted Greenway Council composed of local and state government officials and representatives of economic development and environmental groups to develop a regional planning strategy.
Although the draft study has not been widely circulated, some government leaders, like the County Planning Commissioner, Peter Q. Eschweiler, are familiar with and critical of a greenway concept that duplicates a planning process already in place. ''They appear to be ignorant of the work already done,'' Mr. Eschweiler said, adding that planning leaders from adjacent counties have met regularly for years.
Greenway planners, Mr. Eschweiler said, ''want other communities to be more like Westchester.'' He said the county already owned a significant amount of parkland that providedpublic access to the Hudson River and had a greenway trail in the Old Croton Aqueduct. ''What better trailway could there be?'' he asked. Working more closely with Putnam County, which borders Westchester, is more important than forming a compact with Rockland County, which he described as being ''three miles away.''
County Legislator Timothy S. Carey said that more regional planning was needed but that he doubted whether communities could count on the uncertain financial resources of the state to help them do it. In the town of Cortlandt, which is in his district, Mr. Carey said, the hamlet of Verplanck is on a river peninsula with no public way to the water.
 
The Role of Communities
It is risky to depend on financing from the state, which Mr. Carey said ''has been retrenching and promising to help, then reneging.'' He added that ''the idea of a compact of the communities is a great idea, but state funding to help them is a big question in my mind.''
Communities would be asked to develop waterfront plans according to broad criteria established by the Greenway Council; plans promoting, for example, water-based industries rather than residential development along the river. Planning strategies that most closely meet the goals of the council would be eligible for financial and technical assistance from a Greenway Conservancy, an organization set up to help carry out projects and help purchase land.
''We are asking communities to develop their waterfronts in a way that does not preclude public access or cut off the view,'' said David S. Sampson, executive director of the Greenway Council. ''We are asking that they not develop their open space but concentrate economic development in spaces already used for that purpose. Those that do will have conservancy assistance.''
 
Local Support a Key
The success of the program will depend on local support for it, both Mr. Sampson and Mr. Pataki agreed. ''The state must provide incentives to local governments to participate in a meaningful way and to purchase open space,'' Mr. Pataki said. Such incentives, he said, should include priority consideration for communities that want Environmental Quality Bond Act funds, which provide money to purchase open space.
Croton-on-Hudson is one municipality that is seeking bond act money to purchase a strip of undeveloped land on the river at Mariner Cove for a municipal park, Mayor Salvatore P. Vassallo said. ''We have one of the most beautiful areas along the Hudson, but we already have one development, Half Moon Bay, which has taken up quite a bit of the waterfront,'' the Mayor said, adding that the public does have access to the river through those condominiums. To buy the Mariner Cove property would cost at least $6 million, Mr. Vassallo said, adding, ''We can't even think about it.''
The owners of the property appeared before the Croton Zoning Board of Appeals last week to request permission to build 216 marina slips, a 120-seat restaurant, a 25-unit hotel and a ''boatel,'' or boat-storage area on the site. Although the owners, Seprieo Associates of Sarasota, Fla., have been trying for nearly a decade to find a use that Croton municipal leaders will permit, Mayor Vassallo said the village waterfront had experienced enough development and would continue searching for alternatives.
 
Looking at a Model
In neighboring Peekskill, city planners seem to have recognized the values of their waterfront and to have incorporated those values in a comprehensive plan for the 400-acre site, which is almost entirely owned by the city. Peekskill was cited by Greenway Council leaders as a model for other riverfront communities who might join the proposed Hudson River compact.
Peekskill, said Joseph J. Seymour, the city manager, has steadily acquired its waterfront through a series of negotiations over the last 15 years, ranging from the purchase of property from the Penn Central Railroad to the acquisition of a 75-acre parcel with $1.5 million from the Bureau of Outdoor Recreation. The park has a boat-launching site, picnic areas and concert space looking out toward Peekskill Bay, Thunderbird Mountain, Bear Mountain and Harriman State Park, a view Mr. Seymour called ''one of the most beautiful on the East Coast.''
The city recently completed an $86,000 waterfront master plan with the help of Sasaki Associates of Watertown, Mass., internationally known planner, which establishes guidelines protecting open space and sets architectural standards and height and density limitations.
Six weeks ago, Peekskill got a $750,000 grant from the state's Environmental Quality Bond Act appropriation to acquire easements and to develop linear parks in the hills overlooking the city that have majestic views of the Hudson. ''We are literally bringing waterfront development to a new level,'' Mr. Seymour said.
He said preserving the Peekskill waterfront provided ''a unique opportunity to enhance the desirability of our community.''
''It makes people want to come and live and work here,'' Mr. Seymour added. ''Our waterfront is the future of this city, an asset that can be a catalytic opportunity for growth in other areas of Peekskill.''
Greenway hearings will be held in Nyack on June 27 and in Yonkers on Aug. l6. Copies of the study are avialable from the Greenway Council office in Albany and the telephone number is (518) 426-0667.
