PUB-DATE: May 13, 1990,

SECTION: Section 10; Page 1, Column 2; Real Estate Desk

LENGTH: 2728 words

HEADLINE: Prying Out the Secrets of Co-op Sales

BYLINE: By THOMAS J. LUECK

 BODY:
WHO really knows what a New York City cooperative apartment is worth?
''If you hunt around you find these things out,'' said Richard R. Pergolis, president of the Greater New York Chapter of the American Society of Real Estate Appraisers. ''But it would sure make life easier if we had a central body of information on sales.''
The difficulty stems from one of the many idiosyncracies of the co-op market: Precise, reliable information on recent selling prices and the volume of sales is not available at City Hall, the Register of Deeds or any other official source.
Lenders, appraisers, economists, buyers and sellers found the lack of information easier to accept during the city's housing boom of the mid-80's, when the only real question was how fast prices were rising. But with the market now in a slump, some maintain that better information on sales is becoming critical. 
''One of the things that makes markets efficient is a broad range of information, and you just don't have it in New York City,'' said Eugene Sherman, chief economist of the Federal Home Loan Bank of New York.
Sales information is scarce because owning a co-op is different from owning any other form of residential real estate, at least in the eyes of the law. Someone who buys a house or a condominium receives a deed and the transfer of the property is recorded with government authorities. In almost all cases, information on the transfer, including the selling price, is available to anyone who bothers to look it up.
By contrast, someone buying a co-op gets shares in the corporation that owns the building and a proprietary lease entitling him to live in the apartment. That is regarded as a transfer of personal property and there is no deed to record. And though the selling price must be reported to the state and city governments for tax purposes, stringent rules of confidentiality make it impossible for the public to get that information.
Thus, most New Yorkers in the market for a co-op must judge value, not always reliably, on what they can learn from brokers or from those who already live in co-ops, people who sometimes, but not always, know recent selling prices.
Those hoping for help from the news media get a broader picture of the market, but that picture is limited by the narrow range of reliable data available even to the brokers and lenders who are the only sources of information about sales. Most brokers have knowledge only of the sales they arrange and of a limited number more they learn of through co-broking and informal information sharing.
THE larger brokerages have been producing surveys intended to track sales and price trends. But these industry analyses, distributed widely among real estate professionals and to the media, provide little more than snapshots of the market.
They rely on samplings of recent sales that are too small to reflect the entire market or use theoretical calculations to estimate other selling prices. The surveys, moreover, focus on expensive properties in Manhattan and virtually ignore sales in the city's four other boroughs.
''Everywhere in the nation besides New York, real estate sales are reported and available to the public,'' said Clark Halstead, president of Halstead Properties, one of the Manhattan brokerages that have been trying to track the co-op market. Despite the efforts of his and other concerns, he said, ''we really know nothing.''
Recent changes in tax policies might have opened the door to more information. Since last July, the state and the city have been assessing a real property transfer tax - previously assessed only on houses, condominiums and commercial property - on co-op sales. Sellers of co-ops must now report precisely how much they have received for their homes.
But little of the information is likely to be released. The State Department of Taxation and Finance said it planned within the next six months to begin reporting ''aggregated'' information on co-ops, including the number and dollar volume of sales for each county. But it said it would not disclose specific information on the sale of individual apartments because of tax-law provisions covering the secrecy of individual tax returns.
The city's Department of Finance said it, too, was considering some kind of aggregated analysis, based on receipts from the co-op transfer taxes. Kathleen Grimm, the First Deputy Finance Commissioner, said the analysis might be started as part of a five-year plan to upgrade the department's computerized record keeping.
But the city is clearly determined not to reveal individual selling prices. Last year, faced with a lawsuit aimed at opening up its books on co-op sales, the Koch administration sought and received from Albany a new law that strengthens the city's administrative code and protects information on individual co-op sales, even if formal requests for access are filed under the Freedom of Information Act.
Mrs. Grimm said the city regarded information derived from the transfer tax on co-op sales as confidential in the same way it regards income-tax returns.
''At this point the law is clear,'' she said. ''The intent of the city is to protect the traditional secrecy of taxpayers.''
Still, the secrecy sets New York City - the only major metropolitan center where co-ops are a significant part of the market - apart from the rest of the nation. From the eastern tip of Long Island to the western shores of Hawaii, almost every sale of a residential property is reported to public agencies and is almost always available for scrutiny.
Indeed, most buyers and sellers elsewhere in the nation find it easy to get information on recent sales of houses and condominiums in their communities. They can go to their town halls and do the research themselves or they can get the data from brokers.
The prices paid for comparable properties in recent sales are reliable guides to value. Sales of ''comparables'' are the standard used by professional appraisers and by lenders when they decide how large a mortgage to offer a home buyer.
''New York City is manic,'' said John Striker, publisher of the New York Co-op & Condo Insider, a monthly publication, and its parent company, Brownstone Publishers. ''It makes it virtually impossible to get access to information that is vital to a free market.''
It was Mr. Striker's company that sued in an attempt to have co-op sales information made available by the city. Even without the access he hoped to get, his publication reports selling prices on more than 100 apartments each month with information it gets from brokers and appraisers.
The New York Times also publishes selling prices of co-ops each week in the Residential Resales column of the Sunday real estate section. The newspaper gets its information from brokerages and management companies that are willing to share their knowledge of closing prices.
Even real estate professionals say finding comparative sales figures on co-ops apartments can be difficult.
The New York City Real Estate Board, a trade group, said that in the late 80's it considered starting a broad analysis of co-op sales based on the activity of its member brokerage firms, including most of the brokers in the city.
But, it said, large firms with enough sales volume to track meaningful trends declined to share their information with smaller competitors, and the city-wide analysis has not been attempted.
''You have to do a lot of digging,'' said Anthony Lama, a New York City appraiser. Like others in the profession, he is often employed by banks to make sure their loans do not exceed the value of the homes their borrowers want to buy.
Usually, Mr. Lama said, co-op boards or their managing agents will volunteer information to appraisers, although they are under no obligation to do so. Appraisers also keep their own detailed records on sales and sometimes share them with others in the profession, he said.
Nonetheless, Mr. Lama said the relative scarcity of information on co-ops in New York City is a growing topic of debate, particularly because of the problems faced by lenders who have made bad real estate loans in the Southwest, some parts of New England and elsewhere.
''With all the hullaballoo, one of the problems at banks with bad real estate loans has been a failure to ascertain real value,'' he said, adding that there is a potential for problems among cooperative purchasers in New York City ''because there is no public record.''
The real estate industry surveys, conducted by brokerage and cooperative management concerns, try to dissect the market in many ways. Mr. Halstead reports average asking prices of apartments, but gives no indication if the apartments have sold and how much was received.
ANOTHER survey, begun this year by L. B. Kaye Associates, a residential brokerage in Manhattan, reports the average prices paid for co-ops in the first quarter of the year, but the analysis covered only 221 sales, a tiny sampling of the total sales in the city.
''It is an inexact science,'' said Marilyn Kaye, the firm's president.
A broader survey of selling prices had been conducted by Douglas Elliman, a large management and brokerage firm that until mid-1989 had been reporting prices and the number of sales in 200 buildings that it managed. The survey has not been released for more than six months.
However, Allan Rogers, managing director of Douglas Elliman, said the firm was revising its survey techniques and would begin reporting its findings on a regular basis again by this summer.
The most widely reported survey, by the Corcoran Group, tries to track many more transactions. The brokerage said it analyzed 2,463 co-op sales completed in 1989 and estimated that the average selling price per room, $108,040, had declined 9.2 percent.
''I include every listing I can get in my greedy little hands,'' said Barbara Corcoran, the firm's president, who said she included information on every apartment offered by her own firm, either exclusively or through co-brokerage agreements with others, and had her staff check frequently over the phone and through personal contacts what apartments sold for even if the deals were struck by other brokerage houses.
One limitation of the surveys is that they tend to focus on the upper end of the market. While part of Mr. Halstead's analysis tracks the asking prices for ''silk stocking'' apartments along Park and Fifth Avenues and at other prestigious locations - priced at over $800,000 for two bedrooms - comparable surveys are not available for Brooklyn, Queens or elsewhere in the city where prices are much lower.
Another problem is that even the industry professionals have limited access to information.
''It is a pain in the neck,'' complained Ms. Corcoran, who said she would much prefer ''open access'' to co-op sales information. Mr. Halstead said he warns every customer who reads his survey: ''Thou shalt not price an apartment based on the information contained within.''
To be sure, a scarcity of sales information is only one of the vagaries of the cooperative market, in which some fortunate buyers have been blessed by almost instantaneous wealth by paying cut-rate ''insider'' prices for their rented apartments in conversions. In established co-ops, the bids of buyers have been rejected simply because the boards of directors did not approve of their style of living or found their pockets not deep enough.
While some real estate professionals believe the lack of public disclosure on sales is a troublesome restraint on the market, others say it has not created major problems in the past and is not likely to in the future.
''I don't think we have a problem in terms of values not being understood by appraisers,'' said Steve Rotella, a senior vice president for Chemical Bank. ''I don't recall a situation where we have not been able to obtain information on comparable sales.''
Like most other New York City lenders, Chemical commissions outside appraisers to evaluate co-op apartments before it approves loan applications. In most cases, he said, the appraisers can find recent selling prices by asking co-op management firms, boards of buildings or others in the industry, and their appraisals are submitted to an internal review by a committee of Chemical loan officers.
Others say the difficulty of getting information is not likely to lead the New York City cooperative market into the kind of boom-and-bust cycle that has occurred in Texas and some other parts of the Southwest.
''YOU might have perfectly solid information on recent sales, but that is not much help if those recent sales went for wildly inflated prices,'' said Mr. Sherman, the economist at the Federal Home Loan Bank. He added that the deep real estate depression in the Southwest resulted from much more fundamental economic problems - like the thousands of jobs that were lost when oil prices collapsed - that had nothing to do with public access to government sales records.
Nonetheless, Mr. Sherman said, ''even if recent sales were inflated, it is better to know what they were than rely on somebody's guess.''
Brokers, appraisers and others in the New York City real estate industry say the boards of many cooperative buildings have grown less insistent in recent years about keeping their sales information private. Most are willing to help appraisers and lenders, they say, but still refuse to volunteer information on recent sales directly to prospective buyers.
Indeed, without public disclosure by the government, the flow of information on co-op sales is now controlled almost entirely by individual apartment owners and their boards. In all co-ops, board members are informed of selling prices. In most, but not all buildings, other shareholders are told as well.
Lawyers say one open legal question is whether shareholders in a cooperative are entitled to specific selling prices if they demand the information from their boards.
''A proprietary lease says the shareholder is entitled to inspect the books and records of the co-op, but what that means is open to interpretation,'' said Marc Luxemburg, a Manhattan attorney who is president if the Council of New York Cooperatives.
Although the matter has not been tested in court, he said that most shareholders are informed of selling prices directly by their boards or through word of mouth from other shareholders.
A result is a grapevine that sometimes extends to outsiders. Someone with a friend in a co-op building has a better chance of finding out about recent selling prices in the building than someone without such a source.
''My guess is that all kinds of people know what apartments here have gone for,'' said Wayde Harrison, president of the board of a co-op with 40 apartments on Pierrepont Street in Brooklyn Heights. Nonetheless, he added, his board's official policy is not to disclose the information to prospective buyers until after they have signed a sales contract.
At the Carlton House, a cooperative with 144 apartments in Jackson Heights, Queens, Beverly O'Reilly, president of the co-op board, said she would give a ''ball park figure'' to brokers or prospective buyers inquiring about what apartments had sold for in the past. ''Most of our brokers know this building and have a pretty good idea anyway,'' she added.
But information is often harder to come by in Manhattan, particularly at buildings with the most expensive apartments.
''I just don't see the need for public disclosure, and I think the government should be less intrusive into the affairs of co-ops, not more so,'' said Marsha Hunter, president of the board and managing agent at 123 West 74th Street, a building with 42 apartments.
Like some other Manhattan co-ops, the one managed by Mrs. Hunter does not reveal the exact selling prices of apartments even to others who live in the same building. Instead, she said, twice each year she circulates information on recent selling prices broken down on a price-per-share basis without specifying sellers or apartment numbers.
And, as is common among co-op boards in Manhattan, the one at 123 West 74th Street is not forthcoming when a prospective buyer seeks information on what the apartment he wants, or one similar to it, has sold for in the past.
''This information is between you and the board,'' Mrs. Hunter said.

LENGTH: 1368 words

HEADLINE: Focus: The I-5 Corridor;
A Lively New Washington Growth Area

BYLINE: By HARRIET KING

 BODY:
ONLY three years ago, the suburban community of Everett, Wash., 30 miles north of Seattle, was hobbled by a recession that enveloped the Pacific Northwest. Now commercial activity there is among the strongest in the country, and growth, accompanied by residential and retail construction, is expected to continue until well into the mid-90's.
Evidence of this can be found in the expansion taking place in a wide swath along the Interstate 5 corridor stretching south for 250 miles from Everett to Vancouver near the Oregon border and north about 80 miles to the Canadian border. Among the elements in that expansion are the following:
* The Boeing Company, which makes 747 and 767 jetliners in Everett, recently acquired 300 adjacent acres to expand by four million square feet at a cost of up to $1.5 billion over the next few years. This is attracting aircraft parts suppliers and high-tech and related companies.
* In March, the CornerstoneColumbia Development Company of Seattle, a subsidiary of the Weyerhaeuser Corporation, the timber company, bought 300 acres of forest in Everett. The previous owner, Washington Services of Seattle, had put in roads and underground utilities for an industrial park to be called Seaway Center. 
Cornerstone plans a campus-like industrial park, with 200,000 square feet of warehouse and distribution space to be built this summer and 100,000 square feet more each year for the next 8 to 10 years.
* With Seatac - the Seattle-Tacoma Airport - nearing capacity, Paine Field airport here is expected to become a major hub for the distribution of commercial goods.
If the Navy carries out its plans to make Everett the home port for the nuclear aircraft carrier Nimitz, it could affect expansion plans, which are still nebulous.
Despite the growth, economic problems persist in many rural counties that depend on the forest-products industry, which underwent a shakeout in the early 80's. Moreover, efforts to save the threatened spotted owl and the remnants of once-extensive old-growth forest in which it lives may ban logging in a million acres of that forest.
IN an effort to diversify or lure new commercial business, 22 of the hardest hit rural counties are offering a deferral of an 8 percent sales tax on construction materials as an incentive. The tax is a state levy, but under the state's sales-tax-deferral program counties can defer payment of the sales tax on construction materials for new plants for three years and then extend payment of that tax for five more years.
''The Boeing Company to some extent drives the economy,'' said Richard Bristow, executive director in Seattle for the Associated General Contractors of America. Boeing has an $84 billion order backlog for 1,700 jetliners that are produced mostly here.
Robert MacMillan, Cornerstone's vice president of development, said the company plans to invest about $100 million a year for the next eight years in the Seaway Center area, two miles west of I-5. It intends, he said, to focus on companies seeking build-to-suit facilities and corporate users looking for a campuslike setting on land worth about $5 a square foot.
It will be leased at 31 cents a square foot a month, the going rate in the area.
Seaway Center has been developed so far as a ''smart park'' with sophisticated telecommunications services already in place. Roads have been built to accommodate 29,000 vehicle trips a day and the developer plans to add nature trails, a day-care center, retail and other support services.
A decade ago, construction began about five miles south of here on Harbour Pointe, a 2,000-acre planned housing development that was ultimately to have 4,300 units of single-family detached houses, town houses and apartments. But the project lanquished, with only 400 dwellings built by the time it was bought in January 1989 from BCE Development Corporation of Vancouver, B.C., by Harbour Pointe Limited Partnership. Dennis Vrabek of Bellevue, Wash., and Roger Belanich of Seattle are the general partners of Harbour Pointe and Weyerhaeuser Venture Company is the limited partner.
With Everett now a ''hot spot,'' Mr. Vrabek said, the complex has 1,736 units built or being built, with completion of the whole project expected in five to seven years.
Three years ago, Honeywell Marine Systems Division moved into a 330,000-square-foot building in a 400-acre business park at Harbour Pointe. It was the first tenant and the new developer has begun preparing the partly forested site.
In Bellingham, about 20 miles from the Canadian border, there is so much commercial growth - total building permits last year were valued at $90 million, compared with $30 million in 1985, said Mr. Bristow of the contractors' association, that his group is considering opening an office there. Much of the growth, he said, caters to British Columbians who swarm down I-5 to shop.
The Canadian-American free trade agreement also is attracting so many Canadian companies and developers to border counties - Whatcom and Skagit - that some people are starting to call the I-5 strip between Everett and Canada the Can/Am Corridor. While retail sales statewide grew only 9 percent last year, according to William Geyer, Bellingham's director of planning and economic development, they grew 23 percent in Whatcom County, with 45 to 50 percent of the growth attributable to Canadians, compared with 23 percent five years ago.
''Canadians come down here wearing shorts and a tee shirt and head back wearing three sweaters, coat and hat,'' he said.
In Clark County, the southernmost Washington county on I-5, the Columbia River towns of Vancouver, Camus and Washougal also are attracting development. Employment at the end of 1989 was 112,800, a 27 percent increase over 1984, and several hundred more jobs a year for the next 10 years are expected to develop.
In late March, Sharp Microelectronics Corporation opened a $33 million, 102,000-square foot integrated-circuit plant on Prune Hill in Vancouver, Wash., and SEH America, which makes integrated-circuit wafers, is adding 120,000 square feet to its existing 25,000-square-foot fabrication there.
Robert Levin, executive director of the Columbia River Economic Development Council, said Clark County is attracting commercial activity because of I-5, major ports and the promximity of Portland International Airport, 10 minutes south of Vancouver.
About 10,000 of the 113,000 people in Clark County's labor pool commute daily from Oregon and county officials compete head to head with Oregon in attempts to lure plants. Even so the county's economy is so closely linked with Portland's that many residents align themselves more closely in spirit to Oregon than to Washington.
Yet neighboring counties that depend on forestry-product industries are not sharing the growth. Skamania County, adjacent to Clark, has been depressed because of lumber mill closings since the early 80's and unemployment there is 21.5 percent, the highest in the state.
But Harry Berryman, the state's director of business expansion, said, without further elaboration, that a forestry products company might locate in Skamania County, attacted by the sale-tax deferral, and become a major employer.
Mr Levin, too, is encouraged by the willingness of companies to locate in rural areas because they can be connected to larger cities electronically. He said this means some out-of-the-mainstream communites will be able to attract commercial business that just a few years earlier might have opted for an urban setting.
The Port of Port Angeles, a special-purpose district authorized by the state and created by voters in Clallam County, near the Washington coast, for example, five years ago attracted the Rogerson Hiller Corporation, which makes aircraft components. The city and the Clallam County Economic Development Counciul, a private nonprofit corporation, which Mr. Levin headed at the time, got the company to lease 140,00 square feet in four buildings on a lease-purchase agreement at 15 cnets a square foot a month. The buildings were constructed by the port and, three years ago the company exercised its option to buy them for $2.5 million.

HEADLINE: Focus: The I-5 Corridor;
A Lively New Washington Growth Area

BYLINE: By HARRIET KING

 BODY:
ONLY three years ago, the suburban community of Everett, Wash., 30 miles north of Seattle, was hobbled by a recession that enveloped the Pacific Northwest. Now commercial activity there is among the strongest in the country, and growth, accompanied by residential and retail construction, is expected to continue until well into the mid-90's.
Evidence of this can be found in the expansion taking place in a wide swath along the Interstate 5 corridor stretching south for 250 miles from Everett to Vancouver near the Oregon border and north about 80 miles to the Canadian border. Among the elements in that expansion are the following:
* The Boeing Company, which makes 747 and 767 jetliners in Everett, recently acquired 300 adjacent acres to expand by four million square feet at a cost of up to $1.5 billion over the next few years. This is attracting aircraft parts suppliers and high-tech and related companies.
* In March, the CornerstoneColumbia Development Company of Seattle, a subsidiary of the Weyerhaeuser Corporation, the timber company, bought 300 acres of forest in Everett. The previous owner, Washington Services of Seattle, had put in roads and underground utilities for an industrial park to be called Seaway Center. 
Cornerstone plans a campus-like industrial park, with 200,000 square feet of warehouse and distribution space to be built this summer and 100,000 square feet more each year for the next 8 to 10 years.
* With Seatac - the Seattle-Tacoma Airport - nearing capacity, Paine Field airport here is expected to become a major hub for the distribution of commercial goods.
If the Navy carries out its plans to make Everett the home port for the nuclear aircraft carrier Nimitz, it could affect expansion plans, which are still nebulous.
Despite the growth, economic problems persist in many rural counties that depend on the forest-products industry, which underwent a shakeout in the early 80's. Moreover, efforts to save the threatened spotted owl and the remnants of once-extensive old-growth forest in which it lives may ban logging in a million acres of that forest.
IN an effort to diversify or lure new commercial business, 22 of the hardest hit rural counties are offering a deferral of an 8 percent sales tax on construction materials as an incentive. The tax is a state levy, but under the state's sales-tax-deferral program counties can defer payment of the sales tax on construction materials for new plants for three years and then extend payment of that tax for five more years.
''The Boeing Company to some extent drives the economy,'' said Richard Bristow, executive director in Seattle for the Associated General Contractors of America. Boeing has an $84 billion order backlog for 1,700 jetliners that are produced mostly here.
Robert MacMillan, Cornerstone's vice president of development, said the company plans to invest about $100 million a year for the next eight years in the Seaway Center area, two miles west of I-5. It intends, he said, to focus on companies seeking build-to-suit facilities and corporate users looking for a campuslike setting on land worth about $5 a square foot.
It will be leased at 31 cents a square foot a month, the going rate in the area.
Seaway Center has been developed so far as a ''smart park'' with sophisticated telecommunications services already in place. Roads have been built to accommodate 29,000 vehicle trips a day and the developer plans to add nature trails, a day-care center, retail and other support services.
A decade ago, construction began about five miles south of here on Harbour Pointe, a 2,000-acre planned housing development that was ultimately to have 4,300 units of single-family detached houses, town houses and apartments. But the project lanquished, with only 400 dwellings built by the time it was bought in January 1989 from BCE Development Corporation of Vancouver, B.C., by Harbour Pointe Limited Partnership. Dennis Vrabek of Bellevue, Wash., and Roger Belanich of Seattle are the general partners of Harbour Pointe and Weyerhaeuser Venture Company is the limited partner.
With Everett now a ''hot spot,'' Mr. Vrabek said, the complex has 1,736 units built or being built, with completion of the whole project expected in five to seven years.
Three years ago, Honeywell Marine Systems Division moved into a 330,000-square-foot building in a 400-acre business park at Harbour Pointe. It was the first tenant and the new developer has begun preparing the partly forested site.
In Bellingham, about 20 miles from the Canadian border, there is so much commercial growth - total building permits last year were valued at $90 million, compared with $30 million in 1985, said Mr. Bristow of the contractors' association, that his group is considering opening an office there. Much of the growth, he said, caters to British Columbians who swarm down I-5 to shop.
The Canadian-American free trade agreement also is attracting so many Canadian companies and developers to border counties - Whatcom and Skagit - that some people are starting to call the I-5 strip between Everett and Canada the Can/Am Corridor. While retail sales statewide grew only 9 percent last year, according to William Geyer, Bellingham's director of planning and economic development, they grew 23 percent in Whatcom County, with 45 to 50 percent of the growth attributable to Canadians, compared with 23 percent five years ago.
''Canadians come down here wearing shorts and a tee shirt and head back wearing three sweaters, coat and hat,'' he said.
In Clark County, the southernmost Washington county on I-5, the Columbia River towns of Vancouver, Camus and Washougal also are attracting development. Employment at the end of 1989 was 112,800, a 27 percent increase over 1984, and several hundred more jobs a year for the next 10 years are expected to develop.
In late March, Sharp Microelectronics Corporation opened a $33 million, 102,000-square foot integrated-circuit plant on Prune Hill in Vancouver, Wash., and SEH America, which makes integrated-circuit wafers, is adding 120,000 square feet to its existing 25,000-square-foot fabrication there.
Robert Levin, executive director of the Columbia River Economic Development Council, said Clark County is attracting commercial activity because of I-5, major ports and the promximity of Portland International Airport, 10 minutes south of Vancouver.
About 10,000 of the 113,000 people in Clark County's labor pool commute daily from Oregon and county officials compete head to head with Oregon in attempts to lure plants. Even so the county's economy is so closely linked with Portland's that many residents align themselves more closely in spirit to Oregon than to Washington.
Yet neighboring counties that depend on forestry-product industries are not sharing the growth. Skamania County, adjacent to Clark, has been depressed because of lumber mill closings since the early 80's and unemployment there is 21.5 percent, the highest in the state.
But Harry Berryman, the state's director of business expansion, said, without further elaboration, that a forestry products company might locate in Skamania County, attacted by the sale-tax deferral, and become a major employer.
Mr Levin, too, is encouraged by the willingness of companies to locate in rural areas because they can be connected to larger cities electronically. He said this means some out-of-the-mainstream communites will be able to attract commercial business that just a few years earlier might have opted for an urban setting.
The Port of Port Angeles, a special-purpose district authorized by the state and created by voters in Clallam County, near the Washington coast, for example, five years ago attracted the Rogerson Hiller Corporation, which makes aircraft components. The city and the Clallam County Economic Development Counciul, a private nonprofit corporation, which Mr. Levin headed at the time, got the company to lease 140,00 square feet in four buildings on a lease-purchase agreement at 15 cnets a square foot a month. The buildings were constructed by the port and, three years ago the company exercised its option to buy them for $2.5 million.

PUB-DATE: May 13, 1990,

SECTION: Section 6; Page 32, Column 1; Magazine Desk

LENGTH: 4334 words

HEADLINE: WHY WE DON'T KNOW WHAT WE DON'T KNOW JUST ASK E.D. HIRSCH

BYLINE: By Christopher Hitchens: Christopher Hitchens is a columnist for Harper's Magazine and The Nation. His new book, ''Blood, Class and Nostalgia: Anglo-American Ironies,'' will be published next month by Farrar, Straus & Giroux.

 BODY:
CHARLOTTESVILLE, VA., IS AN IDEAL SITE FORJU the study of American rhythms and continuities. On the famous lawn of the University of Virginia is the cloister where Edgar Allan Poe had his quarters - commemorated today by a plaque reading domus parva magni poetae. On a hill 10 miles away is Monticello, the exquisite home that Thomas Jefferson built for himself, with its slave quarters still visible (even more limited in space and comfort than Poe's), and another touching memorial, a stone obelisk at Jefferson's grave recalling his role as author of the Declaration of Independence and the Virginia Statute on Religious Liberty, and as founder of the university. It modestly and perhaps ironically omits his Presidency from the list of accomplishments. 
Yet according to a nationwide survey, mandated by Congress and carried out in 1988 by the National Assessment of Educational Progress, the chances of a 17-year-old American being able to say anything meaningful about Thomas Jefferson are disconcertingly slight. The chances of the same student knowing anything significant about Poe, or slavery, or of being able to translate the most elementary Latin (''a small home for a great poet''), or even being able to define the word ''ironic'' are slighter still. But, from this Virginian retreat, a self-proclaimed crusade against noneducation is getting under way. In a ridiculous half-timbered pseudo-English building in Charlottesville, the Cultural Literacy Foundation, and its president, E. D. Hirsch Jr., monitor the spread of ignorance and illiteracy in the United States and make proposals for remedying it.
Hirsch, the Linden Kent Professor of English at the University of Virginia, has achieved best-sellerdom with his books ''Cultural Literacy: What Every American Needs to Know'' and ''The Dictionary of Cultural Literacy'' and is on his way to even greater sales with ''A First Dictionary of Cultural Literacy.'' All three have been praised and mocked for trying to summarize essential knowledge in indexes or digests that run from Aaron, Henry, through agribusiness, Clemens, Samuel L., and homeostasis all the way through to noblesse oblige, yuppies and Zapata. Yet Hirsch, who has just completed a cross-country book tour, shrugs off those who laugh at his pedagogic efforts. ''At least,'' he says, ''we are trying to establish a core curriculum.'' ''Core curriculum'' is the key phrase at the foundation -the goal toward which everything is pointed. Unless and until American schools establish a common body of shared and imbibed knowledge, Hirsch argues, there will continue to be chaos and decline in the classroom. And not just in the classroom but further up. A survey by the National Endowment for the Humanities last year found that more than half of the college seniors taking a history and literature test were flunking it in absurd ways. Sixty-one percent did not know where ''the shot heard round the world'' was fired; nearly half didn't know who wrote ''Moby-Dick,'' and nearly 80 percent did not know what the Emancipation Proclamation did.
While at the foundation, I took Hirsch's test for cultural literacy, or a pilot version of it mailed out to a random sample of 500 American attorneys. They were chosen as a profession (Continued on Page 59) for their ostensibly broad academic background - undergraduate plus graduate education - and asked to answer questions like these:
The principal character in Arthur Miller's play ''Death of a Salesman'' is:
 
a) Willy Loman
 
b) Stanley Spencer
 
c) John Smith
 
d) Babbitt
 
e) Tom Joad
A solid-state electronic device does not use:
 
a) insulators
 
b) transistors
 
c) vacuum tubes
 
d) integrated circuits
 
e) semiconductors Very few of the questions were more taxing than the two above - one involved knowing that Nixon rather than Hoover, Carter, Roosevelt or Truman had resigned over Watergate; another that Anne Boleyn, and not Queen Victoria, had been beheaded by Henry VIII - and the average score was 91 to 92 percent. The lawyers were trusted not to cheat in the privacy of their own offices. You will be reassured to learn that your correspondent achieved 98.2 percent when doing the test under supervision, getting the solid-state question wrong and repeating a nagging boyhood blunder about the gerund.
But what could one say of a person who scored low on such a test? How many allusions in daily reading and discourse would he be bound to miss?
Hirsch remembers the day in 1978 when, as he puts it, ''my life changed.'' He and some colleagues had been running a test on readability in prose. They were trying to see in what ways clarity of style influenced comprehension. The correlation between the two seemed simple enough, and Hirsch was encouraged to find that ''students showed a definite sensitivity to the stylistic superiority of one version over another.''
But the test that had been applied to the young people at the university hit a snag when it was applied, for comparative purposes, to the students of J. Sargent Reynolds Community College in Richmond. The decoding skills of these poor and minority students were just as developed as those of their counterparts in the sylvan surround of Charlottesville. But they broke down sooner; in fact they began to break down whenever background knowledge was involved.
The University of Virginia students had shown a decline in comprehension when faced with a passage about Hegel's ''Metaphysics.'' The community college students had comparable difficulty when reading an account of Lee's surrender to Grant at Appomattox. The reason? Most of them had not heard of Lee, didn't know who Grant was, were seeing the name Appomattox for the first time. And these students were Virginians.
That did it for Hirsch. He wanted to know who had let these students down, and how, and why. From being a literary critic and analyst - his ''Philosophy of Composition'' and ''Validity in Interpretation'' are still much discussed among English scholars - he became a committed educational reformer. He delivered a paper at the Modern Language Association in 1981, suggesting that there was a strong connection between cultural illiteracy and the other kind. After an expanded version of the paper, entitled ''Cultural Literacy,'' appeared in the spring 1983 issue of The American Scholar, Hirsch was approached by the Exxon Education Foundation, which urged him to undertake more systematic research and provided some of the means for it. Other educationists, notably Diane Ravitch at Columbia University, got in touch. A team was set up to try to compile the necessary minimum of American general knowledge. (The team's recommendations appear as an appendix to the book.) In 1986, Hirsch founded the Cultural Literacy Foundation, with the purpose of developing a core curriculum and pilot programs for teaching it in the elementary schools. Originally the foundation received grants from Exxon and the National Endowment for the Humanities; today, Hirsch himself provides most of the financing. He and two part-time workers send out information on the core curriculum to the foundation's 2,500 or so members and hold seminars and workshops on how to get ''shared content'' into schools.
PERHAPS MOST IMPORTANT to Hirsch's endeavors, in the climate of opinion then being generated by the Reagan Administration, talk of ''standards'' was all the rage. When William Bennett became Secretary of Education, he was able to make names like E. D. Hirsch and Allan Bloom part of the unofficial national curriculum.
Actually, the propaganda connection made between his own work and Allan Bloom's forthrightly elitist and conservative ''The Closing of the American Mind'' is a source of unease to Hirsch. Politically liberal, he grew up in Marvell, Ark., where his father ran Hirsch's General Store and then flourished in the cotton business in Memphis, where Eric Donald was born in 1928. At the age of 11, he read Gunnar Myrdal's study of the pathology of racism, ''An American Dilemma'' (he attributes his precocity to the virtues of ''a traditional education'') and rebelled against the Southern ethos.
At Cornell University, where he decided forever against the cotton business, Hirsch led an eclectic life, discovered that he wasn't cut out to be a chemist, attended Nabokov's lectures on Russian literature and became hooked on English. Two years in the Navy punctuated his progress, via postgraduate study in Paris and Berlin, through teaching posts at Yale to the professorship at the University of Virginia, which came in 1966. By then he had published an award-winning study of William Blake.
Hirsch looks younger than his 61 years, with an open, rather smooth countenance and a ready, even smile. In conversation, he's committed to talking as if everything were plain and reasonable if not common-sensical; easy enough to resolve if only good will were brought to bear. He wears a pained expression when he discusses the frequent allegation that he's an elitist and a reactionary.
''Allan Bloom's original title was to be 'Souls Without Longing,' '' says Hirsch. ''He's concerned with the spiritual condition of undergraduates at elite universities. I'm interested in the social injustice further down. So I don't see why our books are reviewed together - we aren't part of the same temper of the times. The problem isn't in the colleges. It's in the very early grades that children are being let down.''
During dinner at his house, Hirsch elaborates his disagreements with Bloom and with the whole school of the political philosopher Leo Strauss that Bloom represents. He disagrees with Bloom philosophically for his exclusive stress on Plato and Aristotle (''I'm sure that if Plato hadn't been against music with a strong sexual beat, Bloom would have kept quiet about rock-and-roll''). He dislikes what he terms the antiscientism of the Bloomites (''If there isn't a fact-value distinction, then we are in deep, deep trouble''). And he is an egalitarian (''My proposals are antitracking, antidiscrimination. They are designed to rescue the poor and the underclass''). Most of all, he considers himself a disciple of the optimistic Enlightenment tradition. ''Bloom asked me to a conference in Paris, which was basically one five-star meal and one undemanding seminar every day for five days,'' he recalls. ''The subject was 'The Decline of the West'! I can't see why these guys love Heidegger and Nietzsche and all the enemies of the Enlightenment.''
Yet, in seeking to restore the teaching of fact and information in schools, Hirsch and his allies repeatedly come up against what might be called ''progressive'' impressions. The current educational consensus is deeply in debt to the ideas of Rousseau and Dewey - to the notion that a growing child must be taught self-confidence, ''skills'' and other interpretations of its own ''potential.'' Moreover, and perhaps more powerful because partly subliminal, somewhere in the back of the mind of many educated liberals is the following imperishable memory:
''Now, what I want is, Facts. Teach these boys and girls nothing but Facts. Facts alone are wanted in life. Plant nothing else, and root out everything else. You can only form the minds of reasoning animals upon Facts; nothing else will ever be of service to them.'' (Charles Dickens, ''Hard Times'') ''I recall positive orgies of dates, with the keener boys leaping up and down in their places in their eagerness to shout out the right answers, and at the same time not feeling the faintest interest in the meaning of the mysterious events they were naming.'' (George Orwell, ''Such, Such Were the Joys'')
DICKENS AND ORWELLJU have probably been more influential than Dewey or Rousseau in turning liberals against ''traditional values'' in education. And they make formidable adversaries. Hirsch concedes that there is force to the critique of rote learning and utilitarianism, but points out mildly that the liberal critics already know the facts they affect to despise, and must have learned them somehow. Don't they care that the poor students are so ignorant of what they take for granted?
Besides, he insists, ''Rousseau's theory is based on a tutorial system. But learning in our culture takes place in classrooms where you can't have a one-on-one tutorial. You have to build knowledge on what the children already know, which means that you must know what they know, and also that they must possess shared knowledge.''
In a now celebrated example of this approach, which led to a public exchange in The New York Review of Books with Herbert Kohl, champion of the ''progressive'' educational faction, Hirsch wrote: ''Consider now the primal scene of education in the modern elementary school. Let us assume that a teacher wishes to inform a class of some 20 pupils about the structure of atoms, and that she plans to base the day's instruction on an analogy with the solar system. She knows that the instruction will be effective only to the extent that all the students in the class already know about the solar system. A good teacher would probably try to find out. 'Now, class, how many of you know about the solar system?' Fifteen hands go up. Five stay down. What is a teacher to do in this typical circumstance in the contemporary American school?
''If he or she pauses to explain the solar system, a class period is lost, and 15 of the 20 students are bored and deprived of knowledge for that day. If the teacher plunges ahead with atomic structure, the hapless five - they are most likely to be poor or minority students - are bored, humiliated and deprived, because they cannot comprehend the teacher's explanation.''
Hirsch insisted that ''analogy forms part of the very texture of a teacher's discourse. Teachers refer constantly to concepts like Cinderella or the American Revolution in order to connect new pieces of information with things that are already familiar.'' Kohl ridiculed Hirsch's approach as formalism, proposing instead that the following method be employed:
''Ask one of the children to stand up, and then ask another to get up and walk around the first. Then have a third child walk around the first child, only in a larger orbit. Continue this with the whole class illustrating an orbiting structure. As a next step ask students to think of different natural phenomena that could be modeled by their little dance. Through questioning, discussion and, when necessary, the teacher providing information, the class would come to the notion that the solar system and the molecular system are similar orbiting structures.
''Someone might even note that some social systems have a central body and orbiting smaller bodies, and the teacher might bring up Le Roi Soleil and the analogy that title implies between Louis XIV and the solar system.''
Kohl, who wrote ''The Open Classroom'' in 1969, stressed the importance of disadvantaged students no less than Hirsch. He also proudly underlined the origins of his method in the work of John Dewey, Frances T. Parker and other proponents of ''experientially based education.'' Hirsch only just managed to be polite in his reply:
''Let's assume that using the analogy is an acceptable way to teach sixth graders who, at age 11 or so, are not ready to deal with quantum-theoretical conceptions. Let's also assume that Kohl is teaching the class beautifully, in exactly the way he imagines in his letter. Then, the class ends, and another class of sixth graders arrives to learn the same things from him. But the social background of the second group is very different from that of the first.
''These pupils show themselves to be resistant to Kohl's teaching strategy. They complain that moving about the room in orbits is 'too first-gradish'; they decline to get the larger point; they clown, and feel uneasy; they resent the whole exercise. . . . If Kohl wishes to suggest that successful classroom learning doesn't depend on students sharing extensive background knowledge, then, with regard to that particular issue, I have no hesitancy in saying he doesn't know what he's talking about.''
HIRSCH HAS PROBABLYJU made his own life harder, in this classic exchange with the Deweyites and in other jousts with ''progressives,'' by employing a language of rigorous practicality and utility. His general principle of learning ''could be described,'' he wrote, ''in an analogy with economics, as earning new wealth from old intellectual capital. A diligent first grader who starts off with a dollar's worth of intellectual capital will be able to put it to work to gain, say, 15 percent per year. But a child who starts out with a dime's worth will not only gain less new intellectual wealth in absolute terms, but will earn even that pittance at a lower annual rate, say 7 percent.''
Hirsch went on to speak of ''low educational productivity,'' saying that it now correlated with economic productivity much more closely than before. Much of this came in the context of his insistent pointing out that the United States is very low on international league tables of educational attainment, its 14-year-olds ranking, in the 1988 report of the International Association for the Evaluation of Educational Achievement, ''third to last out of 17 countries'' in science, beating only Hong Kong and the Philippines.
The ''fit'' between this kind of argument and the educational rhetoric of William Bennett has caused Hirsch's critics to accuse him of viewing education as a tool of socioeconomic engineering; a weapon in international competition overseas, and vocational, narrow training at home. ''He forgets,'' said Kohl, ''that there is more to learning in Germany and Japan than being able to recognize the kind of nationalistic cliches, names, dates, places, titles that characterize a good percentage of his list.''
Hirsch wears a look of bewilderment when this sort of attack is mounted. ''The United States is the only developed country that doesn't have a core curriculum,'' he says in the foundation's offices. ''My book is only a theory of the core curriculum - it's not the last word on what it should be. But why don't they want us to have one?''
His director at the Cultural Literacy Foundation, James D. Watkinson, breaks in at this point to say that under the headline of ''Things You Should Know,'' USA Today recently offered a sample from the index of ''Cultural Literacy.'' ''We said that by the end of sixth grade, kids should know the whereabouts on the map of Micronesia, Zimbabwe and Tel Aviv. They should recognize the terms Monroe Doctrine and underground railroad. They should know who Sojourner Truth, William the Conqueror, Mao Zedong, Louis XIV and Sitting Bull were.
''A woman who ran a radio show in New York called up and said she had never heard of Micronesia, or of Sojourner Truth. Well, the United States only happens to own Micronesia and to use it for nuclear tests.'' This doesn't quite seem the language of nationalist cliche.
Still, the shoals of race and gender are the ones that loom before Hirsch and threaten to crunch his frail bark. Members of the ''cultural left,'' as he calls it, are already suspicious of the existing Scholastic Aptitude Tests because they are said to be culturally biased. A national standard curriculum, they imply, would simply impose the dominant values upon women and minorities. This was argued very strongly by Robert Scholes, professor of humanities at Brown University, in the journal College English in 1988: ''For Hirsch, just knowing the names of the great books and authors will suffice. Both Hirsch and Bloom share, however, a nostalgia for a not very closely examined past in which things were better.'' The sociologist Stanley Aronowitz and the educationist Henry A. Giroux were even more withering, accusing Hirsch of arguing ''for a form of cultural uniformity'' and of having an insipid, one-dimensional view of history. ''Culture,'' they wrote, ''is about the production and legitimation of particular ways of life, and schools often transmit a culture that is specific to class, gender and race. Hirsch ends up with a view of literacy cleansed of its own complicity in furthering cultural practices and ideologies that reproduce the worst dimensions of schooling.''
Hirsch is impatient with such objections. ''Do you know the mural at City College in New York, which shows the immigrants being blessed by the Goddess of Education? Well, that's my ideal. Assimilation. That's how everyone else did it, and we know it works.'' He has doubts about the usefulness of the term ''cultural literacy,'' though he knows he's stuck with it by now. A synonym, he thinks, might be ''acculturation.''
But, I propose, isn't that exactly what his critics suspect him of wanting - the homogenization of America by means of safe, accepted standards? ''All education is going to acculturate anyway - even if only into a subculture,'' Hirsch responds. (For similar reasons, he is unconvinced by arguments against standard English or the canon as instruments of oppression.) ''If it's social change you want, then acculturate first, so that everyone can argue in the same language. The cultural left are willing, for the sake of an ideal or even of a theory that hasn't been fully worked out, to risk condemning a generation to ignorance and therefore to poverty.''
Hirsch sees an irony in the opposition of some minority critics of assimilation, ''who were themselves acculturated and who now want to remove the ladder on whose rungs they rose. I would like very much to get in touch with Jesse Jackson, who often sounds very good when he talks to kids in school, but I suspect that like some other black figures he wouldn't want to support me in public.''
HOW AND WHY DIDJU Hirsch, who had a perfectly agreeable career as a critic and teacher, and who by his own admission has no talent for politics, get involved in the debate on literacy and society in the first place? The incident at J. Sargent Reynolds Community College is anecdotally impressive, but did it occur to a mind that was already prepared for it? Are there any clues in his earlier work?
''Validity in Interpretation,'' published in 1967, is not an easy book, but it makes a fairly simple point. Written as a rebuttal to the deconstructionists, it asserted that language requires authorship. No matter how brilliantly it could be argued that textual meaning is independent of the author's control, it remains the case that the unaided text cannot generate its own meanings. You must posit a meaner who means; therefore motive and intention become important.
Rephrase this to say that in order to get meaning you need context, and there is a noticeable analogy between Hirsch's theory of the text and his views on tuition. Just as a reader, no matter how keen his analytic faculties, cannot divine the meaning of a text without understanding the author's intention and the work's place in a broader literary context, so students cannot hope to make sense of the material they are given in the classroom without a shared pool of basic knowledge.
Then there is the key word of ''Validity in Interpretation,'' which is hermeneutics - the interpretation of texts, whether scriptural or secular. It is, in Hirsch's view, the missing link in deconstructive criticism, because properly handled it supplies the connection between reference and meaning. There is a catch, however, in that the process requires an interpreter or mediator - a Hermes, messenger between the gods and man, who lent his name to the science of hermeneutics. In other words, someone has to be daring and presumptuous enough to put himself forward as an objective, disinterested interpreter - a creature whose existence deconstructionists would deny - and to submit his findings to the general consideration.
So, long before he took up ''cultural literacy'' as a cause, Hirsch had disclosed most of the ingredients and conceptions that now inform his public work. Perhaps most crucial was the hermeneutic concept of a mediator: someone who would propose himself as the taker of responsibility at a time when the main cultural tendency was to say that nothing was anybody's fault.
Despite the mockery and skepticism, Hirsch's steady pressure for a curriculum is producing gradual results. His promotional tour for the ''First Dictionary of Cultural Literacy'' has taken him to, among other places, the Miami Book Fair, where he addressed a meeting of high-school department heads. Out of this came a proposal from Paul Bell, superintendent of Dade County, to run a pilot program for a core curriculum for grades one to six based on Hirsch's teaching materials. An appearance on the Larry King radio show has brought sacks of mail to the Cultural Literacy Foundation. A conference on the core curriculum held in Charlottesville in March brought several dozen principals, teachers, board of education members and education professors.
How interesting are the politics of all this? In one sense, Hirsch is apolitical and cares only for quantifiable or at least testable standards. In another sense, he knows that such a proposition is naive because it challenges a politicized education system. In still another sense, he is the traditional liberal whose aspirations have lately become disconnected from practical politics altogether. ''In the 1984 Democratic campaign,'' he moaned to me at one point, ''the only instantly recognizable slogan was 'Where's the Beef?' In the Dukakis campaign, it was something about Joe Isuzu. What does it say that advertising gimmicks are the only memorable things these days?''
It doesn't say much for the common culture, perhaps. But it does say something about how a common culture is formed. And Hirsch has already made an impression by the same means as Joe Isuzu did: first by finding an unsatisfied want and second by being prepared to repeat himself.
