HEADLINE: Panama Needs Help, Now

BYLINE: By Sol M. Linowitz; Sol M. Linowitz, a lawyer, was a negotiator of the Panama Canal treaties during the Carter Administration.

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Nearly five months have gone by since we invaded Panama, toppled the regime, brought Gen. Manuel Antonio Noriega to the U.S. to stand trial and arranged for the swearing in of Guillermo Endara as President. The Panamanians applauded our intervention on their behalf and anticipated economic assistance.
President Endara and his administration are still, for the most part, waiting for Washington to deliver. Meanwhile, they face the impossible task of trying to establish a Government with requisite credibility and authority in a country in economic crisis that depends on U.S. military forces to keep order. 
Before the invasion last Dec. 20, Panama's economy had withered under two years of U.S. sanctions. National income had contracted by more than 30 percent, and more than 40 percent of the work force lacked steady jobs.
The invasion and the destructive rampage that followed delivered another devastating blow. Clearly, assistance for economic reconstruction was urgently required. President Endara was warning us when he said, ''People cannot eat democracy.''
In late January, the Bush Administration proposed a relatively modest aid package. It called for renewed access to U.S. trade credits and for investment guarantees - together worth about $500 million - as well as loans of $500 million more.
These loans would be used to help rebuild housing and rehabilitate business, to open lines of credit for private and public investment and to clear up interest arrears at the World Bank and International Monetary Fund, thereby allowing both institutions to restore their assistance programs.
So far, Washington has delivered only $42 million in emergency aid, as well as trade credits and investment guarantees that do not involve any current outlays.
The critical $500 million in loans -which has been cut to $420 million -remained bottled up for months while Congress and the White House haggled over the precise amount, the specific uses to which the aid was to be put and the source of the funds.
Now that Congress is finally on the verge of approving the assistance package, another obstacle has arisen. The Senate tacked an amendment onto the aid legislation that would allow the District of Columbia to use local tax revenues to finance some abortions. That amendment almost certainly invites a Presidential veto.
Instead of aid, Panama is getting a lesson in Washington politics. This performance can only fuel skepticism worldwide about the depth of Washington's vaunted support for democratic change.
How can other countries take our commitments seriously when we do not help a fledgling Government we ourselves put into office?
What does this say to the newly installed Government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro in Nicaragua, which also awaits U.S. support; to the many Latin American countries that, with our encouragement, struggle toward democracy -and of course to Eastern European nations that count on our help?

HEADLINE: Census Knocks, but Few Want to Answer

BYLINE: By MIREYA NAVARRO

 BODY:
It took Eddie Quiles exactly half an hour on a recent Saturday to knock on nine apartment doors in the South Bronx and compile one of the sorriest records in the annals of door-to-door canvassing - three households did not answer, four asked him to come back later and two told him to get lost.
That these were his neighbors apparently made no difference.
''I told one of you this morning 'No' and I'm telling you now, I won't answer it,'' one woman snapped at the 21-year-old Census Bureau worker.
Another census taker encountered a confused resident during her rounds among the cooperatives and luxury high-rises of the Upper East Side. ''I'm from the census,'' she announced. ''We don't want any,'' came the response. 
And in the Williamsburg section of Brooklyn, an elderly woman ushered Miguel Barreto, a census worker, into her apartment, but not before keeping him knocking for minutes.
''I almost didn't get up,'' she said. ''I thought it was the Jehovah's Witnesses.''
 
A Force of 200,000
So goes the day for the census counters, a force of more than 200,000 temporary workers who are combing apartment buildings and houses throughout New York City and nationwide to elicit information from households that failed to return questionnaires by last month's deadline.
The count is crucial for areas with low mail-back rates like New York City, not only in determining accurate population numbers but also influencing the local share of Federal aid and representation in state legislatures and Congress.
But despite its importance, the job is fraught with frustration and tedium, and a turnover rate of up to 100 percent. For each counter hired, the bureau keeps at least seven replacements ready to take over, recruited mostly from the neighborhoods where they are needed. This candidate pool stands at some 69,000 people in New York City, and about 1.4 million nationwide, bureau officials said.
The job pays $8 an hour in New York City, the highest rate in the country, and workers include professionals and the unemployed, students and homemakers, who say they do it for the money or out of a sense of civic duty. The workers must pass a basic reading and writing test, a background check by the Federal Bureau of Investigation and three days of training.
The work gives them a chance to meet new people, develop detective skills to track down the most elusive and to exercise, the census takers, known as enumerators, say. They say many residents have shown the fear, indifference, antagonism or ignorance about the census that presumably kept them from filling out the form on their own. They have also run into numerous people who insist they already mailed back the form.
''That's the second one. It's ridiculous,'' a tenant at the St. Mary's Park Houses in the Bronx told Clarence W. Rollocks, an enumerator, when he told her she had to respond again.
Mr. Rollocks, 31, a father of six children, who lived with his family in a city shelter for the homeless until recently, said he empathized.
 
Offered Coffee and Meals
But the census takers say they have found cooperation for the most part, and many report having been invited into homes and offered coffee, meals and, in at least one case, champagne. They say many residents explain that they never received the form, while others say they misplaced it, or were away or too busy to answer it.
''They're hospitable, especially if you walk in sweating,'' said Benjamin Robles, 41, a counter in Brooklyn.
The job is not for the weak, however. Many of the census workers agree that only the persistent, the resourceful and the thick-skinned are likely to make it.
In Houston, a female counter, Elizabeth Saragoza, was welcomed by a man who ''stood there totally nude.'' In New York City, 5,500 counters must negotiate access with doormen and concierges, win over the many who are fearful or suspicious of government and brave drug-infested neighborhoods.
 
Constant Paperwork
A day's work can bring slammed doors and racial slurs. Hired for up to 40 hours a week, many work longer as they keep going back for the missing at odd hours and deal with constant paperwork.
''A lot of people don't expect the job to be so hard,'' said Virginia Pei, a counter in the Chinatown section of Manhattan who said she felt like quitting on her second day.
Richard Bitzer, the Census Bureau's assistant chief for field operations, said that those who quit generally are displeased with some aspect of the work or find permanent or better jobs. He said that the bureau expects a turnover of 30 to 100 percent by the time the count ends in mid-June.
''The big cities are always the biggest challenge,'' Mr. Bitzer said. ''It's a little harder to get around Manhattan than suburban America. There are also more multi-story structures with security.''
 
Six Attempts Required
All workers carry a census briefcase, an identification tag, a register with a computer printout of addresses and blank census forms. They are required to make six attempts to reach residents at each address, three in person and three by telephone.
They are expected to complete about 10 forms a day, a production schedule that troubles New York City officials afraid of a gross undercount. They say it may be unrealistic and might prevent the workers from meeting the completion deadline.
''Theoretically they can cover it,'' said Tara Singh, a planner in Mayor David N. Dinkins's census-project office. ''Given the extremely heavy work, it's kind of doubtful.''
Since they only carry addresses, the workers often try to get names from a mailbox or a building superintendent, then try to conduct a telephone interview. As a last resort, they are to use a neighbor, a mail carrier or other knowledgeable source to find out vital information about occupants.
 
'Could I Send Her Up?'
But the job itself varies widely among regions, neighborhoods and even blocks.
On the Upper East Side, for instance, an enumerator waited in the lobby of a luxury high-rise one day last week as the concierge buzzed each unit to announce: ''There's a lady here from the Census Bureau. She'd like to speak with you. Could I send her up?''
The system was the product of delicate talks with the building's management. The census taker would not be provided the names of occupants, but the concierge would try to put her in touch with each apartment. The counter, an unemployed manufacturing executive in her 30's who asked not to be identified, said she had about 200 units to visit in the building and would likely be stationed in the lobby for weeks.
And in Chinatown, Ms. Pei found mostly walk-ups, and the only barrier between her and her objective was unwillingness to respond. She said she found many undocumented immigrants who were fearful, or elderly residents who did not want to be bothered.
 
Three Different Tongues
One day last week her assignment took her to six floors of apartments atop a restaurant. Finding her way to unmarked apartments by speaking three different tongues - Cantonese, Mandarin and Toysan - she was allowed into a four-room apartment thick with the smells of home cooking.
Six men lived there, but four were at work. The two who were present answered her questions but the men said they did not know much about their roommates. She would have to come back.
''You have to be like a hunting dog,'' she said.
Enumerators in New York City are also conducting ''sweeps'' in which groups of them visit public-housing projects to catch as many residents as possible at once and to keep each other safe in the roughest areas.
There have been only two assaults on enumerators reported nationwide, Mr. Bitzer said. A counter, 52, in Monticello, Miss., was shot in the face and chest through a window by a 71-year-old man who mistook him for teen-agers who had harassed him in previous weeks. Another census taker, in Alton, Ill., a 31-year-old woman, was bitten on the shoulder by a woman who mistook her for a fund-raiser.
Many workers say they have experienced verbal threats. As friendships develop among the workers, some male enumerators have taken time of their own to accompany their female counterparts. Sometimes police precincts are asked to patrol a building while enumerators count.
Elizabeth Losey, 28, a construction worker and a counter in the Bronx, also worked in the 1980 census. She always goes out with a partner.
''Back then people weren't scared to go out,'' she said of 10 years ago. ''Now people are more afraid to open their door. There was less crime back then. There were no drugs.''

HEADLINE: Shellfish Is Tiny, but Problems It Could Cause Are Huge

BYLINE: By HAROLD FABER

DATELINE: ALBANY, May 10

 BODY:
The zebra mussel, an aquatic invader from Europe, is rapidly advancing into New York State, threatening to become a major pest in the Hudson, Delaware and Susquehanna Rivers, marine biologists say.
It is moving into New York by a circuitous route, from the west rather than the east, after having been deposited in the Great Lakes in ballast waters of oceangoing ships traveling the St. Lawrence River from European ports.
In only three years, the mussel and its fast-swimming larvae have spread from Lake St. Clair, near Detroit, west into Lake Michigan and east into Lakes Erie and Ontario in western New York. $4 Billion in the Next 10 Years Already a major environmental problem, the small inedible shellfish, which reproduces prolifically, is dangerous in two ways: it clogs the pipes of power plants and it devours microscopic plants at the bottom of the food chain eaten by native fresh-water fish. 
So far it has been found in the intake pipes of power-generating stations at Dunkirk on the east end of Lake Erie, at the Niagara Power Project on the Niagara River just north of Niagara Falls, and at some Canadian projects on Lake Ontario as well as in some midwestern states.
Its economic impact on industry and commercial and recreational fishing will be substantial, said Robert Lange, supervisor of the Great Lakes fisheries program for the New York Department of Environmental Conservation.
''We estimate that it will cost $4 billion in the next 10 years in the Great Lakes area alone,'' said Margaret Dochoda, a biologist for the Great Lakes Fishery Commission in Ann Arbor, Mich. The costs will be borne by businesses, in changing intake pipes to keep the mussels out and in cleaning pipes already clogged; by ship owners and boat owners, in cleaning their hulls, and by the commercial fishing, sports fishing and tourist industries, in lower catches.
 
'Worse Than the Oil Spill in Alaska'
''This is a very serious problem,'' she said. ''We say it is worse than the oil spill in Alaska because these exotic introductions are permanent and spreading. They can't be cleaned up like the oil spill. In a hundred years, they will be all over America, while the oil spill will have been cleaned up.''
To monitor the spread of the mussels into New York, a research program began last month to find out how far they have penetrated into the state.
Twenty monitoring stations were set up in the Erie Canal and the Hudson, Delaware and Susquehanna Rivers by Acres International Corporation under contract with the Empire State Electric Energy Research Corporation, an arm of the state's electric industry. The results are not yet known. Another sign of mounting concern is that Maurice D. Hinchey, an Ulster County Democrat and chairman of the State Assembly's Environmental Conservation Committee, has called a public hearing on the threat of the zebra mussel for May 24 in Niagara Falls.
 
No Natural Predators
''What makes these guys bad is that they have an affinity for pipes, which affects municipal water plants, power plants and industry,'' Mr. Lange said. ''They proliferate to the point where they gum up the works, even stopping the flow of the water.''
Zebra mussels, so named because of dark brown stripes on their light tannish shells, are native to the Black and Caspian Seas. Without any natural predators to hamper their growth and expansion, they have found a new and congenial home here. They can be spread by commercial fishing boats and by recreation boats that are driven on trailers from waterway to waterway.
They attached themselves to navigational buoys, docks and ladders and even plastic bottles in addition to water intake pipes. The shells of dead mussels have already piled up on beaches, causing some bathers in Lakes Erie and St. Clair to wear footgear to prevent cuts, according to a recent report.
Adult zebra mussels grow to an inch to an inch and a half. Colonies can grow quickly from 30,000 to 40,000 mussels a square yard. The mussels prefer moving water, which is why they are so dangerous in industrial water intakes, biologists say.
 
Studying Ways of Control
By depleting the fish food supply, the zebra mussel could cause a decline in the important walleye fishing industry of Lake Erie, in the major whitefish fishing of Lake Superior and, if it reaches the Mississippi River, in the edible mussel industry, as well as in other fishing, the biologists said.
In their native habitat, zebra mussels are kept under control by diving ducks, by systematic repeated flushing of water systems with heated water and by chemicals like copper sulfate and chlorine.
In the United States, both chemical and thermal controls are being studied. At the Niagara Power Project, for example, John Malinchock, the environmental supervisor, said the project was preparing to use chlorine to eliminate them.
Bills have been introduced in Congress to spend $4 million a year for five years on prevention programs and an equal amount on eradication. But marine biologists expressed skepticism about proposed controls.
''There's really nothing that anyone knows right now to prevent them from spreading,'' said Mr. Lange.

HEADLINE: Main Builder In Stamford Is Faltering

BYLINE: By NICK RAVO, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: STAMFORD, Conn., May 11

 BODY:
This is the town that the F. D. Rich Company built. It was F. D. Rich that bulldozed virtually all of Stamford's decrepit downtown 25 years ago. And it was F. D. Rich that erected many of the high-rise office buildings that came to symbolize Stamford's rebirth as a corporate capital.
In the last six months, though, the 70-year-old company has faltered, battered by a glut of commercial office space and by tightened lending policies among debt-saddled New England banks. 
F. D. Rich, a closely held family-run firm, is four months behind on $2.7 million it owes in city property-tax payments; it may have liens placed on some of its properties if payments are not made by May 31.
 
Refused Further Discussion
And last month, the cash-hungry company announced that it had joined with one of the nation's largest real-estate concerns, the JMB Realty Corporation of Chicago, in what appears to be a merger or a partial sale, but which officials at Rich will only call ''a preliminary, non-binding agreement concerning the recapitalization and reorganization of F. D. Rich.''
Officials of F. D. Rich and JMB refused any further discussion of their deal, which must be approved by the company's lenders, or of other aspects of the companies.
''This is one of the risks of being a large-scale developer,'' said Charles T. Lee, chairman of the city's Urban Redevelopment Commission. ''You have to sink so much up front it's hard to hold on long enough to get your return, and you're terribly vulnerable to market downturns.''
The company's troubles are typical of the financial struggles now facing many commercial developers in New England and other parts of the Northeast. ''The real-estate business is screwed up, and it's not unique to Stamford,'' said Ed Tonnessen, senior vice president of Albert B. Ashforth Inc., a Stamford real-estate company.
In Stamford, however, some see F. D. Rich's negotiations with JMB as a sign of the end of an era of staggering growth for this Fairfield County city.
''It's a milestone,'' said Paul King Jr., senior vice president of the Grubb & Ellis Company, a San Francisco-based commercial real-estate firm with an office in Stamford.
The F. D. Rich Company was founded as a small contracting firm by F. D. Rich, an Italian immigrant stonemason who passed the business onto his sons, F. D. (Frank) Rich Jr. and Robert N. Rich. In recent years, much of the company's business has been handled by the founder's grandsons, F. D. (Rick) Rich 3d and Thomas L. Rich.
The company's rise to preeminence in Stamford started in the late 1950's, when it struck a deal with the city and the Federal Government that gave it a virtual monopoly on downtown development. In exchange, the company was required to construct office buildings long before there was any certainty that there would be tenants.
In the mid-1960's, the company demolished acres of decaying buildings in what had been a dying, brick-faced manufacturing town and started the slow process of rebuilding. It began projects like the GTE Corporation headquarters and its own 22-story Landmark Square office building. It was also a partner in the development of the Stamford Town Center mall.
 
Fortune 500 Companies
Over the years, the redevelopment of Stamford was so successful that by the mid-1980's the city had become the commercial hub for a stretch of suburbia covering Rockland to New Haven counties. More than two dozen Fortune 500 companies relocated their headquarters to Fairfield County, making it the third largest center for corporate headquarters in the nation, behind New York City and Chicago.
''If people could see the before-and-after, they would be astounded,'' said John H. Rostenberg, a partner in the Rostenberg-Doern Company, a commercial real-estate firm in White Plains and Stamford. ''Stamford would never look like what it does today without Rich.''
In 1987, however, F. D. Rich started to show signs of financial stress. It hired Salomon Brothers to help it refinance some of its projects and possibly sell some of its holdings. Last summer, it obtained a $114 million loan to refinance its Landmark Square complex.
Much of the company's financial problems have emanated from a high vacancy rate in its office buildings. About 500,000 square feet of its 3.2 million square feet in office space in Stamford is not leased.
''I don't think there is any more boom left here,'' Mr. Tonnessen said.
Stamford has an office space vacancy rate of 24 percent - a slight drop from past years, but prices have not increased and some developers have cut their prices to near-1980 levels.
''Like other cities in the country there was overbuilding in the mid-1980's,'' Mr. Lee said. ''From a city standpoint, that is a blessing in disguise. It now keeps our rental rates low, and we continue to be competitive with New York and New Jersey.''
F. D. Rich's troubles are also a result of the regional economic downturn that has flattened if not cut real-estate prices and dried up credit for both new building and refinancing.
''Stamford hit a nosedive in 1987, as many cities did, after the tax-reform act passed and stopped tax-driven speculative office building,'' Mr. Lee said.
Another drain on F. D. Rich's resources, local real-estate executives said, has been the Commonwealth Center, a $650 million theater-and-office-building complex in Boston, where the economy, and particularly the real-estate market, is softer than in Stamford.
Local business leaders, however, suspect that an arrangement with JMB will likely leave F. D. Rich with a much less active role in the management of its properties.
''It could be a direct purchase, a merger or a partnership,'' Mr. Rostenberg said. ''And how much of the company Rich keeps will be determined by the type of deal JMB and Rich strike, if they strike a deal.''

A Penn graduate, he received a master's degree in international affairs from Tufts University. His first marriage ended in divorce. His mother, Vivette Ravel Rifkin, founded and heads Educational Tape Recording for the Blind in Chicago. His father is a retired plastics manufacturer.

HEADLINE: SPORTS WORLD SPECIALS: STADIUMS;
Winner: Coney Island

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr.

 BODY:
A MAJOR new study by an award-winning Brooklyn research group has concluded that a domed sports stadium should be built in Coney Island and financed by a novel combination of bank loans and public donations.
''An intriguing idea,'' said Robert Zeig, the executive director of the Brooklyn Sports Foundation, which is pushing a similar project.
The report, whose simple, straightforward language could serve as a model for the frequently turgid genre, was prepared by 12 researchers. 
They spent three months conferring with public officials, conducting opinion surveys, studying transportation maps and inspecting the proposed site, much of which, they noted, ''is what we call 'bummed up.' ''
''Some of us went to Coney Island and looked around,'' the researchers said. ''We saw a lot of empty buildings and vandalism. Putting a stadium there would mean tearing down the rundown places to get land to build on.''
The report, hailed by the Brooklyn Borough President, Howard Golden, won a $15,000 first prize in a nationwide contest sponsored by American Express.
It was prepared by members of Frances Schafer's seventh grade classes at the Nathan Hale Intermediate School.
After quickly deciding that Brooklyn needed a stadium, the researchers investigated three sites. They rejected one, near their school, because ''the maps showed us that there was no train and only two buses into the area,'' and another, Prospect Park, because ''Ms. Schafer said some people would kill to save the grass and we want people to like the idea of a stadium.''
They said they liked Coney Island, an established recreation center with extensive transportation, for ''a lot of reasons.''
''It has the beach, amusement parks, restaurants and the aquarium. We figured people could go to Coney Island, spend the day, have dinner and then go to a game. It would be good for the neighborhood because it would help the businesses and it would bring more police into the area to make it safer for the people.''
The analysis ranged from the personal (''We knew it would be fun to have a stadium'') to the economic (''We also figured it would make jobs for construction and for the people who worked in the stadium.'') Schafer said that all the students had contributed to the report, but that the ''main wordsmiths'' were Nandi Ali and Angelo Melendez. ''I typed it,'' she said.
After momentary elation, the students were actually a bit crestfallen when they learned they had won the contest, but only because they had misunderstood when Schafer brought them the news.
''They thought it meant the stadium would be built,'' she said.

HEADLINE: Executives See a Chance Of Deficit Cut

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr., Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: HOT SPRINGS, Va., May 12

 BODY:
Despite repeated disappointments, many of the nation's top corporate executives say they think there is at least an even-money chance for a breakthrough in budget negotiations that begin on Tuesday in Washington, with a sizable number supporting such an agreement even if it includes an increase in personal income taxes.
''I'm encouraged that we will accomplish it finally this time, and it will have all kinds of good effects.'' said Edmund T. Pratt Jr., the chairman of Pfizer Inc., the pharmaceutical company.
A significant reduction of the deficit is a goal that has eluded policy makers for half a decade or more.
Mr. Pratt was one of the company chiefs interviewed at a meeting of the Business Council, a group wtih 100 active members, many of them chief executives of the nation's largest companies. They gather twice a year at the historic Homestead Hotel here. 
Others declaring themselves more or less optimistic included Lewis T. Preston of J. P. Morgan & Company, John G. Smale of the Procter & Gamble Company and Frank P. Popoff of the Dow Chemical Company.
But though a majority of the executives said higher taxes would have to be part of any successful budget deal, not all were willing to accept higher income tax rates.
Mr. Smale, for example, said he would have ''real difficulty'' with any plan to raise rates, including one that would eliminate a feature in the tax law that taxes a portion of middle-income earnings at 33 percent while those with higher incomes are taxed at 28 percent.
Another participant, Michael J. Boskin, the chairman of the President's Council of Economic Advisers, cited rising interest rates and lower corporate profits as factors that prompted the Administration to make budget overtures. He also seemed to indicate that taxes involving fuels and the environment would be prominent candidates if the Administration did agree to higher taxes.
Mr. Boskin, one of the eight members of President Bush's negotiating team, met with reporters after a presentation to the Business Council on the environment, the main subject of the two-day gathering. He responded to an observation that the subject of environmental taxes is increasingly under discussion by noting that the Administration was ''predisposed toward user fees in general.''
In February's Economic Report of the President, Mr. Boskin's office contended that economic incentives were to be preferred over statutory compulsions to deal with the environment and said ''a variety of policy tools, including user charges,'' could be employed, for example, ''to slow the buildup of greenhouse gases in the atmosphere.''
Mr. Boskin declined to comment on whether he considered gasoline taxes to be user fees.
 
Ending the Deadlock
Many members of the Business Council seemed almost eager for new taxes if that would break the long-standing fiscal deadlock that, among other things, has forced the Federal Reserve to adhere to a relatively restrictive monetary policy that has produced high interest rates.
The White House budget director, Richard G. Darman, another of the President's negotiators, said in a lecture last week at Harvard University that ''reducing the deficit is probably necessary to get interest rates satisfactorily down.''
While the members agreed with the Administration in mostly favoring spending cuts over tax increases, they were considerably less interested in the mechanism by which reducing the deficit occurs than in seeing it accomplished.
''Put everything on the table - and not take anything off if it solved the problem,'' advised one executive who asked not to be named. The executive supports raising the top income tax bracket to a uniform 33 percent.
Willard C. Butcher, the chairman of the Chase Manhattan Bank, also proposed higher taxes and spending cuts, perhaps some kind of tax on consumption and the means-testing of entitlement programs like Social Security and Medicare to exclude those who do not need them.
To raise the savings rate, Mr. Butcher suggested that no limit be imposed on the size of yearly contributions to individual retirement accounts.
 
The Issue of Gas Taxes
Roger B. Smith, the chairman of the General Motors Corporation, said that he opposed higher gasoline taxes because they are regressive, but that he could support a ''greenhouse'' or ''carbon'' fee, taxing fuels like oil and coal that pollute the air. He said such taxes would not fall so heavily on the poor.
The group still had numerous doubters as to whether a deficit-reduction agreement could be reached.
''It's not a very good start,'' said G. William Miller, the chairman of Federated Stores Inc. and Treasury Secretary during the Carter Administration, referring to the public sparring that has occurred since the negotiations were set. ''One still has to be skeptical.''
Tom H. Barrett, the chairman the Goodyear Tire and Rubber Company, said he thought it ''too early to tell'' the odds of a successful outcome but he also expressed a fairly widespread suspicion that the talks would not be taking place had there not been some clandestine winks and nods.
''It sounds,'' Mr. Barrett said, ''like there's something going on behind the scenes.''

LENGTH: 1088 words

HEADLINE: New Game Plan for Sports Daily

BYLINE: By KIM FOLTZ

 BODY:
The creators of The National thought they had a formula that could not fail: a daily sports newspaper packed with local and national news.
But so far, the strategy has not been a success. Now, the newspaper is drastically scaling down its coverage of local professional sports in its regional editions to focus more on stories of national interest.
''Our research told us that our readers didn't need The National to give them local sports coverage,'' said Frank Deford, the paper's editor in chief. ''They said they wanted something extra from us.'' 
Since it was started in late January on an initial investment of more than $30 million, The National has received praise from some journalists for innovative graphics and dramatic photographs, and for articles about sports personalities.
But it has been criticized by others because many articles about local sports are too short to give any compelling sense of the games.
 
'No Sense of Urgency'
''There's no sense of the urgency of a daily newspaper,'' said Mike Lupica, the brash columnist who The National hired from The Daily News in New York. ''There's nothing to grab people.''
Among its problems, The National has been unable to provide all the late sports scores in its New York and Chicago editions. Unlike its competition, it does not own its printing presses and cannot set its deadlines as late as it might want to.
Some dailies in New York and Chicago consider the late scores so important to sales that they print editions well into the morning to include them. USA Today also includes late scores in its Eastern editions.
Mr. Deford said the paper was unlikely to add the late scores soon.
Several journalists also said the paper had not yet delivered on its promise of investigative reporting about sports.
Mr. Deford said the paper had produced a few major investigative articles, but he acknowledged that The National had not ''blown the roof off'' of any scandals.
In addition, media executives questioned The National's schedule for expanding circulation. ''They are moving too slowly if they want to attract a lot of national advertising,'' said John Meskil, the media director at Warwick, Baker & Fiore, a New York advertising agency.
Analysts said a primary reason for The National's shift toward national sports coverage was the overwhelming competition from local newspapers and radio and television stations.
''Matching the local sports coverage was simply too difficult to do on a daily basis,'' said Gary Pranzo, the media director for Young & Rubicam.
But The National's new strategy may not fare any better, analysts say. The newspaper will now have to compete for readers and advertisers with well-established weekly sports publications, like Sports Illustrated and The Sporting News, and with USA Today, which many readers buy for its sports coverage.
''We really don't need another national sports publication,'' Mr. Meskil said. ''The National certainly isn't setting the world on fire.''
The newspaper, which is sold primarily in the New York, Los Angeles and Chicago areas, claims a circulation of about 200,000. A limited number of copies are also available in a few other cities, including Buffalo, St. Louis and Bakersfield, Calif.
That circulation, however, has not been verified by an independent audit, and some analysts believe the correct figure is closer to 150,000. Doubts about total circulation, they say, are hurting advertising sales.
Peter Spina, the paper's advertising sales director, said the paper's circulation would probably be audited at the end of this year.
During the second half of this year, The National plans to expand its distribution nationwide, adding one city a month, starting with San Diego in June and San Francisco in July.
''The name 'National' really doesn't fit yet,'' Mr. Pranzo said. As a result, he added, the newspaper is not a ''must buy'' for national advertisers.
The National is running an average of five pages of advertising in each issue, Mr. Spina said. And while he said this exceeded the paper's projections, most advertising was sold at discounted rates.
 
'Jaws of a Media Recession'
The advertising climate is not likely to improve any time soon, analysts said. ''They launched the publication in the jaws of a media recession,'' said John Morton, an analyst at Lynch, Jones & Ryan, an investment firm in Washington.
Advertising in newspapers and magazines has drastically fallen since the first of the year. At Sports Illustrated, for example, advertising pages were down 17.8 percent for the first quarter of 1990.
The National is trying to lure advertisers away from magazines by offering exclusivity. Recently, for example, the paper sold an entire issue to a single advertiser, Philip Morris USA, which ran six ads. ''It is almost as if the paper is a sales brochure for them,'' Mr. Spina said.
The paper also plans to start a classified advertising section in July and special advertising sections for important sports events like the Indianapolis 500 auto race.
But getting the kind of wide distrbution and large circulation that national advertisers demand might prove to be too costly for the paper, analysts said. USA Today, for example, lost more than $100 million in each of its first two years.
 
Prediction of Big Losses
''As the paper expands into new markets,'' Mr. Morton said, ''the costs are going to keep increasing, but for several months the advertising won't increase commensurately and there are going to be big losses.''
The National is backed by Emilio Azcarraga, whose company, Televisa, owns four television stations in Mexico. He pledged $100 million to start the paper. The National's publisher, Peter O. Price, a former publisher of The New York Post, owns a minority interest in the paper. Starting The National cost more than $30 million, Mr. Deford said, but he would not say how much it was costing to keep the paper going on a daily basis and to move into new cities.
Meanwhile, The National will make changes in its staff as it increases its focus on national coverage. It does not need as many local sports reporters as it initially hired, and Mr. Deford said some reporters would be transferred to offices that the paper plans to open in San Diego and San Francisco this summer.
One writer who might be leaving is Mr. Lupica. He said he was unhappy with the direction the paper was taking, and some people who asked not to be identified said he had been negotiating to return to The Daily News.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL REPORT;
U.S. Company Loses Bolivian Mining Deal

BYLINE: By SHIRLEY CHRISTIAN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 13

 BODY:
Faced with public opposition that underscores Bolivians' deep-seated distrust of big capitalism and foreign business, the Government has backed away from a proposed mining accord with an American company.
The contract with the Lithium Corporation of America, which is based in Gastonia, N.C., and known as Lithco, had been viewed by its supporters as an important symbolic step in the efforts of Bolivia, the poorest country in South America, to modernize and expand its economy.
But as President Jaime Paz Zamora, who took office in August, advocates a freer economy and more foreign investment, he faces a formidable obstacle - decades of opposition to capitalism, which he and his predecessor, Victor Paz Estenssoro, and their parties once fostered.
 
Painful Decision
The Government announced on May 4 that it would not proceed with the Lithco deal, which it has been negotiating for several years. 
In announcing what he called a painful decision not to proceed, Mr. Paz Zamora noted that most countries in the world are fighting to attract foreign investment. He urged Bolivians to assume ''a new, modern mental attitude, without complexes or fear of progress.''
The President decided not to complete the agreement after being confronted by hunger strikes from opponents of the contract, widespread criticism of its terms and indications that Congress would not approve it. During labor demonstrations on May 1, some marchers carried signs calling for ''Death to Those Who Would Hand Over the Uyuni Salt Flats,'' the area in southwestern Bolivia covered by the now-rejected contract.
Saying the issue had become ''politicized in the extreme,'' Mr. Paz Zamora said that because of the competition for foreign investment, Bolivia ''ought to place the least number of obstacles in the road and create the best conditions to capture that investment.''
 
Angered by U.S. Ambassador
Both opponents and critics of the contract were angered several weeks ago when the United States Ambassador, Robert S. Gelbard, called on Bolivia to ''overcome its history of statism, confiscations, and nationalizations and cast aside its persistent fears of potential investors.''
The Bolivian Labor Federation responded by saying that it was declaring Mr. Gelbard ''persona non grata.'' Bolivian congressional leaders and editorial writers accused the Ambassador of exceeding the norms of diplomatic behavior.
Mr. Paz Zamora has not abandoned the idea of awarding the contract to a foreign company but said that this time he would put out a call for competitive international bids to explore and exploit the salt flats, which are situated about 400 miles south of La Paz.
The contract with Lithco had been negotiated by the Government. Mining experts said the direct approach was used because the small world lithium market is largely controlled by two companies - Lithco and Foote Minerals. Since Foote is already working in Chile, which is Bolivia's main competitor as a source of minerals other than tin, Bolivia did not want to turn to Foote.
For this reason, there is some doubt here about how much interest there will be in the future bidding. Lithco officials were unclear about whether they would bid.
Lithium, which is found in the salt brine near the surface of the Uyuni Flats, is used in a variety of products ranging from drugs for treating mental illness to ceramics and glass. It may have a more promising future in energy uses, especially if there is a breakthrough in thermal fusion.
 
Value of the Contract
Given the modest demand for lithium, the value of the contract to Bolivia would not have been great. It called for Lithco to spend $6 million in exploration and feasibility studies over three years, then invest $40 million in a processing plant if it decided to proceed.
Experts estimate that lithium exports from Bolivia could total $100 million to $110 million over 10 years, on which the Government would have received roughly 8 percent in taxes and royalties under the Lithco proposal. About 200 people would have been employed.
Mr. Gelbard said the Lithco negotiations would be viewed in the international business community ''as somewhat of a test case.'' The defeat of the deal ''cannot but have an adverse effect on the perception of the investment climate in Bolivia,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Panel Calls for More Spending on Advanced TV <

BYLINE: By ANDREW POLLACK, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, May 13

 BODY:
At a time when the Defense Department appears intent on cutting back support for research on high-definition television technology, a Pentagon advisory panel is urging that support for such research be increased tenfold to at least $100 million a year for the next five years.
The recommendation is part of a report completed this month by the High-Resolution Systems Task Force, which was established a year ago to suggest an appropriate role for the Pentagon in the development of high-resolution video displays and related technology. The Report Could Change The task force was made up of 33 representatives of the electronics industry, universities and labor unions. Its chairman is Alexander B. Trowbridge, the former president of the National Association of Manufacturers. 
The report will now go to the Defense Science Board, a Pentagon advisory body, which could change it. The report, which has not yet been officially released, is likely to be met with a cold reception by the Administration, which has expressed opposition to any Federal program that seems to favor a particular industry.
The Pentagon is reportedly trying to reduce the $10 million a year that is now budgeted for work on high-resolution technologies. The Defense Department last month also abruptly removed Dr. Craig I. Fields, the director of its Advanced Research Projects Agency, who favored programs that help industry.
An earlier draft of the task force report was the subject of news stories last month, but the early draft did not contain the spending recommendation.
 
Two Years of Debate
The report comes after two years of debate over whether the Government and industry should mount a program to develop televisions with pictures twice as sharp as those on existing sets. The debate is no longer confined to consumer televisions. Potential applications include screens for personal computers and medical imaging systems, and the technology involves developing a variety of semiconductor chips and sensors needed for capturing and processing images.
The report's conclusions are reflected in its title: ''High-Resolution Systems Critical to National Security - Both Military and Economic.''
This is partly because high-resolution displays will be used in future military systems, like radar screens, the report says. But it also argues that if foreign vendors end up dominating production of both display screens and semiconductors, they ''could capture the fastest growing segments of our domestic computer industry: work stations, high-end personal computers and portables.'' From there, the report says, foreign companies would be in a position to capture the rest of the computer industry.
 
Risks for Military Security
That in turn would pose unacceptable risks for military security, the report says, because ''our computers control our defense systems.'' Relying on foreigners ''would place the dominant foreign suppliers in a position to alter the balance of power between ourselves and our potential adversaries by their decisions as to which nations would or would not receive their most advanced computers.''
The report said that the United States is not irreversibly behind in development of high-resolution systems because such systems are not yet ready for widespread commercial use. Moreover, the United States is developing the basic technologies in universities and industrial laboratories which could enable the nation to become a ''world class competitor'' in the field.
Manufacturers in the United States still maintain control of the computer industry, which would provide a large market for high-resolution displays, the report says.
The task force report urges the Defense Department to use commercial high-definition products whenever possible, rather than those built expressly for the military. That would save the Pentagon money and stimulate the development of American industry.
But the task force also says that foreign-owned companies could be involved in Pentagon-backed programs provided they do much of their research and manufacturing in the United States.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Rates Expected to Drop Further

BYLINE: By H. J. MAIDENBERG

 BODY:
Many participants in the credit markets say they expect a further decline in interest rates this week, as more investors in fixed-income securities become convinced that the Bush Administration and Congress are moving to confront the nation's budget deficit.
New signs of economic weakness and declining inflationary pressures last week also contributed to the mood change in the bond market.
On Friday, the Government's reports on April retail sales and wholesale prices showed declines that exceeded expectations. The reports caused demand for fixed-income securities to soar and interest rates to drop. Any softening in the economy and easing of inflationary pressures is bullish for holders of fixed-income securities because it keeps interest rates from rising and thus eroding the value of outstanding debt issues. 
 
Bond Yields Are Lower
The market's positive mood was reflected in the sharp drop in yields on both the new and old benchmark Treasury long bonds last week. The 8.75 percent bond maturing in 2020 that was auctioned at an average yield of 8.84 percent on Thursday traded to yield 8.63 late Friday. The yield on the 8.5 percent long bonds due February 2020 plunged to 8.66 percent, from 8.83 percent on Thursday and 8.82 percent the week before.
''Interest rates actually began to drop May 4, after the April employment data showed an unexpectedly small rise in non-farm jobs and rise in the rate of overall unemployment,'' said Philip Braverman, chief economist at the DKB Securities Corporation, the domestic arm of Dai-Ichi Kangyo Bank Ltd. of Tokyo, the world's largest commercial bank. ''But the full impact of what was happening was delayed by the usual concerns that precede a quarterly Treasury refunding. Once the week's auctions of the record $30.5 billion of notes and bonds were over and the paper quickly distributed to retail investors, the rush to lock in yields was on.''
But Mr. Braverman, who has steadfastly predicted that the flow of economic data in the second quarter would cause interest rates to fall, said, ''The credit market believes the latest signs of a weakening economy have caused the Administration to enter into a sort of social contract with the Federal Reserve and money market to reverse the upward pressure on interest rates by working toward a budget compromise with Congress that is likely to include tax increases.''
 
Threat to the Economy
The Administration has little choice, he said, because if it does not act to increase revenues the high borrowing costs plus the cost of the savings and loan bailout will lead to even higher interest rates that will throttle any chance for reviving the economy.
Irwin L. Kellner, chief economist at the Manufacturers Hanover Trust Company, said: ''Perceptions in any marketplace carry as much weight as reality. In the credit market, the fact that politicians are even willing to discuss increasing taxes in a Congressional election has had a tremendous impact on thinking in the credit market in recent days. So has Washington's indirect admission that it has mismanaged the economy.''
But Mr. Kellner also noted that interest rates, as measured by the yield on the Treasury's long bonds, are still almost a percentage point above the level of late December. ''Thus, prices of long-term debt have a way to go on the upward side before we see a significant decline in interest rates,'' he said. ''But we expect that the next batch of economic data will be sufficiently negative to push up prices of fixed-income debt and lower interest rates.''
Leif H. Olsen, who heads a financial management and consulting firm bearing his name in New Canaan, Conn., said on Friday: ''The behavior of the stock market may unnerve some in the fixed-income market, but the 63-point surge in the Dow Jones industrial average mainly reflects the drop in interest rates and lessening inflationary pressures, not the fact that the economy is steadily deteriorating. The market has been blinded by the near doubling of the gross national product in the first quarter, which climbed at an annual rate of 2.1 percent. The next G.N.P. report due out on May 24, will show a downward revision.''
 
Outlook for Other Reports
Mr. Olsen expects this week's flow of economic data to show declines in housing starts and permits, industrial production, factory use and the Consumer Price Index, which will reflect a further decline in consumer spending in April. But the nation's merchandise trade balance for March is expected to show a sharp increase.
Francis A. Scotland, managing editor of the International Bank Credit Analyst, which is based in Montreal, said an important question for the American credit market is how much longer the Federal Reserve is willing to let the dollar drop. ''A further weakening in the dollar, such as one we witnessed this week, combined with falling interest rates could discourage foreign investors,'' he said.

HEADLINE: Bright Outlook For Pacific Rim

BYLINE: Reuters

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, May 13

 BODY:
Economists from 15 Pacific Rim nations said last week that they expected further modest slowing of growth in the region this year but that the overall outlook for the region remained bright.
The economists forecast overall growth this year of 5 percent after a growth rate of 5.3 percent in 1989 and an average rate of 7.2 percent in 1988. 
 
The outlook came from the
Pacific Economic Cooperation Conference, a group that includes China, Japan, Indonesia, the United States, Canada and Australia.
Lawrence Krause, a professor at the University of California at San Diego, said that compared with the rest of the world the Pacific economies were still in outstanding shape.
''There were nine countries in the Pacific in 1989 in this group that grew at about 5 percent or better,'' he said. ''It is very hard to find a country outside this group that grew at 5 percent anywhere.''
Thailand was the leader, with growth this year forecast at 9.1 percent, followed by Singapore and Malaysia, each with an expected 8.1 percent growth rate.
At the low end of the scale were Australia, Canada, the United States, New Zealand and Brunei.

HEADLINE: WORLD TRADE BODY IS EXPECTED TO LET SOVIETS HAVE ROLE

BYLINE: By CLYDE H. FARNSWORTH, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
In an initial step linking the Soviet Union more closely to the global economy - a goal urged by the Bush Administration - Moscow is expected to be granted observer status this week in the organization that oversees world trade.
Observer status in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade, a 97-nation organization based in Geneva, would for the first time bring the Soviet Union into the international organizations that have helped shape the postwar world economy. The move is expected to be approved by the GATT Council at a regular monthly meeting scheduled for Wednesday.
An Administration official said today that President Bush wanted a favorable decision before his meeting in two weeks with President Mikhail S. Gorbachev as ''a tangible sign of American interest in bringing the Soviet Union into the world economy.'' 
 
U.S. Opposition Ends
When Mr. Bush last met the Soviet leader at Malta last year, he pledged to remove American obstacles to Soviet participation in GATT. But the plan at that time was not to allow Moscow in until early next year.
During most of the last decade, the United States had flatly rejected the idea of granting the Soviets observer status at GATT, considering it politically undesirable and economically impractical. Europeans, on the other hand, felt there would be little harm in letting the Soviets in.
Earlier this year, the Administration decided to speed up the process started at Malta.
Torie Clarke, an aide to the United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, said, ''This decision stands today.''
 
No Guarantees
''The United States has let it be known that if agreeable to all other GATT members, we would have no problem with observer status, but we have made it clear that this does not guarantee full membership,'' Ms. Clarke said.
Observer status, said David Woods, head of information at the GATT headquarters, means the Soviets would be able to attend the monthly meetings of the GATT Council and participate in standing committees, like the Committee on Trade and Development, which works with the third world.
In addition, the Soviet observers could speak at meetings, if invited, usually after the full members. They would receive all documentation.
But the Soviets would not be able to vote. Neither would they be permitted to observe nor attend meetings related to the Uruguay Round, the GATT-sponsored effort to get rid of barriers to trade in services and farm products and providing better protection for patents, copyrights and other intellectual property. The Uruguay Round, which began at a negotiating session in Punta del Este, Uruguay, four years ago, is due to be concluded at the end of this year.
While observer status does not guarantee full membership, it does provide experience in the workings of the trading system. To make the transition to full membership, an applicant nation must enact policies to open its economy to competition and foreign goods. There is a no set list of measures that must be adopted for membership, such as moving to a convertible currency, but the overall drift of the nation's policies must be seen as a clear move toward more liberal trading practices. Full membership in GATT usually insures lower import duties on the products of a member country.
The move from observer status to membership can take several years. For example, China has been an observer for the last three years. It was moving to satisfy the membership requirements until it crushed student demonstrations last June. The membership talks have been suspended since.
 
Some Dispute in Congress
The decision to back an early approval of observer status for the Soviets could be contentious, because it comes as the Soviets are cracking down economically on Lithuania.
President Bush announced on April 24 that for the time being he would not order American sanctions against Moscow, but the conflict over Baltic independence is having a significant impact on Washington.
A resolution calling on the President not to support observership so long as the economic blockade of Lithuania remains has been introduced in the Senate.
Japan has also used the issue of GATT observer status for the Soviets as a vehicle for underlining its differences with Moscow. Signaling its displeasure over continued Soviet occupation of four Japanese islands off Hokkaido seized in 1945, the Japanese Government asked for a delay last month when the GATT Council first took up the Soviet issue.
Japan has set the unconditional return of the islands as a condition for concluding a peace treaty and establishing full-fledged economic ties with Moscow.
But Japanese officials, who want to see the Soviet Union move toward a market-oriented economy, say they do not plan to use the island issue to keep the Soviets out of the GATT.
''We are coordinating our position with the U.S. and the European Community,'' said Shataro Yachi, political counselor at the Japanese Embassy here. He said the GATT and island issues ''are not directly linked.''
Mr. Gorbachev is expected to visit Japan next year, and many Japanese expect that he will try to resolve the territorial problem in return for Japanese economic assistance.
GATT is important for both the Soviet Union and China as they seek to normalize commercial relations with the rest of the world. Membership protects a nation's trade interests from the discrimination against nonmembers.
For example, had the Soviet Union been a full member of the GATT, it would have been much more difficult for the United States to deny so-called most favored nation status to Soviet imports, a situation that imposes 10 times higher duties on imports from the Soviet Union than other countries.
Under a Soviet-American agreement that both sides hope to have ready by the time Mr. Gorbachev meets with Mr. Bush, the Soviets could be accorded lower tariffs.
GATT membership is also important as a sign of legitimacy and acceptance by the world community.
Mr. Woods, the GATT official, said membership would involve significant commitments to economic change. ''It cements the reform process that governments wish to pursue,'' he added.
Mexico and Morocco, two of the newest members, for example, have undertaken significant trade liberalization as a result of their accession.
The Soviets have been interested in other international economic organizations besides the GATT.
A $12 billion European Bank for Reconstruction and Development, which is expected to open later this year, includes the Soviet Union as well as the United States.
Moscow has long expressed interest in two important postwar institutions, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. The Soviet Union participated actively in the 1944 conference at Bretton Woods, N.H., where these organizations were born. Yet the Soviet Union decided not to join, foreshadowing the cold war.
The Soviets have not applied for membership in either of the Bretton Woods twins, and it is considered unlikely that Moscow would join, at least until the mid-1990's.

HEADLINE: A Soviet Circus, Deeply in Debt, Is Stuck in U.S.

BYLINE: By ISABEL WILKERSON, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MARIETTA, Ga., May 14

 BODY:
A troupe of the Soviet Union's leading acrobats, clowns, jugglers and animal trainers entered the United States six weeks ago with visions of sellout crowds and warm applause, only to end up in a frustrating odyssey that has left them stranded in a Marietta motel.
The tour of 125 performers in the Great Soviet Circus Bim Bom ran out of money several weeks ago because of a dispute between its American managers and a Kuwaiti investor that backed the group.
Now the circus is deeply in debt and unable to pay its bills. Several dozen circus animals, including lions, bears, horses and monkeys, are stuck at a farm in Newburgh, N.Y. And instead of soaring on trapezes or juggling fire in packed coliseums, the performers, who have been ejected from two motels in the last 10 days, have been spending their days holed up in one of the few motels that will accept them, watching television or practicing their routines in the motel parking lot. 
''They've taken everything in stride,'' said Ben Silva, the art director for International Show Business Inc., the Florida-based company that is managing the circus. ''They're cordial people who don't want any trouble. They go along with what's necessary.'' Debts and Bad Checks The circus, made up of star performers from 60 Soviet circuses, came to this country on March 31 and has left a string of debts and bounced checks in its path. The group trained in West Virginia for several weeks before playing to near-empty arenas in Hershey, Pa., and Knoxville, Tenn. The tour was suspended last week in Johnson City, Tenn., when the group was unable to get enough money to cover the cost of equipment and an arena.
A Holiday Inn in Johnson City evicted the circus, forcing it to come to Marietta, $450,000 in debt, to return rented equipment to its suppliers. Barely unpacked, it was evicted from the Motel Six in Marietta on Wednesday, when it was unable to pay its bill.
At the center of the circus's financial crisis is a disagreement over a contract between the circus managers and a principal investor.
Business managers say the investor agreed to pay $1.5 million to cover the circus's expenses, but abandoned the group after providing only $331,000. ''They said they would finance the whole thing, whatever it takes,'' Mr. Silva said.
Brooks Savage, the lawyer for the Kuwaiti investor, said that the $331,000 was a loan and that the investor was to receive 10 percent of the ticket proceeds. ''It was absolutely a loan,'' said Mr. Savage, who declined to identify his client. ''But it's looking more like a gift every day. We're standing in line to get our money back.''
Meanwhile, people have come from all over town to help the Soviet circus get back on its feet. A laundromat has offered to let the performers clean their clothes at no cost. Several restaurants have sent over free meals. People have gone door to door to collect canned food for them. And the East Side Baptist Church brings lunch over every day.
''I'm in love with them,'' said Kay Bryant, an outreach worker at the church. ''They're precious, sensitive people who have appreciated everything we do.''
But all the warm gestures do not address the real problem. ''There's been a lot of community good will,'' said Gay Watson, a spokeswoman for the local convention and visitors bureau. ''But they don't need just dinner. They need a major investor.''
Their most immediate concern is keeping a roof over their heads. The group is occupying 75 percent of the rooms at the Scottish Inn here, and it's a scramble every day to cover the $1,550 lodging bill. One day it's a credit card, another day, cash. Sunday a friend of the circus manager flew in from out of town to write a check to cover the night's expenses.
Greg Patton, manager of the Scottish Inn, said he took the group in not for political reasons, but for humanitarian ones. ''I just didn't have the heart to put 130 people on the street,'' he said.
While the Soviet performers seem grateful, they do not know enough English to thank Mr. Patton or any of the other volunteers. But the group's best English speaker, Boris Rivchun, the musical director for the circus, said: ''We are a month and a half in American land. Wonderful people. Open souls.''

HEADLINE: Economic Watch;
Debate on Puerto Rico's Future Has a Bottom Line

BYLINE: By PETER PASSELL

 BODY:
If President Bush and Gov. Rafael Hernandez Colon have their way, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico will get the chance next year to vote on joining the Union or casting it off forever.
For many supporters of a binding referendum, the principle of free choice matters more than the choice that will be offered among the three alternatives: statehood, independence and retention of commonwealth status. And as enabling legislation inches its way through e Congress and the debate in Puerto Rico builds momentum, practical questions of jobs and government benefits, not national or cultural integrity, are looming largest.
''Only in Puerto Rico,'' said John Stewart, a consultant to the commonwealth's Economic Development Administration, ''do the taxi drivers refer to sections of the Federal tax code by their numbers.''
 
Effects Would Be Momentous
The economic consequences of a change in political status would be momentous for the island's 3.4 million inhabitants. 
Statehood would make Puerto Ricans eligible for billions of dollars more a year in food stamps, medical insurance and income support payments, and this might explain why statehood narrowly leads the commonwealth option in early polls.
But even advocates of statehood or independence concede that under either option the loss of Federal tax benefits linked by law to commonwealth status would lead to an initial decline in employment and would force sharp cutbacks in the size and reach of local government. Computer simulations by the Congressional Budget Office suggest that growth would be slowed one to two percentage points a year into the foreseeable future.
The best hope in the long run, economists on all sides seem to agree, is that statehood or independence would shatter the sense of Puerto Rico as an economic appendage of the United States, stimulating the savings and enterprise that are needed to break the island free of its dependency.
Puerto Rico's commonwealth status carries with it a unique package of privilege and penalty. Its residents cannot vote in Presidential elections. Nor are they entitled to all the social benefits available to residents of the 50 states.
 
Current Benefits
But Puerto Ricans are American citizens, free to live where they choose. If they live in Puerto Rico, they pay no Federal income tax. And under a benefit that is crucial to the island's economy, subsidiaries of American businesses in Puerto Rico enjoy unrestricted access to American markets but pay no Federal taxes on profits.
That benefit (Section 936 of the United States Tax Code) and the commonwealth's own generous tax incentives for new businesses have induced hundreds of manufacturers to build plants in Puerto Rico. Most are makers of pharmaceuticals, chemicals and electronics equipment, industries that are well positioned to transfer to their island subsidiaries the profits they earn on the mainland from intangible assets like patents and trademarks. And as a result of this encouragement of highly automated industries, relatively few jobs have been created for each dollar of investment.
But so many tax-sheltered investment dollars have been attracted to the island that the overall effect on the size and shape of the Puerto Rican economy has been enormous. Output per person grew at a remarkable 5 percent a year in the 1950's and 60's. The rate of growth plunged to about 1 percent in the mid-1970's after the virtual collapse of the island's tax-sheltered oil refining industry, but it has picked up to 3.6 percent over the last five years.
The overall economic performance, supplemented by substantial infusions of Federal aid and borrowed capital for improvements, has been superb. The densely populated, resource-poor island now enjoys a living standard far above that of any Caribbean or Latin American nation.
The catch, says Bernard Wasow, an economist at New York University, is that the Puerto Rican economy has been cultivated as a fragile orchid, seemingly incapable of blossoming outside the Federal hothouse. Manufacturing, virtually all of it free from Federal corporate taxes, accounts for 40 percent of its output, while agricultural production accounts for only 1.5 percent, far below the level one might expect to find in the tropics.
 
Labor Costs Are High
And labor is in great oversupply on the island. But Mr. Stewart says the effects of Federal minimum wage laws, which have kept worker compensation high by island standards, and the unlimited right of workers to move to the mainland, where they are drawn by higher salaries and greater diversity in employment, have kept labor costs close to levels in the United States. Per capita output in Puerto Rico is two-thirds that of Singapore, Mr. Stewart notes, but worker compensation is twice as high. This discourages the growth of labor-intensive industries, like tourism and apparel, that might absorb excess workers.
Not surprisingly, elected officials in the commonwealth are under chronic pressure to provide the well-paying jobs that private employers cannot. One in four Puerto Rican workers is employed by the Government, and at a cost that Puerto Rico would be hard pressed to cover without Federal aid and tax revenue from the corporations on the island drawn there by the tax breaks.
Either change in status contemplated in the referendum would upset this equilibrium. The Congressional Budget Office confirms that under statehood, Federal aid to individuals would increase to $5 billion by 1995 from $2 billion now, and would provide about one-third of the island's personal income.
The loss of preferred tax status for corporations could prove devastating to the productive economy. The Congressional Budget Office asserts that without the tax incentives, manufacturers would scale back investment in their plants by one-third to one-half. As a result, the rate of economic growth would slow, increasing unemployment by four to seven percentage points by the year 2000. KMPG Peat Marwick, a consulting firm working for partisans of the commonwealth option, predicts that 145,000 jobs, or one in six, would be lost.
Many supporters of the statehood option concede that there would be disruptions in manufacturing, but they believe that the losses would be made up quickly by businesses attracted by the opportunity of expanding into the 51st state.
But if they are wrong, Puerto Rico's economic problems would multiply.
 
Cutbacks in the Offing
Any reduction in Section 936 profits or wage income would cut into Puerto Rico's tax revenue and its ability to borrow capital for development. Under statehood, it could not easily make up the loss by raising the personal income tax. Indeed, there would be pressure to reduce tax rates because middle- and upper-income families would be required to pay Federal taxes for the first time.
Consequently, says Jose Villamil, a private economic consultant in San Juan, the government would be forced to cut back. That need not be a bad thing, even in the eyes of statehood proponents. Michael McKee, a Washington-based consultant to the party that supports statehood, sees benefits in a sell-off of money-losing enterprises owned by the commonwealth. But there is little doubt that jobs would be lost.
Forming an independent nation would also mean the phasing out of Federal aid. And without Federal money, Mr. Wasow, the New York University economist, said, ''Puerto Rico could become the inner city of the Caribbean.'' Moreover, the new nation could have serious problems in replacing the capital now being borrowed from Wall Street or in attracting companies like those lured there by tax incentives.
The Congressional Budget Office estimates that the cost of borrowed capital would rise by at least two percentage points, because interest on the bonds of an independent Puerto Rico would be fully taxable to American investors.
Puerto Rico would become eligible for help from the International Monetary Fund and the World Bank. But the line for assistance is already long, and with the breakup of the Soviet empire, it is likely to get much longer.
 
Independence's Edge
But an independent Puerto Rico would have a significant edge over a Puerto Rican state in attracting corporate investment. United States law gives American companies a $1 tax credit for every dollar they pay in foreign taxes. So if Puerto Rico were to set its tax equal to the Federal rate and then plow much of the revenue into subsidies that made the island a more attractive place to operate, it might win a corporate following.
But Mr. Stewart, the commonwealth's consultant on development, is skeptical. If that strategy is so promising, he asked, ''Why don't other third world countries try it?'' Most, he notes, can already offer foreign corporations the advantage of far lower labor costs.
The strongest economic cases for statehood and independence rest on the idea that the Puerto Rican economy must change radically to achieve its potential. Partisans of statehood make much of the intangible benefits of stability conferred by full partnership in the Union. A more mixed blessing might be the harsh lesson in modern capitalism, as Puerto Ricans discovered that local government could no longer afford to be the employer of last resort, and that tax breaks could no longer substitute for entrepreneurial spirit in creating good jobs.
What applies to statehood applies in spades to independence. ''Instead of being a rich Caribbean country,'' Mr. Wasow said, Puerto Ricans now think of the island ''as a poor part of the U.S.''
Were the island to go it alone, Puerto Ricans might be willing to make the sacrifices that have permitted nations like South Korea and Singapore to make the leap into self-sustained growth. Specifically, they might accept lower wages to increase employment and become competitive internationally. They might also curtail consumption to pay for the capital that now comes entirely from Wall Street and the Federal Government.
''Statehood or independence could have big payoffs 15 years down the road, but the risks are enormous'' Mr. Villamil said. ''Commonwealth is a safe bet.''
