HEADLINE: Warily, Congress and White House Gird for the Budget Joust

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
White House officials and Congressional leaders begin budget negotiations Tuesday with each delegation torn internally by political and philosophical disagreements.
Those differences will probably have to be resolved before the Administration and Congressional negotiators address the fundamental disputes between the two sides.
In appearance if not in reality, the two leaders of President Bush's team are somewhat at odds on the question of raising taxes.
John H. Sununu, the White House chief of staff and the President's top political adviser, suggested last week that Mr. Bush might allow Democrats to propose higher taxes and then reject them out of hand. In a television interview on Sunday, he said the White House would probably ''look askance'' at a tax increase. 
But Richard G. Darman, the budget director, has hinted that some forms of higher taxes might be acceptable if the Administration got concessions in return.
Which view represents Mr. Bush's is unclear. All he has said publicly is that he is entering the negotiations with ''no preconditions.''
 
Political Ambush Is Feared
Among the Democrats, their leaders in Congress, Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri and Senator George J. Mitchell of Maine, are worrying openly about walking into a political ambush.
Mr. Mitchell, for example, said today that ''a great many Democrats'' believed that President Bush, having realized that he must break his campaign pledge not to increase taxes, was now ''looking for political cover.''
Other Democrats, however, say the deficit problem is so severe that party leaders must put politics aside and join with the President to find a solution.
Most of the Democratic negotiators have said they will sit tight on the issue of raising taxes unless President Bush puts the matter on the table first. And if the issue does come up, there are differences of opinion among the Democrats on what taxes to raise.
Representative Dan Rostenkowski of Illinois, chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, for instance, has proposed an elaborate plan that involves higher taxes. He would increase the Federal tax on gasoline by 15 cents a gallon. But Senator Lloyd Bentsen of Texas, chairman of the Finance Committee, has said he is unalterably opposed to a higher gasoline tax.
The Republican Congressional team also divides into at least two camps. Senator Pete V. Domenici of New Mexico, the party's leading Congressional spokesman on budget issues, conceded again today that additional taxes would probably be required to make this ''the last budget summit of the century.''
But another pivotal Republican in the talks, Senator Phil Gramm of Texas, rejected all forms of higher taxes.
 
President Will Avoid Specifics
Mr. Bush will preside over the first negotiating session Tuesday afternoon in the Cabinet Room at the White House. His press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, said today that the President would open the meeting by expressing ''general goals about getting the deficit down'' but would not offer any specific proposals.
That in itself concerns the Democrats, who believe Mr. Bush should speak publicly, perhaps on television, about why he believes the budget situation is so much more serious now than it was in January, the last time he addressed the nation on the subject.
In those comments, in his State of the Union Message, he painted a rosy picture of the economy, citing progress in cutting the deficit and asserting that his budget for the next fiscal year would meet the $64 billion deficit target of the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings balanced budget law without painful spending cuts or higher taxes.
Now, Mr. Darman is saying that even if the Bush budget were passed intact, a political impossibility, the deficit could be $50 billion higher than was anticipated in January.
The economy has not performed as well as the Administration had hoped, Mr. Darman says. Tax receipts are thus lower, and higher interest rates on Government bonds make payments on the national debt more costly. Moreover, the budget director says, the annual cost of liquidating failed savings and loan associations could be much higher than expected in the next fiscal year, although some of this money should be recovered in the following years.
 
Democrats Scoff at Analysis
Democrats accept the Darman assessment of the severity of the problem but scoff at his analysis of what went wrong. They observe that the country's economic performance since January has been about what most private economists and those on Congressional staffs predicted.
They liken the Administration's optimistic economic projections in January to a basketball player in a tie game who heaves a shot from half court just before the final buzzer. If the shot miraculously goes in, his team wins the game. If it misses, he is none the worse for trying.
The Bush budget, they say, was no more than a political shot from midcourt that was almost certain to miss.
After Tuesday's session, the negotiations are expected to move to Capitol Hill. Most of the participants on both sides agree that the substantive issues of spending and taxes cannot be addressed until such procedural matters are settled as how to account for the savings and loan bailout and how to handle Social Security calculations in the budget.
The two sides also agree that the negotiations will last a long time.
''It will go on probably weeks, if not months,'' Mr. Fitzwater said today. ''It is not the kind of thing where anybody expects to run in and throw a proposal on the table and vote on it. It's going to be painstakingly worked out sentence by sentence and debate by debate over a longer period of time.''
Although some last-minute changes are possible, these are the likely participants in the budget negotiations:

LENGTH: 646 words

HEADLINE: Of German Pride and German Conscience

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Like A. M. Rosenthal (column, May 3), I visited Auschwitz (and Birkenau) last month and have also been back to Germany, where I was born, the child of Holocaust survivors. My parents were born in Poland and lost, as did almost all Polish Jews, most of their families.
Growing up in West Germany, I lived well, went to school and university without experiencing anti-Semitism (except for an occasional stupid remark, which did not antagonize me). In the beginning 1980's, however, as I turned 30, I felt a change. 
More and more often I encountered among average Germans indifference and a lack of sensitivity concerning the Hitler regime and the Holocaust, and I decided to come to the United States. It was not anti-Semitism or denial of facts about the Holocaust but a dilution and diminution of its importance which I noticed and found unacceptable.
Certainly, my own sensitivity had increased, but there was also a palpable change of atmosphere, which somewhat coincided with West Germany's development into an economic superpower and with Helmut Kohl's becoming Chancellor. Obviously, there was desire and there was room for national pride, and statements by Mr. Kohl and others pointed to their determination not to allow the national heritage of the Holocaust to overshadow their wishes to feel proud as Germans again, wishes that they shared with many of their countrymen. I believe that this was palpable several years before Bitburg (1985) and the demonstrative inclusion of members of Waffen-SS into the honorable part of the German national heritage, unfortunately with the support of Ronald Reagan (whose talent not to remember was already remarkable at that time).
I understood then that time must go on and that there is real dilemma. West Germany has since 1948 (with few exceptions) been a liberal democracy and contributed much to the unification of Western Europe. Most Germans alive today have no reason to feel guilty for the crimes committed by those Germans who supported or followed or allowed themselves to be used by the Nazis, and most Germans understandably do not want to be burdened with the heritage of the Holocaust.
When I visited Germany recently, however, I did get the impression that a new conscience and interest in and finally an acceptance of the Holocaust is emerging. This development has been credited to the philosophical influence of West German President Richard von Weizsaecker.
However, after a visit to Auschwitz or whenever one just begins to think of the cruelty of the Nazi ideas and of the cruelty of the executioners of those ideas, one feels the urge to speak up for the many whose voices are gone forever: Do not allow what happened to us to be forgotten. Do not let it happen again to whomever, whenever, wherever! With due respect to Mr. Rosenthal's opinion, I do not think that choosing Auschwitz as the place where ''documented German unification and reconciliation with the world should be signed'' would help this purpose. In my belief Auschwitz belongs only to the dead and to their memory. One should walk humbly there and not make much noise. The symbolism of staging the act of reunification of Germany there is understandable, but it is too bizarre.
I am sure that there are better ways to assure that the end of the German separation will not efface the history of the Second World War and the Holocaust, which led to this separation. My suggestion is to retain a part of the Berlin Wall, namely where it cuts to the center of Berlin around the Brandenburg Gate, and to use this area - as it is or with monuments -as a memorial to the victims of Nazi Germany. The center of Berlin, which in the future may well become the center of a unified Europe, would remind and warn generations of the cruelty of which man was and is capable.
 
J. S. SIERATZKI
 New York, May 6, 1990

HEADLINE: Let Private Lawyers Prosecute S & L Fraud

 BODY:
To the Editor:
Attorney General Richard Thornburgh says the Government is unlikely to prosecute all the more than 1,300 major savings-and-loan fraud cases for lack of staff (news story, April 27). I suggest that private lawyers bid to handle these cases for a percentage of the recovery. The higher they estimate the chance of winning a case or the size of the judgment, the more they will want that case and the lower will be the percentage they will bid as their contingency fee.
The taxpayer's burden will be eased a bit and the typical citizen's confidence in the legal system will be increased by seeing that justice was served upon the perpetrators of the biggest white-collar crime wave in the history of the United States.
 
MARK E. SCHAEFER
Associate Professor of Economics
Georgia State University
 Atlanta, May 5, 1990

HEADLINE: Subsidized Housing Hurt in Ailing Market

BYLINE: By ANTHONY DePALMA

 BODY:
As real-estate prices continue to decline throughout the Northeast, one casualty of the falling market is some of the cheapest housing of all, subsidized housing.
After Federal construction subsidies were largely ended in the early 1980's, many housing programs began offering builders incentives to include lower-priced homes in their developments. In many cases, a builder would be allowed to put up additional residences in return for offering some at reduced prices.
For local governments, these subsidies were a relatively painless way to build affordable housing without tax money.
But those incentives worked only when large numbers of houses and apartments were selling in a lively real-estate market. As the market sags and auctions and distress sales must be used to sell what is already on hand, developers are reluctant to enter into projects that rely on these types of subsidies because they depend on building even more units. 
''I don't know of anyone trying to move a new Mount Laurel project,'' said Patrick J. O'Keefe, executive vice president of the New Jersey Builders' Association, referring to subsidized housing undertaken as a result of the state's Mount Laurel court decisions, which require all communities to provide some affordable housing. The loss of this kind of subsidized housing will generally hurt working families with incomes under $35,000 a year, the same families that even with the drop in house prices are shut out of the Northeast's housing market.
Communities across the nation have tried these subsidies, but they have been most heavily used in the Northeast, where the demand for housing had been so great that until recently almost anything built could be sold.
About 50 communities in California, including San Francisco, use the subsidies, but the real-estate market there has held up better than in the Northeast and officials say most of their programs are unaffected.
Affordable housing programs in New York City and its suburbs have been weakened, as have similar efforts in Massachusetts and Connecticut. But the greatest effect is being felt in New Jersey, where market-driven subsidies are at the heart of its court-ordered Mount Laurel housing plan.
''As market rate units are slowing, the delivery of Mount Laurel housing will be slowing,'' said Ara K. Hovnanian, a member of the State Council on Affordable Housing, and president of K. Hovnanian Enterprises of Red Bank, N.J., the state's largest builder of Mount Laurel housing.
''For the first two months of the year, building permits were off 30 percent,'' he said. ''I'd expect Mount Laurel deliveries to be off 30 percent.''
New Jersey does not keep such figures, but interviews with developers and local government leaders indicate that affordable housing production is slowing.
 
Bankrupt With Houses Unfinished
Hovnanian, for example, is completing 225 subsidized town houses in three suburban projects that were started years ago, but besides one other project in Newark, it has no others using internal subsidies. Before the most recent projects, it had built 1,612 subsidized houses, most of them after 1983.
Smaller companies have been hurt so badly that they have stopped building in midstream. In Old Tappan in Bergen County, the developers of Knickerbocker Village declared bankruptcy before any of the 57 houses were finished. The 12 that were supposed to be subsidized were never built.
Others developers are simply waiting until market conditions change, though they can be reluctant to admit it.
In Princeton, 60 of the 300 homes at Calton Homes' White Farm development are to be set aside for low- and moderate-income families. The project has been given preliminary approval, but Anita Robinson, administrative secretary of the Regional Planning Board of Princeton, said the market has held back the developer. ''We haven't heard a word from them,'' she said. #145,000 Affordable Houses Needed A vice president of Calton, Richard M. Griffith, said the company is obliged to meet all of its Mount Laurel obligations and that ''current market conditions have not affected our willingness to proceed.''
The subsidy programs vary. Some let developers build more houses than zoning allows if they set aside 20 percent for the poor; others use profits to write down costs on a few units in the same project or another across town. But all the programs depend on a market that could absorb large numbers of houses or apartments, some at very high prices.
Those market conditions describe New Jersey in the years following the State Supreme Court's Mount Laurel ruling in 1983.
Internal subsidies have been used to help construct 75 percent of the 8,000 Mount Laurel housing units that have been built, according to the Alliance for Affordable Housing, a nonprofit group. The state Council on Affordable Housing has estimated that New Jersey needs more than 145,000 affordable houses.
 
Gone Too Far to Stop
The current slowdown began just as it appeared that many suburban communities had finally decided to end their long opposition to the Mount Laurel dictates and were including subsidized housing projects in their plans. Affordable housing production was just starting to pick up steam when the market stumbled.
Many projects begun before 1988 have gone too far to stop, regardless of current conditions. Morris Township, Lawrence Township and Bridgewater in New Jersey all have current projects with Mount Laurel components. The Hills, in Somerset County, the largest residential development in the state, also continues to build, and has about 50 Mount Laurel homes under way.
Experts say the full impact will be felt in a few years. Joseph J. Seneca, a professor of economics at Rutgers University, said that building permits are running at less than 30,000 a year, compared with more than 60,000 in the peak building years of the 1980s.
''Why build four houses when you can't sell one?'' Mr. Seneca asked.
 
'Just When We Need It Most'
Several housing production programs in New York City also depend on the subsidies, and experts say they are all in trouble. That is especially worrisome because city and state budget problems are likely to result in diminished housing subsidies.
''Just when we need it most we're wiped out,'' said Kathryn Wylde, president of the New York City Housing Partnership, a nonprofit group that helps build affordable houses.
Ms. Wylde said her organization has decided to delay three mid-rise buildings in Harlem that would contain 800 apartments. She said that in the current market there is no way to sell 80 unsubsidized units at $200 a square foot to provide subsidies that, combined with city money, would reduce prices on 160 others to $75 a square foot. The remaining 560 apartments would be sold at cost.
Ms. Wylde said the subsidies have become ''tools we can no longer use anywhere in the city.'' Projects proposed for Clinton, Roosevelt Island and the Seward Park urban renewal area of the Lower East Side have been stalled.
 
Mixed Impact in Connecticut
Massachusetts has an array of these programs, and many of them are strained by an overbuilt and declining market. ''We've had some projects scuttled, some that are on hold,'' said Amy S. Anthony, secretary of the state's Executive Office of Communities and Development. ''Our solicitation of new projects has slowed.''
In Connecticut the impact is mixed. The state plans to buy unsold condominiums and use them for public housing. But a new law that establishes a special panel of judges to hear cases in which towns have rejected affordable-housing projects using subsidies and other assistance may be rendered temporarily useless because of the market slowdown.
The director of policy and planning for Connecticut's Department of Housing, Patricia Downs, said she knew of no developer or nonprofit group waiting to file under the new law when it takes effect July 1.
In Yonkers, officials say the city has been forced to amend its long-range plan to meet a housing desegregation order. The plan called for 4,000 new houses to be built, 3,200 at market rates and 800 to be subsidized with assistance from the full-priced houses.
Nothing has been built, and Karen V. Hill, executive director of the city's Fair Housing Implementation Office, said the city will now rely on tax abatements, zoning variances and state housing assistance.

HEADLINE: Cheating on Sleep: Modern Life Turns America Into the Land of the Drowsy

BYLINE: By NATALIE ANGIER

 BODY:
IF it is sleep that knits up the raveled sleeve of care, then an overwhelming number of Americans are walking around with distinctly tatty shirtcuffs.
Experts in sleep behavior and sleep disorders have found that a majority of people are sleeping at least an hour to 90 minutes less each night than they should. That discovery may not surprise hard-driving workers who scorn the call to relax, but sleep researchers say that even those level-headed people who think they put in a reasonable stint in bed each night probably suffer from some degree of sleep deprivation.
''People cheat on their sleep, and they don't even realize they're doing it,'' said Dr. Howard P. Roffwarg, director of the Sleep Study Unit at the University of Texas Southwestern Medical School in Dallas. ''They think they're O.K. because they can get by on six and a half hours, when they really need seven and a half, eight or even more to feel ideally vigorous.'' 
Basing their conclusions on recent surveys, experiments at sleep disorder clinics, trends in the labor force toward shift work and night work, and the swelling number of Americans who suffer from sleep pathologies and chronic fatigue, sleep scientists insist that there is virtually an epidemic of sleepiness in the nation.
''I can't think of a single study that hasn't found people getting less sleep than they ought to,'' said Dr. David F. Dinges, a biological psychologist at the Institute of Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia.
Sleep experts compare sleep deprivation with another common problem, that of excess weight. ''Some people are a couple of pounds overweight, and it's no big deal,'' said Dr. Thomas Roth, director of the Sleep Disorders Center at Henry Ford Hospital in Detroit. ''Others are obese, and that can be life-threatening.''
Likewise, experts say that mild sleep deprivation is not terribly worrisome, although they believe that people would be more productive, good-humored and satisfied with life if they were able to get a full complement of sleep each night. But when sleep deprivation becomes chronic and extensive, they say, it can have serious consequences, leading to gravely impaired judgment and an increase in automobile and industrial accidents.
So apparent are the potential hazards of chronic sleep deprivation that Congress, as part of an omnibus health bill passed in 1988, has asked a panel of a dozen sleep scientists to conduct a comprehensive study of the subject, to be completed by mid-1991. The commission will attempt to gauge the economic and medical impact of sleep disorders and sleep deprivation and suggest ways that the Government might help ease worker fatigue.
''The Government is finally waking up to the problem of sleep deprivation,'' said Dr. Mary Carskadon, a sleep researcher at Brown University and a member of the commission.
There has yet to be a large-scale epidemiological study of the nation's sleep habits, but sleep researchers have gathered insights about sleep deprivation by studying defined groups, particularly young adults and the elderly, and then estimating from those findings how many people over all are getting less than an ideal amount of sleep.
In a new analysis of several health surveys of 21,000 people 65 years and older, the National Institute on Aging found that more than 50 percent reported sleeping badly and feeling poorly rested upon waking. If applied to the older population as a whole, said Dr. Andrew Monjan, a sleep researcher at the institute, at least 13 million Americans are aware enough of their chronic sleep deficiency to cite it as a source of misery.
More revealing of the problem of hidden sleep deprivation is a series of studies of several hundred college and graduate students between the ages of 18 and 30, conducted over the past several years at Stanford University, Brown University and the Henry Ford Hospital.
In one representative experiment with the young adults, who were generally healthy and got an average of seven to eight hours sleep a night, sleep researchers discovered that 20 percent of these apparently normal students could fall asleep almost instantaneously throughout the day if allowed to lie down in a darkened room. That sleep pattern matched ones exhibited by narcoleptics and others suffering from clinical sleep pathologies - evidence, the researchers said, that the students, despite having had what most would consider a perfectly reasonable amount of sleep, were nevertheless sleep-deprived.
The sleep researchers further discovered that even the students who seemed alert and did not quickly fall asleep under test conditions could benefit from more sleep. If they spent one week getting to bed an hour to 90 minutes earlier than usual, the students improved their performance markedly on psychological and cognitive tests.
To sleep researchers, such results strongly suggest that most, if not all, people who think they are sleeping enough would be better off with an extra portion of rest.
As added evidence that people do not sleep enough, Dr. Wilse Webb, a psychologist at the University of Florida in Gainesville and a sleep research pioneer, cites the most pedestrian of bedside staples, the alarm clock. ''Whenever I ask an audience, how many people woke up by an alarm clock that morning, about two-thirds raise their hand,'' he said. ''If that's how you wake up every day, you're shortening your natural sleep pattern.''
Researchers also point out that ever more people are consulting sleep experts and sleep disorder clinics complaining of constant fatigue. Today there are more than 140 accredited sleep disorder centers in the United States, compared with 25 in 1980. About 1,200 clinicians are members of the American Sleep Disorders Association, a professional organization, up from 710 in 1985.
''Every year over the past decade there's been an enormous increase in our number of patients, sometimes as much as 50 percent a year,'' said Dr. Neil B. Cavey, director of the Sleep Disorders Center at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center in New York. ''And at least 40 percent of those people are suffering from some sort of extreme sleep deprivation.''
 
The Causes
After Light Bulbs Came Talk Shows Researchers trace the beginning of the sleep-deficit crisis to the invention of the light bulb a century ago. From diary entries and other personal accounts from the 18th and 19th centuries, sleep scientists have determined that the average person used to sleep about nine and a half hours a night. ''The best sleep habits once were forced on us, when we had nothing to do in the evening down on the farm, and it was dark,'' said Dr. Roffwarg.
According to surveys of school children in California and popular accounts in magazines, say researchers, that sleep schedule had been whittled dramatically, to between seven and a half and eight hours by the 1950's and 1960's. Now social and economic trends are slicing ever deeper into slumber.
Perhaps the most relentless robber of sleep, researchers say, is the complexity of the day. Whenever pressures from work, family, friends, the community and the health club mount, many people consider sleep to be the most expendable item on the agenda.
''In our society, it's considered dynamic, a feather in one's cap, to say you only need five and a half hours sleep,'' said Dr. Cavey. ''If you say you've got to get eight and a -half hours, people look at you askance, as though you lack drive and ambition.''
Also to blame is the increased prevalence of shift work, in which people either toil at night, or alternate between a day and night schedule. Researchers say that the brain has difficulty adjusting to daytime sleep or varying sleep times, which means that shift workers usually suffer a net loss of sleep. According to the Bureau of Labor Statistics, about 22 percent of all employees are shift workers.
The number of workers keyed into some aspect of the international economy likewise is soaring. Last year about 330,000 commercial planes operated by domestic carriers and tens of thousands of foreign-owned carriers took off for international destinations, carrying with them passengers destined for jet lag. Even if they are not traveling, few people in business can afford to ignore markets abroad.
''If you're in finance, the New York Stock Exchange may be closed at night, but if you don't watch Tokyo and London, you're vulnerable in the morning,'' said Dr. Dinges.
Many sleep researchers indict the availability of round-the-clock entertainment, especially the advent of all-night television. They point out that it was not so long ago that television stations signed off at midnight or 1 A.M. with ''The Star-Spangled Banner,'' a prod to many viewers to retire.
Yet another reason for the sleepiness trend is the prevalence of sleep disorders. The National Heart, Lung and Blood Institute estimates that 4 percent of all people suffer from sleep apnea, in which breathing stops repeatedly during the night, waking a person for a few seconds each time and ruining the restfulness of sleep. Researchers say that an unknown but possibly far greater number of people are chronic insomniacs, who spend their nights tossing fitfully and their days in tired misery.
''You can see how all the causes of sleep deprivation really mount up,'' said Dr. Monjan.
 
The Effects
On the Night Shift At Chernobyl Whatever the root of a person's sleep deficit, sleep scientists have devised tests to assess its extent and consequences. Researchers agree that the most accurate measurement of relative sleep deprivation is the Multiple Sleep Latency Test, devised by Dr. William Dement, director of the Stanford Sleep Disorders Center in California, along with Dr. Carskadon of Brown. Subjects are hooked up to electroencephalograms, which measure brain wave patterns, to track the precise second at which they fall asleep; they are allowed to lie down for 20 minutes in a dark room every two hours.
Those who fall asleep in under five minutes each time are considered pathologically sleep-deprived, because their sleep pattern matches that of somebody with a known sleep disease, such as apnea. An average score of between 5 and 10 minutes is borderline pathological, that between 10 to 15 is fine but not optimum and those who stay awake 15 minutes or longer are considered at their peak of restedness.
Researchers have also put subjects at sleep disorder centers through a battery of psychological and performance tests, like asking them to add up columns of numbers or to recall a passage that was read to them only minutes earlier. ''We've found that if you're sleep-deprived, performance suffers in many areas,'' said Dr. Charles Czeisler, director of Circadian and Sleep Disorders Medicine at Brigham and Women's Hospital in Boston. ''Short-term memory is impaired, the ability to make decisions is impaired, the ability to concentrate is impaired.''
Sleepy subjects have difficulty discriminating between loud and soft tones, or seeing flashes of light on a board. Because their reaction time is affected, sleep researchers say, sleep-deprived people may be more prone to making mistakes on the job. Experts note that many major industrial accidents, including the ones at Three Mile Island and Chernobyl, occurred at night, when workers who monitor equipment were probably not optimally alert.
Sleep researchers say that sleepiness is second only to drunkenness as a cause of automobile accidents. Reporting to Congress last year, the Department of Transportation said that at least 40,000 traffic accidents a year may be sleep-related, and that more than 20 percent of all drivers have fallen asleep at the wheel at least once. And in new studies, Dr. Roth has found that sleep-deprived people are impaired by smaller quantities of alcohol than are rested people, a factor that could further contribute to automobile accidents.
Dr. Dement of Stanford said he was shocked recently when he met a 30-year-old limousine driver who said he worked from 5 A.M. to midnight seven days a week. ''That man is losing up to three hours of sleep a night, and he knows he's headed for trouble,'' said Dr. Dement. ''He told me, 'I'm so sleepy it's scary.' ''
Sleep scientists have found that one bad night's sleep can make a person less efficient on mental tasks. Worse still, they say, the effects of sleep loss are cumulative. A person who chronically sleeps 90 minutes less per night during the workweek than is necessary will feel far worse on Friday than on Tuesday.
''By the fifth night, you've lost seven and a half hours, or virtually a whole night's sleep,'' said Dr. Dinges. ''That's the day when you're just praying to get through it.''
Sleep deprivation also destroys a person's capacity to feel pleasure or to laugh at a joke, which may be equally critical for getting through the workweek.
Trying To Cope More Caffeine Is Not the Answer Sleep scientists say that most people attempt to make up for the sleep deficits of the week by sleeping in on weekends, and that the tactic does help the body recoup vital sleep time. But they warn that in cases of chronic sleep deprivation, a weekend of 10-hour nights is not sufficient.
''I've had businessmen come in who are chronically sleep-deprived complaining of sleepiness they can't understand,'' said Dr. Charles P. Pollak, head of the Sleep-Wake Disorders Center at New York Hospital-Cornell University. ''They say they try sleeping longer on a weekend, but that it doesn't help. Of course a night or two doesn't help. In extreme cases, you may need six weeks of adequate sleep to reverse the effects of sleep loss.''
Scientists say that many people skate through their days on too little sleep by seeking outside stimulation, including banter with colleagues, exercise or the old standard, caffeine. But the stimulation does not solve the sleepiness; it merely masks it temporarily. ''If I start slapping you around, you'll be awake for a little while, but that stimulation is a crutch,'' said Dr. Dement. ''Withdraw it and you're back to where you started.''
Sometimes a severely sleep-deprived brain will try to snatch a break by falling into so-called microsleeps, which last for a few seconds and which may occur without a person's quite noticing it. In Mediterranean and other warm-weather countries, people often take siestas between 1 and 3 in the afternoon, to make up for their traditional late nights. Researchers say that the brain does fall into a lull in the afternoon, indicating an evolutionary predisposition toward napping, but they add that a person who has had a truly full night's sleep will not need a nap.
Sleep experts insist that the effort to squeeze ever more tasks into one's days and nights ultimately backfires. The person who invests in a full night's sleep, they say, will be more than recompensed in heightened productivity, creativity and focus.
But even sleep specialists have trouble taking their own advice. Although Dr. Dement says he is adamant about getting eight hours a night, others, in their zeal to promote the benefits of sleeping, admit that they often work themselves to exhaustion. ''I get by on maybe six, six and a half hours,'' said Dr. Cavey. ''I'm just too busy to get a good night's sleep.''

HEADLINE: Experimental Propulsion System Has No Moving Parts

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD

 BODY:
JAPAN, the United States, and perhaps the Soviet Union, are racing to perfect a revolutionary type of propulsion for ships and submarines. It has no moving parts, is virtually silent and promises great reliability at relatively low cost.
The basis for the advance is a tongue-twisting phenomenon known as magnetohydrodynamics, or MHD, in which magnetic fields are used to move water. There are no moving parts - no motors, no propellers, no gears and no drive shaft. Instead, a superconducting magnet, more efficient and powerful than conventional magnets, exerts a magnetic force on sea water passing through its core, driving water out the back and creating forward motion.
The technology is featured in the movie ''The Hunt for Red October,'' based on the book by Tom Clancy in which an advanced Soviet submarine powered by the process is hunted by the American and Soviet navies. 
In real life, scientists say MHD propulsion might find both military and civilian uses. It might economically power commercial ships and cargo submarines. And it might pave the way for a new generation of military submarines that are quieter than ever, helping them elude foes.
''It's provocative in its simplicity,'' said Dr. Michael Petrick, a scientist who directs research on the idea at the Argonne National Laboratory in Illinois. ''But there's lots of work that needs to be done to make it viable.''
Questions to be answered include both its technical feasibility and utility. So far, the idea has undergone no known large-scale trial, although that is about to change.
Early next year, the Japan Foundation for Shipbuilding Advancement plans to launch a 100-foot-long, prototype MHD-powered ship that will carry up to 10 people. The test is a sea trial for commercial operations.
And the Argonne lab is spearheading a military-sponsored program that centers on a 21-foot-long, 180-ton monster superconducting magnet. Its trials, confined to the laboratory, are to begin early next year. In a different project, the Navy is considering sea trials for MHD propulsion.
''The marriage of an MHD propulsion system to underwater vehicles is a natural,'' said Dr. Daniel W. Swallom, who manages the Navy-financed program on the propulsion system at the Avco Research Laboratory in Everett, Mass. His program's goal is an open-ocean test with a remotely piloted vehicle.
The Soviet Union has carried out much basic research on this form of propulsion, but intelligence experts are at odds on whether the Russians are applying the idea to their submarines.
Magnetohydrodynamics involves magnetic fields (magneto) and fluids (hydro) that conduct electricity and interact (dynamics). The phenomenon occurs naturally in the Earth's core, giving rise to the planet's magnetic field.
In MHD propulsion, a pair of electrodes on either side of the thruster pass an electric current through sea water. The process does not work effectively with fresh water because it can carry little current. At a right angle to the current is the magnetic field generated by the superconducting magnet. The interaction of the magnetic field and the current produces a strong force on the water, moving it through the duct in the center of the magnet. If the polarity of the current is reversed, so is the direction of thrust.
The action is identical to what happens with an electric motor when its magnetic field crosses a bundle of copper wires carrying an electric current, causing it to move and the central shaft of the motor to rotate.
The activity in each case revolves around charged particles. In the motor, the current-filled wires are filled with moving electrons, which carry a negative charge, and are strongly acted upon by the magnetic field. In MHD propulsion, the electric current flowing through the seawater causes the formation of charged particles, or ions, which in a similar manner are acted upon by the powerful field of the superconducting magnet. It propels both the ions and the seawater.
The direction of the force is at right angles to the matrix formed by the current and magnetic field. This effect, known as the Lorentz force, was first quantified by the Dutch physicist Hendrik Antoon Lorentz in the late 19th century.
 
'The Same Old Story'
This form of propulsion was conceived and tested in the United States more than two decades ago but languished until the advent of superconducting magnets. These can be made very powerful and very efficient because, when their coils are cooled almost to absolute zero, they lose no electricity to resistance.
In the late 1980's, Japan became the first nation to publicly embark on a sizable program meant to achieve MHD propulsion. ''It's the same old story,'' said Dr. Petrick at Argonne. ''The idea evolves in this country but someone else picks it up and runs with it.''
Leading the Japanese work is the Foundation for Shipbuilding Advancement, a private concern working with Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, Hitachi Zosen and Mitsui Engineering and Shipbuilding. The foundation is believed to have spent about $31 million on the research since 1987.
''They've gotten the best people from industry, government and the universities to work on this thing,'' said William J. Andahazy, a staffer on the House Armed Services Committee who was once associated with the American MHD effort.
The Japanese work focuses on the 100-foot ship, whose top speed is to be eight knots. It has two MHD thrusters on two huge fins protruding from the craft's hull, according to a paper by the foundation. A thruster is made up of six magnetic modules, each fitted with a sea-water duct some 10 inches in diameter. One thruster assembly is being built by Mitsubishi Heavy Industries, and the other, with a slightly different configuration, by the Toshiba Corporation.
 
A $12 Million Magnet
The Japanese ship is simply a technology test, its small thrusters being relatively inefficient. If the technique is to work commercially, magnets must become lighter, larger and more powerful.
The Japanese work has helped increase American interest in MHD propulsion, although the Defense Department had been studying it for many years. At Argonne, a $4 million program seeking potential Navy applications is under way sponsored by the Pentagon's Defense Advanced Research Projects Agency.
The centerpiece of the lab's work is a huge $12 million superconducting magnet originally built for research on super-efficient generation of electricity from coal. The program's funds were cut, so the giant magnet was never used. Argonne is adapting the behemoth to search for subtle troubles that might complicate the MHD process for large volumes of water.
The big magnet's water channel, 20 inches in diameter, will speed 25,000 gallons of water per minute through a 75-foot closed loop, giving researchers their first clues about the feasibility of full-scale MHD propulsion. If no show-stoppers crop up, the next challenge will be engineering, mainly making heavy superconducting magnets much lighter and more powerful.
''Because the conductivity of sea water is so low, you have to go to very large sizes on the thruster, with big superconducting magnets,'' said Argonne's Dr. Petrick. ''They have to be lightweight. All that's going to require almost a breakthrough.'' The problem is that superconducting magnets are so strong they literally try to tear themselves apart. Intense magnetic fields cause tiny movements of internal parts and coils, in turn generating heat that can trigger the violent loss of superconductivity. To solve the problem, magnet designers use heavy metal fixtures to inhibit movement.
For ships and submarines, said Dr. Petrick, the new generation of super-strong, super-light composite materials would have to be applied to the making of superconducting magnets. ''Theoretically, you can exceed the efficiencies of propellers,'' he said.
 
An 'Acoustic Signature'
Even at low efficiencies, MHD propulsion may be attractive to the military because of its relative silence. Much tracking of enemy submarines centers on listening for the sounds generated by complex power trains and propellers.
MHD propulsion, notes a recent statement from the Navy's David Taylor Research Center in Annapolis, Md., ''offers the potential for an extremely quiet system for propelling underwater vehicles.''
Potential problems from the Navy's point of view include hydrogen bubbles given off at the system's electrode from the electrolysis, or breaking into component parts, of sea water. The bubbles, according to the Taylor statement, ''have an acoustic signature and may produce a visible wake.'' Potential solutions, it said, include gasless electrodes and bubble capture.
Another potential hurdle is a magnetic ''signature,'' or detectable signal. This might be reduced by special magnet designs or shielding.
Hopeful of solutions, the Navy is now building a $1.2 million facility in Newport, R.I., to study the use of superconducting magnets in undersea propulsion. MHD, said the Taylor statement, ''could provide a revolutionary new propulsion system for underwater vehicles in the next century.''
Intelligence experts are divided on where the Soviets stand in the propulsion field. The Russians have published many scientific papers on the topic and have pioneered all kinds of MHD technology.
Some experts say the Soviets have even been trying it at sea, noting the long pods atop the vertical rudder of all first-rank Soviets nuclear attack submarines. However, other experts disparage such analysis, saying the pods are probably for stowing sensors that can be towed behind the submarines. Soviet MHD propulsion, they say, can only be found in fictional exploits such as ''The Hunt for Red October.''

GRAPHIC: photo: The Race For 'Red October': The mysterious propulsion system powering the submarine Sean Connery commands in the movie ''Hunt for Red October'' is actually under development in several labs. The system, magnetohydrodynamics, involves running an electric current through water in a powerful magnetic field. The interaction of the current and the magnetic field produces a strong force on the water, moving it out through the back of the thruster. If the direction of the current is reversed, so is the direction of thrust.; diagrams

HEADLINE: THE DOCTOR'S WORLD;
Despite Many Shifts, Oath as Old as Apollo Endures in Medicine

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE K. ALTMAN, M.D.

 BODY:
AS America's newest physicians receive their degrees, many will swear to the Hippocratic oath, one of the most enduring documents in history.
The oath is attributed to Hippocrates, a Greek physician in the 5th century B.C., but no one is certain about its origins and use over the last 25 centuries. Even today not every medical graduate swears to Hippocrates's standards of professional behavior and the wording of the oath may change from year to year, even in the same medical school.
Doctors probably did not begin swearing to the Hippocratic oath until about 1100. But ''it is as hard to find a carefully researched history of the oath as it is to find out its current use,'' said Dr. Albert R. Jonsen, who heads the department of medical history and ethics at the University of Washington in Seattle. ''There is a lot of mythology about the oath,'' he said. 
Contrary to widespread impression, doctors are not required to take any oath. Another surprise is that the Hippocratic oath is seldom studied in medical school, even at a time of heightened interest in medical ethics. For many doctors, the graduation ceremony is the first and only encounter with the Hippocratic oath.
This single encounter leaves little lasting impression about its content among many physicians, according to a small survey reported in a recent issue of Academic Medicine, published by the Association of American Medical Colleges.
The indifference reflects a feeling among many medical leaders that the oath is inadequate for the enormous scientific, economic, political and social changes that medicine has undergone since ancient Greeks swore to pagan gods and goddesses and relied on garlic poultices and other treatments long discarded. Because ancient physicians could do so little for patients, they did not share the modern physician's problem of differentiating between what can be done and what ought to be done.
Yet many others yearn for traditional values and say that the Hippocratic oath and other ancient codes deserve greater emphasis in medical education. Times may have changed but general principles should not, they say in pointing out that medical leaders are now criticizing their own colleagues for greed, fraud, cheating and even stealing the books for their courses on medical ethics. The oath covers obligations to professional colleagues and patients. Much of it seems sensible, like proscribing sex with patients and breaches of confidentiality. But a literal interpretation would also eliminate tuitions for students that now can reach $24,300 a year.
Many of the oath's principles or moral rules, like prohibiting abortions, have been modified by laws, judicial decisions, professional customs and medical advances.
Physicians now are supposed to report cases of certain communicable diseases to health departments and, in some areas, must inform sexual partners that a patient is infected with the AIDS virus. Confidentiality is further eroded by demands from the Government and private health insurance carriers for access to the contents of medical records.
The original version would leave surgery to a once separate guild; now surgeons are an integral part of the medical profession. And the oath forbids euthanasia, something some physicians practice openly and many more practice in secret. Other points in the oath conflict with trends that have developed over recent years.
Paternalism, for example, is central to the oath; doctors who swear to it promise healing according to their judgment and skills, but the oath ignores the wishes of the patient. The oath also fosters professional secrecy. Today, a prevailing belief is that medical knowledge belongs to the community.
Scholars are skeptical that universal adherence to the oath ever existed. That doctors performed abortions and had sexual relations with patients in ancient Greece is obvious from the proscriptions in the oath. Recent surveys have found that about 5 percent of physicians have admitted to sexual intercourse with their patients.
The humanizing theme of the oath is reiterated in a long list of oaths and codes from Judaism, Christianity, Moslem, Hindu, Chinese and many other religions and cultures.
Many graduating classes write their own oaths. Others use an oath written in 1964 by Dr. Louis Lasagna, now a dean at Tufts University Medical School in Boston. His oath included such vows as emphasizing prevention over cure.
Which oaths are used at which schools is not known. Spokesmen for the Association of American Medical Colleges and the American Medical Association said neither organization had conducted a survey of the oaths given in medical school because the issue was a low priority.
The latest published survey was conducted in 1977 among 112 medical schools in the United States and 16 in Canada by Walter J. Friedlander of the University of Nebraska College of Medicine. An oath was administered in 94 percent of the United States medical schools and 63 percent of the Canadian institutions.
In this country, 6 percent of the schools offered the classic Hippocratic oath and 42 percent a modified version. The Declaration of Geneva, a modernized version of the oath that was written by the World Medical Association in 1948, was administered in 28 percent of medical schools. Ten percent offered the Prayer of Maimonides, an ethical guide to medicine attributed to the 12th century rabbi, physician and philosopher.
The basic axiom of medical ethics, ''above all, do no harm,'' is often attributed to the oath. But the axiom comes from another Hippocratic work, ''Epidemics.''
If the oath is a rock and fortress of medicine, as many contend, it ought to be administered on entry to medical school, used as a takeoff point in classes for further study of the history and ethics of medicine, and repeated at graduation.
A major obstacle to wider study of the oath and other codes is a prevailing belief among medical educators that most students do not find them relevant. Dr. Jonsen says he includes the oath in his course in Seattle and asks students to recite it just before they begin caring for patients for the first time.
Despite a crowded curriculum, medical schools might find room for more discussion of the oath and medical history. As a continuing reminder of the noble tradition of medicine, doctors who take oaths should hang copies along with diplomas and professional honors in their offices as is seldom the practice now.
 
'I swear by Apollo . . .'
Classical Hippocratic Oath
Attributed to Hippocrates, fifth century B.C.
I swear by Apollo, the physician, . . . that according to my ability and judgment, I will keep this oath and stipulation: to reckon him who taught me this art equally dear to me as my parents, to share my substance with him and relieve his necessities if required; to regard his offspring as on the same footing with my own brothers, and to teach them this art if they should wish to learn it, without fee or stipulation and that by precept, lecture and every other mode of instruction. . . .
I will follow that method of treatment which, according to my ability and judgment, I consider for the benefit of my patients, and abstain from whatever is deleterious and mischievous. I will give no deadly medicine to anyone if asked, nor suggest any such counsel; furthermore, I will not give to a woman an instrument to produce an abortion.
With purity and holiness I will pass my life and practice my art. I will not cut a person who is suffering with a stone, but will leave this to be done by practitioners of this work. Into whatever houses I enter I will go unto them for the benefit of the sick and will abstain from every voluntary act of mischief and corruption; and further from the seduction of females or males, bond or free.
Whatever, in connection with my professional practice or not in connection with it, I may see or hear in the lives of men, which ought not be spoken abroad, I will not divulge . . .
 
Oath for New Doctors
Written by Dr. Louis Lasagna in 1964.
I swear to fulfill, to the best of my ability and judgment, this covenant:
I will respect the hard-won scientific gains of those physicians in whose steps I walk, and gladly share such knowledge as is mine with those who are to follow.
I will apply, for the benefit of the sick, all measures which are required, avoiding those twin traps of overtreatment and therapeutic nihilism.
I will remember that there is art to medicine as well as science, and that warmth, sympathy and understanding may outweigh the surgeon's knife or the chemist's drug.
I will not be ashamed to say ''I know not,'' nor will I fail to call in my colleagues when the skills of another are needed for a patient's recovery.
I will respect the privacy of my patients, for their problems are not disclosed to me that the world may know. Most especially must I tread with care in matters of life and death. If it is given me to save a life, all thanks. But it may also be within my power to take a life; this awesome responsibility must be faced with great humbleness and awareness of my own frailty. Above all, I must not play at God.
I will remember that I do not treat a fever chart, or a cancerous growth, but a sick humanbeing, whose illness may affect his family and his economic stability. My responsibility includes these related problems, if I am to care adequately for the sick.
I will prevent disease whenever I can, for prevention is preferable to cure.
I will remember that I remain a member of society, with social obligations to all my fellow men, those sound of mind and body, as well as the infirm. . . .

HEADLINE: Singapore Aim: High-Tech Future

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: SINGAPORE

 BODY:
For most of the 25 years since it became an independent state, Singapore has found industrial fortune by luring many of the world's best manufacturers, first American, then Japanese. It offered a haven of inexpensive but highly skilled labor and Government-supported factories that could be up and running in weeks.
Today, though, companies looking for low-cost labor are politely directed to neighboring countries like Malaysia or Thailand. Singapore is trying to become, in a modest way, the Japan of Southeast Asia: a nation that fosters and attracts research and development, automation and technologies that go far beyond its assemble-it-here image.
 
Risky Strategy
What the Government cannot attract, it has begun to buy. For the first time, in another move reminiscent of Japan, Singapore is actively scouting the United States and Europe for promising high-technology companies that it can snap up and use to hone its own industrial skills. 
This strategy is perhaps the last phase of economic development to be led by Prime Minister Lee Kuan Yew, who is scheduled to step down later this year. Brooking little dissent or second-guessing, Mr. Lee has dominated even the minutiae of planning since Singapore gained its independence from Malaysia in 1965.
But the strategy he has chosen now is risky, for it is unclear whether Singapore has the critical mass of population, universities and high-technology companies to support the ambitions of Mr. Lee's Government. So fearful is the Government that its 2.7 million people will not be enough that it is racing to build more support and incentives for research and is even encouraging young couples to have more children.
Officially, Singaporeans express few doubts that their future holds careers as researchers, software engineers and biotechnology specialists - not factory workers. The effort is starting in places like Singapore Technologies, a conglomerate of companies spun off from Singapore's Government-owned and well-financed concerns that make military goods, probably the strongest base of native technology.
Already, Singapore Technologies has bought a share in a promising Silicon Valley chip company, Sierra Semiconductors; made a faltering entry into the personal computer market, and dipped into joint ventures in everything from telephone switching software to jet engines.
''Our vision is to create a technology base for the nation, an engineering company that will be the first multinational based in Singapore,'' said Wong Kok Siew, the president of the new company, in his office in one of the city's many gleaming new towers. ''We plan to manufacture in any country in the world where there is an advantage - to make things in Thailand where the cost is low, in Germany because the market is big, to do R.& D. in Boston.''
 
Foreign Investment
Like almost every other economic strategy Singapore has adopted in the last two decades, this one depends on foreign participation. Eighty-nine percent of the $1 billion in direct investment here last year came from abroad. And with few native-developed technologies to offer, Singapore is depending on its arsenal of tax incentives and its strategic location in the heart of Asia's flourishing markets to persuade companies to make Singapore a center of design as well as manufacturing.
''Foreign investment has provided us over the years with jobs and markets,'' said How Peck-Huat, the director of the services promotion division of the country's powerful Economic Development Board. ''But now our plants are more automated and our skills much higher. What we need is production technology. We need to learn how to design integrated circuits; we need companies willing to do serious R.& D. that will train our people.''
As Hong Kong, Taiwan and South Korea have learned, it is exactly those skills that countries like Japan are loath to part with. The strategy of Japan, and to some extent of the United States, has been to keep the highest ''value added'' skills at home. Thus, while Japanese companies make computers all around Asia, they do most of their software research in Japan. While videocassette recorders are produced everywhere, most recording heads - the high-technology, expensive components -are rarely made outside Japan.
''If the critical components are made elsewhere, what does it help?'' said Mr. How. ''The value then goes elsewhere.''
 
Signs of Success
There are some early signs that Singapore's efforts are succeeding, if modestly. The Hewlett-Packard Company runs Singapore's largest research and development operation, designing many products for Asia here, and it is one of the few multinational companies that has put Singaporeans into the most senior management posts. The Japanese have not -just as they have not put Americans into the most senior posts of branch offices in the United States. Yet Matsushita, Japan's electronics giant, has, after years of resistance, set up a research and development divison in audio-visual equipment and information technology in Singapore, though it is still dwarfed by the company's manufacturing operations here.
''The only way to get Government incentives now,'' said Eugene Chan, director of domestic marketing at the company, ''is to bring in the very highest technology you can.''
In fact, if companies came first for low-cost labor, they are staying for other reasons: the huge availability of electronic components and other supplies here, the ease of communication and transportation, and the political stability of Mr. Lee's Government. Stability seems especially valuable at a time when Hong Kong and the Philippines seem vulnerable to political turmoil.
The quickness with which companies have adjusted is remarkable. At the sprawling Apple Computer Inc. plant, on a street that looks as though it could be in Silicon Valley in California, Apple II and Macintosh computers came down a production line that turns out a huge slice of Apple's yearly output even though the factory employs only 600 people.
''We could build a plant like this almost anywhere,'' said James L. Forquer, the managing director of Apple's Singapore manufacturing operations, as he walked past machines that were placing and soldering chips on circuit boards, one of the laborious tasks that companies used to come to Singapore to do by hand. But now the process goes on even as the few workers leave the floor for a coffee break. ''The difference here is the source of supply,'' he said. ''Just-in-time delivery is fabulous.'' Most big American chip manufacturers have plants within miles of Apple's factory, and more than half of the world's supply of disk drives for small computers are produced in Singapore.
But what the Government is most interested in at Apple's plant is a small room upstairs, overlooking the manufacturing operation. There Apple recently began development work on video screens for future models. ''It is an area where most of the current technology, particularly in manufacturing, is not in the U.S. anymore,'' Mr. Forquer said.
 
Obstacles Remain
Whether efforts like Apple's will flourish into full-scale research and development centers is questionable. Video screens are important, but are only a small part of the value of an Apple personal computer. While highly skilled labor here is still relatively inexpensive - a software engineer with seven years' experience earns about $1,700 a month - Singapore still lacks the nexus of universities, entrepreneurial companies and experienced engineers to attract the biggest value-added work.
One reason is the shortage of the most highly skilled labor. For years, the Government declined to disclose how many top professionals were leaving. Last year, Mr. Lee, in a speech, gave a figure of 4,700. But many local business people say anecdotal evidence suggests that is too low.
Many of those who leave are reacting to a combination of opportunities abroad and a Government that retains extraordinary control over its workers. Young people who were trained abroad invariably use words like sterile and stifling to describe the country.
Social control remains tight, with the Government seeking to assure that its three main population groups, the Malays, the Chinese and the Indians, remain contained, if not entirely harmonious. All three are mixed in the lookalike Government housing units, in precise ratios. While some people grumble, the country's atmosphere is wholly apolitical, at least publicly. ''When Tiananmen Square happened, Chinese in Hong Kong demonstrated in the streets,'' one senior American businessman here said. ''In Singapore, they just went back to their desks. Protests would have been bad for business.''
 
Opinion Polls
But in the last year or so, the Government has begun to seek public opinion on questions like housing and pensions.
The professional class says that the changes are not enough. ''There are a lot of places I can work, even in Asia, where the Government does not tell me where to work or who my neighbors will be, what newspaper I will read, or exactly how much my pay will go up,'' one Singaporean engineer complained.
How much that changes depends in large part on Mr. Lee's successors.

LENGTH: 1093 words

HEADLINE: High Court Backs Curb On Prices

BYLINE: By LINDA GREENHOUSE, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
Ruling in a closely watched antitrust case, the Supreme Court today gave new protection against antitrust liability to manufacturers that seek to improve their competitive position by imposing price ceilings on dealers.
The Court held that even if such an arrangement is an illegal conspiracy to fix prices at an artificially low level, competing dealers may not sue for damages unless the maximum resale prices are so low as to be ''predatory.''
The 7-to-2 decision overturned a ruling by a Federal appeals court in California in a case against the Atlantic Richfield Company. That 1988 ruling, by the United States Court of Appeals for the Ninth Circuit, permitted the USA Petroleum Company, an independent gasoline retailer, to sue ARCO for a policy of lowered prices that made ARCO dealers more competitive with independent discounters. 
 
No 'Antitrust Injury' Seen
Writing for the Supreme Court today, Justice William J. Brennan Jr. said that lower retail prices helped consumers and did not ordinarily create the kind of ''antitrust injury'' that competitors must show to have standing to sue under the Clayton Antitrust Act.
Because the suit has never gone to trial, the allegations by USA Petroleum against ARCO are unproved. ARCO denied forcing its dealers to lower their retail prices under a new marketing strategy it adopted in 1982, saying instead that its dealers simply passed along lowered wholesale prices.
USA Petroleum, which competes with ARCO in the retail gasoline market in California, Nevada and Washington, said it began losing $800,000 a month when ARCO adopted its 1982 pricing policy.
 
Illegal Under Sherman Act
USA Petroleum sued under the Clayton Act, which permits suits for triple damages by ''any person who shall be injured in his business or property by reason of anything forbidden in the antitrust laws.'' USA Petroleum contended that its injuries were the direct result of a price-fixing conspiracy that is automatically illegal under Section 1 of the Sherman Antitrust Act.
A Federal District Court in California dismissed the suit in 1986, agreeing with ARCO that regardless of whether the pricing policy violated the Sherman Act, USA Petroleum could not bring a private lawsuit under the Clayton Act unless it could show that the prices were ''predatory.'' The Supreme Court has never defined predatory pricing, but economists use the term to refer to a monopolist's tactic of pricing below cost to drive competitors out of business.
The District Court said ARCO's market share of 17 percent did not give it enough power to engage in predatory pricing.
But the appeals court reinstated the lawsuit in a 2-to-1 decision. Judge Stephen Reinhardt wrote for the majority that because ''price-fixing of any kind distorts in a basic way the competitive process the antitrust laws were meant to protect,'' a price-fixer's competitors had standing to bring Clayton Act suits regardless of whether the pricing was predatory.
 
Analysis Is Rejected
In the decision today, ARCO v. USA Petroleum, No. 88-1668, the Supreme Court decisively rejected this analysis. ''The antitrust injury requirement cannot be met by broad allegations of harm to the 'market' as an abstract entity,'' Justice Brennan said. He added: ''Low prices benefit consumers regardless of how those prices are set, and so long as they are above predatory levels, they do not threaten competition. Hence, they cannot give rise to antitrust injury.''
The Court rejected the argument by USA Petroleum that because price-fixing is treated in antitrust law as a ''per se,'' or automatic, violation of the Sherman Act, a competitor should automatically have standing to bring a private lawsuit under the Clayton Act.
Justice Brennan said the different approaches under the two antitrust laws served different purposes. He said the ''per se rule'' of the Sherman Act represented a ''conclusive presumption'' that certain kinds of business practices ''by their nature'' were highly likely to be anticompetitive.
 
Competition Reduction Stressed
But Justice Brennan added that private plaintiffs under the Clayton Act should not be permitted to recover damages on the basis of theoretical presumptions, but ''only if the loss stems from a competition-reducing aspect or effect of the defendant's behavior.''
Justice Brennan's opinion was joined by Chief Justice William H. Rehnquist and by Justices Thurgood Marshall, Harry A. Blackmun, Sandra Day O'Connor, Antonin Scalia, and Anthony M. Kennedy.
Justice John Paul Stevens filed a dissenting opinion that was joined by Justice Byron R. White. They accused the majority of acting in ''haste to excuse illegal behavior in the name of efficiency.'' ''In carving out this exception to the enforcement of Section 1'' of the Sherman Act, the dissenters said, ''the Court has chosen to second-guess the wisdom of our per se rules and to embark on the questionable enterprise of parsing illegal conspiracies.''
 
Suits Against Unions
In a second decision today, the Court ruled that union members may not sue their labor unions for negligence growing out of the way the union carries out its contractual responsibilities.
The 6-to-3 decision, a big victory for organized labor, overturned a ruling by the Supreme Court of Idaho. That court permitted the families of some of the 91 miners killed in a 1972 fire at the Sunshine silver mine to sue the United Steelworkers of America.
The families contended that because the union had undertaken responsibilities to prevent accidents and monitor mine safety, it was legally responsible under Idaho law for the fatal fire. The case had not yet gone to trial.
 
Federal Law Cited
Writing for the majority today, Justice White said that Federal labor law pre-empted state law in all lawsuits growing out of a union's duty under a collective bargaining agreement. Under Federal law, he added, a union's negligence, even if proved, did not breach its duty to represent its members fairly.
The steelworkers and other unions had warned that unions would be reluctant to negotiate safety clauses in contracts if they could then become targets of lawsuits. Suits by union members have been increasing, the steelworkers said, because state worker compensation laws typically permitted only small recoveries by employees against their employers.
The decision, United Steelworkers v. Rawson, No. 89-322, was joined by Justices Brennan, Marshall, Blackmun, Stevens and O'Connor. Justices Kennedy, Scalia and Chief Justice Rehnquist dissented.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS PEOPLE;
Sallie Mae Chief Takes A Post at Dartmouth

BYLINE: By DANIEL F. CUFF

 BODY:
Edward A. Fox, who built the Student Loan Marketing Association into a major financial enterprise, is leaving as its president and chief executive to become dean of the Amos Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth University.
''This came with startling speed,'' Mr. Fox said yesterday, noting that he was informed over the weekend that he had been chosen. ''I'm still coming down to earth.'' At Dartmouth, Mr. Fox, 53 years old, will succeed Colin C. Blaydon, who announced earlier this year that he planned to step down to write and do consulting work after seven years in the post. 
Mr. Fox was the first employee of Sallie Mae 17 years ago. It is a federally chartered, stockholder-owned corporation that buys insured student loans, thereby replenishing local supplies of student credit.
Mr. Fox's move, announced yesterday, coincided with the news that Ronald F. Hunt, 47, Sallie Mae's executive vice president and general counsel, plans to resign and return to North Carolina to begin a private law practice.
''He wants to be a country lawyer,'' Mr. Fox said, adding that there was no connection between the two departures. ''This is just two people making an adjustment at roughly the same time.''
The two announcements were made in Washington by Harry R. King, Sallie Mae's chairman. He said the board will meet this week to begin looking for a successor to Mr. Fox. Mr. Fox will be leaving for Dartmouth about Labor Day.
Mr. Fox, a graduate of Cornell with an M.B.A. from New York University, said he planned to apply the same amount of energy to being dean that he had put into the Sallie Mae post.
He was director of finance for the Federal Home Loan Bank System in Washington when he was chosen to start up Sallie Mae. ''I never expected that I would create a $40 billion company as an entrepreneur,'' he said.
The first five or six years were entrepreneurial, he said, and in the late 1970's demand for the company's services took off with high inflation and soaring tuitions. Of the situation then, he said, ''You don't manage it, you survive it.'' In 1983 the company was listed on the New York Stock Exchange and has become one of the larger financial services companies.
Mr. Fox said that Ross Perot, the Texas businessman, had remarked to him that not many had created such large corporations. ''Mr. Hewlett, Mr. Packard, Mr. Wang, himself,'' Mr. Fox said. ''I told him that 'you guys did two things: You created them, but you also learned how to own them.' ''

HEADLINE: Market Place;
Behind the Rally In Bank Stocks

BYLINE: By MICHAEL QUINT

 BODY:
BANKING company stocks, after being shunned by Wall Street for the last seven months, increased sharply during the stock market rally of the last two sessions, and may be treated more graciously in coming months.
The problems that caused bank shares to fall sharply persist: mounting losses from bad real estate loans and fears of losses on loans to heavily indebted companies if the economy weakens. But some analysts and investors say bank share prices have fallen enough to compensate investors for the remaining risks.
An index of bank stocks compiled by Keefe Bruyette & Woods showed that through May 11 these stocks had fallen more than 22 percent from their early-October peak; in the same period the Standard & Poor's 500 stock index slipped 1.8 percent. But from April 6 through May 11 the bank index has rebounded to gain 9.6 percent, while the S.& P. was up 4.3 percent. Yesterday, the S.& P. rose less than 1 percent, and bank stocks also gained. 
Charles P. Vincent, an analyst and money manager at the PNC Financial Corporation, a banking company, said, ''Even if you cut banks' projected 1990 earnings by a third, their current prices are looking pretty reasonable.'' After pulling out of the bank stock market last summer, he is not yet ready to buy heavily, but says, ''I think we have seen the worst of it.'' By the second half of this year, he expects many companies to be reporting higher earnings than they did a year ago.
One impetus for the surge by large banks in the last few days has been the drop in yields for Treasury securities. Declining interest rates usually help bank stocks, even though many analysts say that for many banking companies, the interest they earn on loans tends to fall at least as fast as the rates they pay on deposits.
But a decline in rates does make bank dividends more attractive, expecially for banks with common stock dividend payments so large, and presumably so reliable, that stockholders earn yields considerably higher than are available from the Treasury.
Now that Treasury bond yields have fallen to 8.57 percent, from 8.97 percent as recently as May 3, the dividend yields of several New York City banks are looking better than ever.
''To the extent the decline in bond yields continues, it is the No. 1 near-term trigger event for higher prices for money center banks,'' said Frank DeSantis, an analyst at Paine Webber Inc. Although Mr. DeSantis does not recommend buying shares of the Chemical Banking Corporation, the Chase Manhattan Corporation or the Manufacturers Hanover Corporation, he said dividends of those companies were secure, and high enough to attract investors willing to wait for improved earnings.
Chase, which pays an annual dividend of $2.48, yields 9.77 percent at yesterday's closing price of $25.375, up $1.125 in the rally of the last two sessions. Chemical, paying $2.72 annually, yields 10.41 percent at yesterday's close of $26.125, up $1 in the two days, and Manufacturers Hanover yields 9.37 percent, at a price of $35, up 75 cents.
High yields for stocks are a reliable sign of risk, just as they are with bonds. But many analysts have concluded that their dividends are safe, although they are not likely to be increased soon. By allowing Chemical to declare its 68-cent quarterly dividend on Thursday and Citicorp to raise its quarterly payment to 44.5 cents from 40.5 cents earlier this year, regulators signaled their faith that those large banking companies can both improve their earnings and strengthen their financial condition in coming quarters.
Among other large New York banks, dividend yields are lower than those at Chase, Chemical and Manufacturers Hanover, but still high by standards of past years. Citicorp closed yesterday at $23.875, up $1 for the two days, to yield 7.46 percent. J. P. Morgan & Company, whose earnings have not been rising but which remains financially the strongest New York bank, pays $1.82 annually to yield 4.89 percent at yesterday's close of $37.25, up $1.75 over the two days.
Carol Berger, a banking analyst at C. J. Lawrence, Morgan Grenfell Inc. does not recommend any New York City banking companies. But she noted that in past years investors did well if they bought large New York bank stocks when their payouts rose to an average above 8 percent.
In addition to the attraction of high dividend payments, Richard Bove, an analyst at Dean Witter Reynolds Inc., said large banks stand to benefit greatly from recent developments in Argentina and Brazil, neither of which has been paying interest on its bank debt.
He noted that last week's $60 billion increase in the International Monetary Fund's capital makes much more money available to help refinance the debts of those countries, particularly if they continue to reform their economies. Banks have already made reserves for partial losses on Latin American loans, and the resumption of even limited payments of interest by Argentina and Brazil ''would be of tremendous benefit to the large banks,'' he said.
