HEADLINE: Inventories Steady as Sales Rise

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 14

 BODY:
Businesses held inventories steady while increasing sales in March, the Commerce Department reported today.
Analysts said the report indicated that there was little threat of production cutbacks or losses of jobs.
The department said that shelf and backlot inventories were unchanged at a seasonally adjusted $794 billion. Backlogs had risen a revised four-tenths of 1 percent in February and three-tenths in January. February inventories originally were reported to have fallen by four-tenths. 
Sales rose in March by six-tenths of 1 percent, to a seasonally adjusted $539.1 billion following increases of 1.4 percent in February and four-tenths in January. The February increase was first reported at 1.3 percent.
 
View Called Realistic
What the report means, said Gilbert Benz, an economist with the Swiss Bank Corporation in New York, ''is that producers are looking very realistically at domestic demand and the possibility of a slowing overseas demand for United States-made goods and are bringing production in line with those expectations.''
He added that ''unlike a period of slow growth where businesses often get caught short with an excess buildup of stocks, in the current environment we see they are anticipating a slowdown and adjusting production so they don't have to slash inventories and cut production radically.''
March business activity produced a 1.47 ratio of inventories to sales, down from 1.48 in February and matching a January 1989 ratio that was the lowest since the current economic expansion began after the 1981-82 recession. The ratio means that it would take 1.47 months to exhaust inventories at the March pace. It peaked at 1.70 in October 1982.
 
Drop for Second Month
The decline in inventories was greatest in the manufacturing sector, dropping by three-tenths of 1 percent for the second consecutive month. However, backlogs edged up by two-tenths at the wholesale level after declining by three-tenths in February. Retail inventories rose by three-tenths after posting a loss of seven-tenths the previous month.
Sales, on the other hand, dropped by two-tenths of 1 percent at the retail level. The Commerce Department reported last week that retail sales fell by another six-tenths in April, the biggest plunge in six months. But manufacturing sales rose by 1.1 percent and wholesale sales increased by eight-tenths of 1 percent.

HEADLINE: CREDIT MARKETS;
Long-Term U.S. Securities Rise

BYLINE: By KENNETH N. GILPIN

 BODY:
The bond market rally continued yesterday, as prices of long-term Treasury securities rose in moderately active trading, and yields fell to their lowest levels since mid-April.
Credit market participants said that clients were buying in the hope that conferees in the Washington budget talks today would be able to hammer out a substantive accord to cut the Federal budget deficit.
''Based on the price action, right now we are ignoring the larger needs of the Treasury, Refcorp and all the rest,'' said David Green, head of government bond trading at Chemical Bank. ''People are focusing on the fact that something is going to come out of this budget conference.'' 
Another bond trader, who asked not to be identified, said that ''deficit reduction, arms reduction, higher taxes and fiscal responsibility are all terms that have appeared prominently in the media recently and are all phrases that give people a better feeling about bonds,'' adding, ''I think the market is in excellent shape.''
Based on the move in bond prices over the last two weeks, it is difficult to muster a case for pessimism.
Since May 1, yields on 30-year Treasury bonds have fallen by more than 40 basis points, or hundredths of a point.
The rally was unleashed on May 4 by April employment data that were much weaker than expected, suggesting the Fed would not need to tighten credit. It received further support last week from the successful auction of $30.5 billion of new Treasury notes and bonds, as well as from retail sales and inflation figures that suggest the economy is soft and that inflationary pressures are receding from their torrid first-quarter pace.
As a result of all this good news, ''domestic investors are interested again, and dealer inventories are very light,'' the bond trader said. ''That is very encouraging news.'' The bulk of yesterday's buying was concentrated in long-term Treasury securities. Prices of intermediate- to short-term issues, by comparison, did not move much.
By late in the day, the Treasury's new 8 3/4 percent benchmark bonds of 2020 were offered at a price of 101 7/8, up 5/8 point, to yield 8.57 percent, down from 8.63 percent on Friday. It is the lowest yield on the bellwether bond since April 11, when the 8 1/2 percent issue of 2020 was offered at a price to yield 8.56 percent.
Among note issues, the 8 7/8 percent 10-year notes were offered at 101 26/ 32, up 1/4 point, to yield 8.60 percent. And the 8 7/8 percent two-year notes were offered at 100 21/32, up 1/ 32, to yield 8.50 percent.
Rates on new three-month and six-month Treasury bills fell sharply at the weekly auction.
Bids on the new three-month bills produced an average discount rate of 7.67 percent, down from an average rate of 7.79 percent at last week's sale.
Meanwhile, six-month bills were auctioned at an average discount rate of 7.68 percent, compared with a rate of 7.84 percent at the auction a week ago.
 
Cause to be Optimistic
Over the years, the credit markets have tended to cast a highly cynical eye on attempts to cut the Federal budget deficit. But analysts said that this time there was some cause to be optimistic.
''The difference between a structural budget deficit of $150 billion and the Gramm-Rudman target of $64 billion is so large that there is now a willingness to take some action,'' said Neal M. Soss, chief economist at the First Boston Corporation. ''The magnitude of that gap is what has brought the President and the Congress to the threshold of a new aggreement.''
Even if a mixture of new taxes, accounting changes and revised economic assumptions pares $50 billion to $75 billion from the deficit figure, Mr. Soss said there is no reason to expect that interest rates will fall by much.
''In 1987, the year Gramm-Rudman was first implemented, the budget deficit fell by one-third,'' he said, ''but interest rates didn't go down. They went up. There is no magical link which says that lower budget deficits mean lower interest raets on a day-by-day basis.''
Encouraged by recent rate declines, a number of corporations priced new debt issues yesterday.
Among them, the Cincinnati Gas and Electric Company, offered $100 million worth of 30-year first mortgage bonds. The 10 1/8 percent bonds, which mature May 1, 2020, were priced at $99.567, to yield 10.17 percent, 1.55 percentage points over the prevailing yield on the 8 1/2 percent Treasury bonds of 2020 at the time of pricing.
The bonds, which are nonrefundable for five years, are rated Baa-1 by Moody's Investors Service and BBB-plus by the Standard & Poor's Corporation. Morgan Stanley & Company acted as lead manager for the transaction.
Activity in the secondary market for investment-grade corporate bonds was fairly light, traders said. Prices of most widely quoted issues rose by 1/4 point to 1/2 point.
In the secondary market for tax-exempt municipal bonds, traders said that prices of most actively traded issues rose by about 1/4 point.

HEADLINE: Careers;
Students Aid East Europe Businesses

BYLINE: By Elizabeth M. Fowler

 BODY:
NOW numbered in the dozens, hundreds of business school students may eventually be spending summers abroad to help Hungarian, Polish and other foreign businesses. Plans for such programs have already been disclosed at three major schools - Cornell University, the University of Michigan and the University of Pennsylvania.
James M. Jennings, a 26-year-old M.B.A. student at Cornell's Johnson Graduate School of Management, got the idea last September to introduce such a program.
''The Berlin wall was still up, so choices were between Hungary and Poland, '' he said last week. ''We decided on Hungary.'' Hungarian business had been focused on the West for some time through joint ventures, he explained. 
Eight students are going, he said, adding that Dean Alan G. Merten had a discretionary fund that will cover air fares. The five men and three women will live in dormitories at Budapest University, known until recently as Karl Marx University. Hungarian companies will pay them about $150 a month, which Mr. Jennings says is enough to cover room and food.
''We do not see ourselves as missionaries of American capitalism; we don't want to force our thinking on anyone,'' he said. ''Part of the excitement is that we are doing something positive. We will be working for entrepreneurial ventures in Budapest, sharing with them our knowledge of marketing, strategic planning and finance. They are starved for management help.''
He explained that in Hungary entrepreneurial companies were considered ''separate,'' which means only that they are apart from the central planning authority. ''We will be involved with companies that must export to gain money so that Hungary can import consumer and other goods it needs,'' he said. Hungary's growth, he stressed, would be ''export-led.''
At the University of Michigan's School of Business Administration, the initiative for students going to Poland came from Edwin L. Miller, an associate dean and professor. He said last week that the students ''will be taking part in a major historical drama while they help a controlled economy turn into a free-market one.'' He added that ''I sense an idealism like that in the early days of the Peace Corps.''
Four out of the nine going to Poland will be financed by the business school, said Kathleen Hulik, its media director. She added that a real estate developer, Samuel Zell, a graduate of the University of Michgan, had given money to help. The business school will provide the four interns with stipends of about $2,000 a month to make up for lost summer earnings. A fifth, Anne-Laurence Mace, a French exchange student, is being financed by her graduate school, L'Ecole des Hautes Etudes Commerciales, at Jouy-en-Josas, France.
Another four have ''volunteered'' to go by paying their own way, an estimated $3,500 to $4,000, including air fare.
A husband-and-wife team, Kenneth and Karen Knister, expects to rent an apartment while others will live in dormitories or with Polish families.
The nine students are now taking a crash course in Polish history, culture and language. Dr. Miller, who plans a midsummer trip to Poland, has asked them to keep day-by-day journals of their experiences.
At least two will work on financial analyses of state enterprises for the bureau of privatization, a unit of the Polish Ministry of Finance. The aim is to prepare state-owned operations for sale through public offerings or private placements.
Dr. Miller said that Doradca, a consulting firm in the city of Sopot, on the Baltic Sea near Gdansk, would assign students to work with a variety of companies that make plastics, wooden products, medicines and cosmetics, and a firm that organizes music festivals. In Cracow, a student will make marketing plans for a computer software company and another skilled in operations management is assigned to an agricultural equipment plant in Bydgoszcz.
At the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School, Bulent Gultekin, an associate professor of finance, said he tentatively planned to spend the summer helping the Polish Ministry of Finance, along with ''half a dozen Wharton students.'' The program has not been made final, he said.
Dr. Gultekin, who returned last year from a two-year stint helping the Turkish Government privatize some industries, explained that the stituation in Poland ''is like a turnaround situation'' in the United States. ''They don't have to start from scratch; however, 80 percent of the economy probably will be privatized,'' he said, noting that capital markets must be organized, including a new stock exchange.
Another Wharton group, mostly minority students, returned recently from their third and final week in St. Croix, V.I., where they helped businesses hurt by Hurricane Hugo last fall. The group - three in the graduate program and 10 undergraduate seniors - was financed by $10,000 anonymously donated by a professor and by corporate gifts.
Describing the advice offered, Suzanne Virgo, who will receive an M.B.A. this month, said she and others had helped an owner of two pharmacies, one of which was demolished by the storm, with inventory control. They also urged a soft-drink bottler to improve distribution by adding trucks.

HEADLINE: CURRENCY MARKETS;
Dollar Off More Than 2 Yen In Tokyo Morning Session

BYLINE: AP

DATELINE: TOKYO, Tuesday, May 15

 BODY:
The dollar plummeted more than 2 yen against the Japanese currency this morning. The American currency closed the morning session here at 151.15 yen, down 2.20 yen from Monday's close of 153.35 yen.
The yen's strength against the dollar bolstered Japan's stock and bond markets. 
The Nikkei stock average, which rose 530.51 points on Monday, gained 73.34 points, or 0.22 percent, to close the morning session at 32,115.99 points.
The price of the benchmark 10-year Japanese Government bond edged higher to 88.06, from Monday's close of 87.86 points. That dropped the yield to 6.945 percent, from 6.988 percent.
Currency dealers said the dollar's retreat followed its overnight decline in New York, where the American currency ended at 152.50 yen, down from 152.70 yen on Friday.
''The market's dollar-selling mood results from investors' expectations of a slowdown in the U.S. economy ahead of the release of major U.S. economic indicators,'' said Masato Hayashi, a dealer with the Bank of Tokyo.
Washington is to release its April report on industrial production today, April consumer prices and housing starts tomorrow and March trade figures on Thursday.
On Monday, the dollar was unchanged to weaker against the British pound. Sterling cost $1.6817 in London, unchanged from Friday, and $1.6825 in New York, up from $1.6790.
Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Friday's quotes, included: 1.64288 West German marks, up from 1.6380; 1.3915 Swiss francs, down from 1.3995; 5.5360 French francs, up from 5.5295; 1,208.00 Italian lire, up from 1,207.75, and 1.17715 Canadian dollars, up from 1.17575.
Late dollar rates in Europe on Monday, compared with late Friday rates, were: 1.6442 West German marks, up from 1.6300; 1.3952 Swiss francs, down from 1.3955; 5.5430 French francs, up from 5.5096; 1.8472 Dutch guilders, up from 1.8330; 1,209.75 Italian lire, up from 1,200.40, and 1.1767 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1783.
Gold prices fell after rising overseas.
On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $368.40 a troy ounce, down 40 cents from late Friday. The Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $368.10 an ounce, also 40 cents lower.
Gold rose in London to a late bid price of $369.75 an ounce, from $369.05 bid late Friday. In Zurich, gold fell to $368.75 an ounce, from $368.80 Friday.
Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell 97 cents to close at a bid $369.10 an ounce.
Silver prices gained ground. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $5.066 a troy ounce, up from $5.043 Friday. Silver rose in London to $5.09 an ounce from $5.06.

HEADLINE: Partnership in Firm Awarded to Victim of Sex Bias

BYLINE: By TAMAR LEWIN

 BODY:
A Federal district judge in Washington has ordered Price Waterhouse, one of the nation's largest accounting firms, to give a partnership to a woman who said she was denied the promotion in 1983 because of negative sexual stereotypes.
The case, which had gone to the Supreme Court and back to trial, is apparently the first in which a court has awarded partnership in a professional firm as a remedy for discrimination based on sex or race.
Throughout the 1980's there has been heated legal debate on whether accounting and law firms can be ordered to award partnerships to victims of discrimination, or whether partnership involves such special personal relationships that courts cannot intervene in a firm's decision making.
In the ruling handed down on Monday and reported yesterday in The Washington Post, the judge said that making the woman, Ann B. Hopkins, a partner at Price Waterhouse was the best way to right the wrong. 
''Ordering Price Waterhouse to simply reconsider Ms. Hopkins for partnership would be futile and unjust because the testimony of Price Waterhouse's chairman suggested that the deck is stacked against her,'' wrote the judge, Gerhard A. Gesell. ''Price Waterhouse plainly does not want her and would not voluntarily admit her. Partnership, not simply a new vote, is the logical remedy, given the finding that Ms. Hopkins was likely to have been made a partner if not for unlawful discrimination.''
Ms. Hopkins's lawyers presented evidence in the case that the partners at Price Waterhouse had called her overbearing, macho and abrasive and had said she would have a better chance of becoming a partner if she would wear makeup and jewelry, and walk, talk and dress ''more femininely.''
Ms. Hopkins, 46 years old, who now works at the World Bank in Washington, was awarded back pay amounting to about $400,000, in addition to the partnership. The exact amount of the back pay and the interest due her has not yet been computed.
Judge Gesell said Price Waterhouse must make Ms. Hopkins a partner as of July 1 and pay her as much as the average management consultants who were admitted to the partnership in 1983, when she was turned down, now earn.
Ms. Hopkins said she was ''prepared to go back'' to Price Waterhouse but was yet convinced that her seven-year legal fight was finished.
''It's not over until it's over,'' she said. ''The judge hasn't signed the order yet and Price Waterhouse has appealed everything so far, so I'm not going to deal in conjecture. My kids keep asking how many times we have to win this before it's over.'' #27 of 900 Partners Are Women Ms. Hopkins said she had not yet heard from anyone in management at Price Waterhouse. ''And frankly, I would die of shock if I do,'' she added.
A spokeswoman for Price Waterhouse, a 900-partner firm with 27 female partners, said the firm was still studying the decision to determine its response.
Douglas B. Huron, a lawyer who represented Ms. Hopkins, said: ''The most important thing about this case is the remedy that was ordered. The judge looked at it carefully and decided that she was entitled to what she had been denied. That means that under the law, women and minorities can get what's coming to them.''
Ms. Hopkins went to work as a management consultant at Price Waterhouse in 1978 and was nominated for partnership in 1982, the only woman among the 88 candidates for partnership. Although Ms. Hopkins had brought in more business than any of the other candidates, she was also the subject of more negative comments from partners than any of the others. Most of the comments criticized her handling of interpersonal relationships.
 
'An Irrational Explanation'
In early 1983, Ms. Hopkins was told that the partnership decision had been delayed, and a few months later she was told she was not being renominated. In 1984 she resigned and sued the firm for sex discrimination.
''I never thought being a woman was an obstacle when I was at Price Waterhouse,'' Ms. Hopkins said. ''At the time I left, I just thought I had been given an irrational explanation for a bad business decision. It was only later, when we were in litigation, that I found out about the comments that I needed to go to charm school, that I was too macho, that I was overcompensating for being a woman.''
The question of whether someone passed over for partnership can sue for employment discrimination first went to the Supreme Court in 1984, in a suit brought by Elizabeth Hishon against King & Spalding, an Atlanta law firm. Although the High Court said such claims would be allowed, the case was settled out of court; Ms. Hishon never returned to the firm.
Ms. Hopkins's case went to the Supreme Court last year on the question of what standard had to be met by claimants and employers in such discrimination cases.
The Court ruled, 6 to 3, that claimants had the initial burden of showing some evidence of discrimination but that it then fell to employers to prove their innocence.
 
Evidential Standards Eased
The Court said employers had only to show ''a preponderance of the evidence,'' not ''clear and convincing evidence,'' that they had legitimate, nondiscriminatory reasons for denying the promotion.
The case then went back to trial. In his ruling on Monday, Judge Gesell found that Price Waterhouse had not met the lower standard. Judge Gesell found that the firm maintained a partnership evaluation system that ''permitted negative, sexually stereotyped comments to influence partnership selection.''
The judge acknowledged that ''it is indeed a strained partnership relationship that lies ahead'' for Ms. Hopkins, one that would require mutual accommodation.
He said he would order Price Waterhouse not to retaliate against her for having brought the lawsuit.

HEADLINE: Novel Program for the Jobless Aims to Create Entrepreneurs

BYLINE: By PETER T. KILBORN, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: VANCOUVER, Wash.

 BODY:
What if the Government gave people who lost their jobs their half-year of unemployment benefits all at once, in one check, to start a business?
Soon there will be an answer. Glen P. Meyers, Dixie Gantka, Marvin W. Mills and about 30 other laid-off workers here received checks averaging $4,100, most of them in January, and went to work for themselves.
They are the first of 1,000 people in the State of Washington who are being selected under a state-supervised experiment, which is backed by $2.75 million from the Federal Department of Labor to see if such a program might work nationwide. Cathy Countryman, the state's director of research projects, said she expected about 500 of the participants actually to start businesses by the time the program ends in December. Most so far are small manufacturing or service operations. 
This idea is not for most unemployed people. Participants must be highly motivated and willing to take risks, and each must submit an elaborate plan that persuades the authorities that the business can succeed.
Still, fierce believers in entrepreneurship think the idea could prove a boon to the economy, spawning big new companies. Others say that even if it merely gives some unemployed people the chance they need to make a modest living, that is good enough.
The notion that businesses as tiny as those in the Vancouver program can succeed, much less blossom into corporate giants, seems quixotic. The odds against any new business's surviving a few years are fairly high, especially those starting with just $4,000 to pay for inventory, machinery, advertising and the like. Some participants have savings and spouses with jobs, but few can qualify for additional funds, and few have experience in the rudiments of commerce.
Whatever the odds, Mr. Meyers, who has started a welding business; Ms. Gantka, a doll maker; and Mr. Mills, who makes videotaped programs for companies, are plugging along.
''There's no doubt in my mind that this will work,'' said Mr. Mills, who is 34 years old.
Ms. Gantka, who is 51, said: ''I have never been so happy in my entire life. Ever since I was 18 the one thing I wanted to do was have a doll repair shop or make dolls.''
Ms. Gantka spent most of her career as a secretary and was laid off in November. Now she is the president, proprietor and sole employee of the Doll Company. She makes exquisite china-like dolls in her ranch house in Vancouver, just across the Columbia River from Portland, Ore. She makes one model about 4 inches tall, one about 10 inches and one about 16 inches.
Ms. Gantka starts with a soupy gray clay that she pours into plaster molds to form hollow heads, arms, legs and torsos. When the parts are removed, she sets them to cure for three days.
''I scrape off the seams and sand them,'' she continued, ''and then I put on the pre-bake paint. I put them in the oven at 375 degrees for an hour and a half. I paint on the skin coloring. Then I do eyelashes, lips, nostrils and nails.''
Ms. Gantka says she now makes only three dolls a week but is picking up speed. She sells mostly at doll shows but has found a candy shop to sell them for her and is looking for other stores.
She asks $40 to $150 for each doll and is earning very little so far, about $500 a month. But with her two children grown and her mortgage at only $6,000, she says she is getting by. Of her $3,100 lump sum start-up money, which she is using to buy more molds and materials, she said, ''I still have $1,300 left.''
 
A New Look at Laws
Three years ago, Congress authorized the Government to examine the unemployment-benefit laws to see if they could be made more helpful. As it is, even without Government help. 6 percent of people who lose their jobs start businesses, the Bureau of Labor Statistics says.
But the laws discourage starting businesses, because to qualify for the typical 26 weeks of unemployment pay, people have to demonstrate that they are busily looking for jobs, and they have to agree to take any that suit their skills. So for people admitted to the experimental program, the Self-Employment and Enterprise Development project, the job-hunting requirement has been waived.
Since late last fall in Vancouver, and since February in Seattle and four other Washington cities, people who lose their jobs are told of the SEED program when they first seek benefits. They are invited to apply and to fill out a detailed form about their plans. Fewer than 5 percent of the unemployed have responded.
A computer randomly selects two groups of applicants, one of which will become eligible for the lump sum payment. The authorities then monitor both groups to see how many in each group are able to start a business.
Once selected, a participant must join a training program conducted by a public-private business development group - in the case of Vancouver, the Columbia River Economic Development Council. The recipient is required to take four classes: business feasibility, marketing, finance and accounting, and organization and management. Participants are then given reading material and must go the library to do market research.
The candidate must prepare a business plan discussing the market for the product or service, projecting the business's progress and showing that there is adequate financing. All this is subject to the scrutiny of the candidate's counselor, often a recently retired business operator.
There is an incentive to hurry, especially with the business plan, the hardest part of the program. Candidates receive their weekly benefits throughout the training, but the more they receive in benefits, the smaller the lump sum payment. One received $7,110, the maximum allowed, and the lowest payment so far was $904.
There are also incentives to be thorough - or to drop out, if the business idea seems unrealistic. Self-employed people do not pay unemployment insurance, so they cannot receive benefits if their businesses fail.
There is also a risk for the Government. A participant can abandon the business after getting the lump sum payment, go work for someone else yet keep the money. So far, said Clare Phillips of the State Department of Trade and Economic Development, only a couple of people have done so.
Danny Gaughan, 31, laid off from a construction job, appeared at the SEED training center here in early May for his first appointment with Kirk Williams, a counselor. The computer had selected Mr. Gaughan for SEED, and he brought with him a packed three-ring binder and a preliminary business plan, painstakingly handwritten on pages of yellow legal paper.
 
Purchase of Vehicle
Mr. Gaughan said he wanted to open Mr. D's Deli and Pasta Shop, a food truck that he would take to fairs and other crowded places. He has already made an essential investment, a 28-year-old camper that cost $395, and he is remodeling and fitting it with a kitchen.
Mr. Williams said he had been surprised by some of his charges, like Marvin Mills, 34, who lives east of Vancouver in Washougal. ''He's doing about what he forecast in his business plan,'' Mr. Williams said, ''which I thought was quite wild.''
In November, Mr. Mills lost a $32,000-a-year job as a production manager when the Japanese-owned plant where he worked in Portland shut down. He formed the See First Video Company, using his bedroom as his office and his television set for editing. He uses a typical home video camera but says he is getting a professional model.
In December, while waiting to be approved for the SEED program, Mr. Mills approached an aluminum company. ''They wanted an orientation video for new employees about how aluminum is made,'' he said. ''I do a lot of movement with the camera, zooming, putting in fades. I ended up getting $4,750.''
Mr. Mills says he has other clients lined up and is busily trying to drum up more business. His secret, he said, is a dearth of competition. He charges $250 per minute of completed taping, while the closest competition, burdened with overhead, charges $1,000.
Mr. Meyers, who is 51 and lives in the rustic town of Castle Rock, about an hour north of Vancouver, thinks he has a similar edge in lack of competition. His business is field welding: he loads $3,000 in welding gear into a pickup truck and goes to construction sites and logging camps to fix big shovels and grapples, the things logging companies use to grab fallen trees.
''I charge $30 an hour,'' he said. ''The lowest I've seen around here is $42. The $30 grab covers my overhead and my wages. I don't charge any overtime, and I'm on call 24 hours a day, seven days a week.''
 
Dropouts From Program
Some people have dropped out of the program. Pauline Witthauer, a widow with three children who was laid off from a bookkeeping job, wanted to expand a tax accounting business she had started in her spare time. ''I found I wasn't able to create a lot more business than I had in the past,'' she said.
She said she might have been able to pursue more business with a bigger lump sum. Even so, she has been smitten by the appeal of self-employment. With what is left of her own resources, she says she is starting another business called Sweats and T's, taking orders from businesses for sweatshirts and T-shirts emblazoned with their emblems and having them made by a local company.
''I'm not going back to working for someone else,'' she said.

HEADLINE: STRIKES TESTING CHAMORRO'S RULE

BYLINE: By MARK A. UHLIG, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: MANAGUA, Nicaragua, May 15

 BODY:
Striking civil servants loyal to the opposition Sandinista Front ignored a Government ultimatum ordering them to return to work by 9 A.M. today, confronting the new and impoverished Government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro with its first serious political crisis.
Police officers in riot gear intervened to help Government ministers enter their offices in several buildings occupied by the strikers. At the Foreign Ministry, they fired tear gas, but were unable to gain access. They made no attempt to eject the strikers, who had expanded a weeklong work stoppage to paralyze telephone service, public transportation, border crossings and the national airport. [The Government's deteriorating political circumstances are matched in the economic sector. In a letter to President Bush seeking an emergency loan from the United States, Mrs. Chamorro declared her country bankrupt. Page A10.] 'The First Big Showdown' 
The strikers, led by Sandinista labor unions, are demanding a 200 percent raise and the reinstatement of a law giving sweeping protections to the Sandinista-dominated civil service. Union leaders have asserted that as many as 60,000 of an estimated 150,000 Government workers are taking part in the strike.
But the strikers' specific demands are widely seen as secondary to the larger test of wills between the new Chamorro Government and the Sandinista Front. Sandinista leaders have repeatedly declared their intention to ''rule from below'' despite their defeat in national elections Feb. 25, and Mrs. Chamorro's Government has now committed itself to breaking the Sandinistas' hold on the state bureaucracy and public services. It has declared the strike illegal and threatened to dismiss any strikers who do not return to work.
''This is the first big showdown,'' a European diplomat said. ''They are measuring each other's strength.''
In confrontations with workers at barricaded government offices around Managua today, the Chamorro Government appeared to have authority over the large, Sandinista-trained national police force, whose loyalties are considered a crucial variable in the current standoff. But the Government apparently made no attempt to test the limits of its control because the police did not try to eject the crowds of Sandinista workers who occupied the buildings, chanting slogans such as ''Not one step back!'' and ''Violeta, start packing your bags!''
 
Services at a Standstill
Truckloads of helmeted riot troops with shields, rubber clubs and tear gas were deployed outside the entrances to several government buildings. But they were withdrawn to a safe distance after helping government ministers enter their offices, and no serious violence was reported. The situation appeared stalemated, leaving vital government services at a virtual standstill and Sandinista strikers defiant.
''If the Government doesn't reflect on this and come to the negotiating table, this problem can escalate,'' said Jose Angel Bermudez Lazo, secretary general of the Sandinista-controlled National Employees' Union. ''The strike will continue.''
The specter of a paralyzing confrontation with the Sandinista Front, which shaped the government bureaucracy and filled it with militant supporters during 10 years in power, has shadowed Mrs. Chamorro since she won election in February. The desire to avoid a crippling showdown is believed to have been a key element in her decision to keep a central figure of the Sandinista Government, Gen. Humberto Ortega Saavedra, as her top military officer.
But even before Mrs. Chamorro's inauguration on April 25, Sandinista unions staged a number of demonstration strikes that interrupted telephone service and power and water supplies and halted the bus system, the main form of transportation for the capital's estimated one million residents.
 
Civil Service Law Suspended
In the wake of those strikes, many Nicaraguans had come to believe that a confrontation between the Sandinista leadership and Mrs. Chamorro's Government regime was only a matter of time. But many, including senior Sandinista leaders, appeared to be taken off guard by the timing of the current dispute, which appears to have been pressed forward in large part by government leaders in an attempt to face down Sandinista labor strength while the new Government still enjoys a burst of post-inauguration popularity.
The immediate catalyst for the current strike was Mrs. Chamorro's decision last week to suspend a civil service law that would have granted broad job protection to state workers hired under the Sandinista Government.
The law, which would have protected even senior Sandinista officials from dismissal, was part of a series of measures passed hastily after the Sandinistas' election defeat. Its suspension brought predicted protests from the Sandinista unions, beginning with a small work slowdown.
But the Government then responded with the tough ultimatums that helped produce the current standoff. Government spokesman have sought to portray the spreading strikes as an attack not only on the Chamorro Government but also on the county's broader democratic process.
''What we are now experiencing is a strike that has absolutely no economic merit,'' said Luis Sanchez Sancho, a senior member of Mrs. Chamorro's coalition and vice president of the new National Assembly. ''It is a seditious strategy to hinder the consolidation of the new democratic Government.''

HEADLINE: CAUTION PREVAILS IN OPENING SESSION OF BUDGET TALKS

BYLINE: By DAVID E. ROSENBAUM, Special to The New York Times

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, May 15

 BODY:
President Bush opened budget negotiations with Congress today by refusing a request from the Democratic Congressional leadership that he make a televised address outlining the nation's economic problems and putting forward his own remedy.
In the first session of the talks today at the White House, Mr. Bush said a sense of political caution prevented him from explaining the severity of the budget deficit to the public or from offering a sweeping solution of his own.
Although the meeting was closed to reporters, several people who were there said Mr. Bush expressed concern over creating a financial panic if he described the depth of the problem without presenting a solution. The President added that if he were to offer a solution before a deal was struck with Congress, it would be rejected and the country would be no better off than if he had said nothing. 
 
The Delicate Tax Matter
Participants said neither side touched on the pivotal question of whether tax increases would be needed to reduce the deficit, which the budget director, Richard G. Darman, has said could soar as high as $190 billion in the next fiscal year. Since the question of higher taxes was not discussed, the politically sensitive question of who would first broach the subject was left unresolved.
The meeting was described as an inconclusive get-acquainted session full of partisan maneuvers but free of disputes. What jousting there was centered on whether the President would take public responsibility for financial sacrifices that might be needed.
The White House press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, quoted Mr. Bush as saying that no crisis was at hand but that ''it is important to act while the economy is still growing, for growth is not as strong or secure as it should be.''
 
One by One, a Challenge
After Mr. Bush's presentation, he called on several of the 21 lawmakers around the table in the White House Cabinet Room to make presentations of their own. It was at this point that Mr. Bush was challenged by the Democrats to make his case publicly.
''Foley, Gephardt, Rosty, Mitchell,'' said Representative Silvio O. Conte of Massachusetts, a Republican negotiator, calling off the names of some of the Democratic participants. ''They sounded like a broken record. They asked the President to go on television and lay this all out.''
Mr. Bush waited until the end of the meeting to turn down that suggestion. The Democrats did not challenge the President directly, but many of them did say in the meeting that they would not be able to sell belt-tightening to their constituents without his help.
In the end, Mr. Conte and other lawmakers said, the President promised to go out of his way to help negotiate an agreement and to persuade the public of its worth. But he said he would not hold an immediate news conference or make a major speech on the subject because he did not want to affect the financial markets adversely.
Participants said today's meeting consisted primarily of a general discussion of the economy and the nature of the deficit problem. Taxes were only mentioned generally as a matter that would have to be addressed later.
Most of the participants expect several more meetings in which they dance around the ring before a real punch is thrown. The next session is scheduled for Thursday on Capitol Hill, and the President is not expected to be there.
 
Some Optimism About Success
Lawmakers and Administration officials alike said the meeting today lacked the edge they expect once full-scale negotiations get under way, but they expressed guarded optimism that a way could be found to reduce the deficit.
''I get a feeling from having been around a lot of deals in my time that this one's going to happen,'' said Treasury Secretary Nicholas F. Brady, who spent most of his career as an investment banker on Wall Street.
Still, Democrats said after the meeting that they were not satisfied with Mr. Bush's refusal to make a public statement. ''There is still a sense of unease and an expectation on the part of the Democrats that the Administration will take the leadership role and lay out its solutions,'' said Senator Jim Sasser, a Tennessee Democrat who is chairman of the Senate Budget Committee.
The House Budget Committee chairman, Representative Leon E. Panetta, Democrat of California, shared that assessment. ''At some point, he's going to have to get the message to the American public,'' Mr. Panetta said.
The Democratic view is that the urgency of the problem is a result of an unrealistic budget that Mr. Bush sent to Congress in January. He said then that reduction of the deficit to $64 billion, as required by the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings balanced budget law for the fiscal year that begins in October, could be accomplished without higher taxes or painful spending cuts.
The Administration's figures were based on economic projections that were much more optimistic than those of private economists and the Congressional Budget Office, whose forecasts have since proven to be accurate.
 
A New Administration View
For example, the Administration's prediction was that corporate profits would rise in the next fiscal year by 17 percent. The consensus of private economists was that the figure would be less than 5 percent. So far this year, those profits have actually dropped from last year.
Mr. Darman, the budget director, told the lawmakers today that the Administration now believed about $75 billion in deficit reduction would be required to meet the law's target, as against the $36 billion predicted in January.
If expenses associated with propping up failed savings and loan associations are counted, Mr. Darman reportedly told the lawmakers, the $75 billion figure could rise to $125 billion.
If the deficit target is not achieved, the budget balancing law calls for sharp reductions in most Government programs except Social Security and welfare benefits. Both the Administration and Congress want to avoid those broad cuts.
Lawmakers said that neither the President nor Mr. Darman apologized for the poor economic forecast. But Mr. Darman said that lower corporate profits had meant less revenue for the Government, and that higher interest rates than expected had meant the Government had to pay more on its bonds. In addition, expenses for Medicare, food stamps and some other programs had turned out to be higher than anticipated, Mr. Darman reportedly said.
